fields.headline: Solanki to graduate at last
fields.standfirst: Worcestershire all-rounder can embellish England's Asian aspect
fields.trailText: Paul Weaver examines the potential of Vikram Solanki who is expected to make his debut in the one-day match against South Africa in Bloemfontein tomorrow.
fields.body:
Having experimented with South African batsmen and fast bowlers of Caribbean extraction, the England cricket team's most vivid colours are now most definitely Asian.

The captain himself, Nasser Hussain, was born in Madras. Mark Ramprakash, with his Guyana-Indian roots, is, though currently out of fashion, the most technically accomplished batsman in the country. And Vikram Solanki is certainly the most exciting prospect around.

The Worcestershire all-rounder, 23, is expected to make his full international debut in the one-day match against South Africa here tomorrow following an outstanding A tour of Bangladesh and New Zealand. It will be England's first appearance in the triangular series, which also features Zimbabwe.

It is not, of course, the first time England have looked to this part of the world for help, as ageing admirers of Ranjitsinhji, Duleepsinhji and the Nawab of Pataudi Sr would readily testify.

However, the progress of Solanki, who was born in Udaipur, India, is even more significant because this could be a torch-bearing exercise for a vast Asian community that has mostly played cricket for fun while following more traditional professional paths.

He says: "If my call-up has a positive effect that will be great, although I don't know whether it will. There are a lot of cricketers with Asian backgrounds now coming into the county game.

"It is becoming an accepted profession among Asian families who in the past might have preferred their sons to have become doctors or lawyers."

The intelligent and articulate Solanki, who has nine O and three A levels, has placated his parents by pursuing his education and is completing an economics-based university degree.

"While I was in New Zealand I sat a three-hour exam. We had nets in the morning and I went off to Christchurch University in the afternoon. At least it got me out of fielding practice."

Solanki, a practising Hindu, was discovered by Worcestershire as a 15-year-old and made his debut in 1993. He won his county cap five years later and last season was the leading England-qualified run-scorer in the country with 1,339 at 40.57, with three centuries. He was also the leading scorer in the recent A tour, with 597 runs at almost 60.

"The A tour went very well for me. But I was pleasantly surprised when I was picked for the one-day series because what little success I've had has been in the first-class game."

His A tour included a career-best 185 in Chittagong, an innings played on a turning pitch and in oppressive heat in front of more than 30,000.

"The whole idea about touring on the subcontinent was brought home to me there. It was very hot, the pitch was very dry and took spin early on. There was also a howling, biased crowd. It was all very satisfying."

Solanki came to England in 1984 aged eight. Both parents are Indian - his mother was born in India of English parents. Solanki could have qualified for India and says: "I still have a lot of family and friends there who I hold dear but I learned all my cricket in England and it never crossed my mind to play for anyone else.

"I love going back to India and if I wasn't playing for England this winter I might have been playing professional cricket there. But since I started playing for Worcestershire all my ambitions were directed to playing for England."

England's A tour manager Martyn Moxon is convinced Solanki can make the jump up. He said: "I was delighted with him on tour; he is a stylish batsman with a lot of flair and a sound technique. He is very wristy but he is also powerful for someone who is slightly built. Some of the shots he played were fantastic. He can take a bowling attack apart.

"He is also a tremendous fielder and bowls well too, giving the ball a great tweak. He is also desperate to succeed and in my opinion has a great chance of doing so.

"He is as exciting a young player as there is in the country at the moment and I would have thought he must have been in the frame when Ramprakash went out as cover."

If Solanki establishes himself it would be ironic if it came at the expense of his Worcestershire colleague Graeme Hick. "My entire career feels as though it has been linked with Graeme's," Solanki said. "I scored my maiden century while he was at the other end making his hundredth. It made me feel a little insignificant.

"Graeme has been around a lot at Worcester and when I walked out on Thursday to play my first one-day game at senior level he was batting. It feels good to know he's around. But it was last summer, when he and Tom Moody were away on World Cup duty, that my game really developed. The rest of us had to take more responsibility and I settled in at No4."

There are some who feel that Solanki might have reached this level earlier. "Youngsters are not being fast-tracked quickly enough," says the Sussex chief executive Dave Gilbert. "Solanki was one of the best young players around when I was at Surrey three years ago but he is still waiting to play Test cricket."

webTitle: Cronje gets back in the groove

fields.headline: Cronje gets back in the groove
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe 226 South Africa 229-4
South Africa win by six wickets
fields.trailText: Hansie Cronje made a welcome return to form in Johannesburg last night when he led South Africa to a comfortable victory over Zimbabwe in the opening match of the triangular one-day series in front of a capacity crowd at the Wanderers.
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje made a welcome return to form in Johannesburg last night when he led South Africa to a comfortable victory over Zimbabwe in the opening match of the triangular one-day series in front of a capacity crowd at the Wanderers.

The South African captain, who endured a dreadful Test series with the bat against England, made an undefeated 83 in 110 balls, his first one-day half-century in 18 matches. Cronje also became the first South African to pass 5,000 runs in this form of cricket.

At 55 for three, with Gary Kirsten, Jacques Kallis and Dale Benkenstein out cheaply, South Africa looked as though they would struggle to reply to Zimbabwe's modest total.

But a partnership of 104 from 121 balls between Cronje and Herschelle Gibbs (65) swung the match emphatically before Lance Klusener, to a rapturous reception, came out to finish the job off with Cronje, who was named man of the match.

Earlier Murray Goodwin's brisk 73 had held Zimbabwe's innings together while Shaun Pollock took three for 31 for South Africa.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: The MCC yesterday stressed it is anxious for Middlesex to continue playing cricket at Lord's, but revealed the current leasing arrangement is leaving them out of pocket.
fields.body:
The MCC yesterday stressed it is anxious for Middlesex to continue playing cricket at Lord's, but revealed the current leasing arrangement is leaving them out of pocket.

The Middlesex chairman Phil Edmonds has written to his county's members warning that the 137-year association with the MCC is under threat because of a financial dispute over their tenancy. The MCC administers all matches at Lord's and pays a percentage of gate receipts and perimeter advertising to Middlesex - but this money is now in doubt.

After spending around £30m in the past five years on ground developments without government or lottery funding, the MCC admits that there is an urgent need for it to balance the books.

Chris Rea, head of marketing and public affairs for the MCC, was yesterday angered by Edmonds's suggestion that Middlesex "were not being treated fairly or with the respect due from our long-standing relationship".

Rea said: "We view our arrangement with Middlesex as mutually beneficial and it's very important for the MCC and our members that we have first-class cricket played at Lord's.

"With Middlesex living rent-free it is of tremendous advantage to them considering they still benefit from ECB distribution funding - in fact they have fewer outgoings than any other county.

"Our problem is that we are effectively paying Middlesex to play at Lord's. When you look at the figures we made a six-figure loss from staging Middlesex matches last season."

 A brilliant all-round performance by Pakistan's Abdur Razzaq helped his team to a 32-run victory over India at the Bellerive Oval in Hobart yesterday.

In the latest match of the tri-nations Carlton & United series, Razzaq smashed an unbeaten 70 from 57 balls to revive his side's faltering innings, before claiming bowling figures of five for 48 in India's reply.

Wasim Akram bowled Debashish Mohanty for a duck to clinch Pakistan's third win of the tournament and ended with figures of three for 34 but 20-year-old Razzaq was the deserving winner of the man-of-the-match award.

India have lost all of their four matches and have little chance of reaching the best-of-three-match final.

fields.headline: Thinking of the fans
fields.trailText: Well, there's a turn-up for the books. The event that's just taken place in South Africa isn't the sort of thing you see every day in the cricket world. And no, I'm not talking about England winning a Test match - although that's not the sort of thing you see every day either. I'm talking about the fact that, when making the decisions they did, the two captains actually seemed to be considering the plight of the supporters.
fields.body:
Well, there's a turn-up for the books. The event that's just taken place in South Africa isn't the sort of thing you see every day in the cricket world. And no, I'm not talking about England winning a Test match - although that's not the sort of thing you see every day either. I'm talking about the fact that, when making the decisions they did, the two captains actually seemed to be considering the plight of the supporters.

Cricket supporters are by nature a long-suffering breed. The hours of travel, the rain, the out-of-form batsmen, the mediocre bowling, and the uncomfortable seating are only rarely compensated for by the days in the sun when your team is on top form and the game is exciting. You have to admire any punter who turns up to the final day of an ostensibly dead match, but three cheers for the England supporters who stayed on after the series was already lost, and then stuck with it through three days of rain to turn out for what was, apparently, a pointless exercise.

They can hardly have expected Tuesday's surprise move. Let's be honest - Hansie Cronje and Nasser Hussain are hardly the two most attacking or innovative captains in the world. Nobody would have been at all surprised if they'd settled for playing the day out with a bit of gentle batting and fielding practice, then gone home for a nice cup of tea, thank you very much. Instead they took the unprecedented step of forfeiting an innings each (even if England's first innings was technically declared on 0 for 0) in order to make a game of it. Now, this may just have been an attempt to get themselves into the next edition of Trivial Pursuit, but they may actually have wanted to play some competitive cricket too.

All over the world, purists were shocked; traditionalists shrieked in outrage and dropped their gin and tonics; statisticians leafed through stacks of material to try and find a precedent. Meanwhile, back at Centurion, the spectators - you know, the ones who actually forked out for the entrance fee and bothered to turn up to support their team in a dead match - were treated to the rare sight of an exciting fifth day with a closely-fought finish.

Cronje and Hussain may well end up getting slapped on the wrist by the UCBSA, the ECB, the ICC or some other bunch of initials, but they've just boosted their popularity with the humble fan everywhere, starting with this one. So raise a glass to two of the most improbable innovators the game is ever likely to see, and drink to the spectators at Centurion, finally and justly rewarded for their support.

Catherine Hanley is an Australian supporter living and working in Sheffield

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Do not go until you read Martin Thorpe's celebrated trivia.
fields.body:
Here's something that proves Manchester United are really into themselves. One of Russia's most traditional Russian doll factories has come up with the ultimate football doll. David Beckham opens up, and inside is Gary Neville. Inside him is Paul Scholes. Inside him is Andy Cole. And inside him is a teeny-weeny Ryan Giggs.

A group of Irish businessmen wanted to place an order for 12 dolls containing Alex Ferguson and 11 players. But in true Martin Edwards fashion, they were put off by the price: £125 a set.

 A reader asks: as Manchester United's new pitch comes from the Netherlands, could they finish the season on a high thanks to Dutch grass?

 One of the heroes of the English game is undoubtedly Kenneth Wolstenholme, the former BBC television commentator who, in the summer of '66, made sure of his personal immortality by uttering the words: "Some people are on the pitch. They think it's all over. It is now."

Strange, then, to discover that Wolstenholme's favourite player is not one of England's 1966 World Cup-winning side, but one of the German losers in that final, Wolfgang Weber.

It's obvious really. As Wolstenholme recently explained: "If Weber hadn't scored West Germany's late equaliser, England would have won 2-1, there would have been no Geoff Hurst hat-trick, nobody would have come on to the pitch, so I would never have said what I did and everyone would have forgotten me."

 A reader asks: if players are to be paid a fee each time their goals are shown on television, does that mean the end of the free-kick?

 Given that Coventry's Youssef Chippo is Muslim, and as such does not drink alcohol and fasts during Ramadan, can anyone explain why his kit sponsor is the Old Smithy Free House and Restaurant?

 While we are on the subject of Coventry, not many people know that Chippo's Moroccan team-mate Mustapha Hadji is the new Ian Wright. Not as a player, but as an advertiser of coffee, on posters all over Casablanca. Yes, but is it making a mocha-ry of his playing role?

 Regular readers may remember the story of the Romanian player sold for a lorry load of firewood and another for two tons of meat. Most of the country's football clubs are struggling with such a chronic shortage of funds that this week Second Division Olimpia Satu Mare received the latest instalment from their sponsors: a calf and a pig. The latter was immediately slaughtered and sent to the team's winter training session.

 In one way it is surprising that Marcel Desailly is such a great defender, because he is nearly always on the phone. In fact he owns no fewer than five mobiles, a fact that was deliciously exposed in Eyes on the Blue, a film to celebrate France's 1998 World Cup win.

In it, his current Chelsea team-mate Didier Deschamps is shown taking the mickey out of Desailly's... well, hang-up would obviously be the wrong word. Shall we say, multiple handset use?

The scene made such an impact that the defender now has a lucrative advertising contract with a French phone company. It obviously pays to talk.

 By the way, if Ken Bates is right and Chelsea's players are a bunch of training-ground ponies, why can't they win two games on the trot?

fields.headline: On-form Henry adopts striking attitude
fields.standfirst: The former Juventus wide man will shoulder the goalscoring responsibility at Old Trafford
fields.trailText: Thierry Henry will be the Gunners' main source of fire power in Monday's titan clash against Manchester United at Old Trafford. He talks to Martin Thorpe.
fields.body:
Thierry Henry was a bit worried while walking in London recently. A man kept staring at him but said nothing. What made the scene more bizarre to this Frenchman abroad was that the voyeur appeared to be a respectable businessman, dressed in the office uniform of sharp suit and briefcase.

"I thought to myself, 'This guy is strange'," recalls the softly spoken Henry. It was an impression which did not diminish when the man started undoing the buttons on his shirt.

But Henry was even more surprised by what happened next. "He undid his button and underneath pointed to the Arsenal shirt he was wearing. He didn't even talk to me. He just showed me the shirt and walked off.

"It was incredible because the guy was in a suit with a briefcase. In France some fans don't like to put on the team shirt to see the game."

Since arriving at Highbury in early August, the man with a touch of Paul Ince in his looks has been adapting to life in his new domain. Not only is the 22-year-old coming to terms with just how close to their hearts the supporters hold Arsenal, but his English and his goalscoring are in a race to see which will become fluent first.

At the moment Henry, with six goals in his last seven league games, is doing his talking on the pitch. What makes that statistic so fascinating, however, is that the Thierry Henry bought from Juventus for £10m on a five-year contract six months ago was a winger, good enough to win a French league title with Monaco and a World Cup with France.

But Arsène Wenger is a man who forgets nothing. Having seen the teenage Henry advance through the Monaco youth ranks as a striker while coach there, the Arsenal manager decided that his one-time proteg&#'233; would make the ideal replacement for Henry's fellow countryman and friend Nicolas Anelka in the middle of the Gunners attack.

On Monday Henry faces the ultimate Premiership test of his new role. With Dennis Bergkamp injured, Davor Suker suspended and Nwankwo Kanu on international duty, the rookie forward is likely to be handed the responsibility of playing lone striker at Manchester United in a game from which Arsenal must take at least a point to retain any meaningful hopes of winning the league title.

Wenger may give him a makeshift partner, but either way the weight is on Henry's slender shoulders. Thankfully for Arsenal the test has come at the right time. At the start of the season he would have struggled.

"At the beginning of the season I played the first half against Liverpool as a striker and was very rubbish," he says honestly. "The boss put me on the wing for the second half. But I came on against Southampton as a striker and then played against Derby and that was when everything started to work well."

It has been a long process reawakening old memories. Henry was a striker for 10 years until he was 17. But there were so many fine goalscorers at Monaco then that, when Wenger left, the new coach played him out wide and he stayed there.

"Arsène Wenger said before he signed me at Arsenal that he wanted me to play as a striker again and I could have said no. But I wanted to play for Arsenal and no one knows me like him, so I said OK.

"He convinced me I would score as a striker because of my pace and there are not so many players to beat to get to goal as there are on the wing. But it has been difficult relearning the role. The most difficult thing was to remember not to come too deep to get the ball. I have to stay nearer the last defender to make the run.

"When you play on the wing you have to come back and you touch the ball more. So in the beginning as a striker I came back because sometimes I wanted to touch the ball more."

The relearning process included asking defenders what they do not like from strikers. "I asked Martin Keown and he said making runs behind him. If you come too deep defenders are happy because they can see you.

"So I have to keep that in my mind and remember it all the time. When you play four years on the wing you get used to certain things and when you have to change it's not easy. But now it is more instinctive."

Henry not only picked Keown's brain but worked after training with Wenger and even studied matches on television to see how strikers moved and which positions they took up.

His dedication to the task offers ample evidence of the personal qualities which have always attracted Wenger. The Arsenal manager tried to sign him after the last World Cup but Juventus had first option. What made the scene more bizarre to this Frenchman abroad was that the voyeur appeared to be a respectable businessman, dressed in the office uniform of sharp suit and briefcase. "I thought to myself, 'This guy is strange'," recalls the softly spoken Henry. It was an impression which did not diminish when the man started undoing the buttons on his shirt. At the moment Henry, with six goals in his last seven league games, is doing his talking on the pitch. Three tackles in a row and they're in seventh heaven." But he insists he prefers playing in England where the speed of the game suits his innate pace. fields.headline: Lacey
fields.standfirst: Ashton's outburst overlooks deeper malaise
fields.trailText: Joe Ashton might have done better applying himself as an MP to the broader problem of spiralling wages rather than waving a rattle as Ashton the fan.
fields.body:
Disaffected football supporters can show their feelings in any number of ways. They can chant "what a load of rubbish" or they can simply not turn up.

They can fill the letters column of their local pink 'un - always assuming that one still exists - or they can scorch the airwaves on radio phone-ins.

Some go further still. A disillusioned Tottenham fan, in a private publication, has just produced a paperback based on lengthy correspondence between himself and the Spurs chairman Alan Sugar as well as a football journalist on one of the leading tabloids. An unlikely bestseller admittedly, but at least the man cares.

So, it would seem, does Joe Ashton, one of the four local MPs whose intervention in Sheffield Wednesday's struggle to avoid being relegated from the Premier League has attracted considerably more national interest than the performances of Danny Wilson's team.

Whether Ashton is getting involved as a Wednesday supporter who happens to be a member of parliament or vice-versa has not been made clear. Either way the effect has been of a man-of-war sailing into a Chinese harbour and blasting away at the junks.

Precisely what Hillsborough target has attracted the weightiest cannonballs of Ashton and his parliamentary colleagues is unclear. Originally, when news of the gang of four's talks with the investment group Charterhouse, which holds a 36% interest in Sheffield Wednesday, leaked out it appeared to be Wilson whose immediate dismissal as manager they were said to be demanding.

Ashton later played this down, saying that Wilson's position had been discussed for only 30 seconds during a meeting of several hours. But much can be said in 30 seconds. The Gettysburg address, read at normal speed, lasts less than a minute.

Wednesday, meanwhile, beat sinking Bradford City last Saturday and went on to knock Wolves out of the FA Cup on penalties at Molineux three days later. No matter that the scoreless match that preceded the shoot-out was a candidate for Room 101, wherein lie the worst things in the world, Sheffield Wednesday have now gone four matches unbeaten, their best run of the season so far.

Having quickly backtracked on the idea of sacking Wilson, Ashton then turned his wrath on the Wednesday chairman Dave Richards. In an open letter he asked for details of the club's finances and questioned Richards' ability to chair both Wednesday and the Premier League.

More bizarrely, Ashton also propounded the theory that there were some at Hillsborough who would welcome a drop to the Nationwide First Division because it would mean Wednesday having to trim their finances and reduce their debts, thus making them a more attractive proposition for would-be buyers.

Ashton was a vice-president at Hillsborough until he resigned last week and can therefore be presumed to have a certain degree of inside knowledge. Yet his case against Richards appears flawed.

For several seasons now the Wednesday chairman has been the voice of reason in a game beset by financial insanity. Even when the team were riding relatively high in the Premier League he was warning of the consequences of Bosman and spiralling salaries.

This season, after Wednesday had been held 2-2 at home by Watford, a fellow struggler, Richards gave an impromptu press conference during which he reiterated his misgivings about the way football was heading.

It is a view shared by more than a few Premier League chairmen whose clubs were once the solid mainstream of English football but are now finding it increasingly hard to live with the combined effect of wage inflation and the greater bargaining power handed to footballers, and their agents, by the Bosman ruling.

Last November the chairman of Derby County, Lionel Pickering, echoed Richards' fears for the future. Pickering said that though Derby's attendances had risen from 17,000 to 29,000 in three years and in spite of extra revenue from corporate investors, BSkyB and transfer profits, all the money had gone on players' wages.

"The simple fact is the Bosman ruling, which gives the player the right to walk away from his club at the end of his contract, has changed football finances for ever," Pickering explained. "It's no fault of the players; good luck to them, it's a short life and who can blame them for exploiting the system.

"Nevertheless, for all but the richest clubs in the Premiership, we're all living on a financial knife's edge."

Richards has been saying as much for rather longer. He has also said more than once that he would be prepared to stand aside for a suitable successor if it benefited the club.

Doubtless many Wednesday followers would welcome a Yorkshire clone of Blackburn Rovers' Jack Walker. But this did not render Blackburn immune to relegation and even if Hillsborough did acquire a squillionaire it would not solve the difficulty of paying the better players and keeping them, not with Roy Keane on £50,000 a week at Old Trafford and others likely to follow.

Ashton the MP might have done better to apply himself to this broader problem rather than simply waving a rattle as Ashton the fan.

fields.headline: White ' s week
fields.standfirst: Jim White explores the wider, weirder world of sport: Learn how to tell the difference between Wright and wrong
fields.trailText: Ian Wright is not a football agent. Is that Wright or wrong?
fields.body:
Ian Wright, the chat show host, chicken connoisseur and record-breaking striker, has made it clear this week that, whatever appearances might suggest, he has not added another string to his multi- talented bow.

He has let it be known that he is not acting as a football agent. Despite the fact that an agency called Wright Wright Wright sent a Venezuelan client called Fernando de Ornelas from Crystal Palace for trials at Celtic, a club with whom Wright has an occasional playing interest, Wrighty himself was not involved.

He pointed out that the agency is run by a couple of old friends from his Palace days - Andy Gray and Tony Finnigan - who borrowed his name purely for marketing purposes. In any case, it is obvious that the nearest thing the sport has to a renaissance man, a sort of footballing Kenneth Branagh, could not have been involved in any negotiations involving De Ornelas because that would have been against Fifa rules, which insist that anyone wishing to act as an agent has to have a licence, a procedure that involves putting up a bond of SFr200,000 (£76,000).

Wright doesn't have a licence. But then he couldn't have: the rules ban current players from practising as agents. And the last thing Wrighty would ever do is break the rules. Intriguingly, though, Gray was quoted in the Palace match programme recently, saying of his client De Ornelas: "There are a lot of gifted players who could play here, but it is a case of who you know rather than what you know. Ian Wright knows a lot of people and a lot of people know him."

Clearly the old cliche "quoted out of context" must apply here because, as has been stated this week, Wrighty had no involvement whatsoever in the De Ornelas business. Perhaps it was Wright's current position at Celtic that caused all the confusion, because there is absolutely no problem at all in a former player, officially retired from the game, becoming an agent, providing he gains a licence. It is just the active participants who are precluded.

And increasing numbers of former players are attempting to make the step on retirement. You can understand why: they know the game, they know the participants, their reputation can open appropriate doors. Plus young players are likely to believe an ex-pro has their best interests at heart.

As Gray himself put it, when explaining the thinking behind Wright Wright Wright, whose clients already include Chris Bart-Williams of Nottingham Forest and Bolton's John O'Kane: "We all wanted to try and ensure that the players we look after get better treatment than we did."

David Speedie, Steve Archibald, Ronnie Rosenthal, Stuart Pearson: they have all tried their hand in the business, with varying results. Not everyone has found it easy. It may surprise you to discover that some players-turned-agents never got round to the inconvenient business of gaining a licence.

Indeed Bill McMurdo, George Best's former agent and a former professional with Hibernian, is anxious to disabuse any player of the notion that the job has achieved the happy alchemy of producing money from old rope. He recalls one wannabe Eric Hall (who will remain nameless) ringing him up and saying: "There must be an easier way to make a living than this." McMurdo adds: "Being an ex-player gives you an insight into the way the game operates and it can open doors. But there is a lot more to the job than that. You have to have business acumen. In particular you must be able to assess a player's value honestly. It does no one any good hanging out for a ridiculous deal for someone who is not worth it."

So what advice does McMurdo have for Gray and any other former player looking to get their foot in the chairman's door? Though not Ian Wright who, it cannot be stated often enough, has no interest in that kind of thing. "Players recommend other players to managers informally all the time," he says. "And they think that's all there is to being an agent, tipping the wink here, a nod there. I reckon it took me a good five years to get established. So many ex-players have fallen trying to make the grade." What's more McMurdo, who currently represents 70 players, believes things can only get harder. "When I started in 1978 there weren't any agents," he says. "Now, I often say there are more agents than the Queen's got soldiers. There must be over 600 worldwide. There's not enough work to go round." Besides, there is another reason why Gray may eventually come to the conclusion that the traditional recourse of buying a pub would, after all, be an altogether less stressful way to earn a living after retirement. He has just added Stan Collymore to his books.

webTitle: Gunners fret over lack of firepower

fields.headline: Gunners fret over lack of firepower
fields.trailText: Two months ago Arsène Wenger had so many strikers at his disposal that he started Nwankwo Kanu and Davor Suker on the bench. What he would do for such luxuries at Old Trafford on Monday night.
fields.body:
Two months ago Arsène Wenger had so many strikers at his disposal that he started Nwankwo Kanu and Davor Suker on the bench. What he would do for such luxuries at Old Trafford on Monday night.

Instead, with Dennis Bergkamp injured, Suker suspended and Kanu on international duty, the Arsenal manager may have to abandon his beloved 4-4-2 for the most impor tant game of his season so far. A suffocating five-man midfield may make a rare appearance.

"That's one example of what I could do because I think the game could be won or lost in midfield," he said. "We have to go there to win but it is crucial we don't lose because then we will be in dreamland if we think we can win the title."

If Wenger opts to give Thierry Henry a partner up front, the names of possible candidates will not strike fear into Manchester United's defenders. Marc Overmars is injured, so Fredrik Ljungberg is the only first-team regular in with a shout.

Beyond that there is Christopher Wreh, recently loaned to Birmingham and only at the club because a move to Le Havre fell through, or Graham Barrett, left, an 18-year-old with only eight minutes of first-team experience behind him.

Sir Alex Ferguson can probably smell revenge. "It's a role reversal from two years ago when we had a really weakened side with seven players missing and they beat us 1-0," the United manager said. "That result set them up to win the league."

If his side fail to claim the championship for the fourth time in five years he believes it will end up at Highbury. "In my mind they will be the main threat to us again," he said. "Leeds are ahead at the moment but Arsenal have that experience."

fields.headline: Rangers beware refreshed Dons
fields.trailText: Ian Archer has a look at today's resumption of the Scottish Premier League.
fields.body:
The Scottish Premier League resumes today after its mid-winter break and, curiously, absolutely nothing has changed since it shut down at Christmas - apart from the predictable fact that the weather over the past few weeks has been well nigh perfect for playing and watching football.

But the tables stay the same. Rangers hold a four-point advantage and have a game in hand over Celtic in the only contest that really matters. Dick Advocaat, the Rangers manager, knows that and says: "We can smell the Champions League."

He will, however, worry a little about today's game against Aberdeen. Last year, after the first shutdown, the big clubs returned for Scottish Cup ties which provided a small string of surprise results. That hardly surprised those cynical enough to think that taking a football team to the tropics for "quality training" was simply another way of telling the world that the lads were due a good blow-out.

"We came back and beat Falkirk but it was a struggle," admitted Advocaat, whose side had spent the break in Florida.

Though the cup has been shelved for a week this time, Aberdeen are prepared to spring another surprise after beating Rangers in a League Cup quarter-final last month. "We have more quality than them but they can give us a bad time," said Advocaat.

In Scotland, however, the actual playing of the matches is quite the most boring part of the game. In the vacuum of the past three weeks, much has happened. Rangers have signed Tugay Kerimoglu, a Turk from Galatasaray, who will sit on the bench today to learn at close range the cultural differences between Glasgow and Istanbul.

Celtic, who play at Kilmarnock tomorrow, also spent £4m on the unfortunately named Rafael Scheidt, whose shirt will call him by his christian name. The centre-back arrived hale and hearty at Celtic's retreat in the Algarve, then came back to Glasgow, felt a pain in his stomach and a few hours later was undergoing an appendix operation that will keep him out for two months.

"It's a terrible thing to happen to him personally," says the coach John Barnes with some compassion. With Alan Stubbs also laid low with gastro-enteritis it might not be the cleverest thing for the club either. A quick stumble this weekend would virtually gift the league to Rangers with more than three months of the season still to go.

webTitle: Promotion was a dream - but is life in the Premiership turning into a nightmare?

fields.headline: Promotion was a dream - but is life in the Premiership turning into a nightmare?
fields.standfirst: A survivor and a struggler
fields.trailText: Watford visit Bradford this afternoon in a battle that could determine either club's future in the Premiership. Jon Brodkin talks to Bradford manager Paul Jewell who's been feeling the strains of life in football's fast lane but has yet to throw in the towel.
fields.body:
If Watford need an injection of confidence before their crucial game at Bradford this afternoon, they should arrive by train. The signs at Interchange station suggest the locals were never convinced their football team could live with big boys. "Welcome to Bradford," the signs say, "Home of the Bulls."

Given that both sides are, to put it mildly, knee-deep in it, the wording is appropriate. Indeed at least one Bradford player believes their chances of survival hinge on today's result. And the abuse Paul Jewell suffered from his own fans at Hillsborough last weekend points to a worrying loss of faith at Valley Parade.

"I think that was the lowest I've been," the manager says. "I was still feeling it three days later." Hardly surprising when scornful chants of "You don't know what you're doing" greeted his substitution of Stuart McCall. Welcome to another victim of his own success. And they reckon goldfish have short memories.

"I think there are a few people waiting to say 'I told you so', people who didn't want me to get the job in the first place," says Jewell, whose appointment in 1998 did not spark dancing in the streets. "I've just got to prove them wrong again. I'm not one for patting myself on the back but you have to live in the real world. It was only three seasons ago we had to beat QPR to stay in the First Division. If this time last year you had asked all those people who criticised me whether they would like to be third from bottom of the Premier League, I think they'd have taken it. We're way ahead of schedule.

"We need the fans to stay with us. We're not in the Northern Premier League, we're in the Premier League and we should be proud of that. Everyone - players, manager, supporters - should be bursting with pride that we're in the Premier League and still fighting."

Whether they can sustain the fight should become apparent today. Recent defeats by Southampton, Gillingham and Sheffield Wednesday do not bode well. Attempts to buy Craig Hignett and Marcus Stewart from Barnsley and Huddersfield this week have failed. "It's a game we need to win badly," Jewell admits.

He says only the bottom four are in real danger, and unless Southampton lose their way or their manager, their escapology expertise should see them through. Whereas Bradford - with Neil Redfearn, a bad-luck charm at Barnsley and Charlton in the past two seasons - are heading straight back down along with Watford and accompanied by Wednesday.

Watford and Bradford are not short of spirit. What they lack are goals and players who can turn a match, a Matt le Tissier of old, for instance. "It's certainly a matter of quality," says Jewell. "My players have been magnificent but this Premier League takes it out of you, not just physically but mentally.

"More often than not my players are up against people better at their jobs than they are, so they have to climb a level every week to get a result. It took a monumental effort against Chelsea to get a draw and since then we've been flat."

If Bradford's match with Watford is pivotal, Jewell can walk on with marginally more hope in his heart. Watford's improving attack is too often undone by a Luxembourg-style defence; Bradford have the greater experience, using £2.8m to bring in Dean Saunders, David Wetherall and Redfearn among others. More will be spent.

"I thought experience was important because at times like this they're the people you look to," Jewell says. "Every manager would like good young players. But to buy top Premier League players who are young... well, we just can't get them."

Nor of course can Watford, though their approach has been different. Youth and imports have featured far more prominently. Riskier perhaps in the short term but arguably better if the club go down.

Graham Taylor has used 11 home-grown players to Jewell's three. Only one of his 11 buys is over 30 and he, Xavier Gravelaine, has joined initially until May. Taylor has spent his £3.4m carefully, always with the future in mind.

"It would be irresponsible if we spent £9m or £10m with no guarantee of staying in the Premiership," he said. "We should be developing the club. That's why I'd rather give boys like David Perpetuini [a 20-year-old midfielder] a chance when we've got players injured.

"We've got to make sure that even if we're relegated there's money to spend, so in two or three years' time we've got every chance of competing with the big boys."

With Geoffrey Richmond as chairman Bradford should have few financial worries, but they are caught in a cycle of perpetual buying. The good news is that the reserves are flourishing and the club may start an academy next season. Jewell, though, faces a more immediate rebuilding programme on his ageing squad.

And some advice from one of his thirtysomethings, Saunders. Away from home Bradford have frequently tried to nullify their opponents, but Saunders says: "You have got to have a go at teams and not be in awe of them. If you sit back, good players don't make mistakes. No one likes it when you can't control the ball without three men around you, and that's what we've got to do."

Barnsley

Relegated 1998

Now Fourth in First Division

"Our finances are under control. I've always tried to run the thing with a degree of sanity. Set against the backdrop of massive wage inflation it's not always easy to do, but we have to do that and retain our ambition."

Chairman John Dennis

Swindon Town

Relegated 1995

Now 24th in First Division

"We have tried in vain to live with the action plan initiated two years ago to achieve a play-off position in Division One and achieve Premiership status. It appeared right at the time but now it seems a foolish gamble."

Chairman Cliff Puffett

fields.headline: England Euro 2000 stadium 'unsafe'
fields.trailText: England's Euro 2000 match against Germany will go ahead in Charleroi despite warnings from Belgium's federal police union yesterday that the stadium is so unsafe, the smallest hint of trouble could cause a tragedy.
fields.body:
England's Euro 2000 match against Germany will go ahead in Charleroi despite warnings from Belgium's federal police union yesterday that the stadium is so unsafe, the smallest hint of trouble could cause a tragedy.

After carrying out security tests the union warned that a repeat of the Heysel disaster of 1985, in which 39 spectators died, was possible if the game went ahead there on June 17.

"We want to draw the authorities' attention to these problems," said its chairman, Paul van Keer. "We want to prevent Belgium adding another drama to its list."

Van Keer claimed work carried out to raise the capacity to Uefa's minimum of 30,000 had made the ground dangerous. During tests mountain rescue techniques had to be used to evacuate victims.

"The over-hasty construction in no way takes the security of the fans into account," he said. "It is next to impossible to evacuate fans who are sick or hurt. If the least thing goes wrong it will be a tragedy."

Yet a Euro 2000 spokesman, Richard van der Eijk, said there was no chance of the tie being moved.

"Nobody else who has inspected the stadium has expressed any concerns and that includes the local police and fire services, who have both passed it safe," he said. "We don't feel his comments are justified."

Van der Eijk also brushed aside criticism that Charleroi is too small for such a high-profile fixture, though he admitted 100,000 tickets could have been sold.

Charleroi, which also hosts England v Romania, will undergo a final test during a friendly between Belgium and Portugal on February 23.

 Coventry, currently denied their Moroccans, Moustapha Hadji and Youssef Chippo, have looked even farther afield and made another double signing with the Peruvian internationals Israel Zuniga and Walter Zevallos, from Melgar, in a combined £1.5m deal. Zuniga, 23, is holder of the South American Golden Boot; he scored 32 goals in 26 games in his first season. They will link up with Coventry next month, when the Moroccans return.

 Barnet were warned yesterday that they face expulsion from the Football League unless they can upgrade their Underhill home or find another base. They have until August to improve their stadium to the 6,000 minimum capacity required, including 2,000 seats, or face playing elsewhere, possibly ground-sharing.

 Ray Harford has parted company with Oxford United after six weeks as their technical director.

fields.headline: Raking over the Ashes
fields.standfirst: As Angela's Ashes comes to life on the big screen,  Tara Mack visits a much-changed Limerick and is in two minds over its literary heritage
fields.trailText: As Angela's Ashes comes to life on the big screen, Tara Mack visits a much-changed Limerick and is in two minds over its literary heritage.
fields.body:
There is at least one thing that hasn't changed in Limerick since Frank McCourt, author of Angela's Ashes, lived here - the weather.

This south-western city that hugs the River Shannon is still capable of producing a damp chill that slithers under your coat and tickles your throat. In the book, McCourt blamed the weather for the pneumonia and consumption that were rampant in his neighbourhood. Limerick was saturated with just such a chill the day I set out on the Angela's Ashes tour.

But my guide, Michael O'Donnell, hadn't moved 10 feet from the tourist centre before he was assuring me that little else has stayed the same.

"Limerick today is a different place," he stressed. "It's a much more modern, vibrant city."

Limerick was once poor and run down with a reputation for violence that earned it the nickname "Stab City". But Ireland's economic boom has turned the city's fortunes around. It buzzes with a new energy. Like the rest of Ireland, the population is predominantly young and increasingly prosperous. And people are hoping that Angela's Ashes, which sold millions of copies worldwide, will bring in the tourists.

Not that Angela's Ashes is an obvious draw. McCourt's Limerick of the 1930s was a miserable place. The streets where his family lived, called the lanes, were cramped and filthy. Dirt, cold and malnourishment killed two of his brothers and gave him typhoid. He left when he was 19. Not much of a plug for the city. But that hasn't deterred the organisers of the Angela's Ashes walking tour.

Many of the roads and buildings that feature in the book are gone (the Lyric Cinema, for example, is now a car park). So, much of the tour focuses on the one institution that has lasted, namely the Catholic Church. We look at the church where McCourt had his first communion, the church where he saw his mother begging for food, the church where he confessed having "the excitement" with a young woman dying of consumption.

Roden Lane, the street where McCourt lived the longest, has been torn down along with most of the other lanes in Limerick. But you can get close to the spot where it once stood. The street next to it is now solidly middle class with lime-green town houses and Toyotas and Volkswagens parked out front.

In the evening, I took a cab to suburban Dooradoyle for the Irish premiere of Alan Parker's Angela's Ashes. The movie has stoked the embers of a controversy that was first ignited when the book was published in 1996.

Some of the older residents, many of whom knew the McCourt family, say the book is inaccurate and insulting. McCourt, they say, accuses his neighbours of sexual transgressions, trashes beloved institutions like the Catholic Church and the charitable St Vincent de Paul Society and overstates the poverty.

Rita McClosky, born and raised in Limerick, was one of the few people I met at the premiere who thought the book was an insult. "I lived 100 yards from where he lived," she said. "And I know there was poverty in those years, but he exaggerated."

But most of those gathered in the neon lobby of the Omniplex were full of praise for McCourt. "I loved the humour and the dialogue," said local resident, Suzanne Kennedy. "I think the people of Limerick should be very proud."

The practicals

Tara Mack flew to Shannon from Stanstead with Virgin Express (020 7744 0004). Flights start from £68. She stayed in Hanratty's Hotel, Limerick (00353 61 410999), where a double room costs Ir£50 a night inc.breakfast. St Mary's Integrated Development Programme organises the Angela's Ashes tour (00353 61 318106). at a cost of Ir &#'163;4pp.

fields.headline: The laws of not-so-natural selection
fields.standfirst: If you're not on the list, you ain't comin in!
fields.trailText: If you're not on the list, you ain't comin in!
fields.body:
Ever queued for a gig or club and noticed the in-crowd swagger past wearing proudly their plastic IDs which grant them "Access All Areas". Creeps!

If you're a final year student or graduate, you may find something similar happening in the world of recruitment.

There was a time when getting your first job was fairly democratic. To win an interview with the employer of your dreams you visited the campus career fair when the "milk round" pulled into town, and fought your way to the company's stand along with thousands of other sweaty, job-hungry students.

But the democratic state of graduate recruitment is under attack with many employers becoming more selective in the methods they use to find recruits.

Some have bailed out of the milk round and careers fairs, and target only certain universities.

But an emerging trend is the invitation-only event where participants are hand-picked and viewed by an elite roster of recruiters - a bit like a beauty pageant.

Recruitment consultant EMDS, which claims to have pioneered the concept of invitation-only 'forums' currently runs more than 50 selective events around the world each year - last weekend it was the turn of Brussels to host an event and the company confidently predicts that around 50% of the candidates who attended will receive at least two job offers as a result.

As Martin Cerullo, manager of consultants at EDMS, is keen to point out, anyone is welcome to apply. It's as simple as filling in a career profile form in the network section of the the company's website website www.emdsnet.com or sending in just an application and CV. But the EMDS database currently stands at more than 150,000 CVs and you have to be pretty darn good to make it past the bouncers.

As an indication, EMDS received more than 2,200 applications to its last EMDS AfricaManagers forum - just 460 candidates were selected and subsequently attended.

If selected, EMDS presents your information to the 20 to 50 companies participating in each of its forums - employers who "specifically value your skills".

The privileged few are guaranteed up to five pre-scheduled interviews during the forum, and the chance to arrange as many other interviews as they wish while on site.

So which graduates have the faces that fit?

Typically, they are those, says EMDS with high academic performance, strong managerial potential, and outstanding intellectual and interpersonal skills. Many of the successful applicants are multilin gual with an international background and a desire to be geographically-mobile.

So, two months before a forum, all the applications are reviewed and assessed by EMDS consultants, with criteria based on academic achievement, professional experience, language skills, international orientation, mobility and extra- curricular activities. These scrutineers also seek out attributes closely matching the employers' specific recruitment requirements.

Then six weeks before the forum, employers receive the applications matching their search profiles. Over a period of ten days, they choose the candidates they wish to interview.

A month before the forum, the successful applicants get their invitations in the post including at least one interview appointment from a recruiting company.

At the forum itself, scheduled interviews are conducted from 9am to 7pm on day one and from 9am to 5pm on day two - but there's plenty of time for unscheduled interviews to take place too. EMDS also lays on company presentations, workshops and round-table discussions.

To lessen the stress, every event takes place in a five-star hotel. Interviews are held in private rooms while hospitality suites provide the venue for informal networking.

"Recruiting this way means employers can be assured of quality candidates at a fration of the cost and time spent at traditional careers fairs," says Cerullo. "For students and graduates, it means they can focus their time on specific employers without having to fight to be heard at a stand.

"It's a privilege to be selected for one of these events - something to put on your CV."

EMDS flatly rejects charges of elitism. "We give everyone the same opportunity to apply - we don't even discriminate on the grounds of which university someone attended," says Cerullo. "Much of our assessment and recommendation is based on a candidate's potential.

Some employers across the Atlantic are taking unnatural selection a step further. From the pool of 25,000 computer science students who graduate each year, Microsoft creates a shortlist of 8,000 CVs, which are reviewed to identify the 2,600 targeted for campus interviews. Following these, about 800 are invited to visit Microsoft's Redmond campus near Seattle.

But this process leads to only 20% of Microsoft's annual recruitment. Most of the remaining 2,000 staff Microsoft brings on board each year are identified by a full-time team of 200 recruiting experts. This is Microsoft's so-called "strike team", whose sole job is to ferret out the industry's most talented people.

Once someone has been identified as "hard core" - Microsoft's euphemism for the kind of highly talented and driven people they seek - the pursuit is relentless, if subtle. Regular telephone calls at discreet intervals, invitations for informal dinners - strike team members employ every means to keep the lines of communication open with the potential candidate.

According to Cerullo, EMDS has been approached by several dot coms to undertake similar talent trawls. His advice on getting noticed? Be focused on what you want to do, learn another language and get into some extra-curricular activities.

&3149; The next London event is EMDS Africa Managers on April 16-18. The deadline for applications is February 24, 2000.

Regular telephone calls at discreet intervals, invitations for informal dinners - strike team members employ every means to keep the lines of communication open with the potential candidate. According to Cerullo, EMDS has been approached by several dot coms to undertake similar talent trawls. His advice on getting noticed? Be focused on what you want to do, learn another language and get into some extra-curricular activities. &3149; The next London event is EMDS Africa Managers on April 16-18. The deadline for applications is February 24, 2000.

webTitle: How to... change your habits for a lifetime

fields.headline: How to... change your habits for a lifetime
fields.standfirst: Even a small shift in your routine could make a huge difference
fields.trailText: Even a small shift in your routine could make a huge difference
fields.body:
Paper, says Paul Shaw, testing manager for an interactive TV company, is a very great thing indeed. Lots and lots of paper. "Forget all this paperless office stuff. Outlook and Lotus Notes and e-mail are all very well, but give me pieces of paper that I can see, touch, stick to my monitor, keep in a book. With my memory, having things stored on computer just means I forget about them but since I have rediscovered the joys of paper I'm working loads more efficiently."

Becoming a born-again paper fan may not be everyone's way of becoming more productive at work, but the fact is that most people would benefit from changing their working habits in some way. The vast majority of office workers waste time during the day through bad habits - chatting, working ineffectively - or just by staring into space, says Ros Taylor of Plus Consulting.

"It's all about planning - set yourself a list of tasks each day and tick each one off as you have achieved it. If you're in the habit of skipping lunch, don't - take a proper break or by 3pm you'll be good for nothing. I have worked with senior managers who were working until 9 or 10pm - once they'd been shown how to plan effectively, they got twice as much done and were off home by six."

Which is all very well if you're in the upper echelons of a company, and someone is paid to come in and sort you out. But for the rest of us who have to struggle against our own bad habits with no outside help, making a change can be more difficult.

"Bad habits are the same whether it's smoking, eating or at work - you need willpower to make a resolution and stick to it," says sub-editor Caron Martin. "I'd got into a routine whereby I never answered e-mails when I received them - I'm a terrible one for putting things off. So, at the end of the day there'd be a whole stack of things I had to reply to.

"Or I'd spend half the afternoon apologising to people that had been expecting a reply straight away. In the end, I decided that I would answer each e-mail as soon as I got it - it's a pain at times, but if it means that I get away from work earlier and spend less time with cross writers barking down the phone at me, then I intend to keep it up."

Of course, bad working habits aren't simply about how you work, but can also be inherent in how you think about work and how you communicate. Miscommunication - or lack of it altogether - is one of the prime causes of problems in the workplace, and judgements and perceptions are often made based on how articulate someone is.

"I get very nervous in meetings," admits Sarah Tullett, a marketing research executive. "So, I talk a lot to try and cover it up. Also I feel that the men I work with tend to talk a lot at meetings and I have to keep my end up - so I babble away, knowing that most of what I'm saying is pretty useless, but believing that I have to get my voice heard.

It wasn't until a colleague suggested, somewhat unkindly, that she didn't have to make every point three times, that she decided to try to change. "Now I try to be more aware of what I want to say, and keep it clear and concise. I still get the urge to babble on, but I'm more aware and do have better control of it now."

"At work talk is always public," says Deborah Tannen, author of Talking 9 to 5, "and in most work settings your performance will, at some point, be evaluated on your conversational style. It might seem impossible to change the way you communicate, but even a small shift in style can make a big difference. If you never speak in meetings, make an effort to say at least one thing. If you're worried that you come over as slightly bossy, try and use softer words - say it would be helpful, rather than I need you to. If you're always first to voice an opinion, make sure you remember to ask others for theirs."

If you don't remember anything else, remember this...

Slipping back into bad habits can be hard to avoid. But, unlike dieting and giving up smoking - which both involve giving up something enjoyable - the only thing you give up by changing work habits is late nights at the office. More time to indulge all the other things that you've just given up.

webTitle: Can you have a career  and live with mum?

fields.headline: Can you have a career  and live with mum?
fields.standfirst: Home is where the heart is - along with the washing machine
fields.trailText: Home is where the heart is - along with the washing machine
fields.body:
You've spent three years tripping merrily down the yellow (or red) brick road of university life, overcoming every academic, social and financial obstacle in your way. Now, as you stand proudly, your degree certificate in your hand, you look forward to an independent life and a challenging career.

The last thing you want to do is click your heels three times and chant: "There's no place like home, no place like home."

The sad truth is, thanks to today's wicked witches of the West - student debt and graduate unemployment - home is exactly where many of you will end up. Lawrence Wilson, careers adviser at Christchurch Canterbury, University College, says that unless you've been lucky enough to graduate straight into a well-paid job, renting a place of your own is simply not a practical choice.

"Financially speaking, coming back home is usually the cheapest option. You may not find a job immediately and you may have to spend six months temping to pay off your debts. In addition, you may need to work unpaid for a while to get the experience you need to enter your chosen career."

The expectation of leaving home at 18, never to return, singles us out from our European counterparts. "British students are unusual," says Lawrence. "They become independent far younger than in many other countries where students do national service, often stay at home to study and don't graduate until their mid-twenties."

But after three years of student life - doing what you like, when you like, with whom you like - returning to the family home, with its rituals and routines, is rarely easy. You've developed your own ideas, tastes and values, some of which will clash horribly with your parents'. In short, you've grown up.

"For many graduates, having to go back home is one of the hardest things to do," says Lawrence. "Having become independent, you're having to go back to being semi-dependent and that can put a lot of strain on the relationship between parent and child."

If the thought of moving back to cries of "Where have you been till this time", or "You're treating this house like a hotel", sucks, imagine what it's like for your parents. They've had three years of peace and quiet, a spacious home and much-reduced phone-bills. Depending on their age, they might even be thinking about retirement. In the three years you've been away, they've grown more set in their ways. The last thing they want is to support a prodigal son or daughter.

Dianah Worman, adviser for the Institute of Personnel and Development, says few parents plan for the return of their graduate offspring: "Parents expect their children's lives to follow a similar pattern to their own. In their day, things were different. Students graduated straight into a good job and it's likely they got married younger than people do today, perhaps soon after finishing university. You're a drain on their cash that they hadn't predicted.

"When a graduate returns home, everyone needs to adapt and modify their behaviour. You need to respect your parents' freedom and space too."

Lawrence Wilson says it's important that neither parent nor child sees a graduate's return as a sign of failure. "Where aspirations don't match, there can be problems. But in my experience of talking to parents, most are very supportive and understanding of the current graduate labour market. Often it's the graduate who feels guilty. They'll say, "My parents have supported me all my life and I no longer wish to be a burden'."

Going back home doesn't have to be an unpleasant experience. Let's not ignore the benefits of a warm bedroom, hot meals and - if you're very lucky - a free laundry service. The months after graduation can be an unsettling time; don't knock the security of a familiar base from which to apply for jobs and plan for the future.

Nishi Shah, now 28 and a lighting designer, has been living at home since she graduated from Leeds University in 1993. "I never thought I'd live at home for more than a few years," she admits. "Initially, I moved back because I couldn't afford a decent place of my own and because my parents appreciated me being at home. I'm Asian and, culturally speaking, it's usual for graduates to move back to their parents' home.

"When I first came back after four years away, it was difficult to settle down. I wasn't used to answering to anyone else or having set times. It was hard not being able to have friends over without pre-arrangement and I resented doing more housework than I wanted to. It was a big adjustment, but we've both adapted and compromised.

"I no longer see my mum's concern as an invasion of my privacy and she has learned not to wait up for me. I pay my share of the food and bills, so I don't feel I'm sponging off her.

"On the plus side, I get the creature comforts - my mum's cooking is a big draw - and the space of a family house, rather than a cramped flat. I have thought about moving out, but I'm in no great hurry. I wouldn't want to live with strangers and most of my friends are settled. I wouldn't recommend living at home to everyone, but it works for me."

fields.headline: Emotional baggage
fields.standfirst: Once they were slave forts, now they are tourist attractions.  Polly Pattullo on the delicate balance between preserving Ghana's historic sites and pulling in the punters
fields.trailText: Once they were slave forts, now they are tourist attractions. Polly Pattullo on the delicate balance between preserving Ghana's historic sites and pulling in the punters.
fields.body:
Visitors look at new places with eyes that are loaded with their perceptions about the world and where they come from. Depending on the "view", we can be fascinated, bored or anguished. It can be unforgettable or mundane. Our hosts, who look at that same view every day, see things differently.

Such confusion usually makes only for passing amusement or embarrassment. But in some cases, the contradictions are fundamental and the responses more complicated. Sometimes, it is the visitors who dictate the agenda, forcing the hosts to make difficult compromises. What happens, for example, at places that were once witnesses to horror and that have now become shrines? As tourist attractions, what are they there for and for whom? And what is the responsibility of the hosts who find themselves the caretakers of such memorials?

These questions have recently become pertinent in west Africa where some of the coastal trading forts are now open to the public. They were built for trade in gold, ivory - and slaves. Now Unesco World Heritage sites, the forts at Elmina and Cape Coast, in particular, have become key features of Ghana's tourist industry.

The history of Elmina fort began in 1482. The Portuguese established the first European building in tropical Africa there on a promontory on the edge of the Atlantic. Trading with African partners, its wealth was generated from the hinterland - a land of gold and, later, slaves destined for the Middle Passage. The Dutch captured Elmina in 1637 (being pragmatic Protestants they turned its chapel into an auction house). Then it was the turn of the British, who held it from 1872 until independence in 1957. During British rule, it was used to imprison an Ashanti monarch.

Since independence, Ghanaians have used it as a school, a government office and a police training academy. And now, with its buildings restored, it staunch walls whitewashed, with its views of the town's fishing fleet, the curved beach and the swirling waves of the Atlantic at its feet, it has become a tourist attraction. It has been many things to many people. And so it remains.

For Ghanaians, the forts - and the slave trade - are one aspect of their history. Their interest as tourists to Elmina Castle may be in exploring the rooms where the Ashanti leader, King Prempeh I, was imprisoned in 1896 before being exiled to the Seychelles. Their interest as hosts may be to construct a tourism that brings money to the local economy and ensures that local people play a central role in determining what should happen at the Castle.

For whites, the details of life in the slave forts produce a shamble of emotions. We are shown, foe example, "the door of no return", that narrow slit in a wall through which slaves were forced on to a waiting ship.

The Ghanaian guide is neither melodramatic nor evasive; perhaps he edits his talk according to his clientele. Whatever, we white tourists shuffle helplessly. We cannot quite imagine ourselves as those Africans. But we can think of what role - as herders of the herded - we might have played in that dismal history. But then, with the tour over, we have a drink in the café, turn our back on the fort and watch the fishing boats, a picturesque tourist image of bustling, modern Ghana.

So, too, can African-Americans. But they are not there to admire the view. For them, the forts hold a particular intensity. As an American anthropologist pointed out, for some visitors from the black diaspora, the "castles are sacred ground not to be desecrated. They do not want the castles to be made beautiful or to be whitewashed. They want the original stench to remain in the dungeons."

For them, these unembellished forts are places of pilgrimage. And those tourists bring wreaths and flowers and perform ceremonies of purification and remembrance in the dungeons. They are there to reclaim their own history.

Ghana must balance such different needs and perceptions in displaying its forts to the world. Complete with souvenir shops and interpretive centres (like the good one at Cape Coast), they have become destinations competing with rainforests, festivals and markets for a slice of the tourist trade. At the same time, they must respect the needs of those for whom the forts are a spiritual home, the "gates of return". Five hundred years of entrepreneurial and moral tussle for control of the forts is clearly not over.

webTitle: Scaling Table Mountain in South Africa

fields.headline: Turning the Table
fields.standfirst: With 350 paths to the summit,  Giles Foden  assumed that scaling Table Mountain would be like a stroll in the park. Big mistake
fields.trailText: With 350 paths to the summit, Giles Foden assumed that scaling Table Mountain would be like a stroll in the park. Big mistake.
fields.body:
It was my second visit to Cape Town, and this time I was determined to do what I'd shied away from last time: climb Table Mountain. This time I had brought a friend with me, Chris. He was a tough Scotsman, and it would have been too much loss of face to cry off. So we had breakfast, and made our preparations - mine consisting of little more than changing into an old pair of jeans.

Our hotel, the Mount Nelson, was handily placed for the ascent; it also did a good line in canvas laundry bags, into one of which we packed three bottles of mineral water. It would, we believed, be enough to see us through the 1,086m climb.

First, we had to break out of the city, and the ever-present ARMED ALERT signs bearing witness to Cape Town's crime epidemic, and walk up grassy paths under the shade of enormous bluegums.

We only had a rough idea of which one to take (there are 350 recognised paths to the summit), but the sight of the mountain, with its cable-station on the "table" drew us on well enough. We set ourselves the initial target of a lonely tree about half way up, and pressed on.

The cover of bluegums soon gave way to other vegetation on the lower slopes, gorgeous plants appearing nowhere else on earth, such as the rare Silver Tree and the wild orchid Disa Uniflora. The real attraction, though, was the sandstone-sculpted summit of the table itself, measuring 3km from end to end. There was no "tablecloth" today (as Capetonians call the layer of cloud that sometimes boils over the edge), and we were already beginning to see stupendous views: the panorama stretches from Table Bay to False Bay, and around the mountain to Hout Bay Valley and Kommetjie.

My jeans were turning out to be a very bad fashion choice for mountain climbing, impeding every upwards step. So, impervious to embarrassment, I took them off, and continued - in my boxer shorts, my shirt hanging out - with greater ease. I was glad there were no other walkers about, though: everyone else seemed to be coming by vehicle up the Tafelberg Road and into the cable-car's lower station.

For us, the lonely tree having long been passed, the upper station, right on top of the summit was now the object. Navigation, at this point, became more difficult: we were now hard by the face of the rock, zigzagging up on paths that were becoming ever narrower.

We had seen no one at close quarters till, rounding a corner, we came up on a couple sitting in the crook of rock. They were both white (one of the saddest hangovers of the apartheid era is that you see very little of the rainbow nation on the Cape Peninsula's premier tourist attraction) and had the wiry look of those who knew the mountain well.

They looked at us with something like disdain and, since they didn't seem keen for conversation, we made to continue. Then, as we were turning away, there came a voice heavily accented with Afrikaans. "Do you know the mountain well?"

"Not too well," I replied.

"Well, you don't want to go that way," said the man, who was wearing an old, black-felt voortrekker's hat with a feather in the band. "Take the path to the right."

Thus corrected, we continued on our way, until we reached a second rock face. Here, Chris noticed the trace of a fossil in the rock, and we stopped for a moment to inspect it - a trilobite, perhaps, from times long ago when this mountain was underwater, or some other ancient remnant of a 245-million-year-old aquatic crawler or burrower.

At this point, it seemed to be taking that sort of stretch of time to get anywhere. Like all mountains, this one was deceptive, reserving its longuers till last. We weren't alone now, anyway: some South African students were snapping at our heels.

We were so, and I knew that I couldn't. I made my uncertainty known to Chris, and he accommodatingly agreed that we would instead squeeze through the crevice and try another route on the other side of the mountain. We made our shameful retreat, leaving the South Africans to haul themselves up.

The path was soon gone, and we spent two painful hours making our way through thick, thorny bush looking for a way up when we realised there wasn't one. And no way back, if we were to get down before sudden, tropical dark. We'd come too far now to get to the cableway, or to retrace our steps. I began to think of helicopter rescues and midnight airlifts. There was nothing for it but to cut straight down.

Which is what we did, sliding and scraping on our backsides for a good four hours. My jeans, back on now, were ripped to shreds, as were my face and forearms. The sun was hotter than ever and my face was beginning to blister. It had even begun to take its toll on Chris, who had resorted to tying the laundry bag over his head, like an Arab burnous.

Dehydration soon set in as well, and I do believe I began to hallucinate a little. By the time we reached the foothills - we were on so different a part of the mountain that we were heading not for the city itself but the neighbouring beach resort of Camp's Bay - I was staggering and grabbing for support at the rare flora I had admired on the way up. There were many moments I didn't think we would make it.

But at last we cleared the scrub, and hit a dirt track that eventually opened into the upscale suburbs of Camp's Bay. Surely we'd now be able to find a bar, somewhere to slake our thirst. Oh no, this was white South Africa at its meanest, for zoning regulations had long ago forced out the kind of roadside shack selling soft drinks you'd find anywhere else on the continent. More ARMED ALERT signs, together with the sight of chained-up alsatians, put us off nipping into someone's garden to swig from a hosepipe. We looked pretty strange now, anyway: me with my tattered jeans and flash-fried face, Chris with the laundry bag over his head, and both of us covered in dirt and lesions.

We had to walk for another hour before hitting the main drag of Camp's Bay, where, faint from heat exhaustion, we fell into the Jazz Café and sank two litres of mineral water and seven cans of Coke apiece. I was pleased I had persevered, but I had learned my lesson: never climb a mountain unprepared.

Tips for climbing Table Mountain

Safety rules: tell someone you are going, and your route. Never climb alone. In the event of an accident, someone should always stay with the injured person. Allow four hours each for ascent and descent.

Hazards: heat-related illness, ankle and spinal injuries on rough ground, stone falls, snake bites.

Rescue services: Metro Rescue, South African Air Force, Mountain Club of South Africa (the latter is called out 50 times a year). The emergency rescue number is 10177. If you have a cellphone, call 112 and say you are calling from the Western Cape.

Equipment: map, boots with rubber soles, food, at least two litres of water per person, rucksack, torch, hat, high- factor suncream, warm and waterproof clothing.

Life online

Mountain Club of South Africa is at www.mcsa.org.za. For information on Cape Town, go to the city's official website at www.ctcc.gov.za. A more general South African webzine can be found at www.southafrica.co.za.

The practicals

South African Airways (0870 7471111) currently has a return fair to Johannesburg for £600, although you should call for special offers. A standard double room at Mount Nelson Hotel in Cape Town costs £274 per night. Call 202 7568 8366 for reservations.
