fields.headline: Turquoise delight
fields.standfirst: A week at sea with a bunch of strangers could be some people's idea of hell. But how bad can it be when you're sailing the Turquoise Coast with a cooler crammed full of booze and a chef who feeds you like royalty?  Andrew Gilchrist  rides the crest of a wave
fields.trailText: A week at sea with a bunch of strangers could be some people's idea of hell. But how bad can it be when you're sailing the Turquoise Coast with a cooler crammed full of booze and a chef who feeds you like royalty? Andrew Gilchrist rides the crest of a wave.
fields.body:
We were about two miles out of Fethiye harbour when the captain stuck his head out of the bridge, felt the seawind whistle past his ears and, as the morning sun poured down like silver across the tips of the waves, gave the order we had all been waiting for: "Sail!"

He cut the engine and Mustafa and Mehmet, the youngest and most energetic members of the Grandi I's four-man crew, jumped up on to the sundeck and leapt into the air, grabbing the ropes above our heads and yanking them down, each new thud hoisting the giant middle sail a yard further up the mast.

Within minutes the sails were all up - 400sq m of brilliant white tarpaulin that caught first the sunlight then the wind. Jibs were secured, knots were tied, loose crockery was put away, drinks were finished and then suddenly, as if rousing herself from a deep sleep, the Grandi I gave one last lazy pitch forward - and took off across the waves.

This was the fifth day of our week-long cruise around the Turquoise Coast, the sun-baked southwestern shores of Turkey that once housed the ancient independent kingdom of Lycia, and it wasn't the first time Captain Umit had raised the sails. But we'd never had a wind as fast as this.

The Grandi I - a sleek, 29m, 100-ton yacht - swayed from side to side like a drunk as she ploughed through the waves at an exhilarating 10 knots, turning passengers into human pinballs as we tried to serve ourselves lunch or raced to nab the best seat in the house: the bowsprit, or beam overhanging the front, where every movement of the boat was magnified, every spray-lashed second breathtaking.

I was one of nine passengers who had come aboard the Grandi I, one of a fleet of seven yachts, at a quiet cove near Marmaris, a large developed resort whose intricate, bazaar-strewn backstreets have been all but eclipsed by the sprawl of concrete. After dumping our bags in the mahogany-lined cabins belowships, it was shoes and socks off and up on to the aftdeck for champagne with the captain, who spread out a well-worn map of the waters we would be navigating, and the ports we would visit.

Spending a week in a confined space with a handful of strangers might be some people's idea of hell. Cynics may find it hard to believe but Tussock, the people who organise these cruises, insist their groups always get along, as they take great care in ensuring a good mix: singles, couples, whatever, whoever, so long as they're likely to gel. They even take pop stars, and have performed weddings at sea. Our group, a not-exactly-shy bunch of twenty-, thirty- and fortysomethings, seemed to hit it off right away; but maybe it's not that hard to break the ice when the needle's nearing 90, the cooler's crammed with booze, everyone's on holiday, the Med's your oyster and there's a daily excursion to look forward to.

Despite the occasional burst of speed with the sails hoisted, mornings and early afternoons were mostly given over to taking it easy. We'd rise whenever we wanted, tease whoever had overdone it the most the previous night, help each other smear on the factor 16, then ooh and aah over what new treat Selahattin, our cook, had prepared for breakfast. One day it was chopped apple in light yogurt, another day banana slices doused with dark honey still dripping from the comb - always fresh, always delicious, always different and always served up with feta cheese, eggs, olives, nuts, sliced tomatoes and Turkish coffee so thick you could barely get the spoon in.

No one, we were told, loses weight on these cruises, despite the fact that the moment the Grandi I dropped anchor anywhere we'd cool off with a plunge into the clear blue waters, and the crew would look out the ship's canoeing, windsurfing and snorkelling equipment for us to go up and down quiet coves making noisy nuisances of ourselves.

Selahattin used to be a fisherman, in the days when these waters still had plenty of fish. But now, as we discovered on a shopping excursion to Fethiye, tourists are the main catch. "My friend, my friend," we heard constantly as we strolled past the bars, cafés, restaurants, carpet stores and sweet shops that make up this pleasant town. "Come in, yes please. Where you from?"

I stopped off at a simple store for a box of Turkish delight - not the jellied variety dusted with sugar, but the rolls of curled-over candy steeped in rose water and dotted with pistachio nuts that come in flavours like banana, fig or chocolate, and have to be snipped into slices with scissors. "Glasgow?" said the shopkeeper when I told him where I was from. "See you, Jimmy!" he growled, then named some pubs in the city centre before pulling a cross-eyed face and saying: "Get oot ma road ya wee bampot!"

If it was a gimmick, it was a pretty good one and, before I knew it, I was sitting on a chair in the middle of the shop, drinking apple tea and being introduced to his family. Fifteen minutes later, I left laden with four boxes of Turkish delight, five pots of crushed-nut honey, a cup with the tail of a fish for a handle, a bright blue-and-yellow ashtray, a stone turtle, and a huge, elaborately hand-painted plate. He named a price and I paid it, lacking the strength and the nous to haggle, as is expected. It was still early evening when I headed back to the boat, but over my shoulder I could see him excitably shutting up shop, possibly for the rest of the month.

Our first big excursion had, by contrast, been to ancient ruins in Letoon and Xanthos, the heartland of ancient Lycia. Situated near the southern port of Kas, both sites are a great introduction to the rich history that ancient Lycia and its environs boast (despite the fact that much of what was uncovered here in the 1800s was plundered for Britain). For thousands of years, these Turkish shores were the stage for invading armies and ancient civilisations: Luwians, Hurians, Ionians, Trojans, Carians, Lycians and Persians.

In 540BC, the people of Xanthos, finding their city surrounded by Persian troops, gathered up all their belongings and formed them into a giant funeral pyre. The women and children died in the flames, the men perished fighting. Only eight families, who had been away, survived. Then in 42BC, during the Roman civil war, Brutus besieged Xanthos and the citizens put their city to the torch all over again.

My favourite character, however, was the Persian King Xerxes, who had plenty of style but little luck. In 479BC, he followed the progress of his army at the sea battle of Salamis from a throne of gold placed on a hilltop. His forces were four times more powerful than their Greek opponents but still he watched helpless as his ships sank one by one. "My men have fought as women," he said, "and my women have fought as men."

Then, half a century later, there was King Mausoleus who, to keep power in his family, married his sister, Artemisia II. And so happy was she in this union that, every day after his death, she drank a glass of wine containing a sprinkling of his ashes.

The daily excursions are all voluntary but there was one trip everyone signed up for: the hamam, or Turkish bath. Off we went, towels round our middles, legs like lava lamps thanks to badly applied suncream, each emerging into the humidity of the rounded marble bath chamber.

At the centre of the hamam is the naval stone, a raised platform heated from below. On this we lay, as a masseur scrubbed us up and down with a kese (abrasive mitt), sloshed us with hot water, then produced a large white cotton bag into which he popped six bars of soap. This was dipped in warm water, blown into, then held tightly shut and pushed down over whoever was on the slab, causing an explosion of lather that was then massaged in. Just as I was getting the treatment, a Turkish bloke in the corner began a chant so low and penetrating it seemed to come from the marble itself. As the tiny bubbles of lather popped in my ears, it felt like I was drifting off on a magic carpet.

We had eaten ashore the day before, at an attractive little port called Kalkan, taking the biggest table in a seafood restaurant overlooking the white walls of the harbour reddenning in the twilight. But, after the hamam, we ate back onboard the Grandi I, skin still tingling as Selahattin fried up the sea bream we'd seen him descaling that afternoon, and served it with the usual 1001 delicacies - cous cous, bulgur wheat, fried pancake rolls stuffed with cheese and parsley, goulash, carrot yogurt, artichokes with garlic - dishes that were probably as mundane and everyday to him as a cheese-and-pickle sandwich is to us. But we fell upon them and felt like royalty.

In true Mediterranean fashion, it was over the food and drink that our group really came together. By day we'd split up into smaller groups; then, later, we'd reassemble around the long table on the aftdeck of the Grandi I, experiencing the richness of Turkey through the dishes before us. And, as the wine flowed and the captain put on Turkish music or let us play our own, we would open up to each other more and more.

We had started the week as strangers. But now - after excursions up the labyrinthine Dalyan River to the tombs of the Lycian kings engraved in a cliff; after smearing ourselves in the skin-cleansing, grey-green mud from a warm sulphurous spring; after being tossed about in the waves at Patara Beach, one of the Med's longest; after sitting up talking, drinking and laughing around the dinner table till the small hours, then staggering off to sleep on the sundeck beneath the stars - we were as easy in each other's company as old friends.

And beneath us, on that last night on the Turquoise Coast, was our other new friend - that giant timber cradle gently rocking us to sleep, the Grandi I.

The practaicals

Tussock cruising (www.tussockcruising.com) offers one week's cruising starting from £331, including breakfast, lunch, dinner (four dinners in the course of the week) and all drinks. Flights not included. Passengers can book individually or charter a yacht with a group of friends, for one, two or three weeks. Themed cruises are available (eg. nature, archaeology). IN May, June and October, four can travel for the price of three. For a brochure call 020 8510 9292 or email tussockcruisinguk@compuserve.com.

In 540BC, the people of Xanthos, finding their city surrounded by Persian troops, gathered up all their belongings and formed them into a giant funeral pyre. The women and children died in the flames, the men perished fighting. Only eight families, who had been away, survived. Then in 42BC, during the Roman civil war, Brutus besieged Xanthos and the citizens put their city to the torch all over again. My favourite character, however, was the Persian King Xerxes, who had plenty of style but little luck. In 479BC, he followed the progress of his army at the sea battle of Salamis from a throne of gold placed on a hilltop. His forces were four times more powerful than their Greek opponents but still he watched helpless as his ships sank one by one. "My men have fought as women," he said, "and my women have fought as men." Then, half a century later, there was King Mausoleus who, to keep power in his family, married his sister, Artemisia II. And so happy was she in this union that, every day after his death, she drank a glass of wine containing a sprinkling of his ashes. The daily excursions are all voluntary but there was one trip everyone signed up for: the hamam, or Turkish bath. Off we went, towels round our middles, legs like lava lamps thanks to badly applied suncream, each emerging into the humidity of the rounded marble bath chamber. At the centre of the hamam is the naval stone, a raised platform heated from below. On this we lay, as a masseur scrubbed us up and down with a kese (abrasive mitt), sloshed us with hot water, then produced a large white cotton bag into which he popped six bars of soap. This was dipped in warm water, blown into, then held tightly shut and pushed down over whoever was on the slab, causing an explosion of lather that was then massaged in. Just as I was getting the treatment, a Turkish bloke in the corner began a chant so low and penetrating it seemed to come from the marble itself. As the tiny bubbles of lather popped in my ears, it felt like I was drifting off on a magic carpet. We had eaten ashore the day before, at an attractive little port called Kalkan, taking the biggest table in a seafood restaurant overlooking the white walls of the harbour reddenning in the twilight. But, after the hamam, we ate back onboard the Grandi I, skin still tingling as Selahattin fried up the sea bream we'd seen him descaling that afternoon, and served it with the usual 1001 delicacies - cous cous, bulgur wheat, fried pancake rolls stuffed with cheese and parsley, goulash, carrot yogurt, artichokes with garlic - dishes that were probably as mundane and everyday to him as a cheese-and-pickle sandwich is to us. But we fell upon them and felt like royalty. In true Mediterranean fashion, it was over the food and drink that our group really came together. By day we'd split up into smaller groups; then, later, we'd reassemble around the long table on the aftdeck of the Grandi I, experiencing the richness of Turkey through the dishes before us. And, as the wine flowed and the captain put on Turkish music or let us play our own, we would open up to each other more and more. We had started the week as strangers. But now - after excursions up the labyrinthine Dalyan River to the tombs of the Lycian kings engraved in a cliff; after smearing ourselves in the skin-cleansing, grey-green mud from a warm sulphurous spring; after being tossed about in the waves at Patara Beach, one of the Med's longest; after sitting up talking, drinking and laughing around the dinner table till the small hours, then staggering off to sleep on the sundeck beneath the stars - we were as easy in each other's company as old friends. And beneath us, on that last night on the Turquoise Coast, was our other new friend - that giant timber cradle gently rocking us to sleep, the Grandi I. The practaicals Tussock cruising (www.tussockcruising.com) offers one week's cruising starting from £331, including breakfast, lunch, dinner (four dinners in the course of the week) and all drinks. Flights not included. Passengers can book individually or charter a yacht with a group of friends, for one, two or three weeks. Themed cruises are available (eg. nature, archaeology). IN May, June and October, four can travel for the price of three. For a brochure call 020 8510 9292 or email tussockcruisinguk@compuserve.com.

fields.headline: Corridors of powder
fields.standfirst: Next week the World Economic Forum meets in Davos, but the powerbrokers are unlikely to venture out on to the slopes. Denis MacShane MP finds out what they'll be missing
fields.trailText: Next week the World Economic Forum meets in Davos, but the powerbrokers are unlikely to venture out on to the slopes. Denis MacShane MP finds out what they'll be missing.
fields.body:
On Tuesday, the world's political and business leaders assemble in the Swiss resort of Davos for their annual pow-wow on globalisation.

One of the perks on offer to Clinton, Blair, Putin and the world's top CEOs will be a day's free ski pass on the four linked stations that make up Davos's gigantic ski area. But it is unlikely they will get an opportunity to take up the offer. Given the chance to talk or the chance to ski, the managers of World.com prefer hot to cold air.

However, the choice of Davos for the annual gathering of the World Economic Forum has reinforced the resort's image as a world-class ski centre for the rich and famous. Actually, Klosters, further down the valley, is the real home to Sloane skiers, aristos and City lawyers. Davos is usually full of ordinary Swiss having family holidays, although you may occasionally spot New Labour luminaries such as Lord Winston and Ralf Dahrendorf, no doubt organising apres-ski seminars about what's wrong with the NHS or the universities.

When I looked over which bit of the Alps my family could go skiing over the millennium holiday - we weren't, thank goodness, invited to the Dome's opening but we're going, we're going - Davos was cheaper than the packages on offer for the better resorts in France or Italy. Long experience of Christmas or New Year in a snow-free Alps made me go for height, and since Davos itself starts at 1,500m, the snow is always available. The huge snow cannons installed on all the village-bound runs - at long last, Swiss artillery have something to fire at - ensure you can ski down to the bottom of every mountain.

This time, there was no problem. Arriving the day after the hurricane that devastated France and Switzerland, there was plenty of snow. A rotten day of blizzard skiing, including a miserable 45 minutes in a gondola swinging wildly in 80mph cross winds, was followed by a luxuriant mix of snow by night and sun by day. Early morning runs down black slopes through white powder were sublime.

Swissair and BA are now flying London-Zurich for under £100 - less than a second-class standard rail return to Doncaster. The best surprise, however, is how reasonably priced are the Davos hotels. We stayed in the Hotel Herrmann, a couple of minutes' walk from Davos Dorf station. Even at high season, the price for a good room with bath, a big evening meal and enough breakfast to last the day came to SFr105 - around £36. The basic hotel cost for a week's skiing was £250 a head. Next door at the five-star Hotel Fluella, one of the great Alpine hotels, prices start from £100 a night for half-board, still very good value compared with what you can pay for a second-rate hotel in most British cities.

I had two small second-year-on-skis children in my group who were handed over to the Davos ski school for the whole day. Ski teaching for children has been transformed in recent years. The learning slopes have been converted into playgrounds. Skiing becomes fun, not a series of lessons. The cost of a week's teaching is SFR222 per child, about £80, including the ski lifts.

One big complaint, however: unlike French resorts, Davos does not have a creche or baby-age kindergarten and babysitters were hard to come by and unreliable.

The Davos ski school has 250 teachers, all of whom seem to speak excellent English. It offers a ski tour each day and a new special school for skiers in their fifties.

The skiing is very, very good. With five distinct areas to choose from, there is variety and a chance to avoid queues. If the weather is bad, the funicular climbs to the mountain top with a great run back to the village that progresses from blue to red to black.

The runs down to Klosters or Kublis are among the longest consecutive runs in the Alps. Davos is so high that there is always powder within sight of a piste. Challenges exist in the shape of signposted but unpisted and unpatrolled runs that either go back through wilderness to lost valleys or, like the endless jump-turns down the 'wrong' side of the Weissfluh flank, bring you back to a piste. These runs are closed off if there is danger, though it is important to bear in mind avalanche warnings: even in security-conscious Davos, accidents happen.

If Clinton and Blair have an hour to spare, they could use it to go to the Kirchner museum beside the Davos congress centre. The German painter, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner exiled himself in Davos from the 1920s until his despair at Hitlerism drove him to suicide in 1938. He did the impossible, painting the Alps by discovering their hidden colours, instead of the white, grey, blue, green and browns of conventional mountain painters.

High on the Jakobshorn on New Year's Day, I saw a Kirchner cloud which consisted of pinks, yellows, blues and greens swirling in changing combinations. Yet another reason why skiing is the best sport invented.

Denis MacShane MP paid for his travel and accommodation and family costs.

The practicals

All Davos hotels are linked into one booking system (00 41 81 415 2121). Davos Information Centre is on 00 41 81 415 2121. Flights from BA (0345 222111) and Swissair (0234 581333).

fields.headline: Creche landing
fields.standfirst: To a young  Ian Katz, Club Med resorts held out the promise of discos, girls and unlimited wine. By the time he could afford to go to one in Florida, though, childcare became the be all and end all
fields.trailText: To a young Ian Katz, Club Med resorts held out the promise of discos, girls and unlimited wine. By the time he could afford to go to one in Florida, though, childcare became the be all and end all.
fields.body:
For as long as I can remember, Club Med has occupied a special place in my holiday fantasies. As a child, it always seemed the kids staying in the leafy "resort village" nearby were having more fun. As a teenager, I coveted the fleets of sailing dinghies and waterski boats reserved for the use of the gentil membres. A little later, I remember listening enviously to the distant thudding of a Club Med disco, convinced that sex was as freely available within the whitewashed precinct as the unlimited food and wine that I'd heard any guest could demand.

Eventually, the temptation was too much. A friend and I hatched a plan of military precision to gatecrash the Club Med village on Eleuthra in the Bahamas. (It would be slightly overstating the operation if I didn't admit that we were already staying on the island.) Remarkably, it worked - at least until we tried to buy a drink. Ignorant of one of the most basic rules of the club - that payments of any kind were made with coloured beads rather than cash - we were swiftly unmasked and escorted to the gates.

That episode only sharpened my image of Club Med resorts as havens of sybaritic sophistication. I had seen the promised land, but not been allowed to taste its fruits. Oddly though, even after the cost of a Club Med holiday came within range of my bank balance, it never occurred to me to actually go on one. It was like ballroom dancing - appealing in theory but essentially something that other people did.

It took children finally to get me into a Club Med by the front door. As any parent knows, kids change nothing more than the way you think about holidays. Only a couple of short years ago, I remember agonising with my wife over whether a particular destination offered the precise combination of delicious food, good weather, interesting culture and copious activities that we craved. Now our requirements were a little simpler: childcare and sun. In that order.

In early November, that pretty much narrowed things down to Club Med's Sandpiper village in Florida. There are plenty of other Club Med resorts (and more run by competitors, such as Mark Warner) offering childcare, but none promising the magical combination of what the trade calls "winter sun" and a creche for children as young as our one-year-old twins.

I must confess that the idea of losing my Club Med virginity, as it were, in Florida seemed a little disappointing. After all, the point of Club Med, it had always seemed to me, was to enable relatively unadventurous travellers to take their holidays in adventurous places - or at least adventurous-sounding places. I pored longingly over pages devoted to villages with names like Turquoise (Turks & Caicos), Nosy Be (Madagascar) and Rio das Pedras (Brazil) before accepting that safe, sanitised, theme-park-infested Florida was our lot.

In fact, as any Club Med initiate knows, I might have saved myself the deliberation because aside from the trip from the airport, one Club Med holiday is pretty much like another, give or take a palm tree (and activity) or two. That, after all, was one of the key tenets on which Gerard Blitz built his empire of more than 100 resorts in 36 countries. The company moves its gentils organisateurs (essentially high-class redcoats) between resorts at roughly six-monthly intervals, secure in the knowledge that if they can do their jobs at Les Boucaniers (Martinique), they'll also be able to do them at Les Almadies (Senegal).

Sandpiper itself is two hours north of Miami in the town of Port St Lucie. It is one of the fastest growing towns in Florida, swelling weekly with New Yorkers and other northern exiles lured by cheap property and year-round sun. Fortunately, you would never guess this from inside the Sandpiper compound, which manages to create the illusion that you have ventured more than five miles from the nearest Gap.

The recently-renovated village is made up of a group of unassuming communal buildings clustered around three of the resort's five pools and a series of outlying accommodation blocks that give the whole place the feel of an upscale military base. Brightly-coloured pendants trumpet cheerful slogans like "relax", "renew" and "recharge".

Despite the window dressing, there is a slightly dated feeling about the resort and its modus operandi . On checking in, for instance, we were issued with a vast bundle of paper coupons and plastic cards - some for claiming free drinks, some for collecting towels, others for making external phone calls. Our room, too, while spacious enough, felt firmly rooted in the 1970s. But then, as any regular would tell you, if you're the type who spends time in your room on holiday, then Club Med is probably not for you.

As if to remind you of this fact, a whole channel on the resort's TV sets is devoted to each day's exhausting schedule of activities. For my wife, this was a delicious opportunity to marry her twin passions: sport and list-making. By the second day, I was waking up to find terrifying "to do" lists propped up on my bedside table: "7am: dress kids; 8am: breakfast; 8.45am: L&S to baby club; 9am: tennis lesson; 11am: golf lesson (IK sailing optional); 12am: check girls."

Even my hyperactive spouse, though, balked at some of the additional activities organised throughout the day by the resort's regiment of permanently-grinning GOs. Every day at noon, for instance, the chef de village himself would lead a surprisingly large contingent of GOs and GMs in a session of "crazy danseeeng" around one of the resorts pools.

The combination of this relentless high-spiritedness and the statutory delivery of all announcements in both English and French creates an atmosphere somewhere between a Butlin's camp and the Eurovision Song Contest. In the vast canteen, where GMs eat most of their meals, guests are strenuously encouraged to dine with GOs and, even more terrifyingly for us retiring Brits, other GMs.

All this would be fine if the central premise held - that you could drop your kids at the creche and then spend a guilt-free day indulging yourself with activities ranging from golf to trapeze artistry. Unfortunately, though, it manifestly did not. Quite simply, the standard of childcare was not high enough to allow you comfortably to leave your children for any more than a couple of hours at a time. In fairness, staff shortages during our stay meant that the ratio of carers to babies was considerably poorer than the "one to four" the company attempts to maintain. In truth, though, even that is too stretched for staff to do anything other than attempt to mollify a band of increasingly angry babies.

This failing is unfortunate because, in most other respects, the resort was excellent. Although most of the coaching takes place in large groups, the respective GOs offered an accessible and encouraging introduction to each of the activities we tried. While the (free) basic tennis lessons provided a perfectly sufficient challenge for terminally uncoordinated duffers, like me, Wimbledon wannabes slugged it out on an intensive three-day ATP-approved course for the relatively modest sum of £100.

My wife, meanwhile, raved about the golf. She hadn't, she said, come across a better place to learn. There were morning and afternoon beginners' classes with bi-lingual coaches offering guidance on everything from how you stand to how to hold a club, away from the unsympathetic glare of the initiated. At Sandpiper, the beginners had their very own nine-hole pitch-and-putt course, with two 18-hole courses available for those who knew what they were doing.

Just as it would be almost impossible even to try all the activities on offer, the thrice-daily buffets offered a choice of dizzying proportions. At each sitting, a small army of chefs turned out at least 30 different hot dishes covering the whole culinary waterfront from TexMex to fancy French, on top of the countless cold counters brimming with meats, salads and assorted cooked delicacies.

On our penultimate night, the main attraction in the restaurant was a mountain of whole lobsters roughly the size of our front room at home. After tucking into her own, the GO with whom we were sharing a table complained that the trouble with the life of a GO at Sandpiper was the sheer abundance of everything. "There's an abundance of food, there's abundance of alcohol and there's an abundance of sex," she lamented. So I was right all those years ago after all.

The practicals

Seven nights at Club Med Sandpiper costs from £863 for adults. The price includes return flights and transfers, all meals, wine and beer, most sports and tuition, children's clubs from four years, entertainment and holiday insurance. The price for children from 0-2 years is £164; 2-3 years, £275; 4-11 years, £422 ; and 12-17 years, £814. Call 0700 007007007 for a brochure.

webTitle: Mike Ford: A good sense of humour | A bath towel | Photographs

fields.headline: Mike Ford never travels without
fields.trailText: A good sense of humour | A bath towel | Photographs
fields.body:
A necessity: A good sense of humour and the ability to remain patient and charming at all times. When you are going abroad the rules are different, the people are different and, by smiling, you can take the sting out of almost any frustration.

A luxury: A bath towel because, although it takes up half your rucksack, a fluffy towel after a shower is unbeatable for that feeling of luxury.

A memento: I take photographs of my room, my house, my family and my cats, and also of sheep, cows and roads. They are not to remind me of home - I don't get homesick, but they help explain where I come from.

If only: A personal teleporter. I would love to be able to say: 'Beam me up' and not have to bother with airports, long bus journeys or queuing for railway tickets.

fields.headline: This side of paradise
fields.standfirst: David Newnham discovers the unlikely birthplace of the 'green belt', social housing and the National Trust in a quiet Fenland town
fields.trailText: David Newnham discovers the unlikely birthplace of the 'green belt', social housing and the National Trust in a quiet Fenland town.
fields.body:
Wisbech, capital of the Fens, said the sign. But would it have a shop that sold fenugreek? Yes and no.

'Fenugreek?' said the woman behind the counter. She wasn't happy. 'I've got fenugreek,' she confessed. 'But I don't like selling it.'

She found a packet of brown powder and, somewhat grudgingly, began pouring it out. 'It'll take weeks to get rid of the smell,' she moaned. 'The shop will smell, and my clothes... When I go home tonight, my husband will say, 'You've been selling that fenugreek again.' Now, how much did you say you wanted?'

Twenty years on, my guilt has all but vanished. And so, too, has the tiny spice shop, snuffed out, I guess, by the new shopping precinct, where everything comes tightly sealed, and the only smell is of money.

And not too much of that, these days. Straddling the Nene on the last leg of its journey to the Wash, Wisbech is reckoned to be the most architecturally distinguished town in Cambridgeshire outside Cambridge itself. But there's a rash of whited windows in the handsome shopping streets.

Not that you'd notice anything amiss on North Brink. This great curve that clasps the brown river has been compared to a Dutch canal front - even to the banks of the Liffey in Dublin. Centre stage is Peckover House, 18th-century home to something you might consider an oxymoron, a Quaker banking family.

At South Brink, across the eddying water from the Peckovers, there once lived another banker. James Hill was his name, and he had a daughter called Octavia. 'Come in,' says Ann Clayton. She has turned out especially to open the Octavia Hill Birthplace Museum for me - the museum that her husband Peter founded five years ago to celebrate the life and works of the banker's daughter.

'In the beginning, nobody wanted to know,' says Mrs Clayton. 'Now people come here from all over the world.'

This town never was sure about the Hills. In 1837, James and his wife Caroline set up the Wisbech Infant School, where, instead of religion, poor children were taught 'the impor tance of truth, justice and mutual kindness and forbearance' (it soon became known as the 'Infidel School', and today survives only as the foyer of the Angles Theatre). And if all that didn't make him unpopular enough, James would organise marches to comandeer land for the poor. Then, in 1840, he went bankrupt, and Octavia was obliged to begin a rather different life on the banks of the Thames.

That's how it all began. At 14, she was already helping at a Ragged School. One day, a little girl took Octavia to her home in Paradise Place in Marylebone, and showed her the true texture of poverty. Home was one room to an entire family, with a lodger sleeping in the corner (they have recreated the slum in the museum basement).

'From that day,' says Mrs Clayton, 'she never dressed up. She kept a dowdy look, because she had seen the squalor and the horror.'

Octavia was to revolutionise the provision of housing for the poor - not only in Britain, but globally. And for her, that meant more than providing decent, affordable homes.

'Her style,' writes Peter Clayton in a biographical booklet, 'was patrician but not patronising. She would not, for instance, go into a tenant's home without being invited.'

And she didn't stop with housing. By the time she died in 1912, she had secured countless urban parks, invented the concept of the 'green belt' and more or less founded the National Trust.

The river is ebbing now, surging through the little port to which this town owed its former prosperity. Here and there, the window of a vacant shop front offers free advertising space to anyone with a glue-pot. One poster crops up time and again. 'Hirameka Hi-Fi,' it says. 'Super noisy teenage punks. Upstairs at the Angles Theatre.'

The Angles Theatre? Doesn't that ring a bell? Ah yes. The Infidel School.

The Octavia Hill Birthplace Museum is open March to October, and throughout the year by appointment. Call 01945 476358 for details.

fields.headline: Far-out weekends
fields.standfirst: 3 minute guide
fields.trailText: 3 minute guide.
fields.body:
Friday to Monday is a yawning gap. Any suggestions?

A faraway weekend has never been so accessible.

What's the long and short of it?

That this year's city-break brochures break the barriers.

Beyond Paris and Rome?

The world's your weekend.

Literally?

Slip away to Syria with JTS (01628 483550), say, and pack the Crusader Castle at Krak des Chevaliers and the old city of Damascus into your four nights, for £883pp.

A hot destination?

One of several. Try Tunis - exotic food, medieval souks and sandy beaches are 21/2 hours away with Wigmore Holidays (0171-486 4425, £349 for four nights).

What about the jetlag?

Precious little so far. Another short blast of winter sunshine comes from The Gambia Experience (01703 730888) without the need to adjust your watch at all.

So Paris is all very well...

But the 'Paris of the East' has more cachet. Shanghai is a new Thomson Breakaway (0870 6061476).

I've heard it billed as the next Hong Kong?

For a bill that begins at £699 for five nights.

Are the old chestnuts still there?

As romantic as ever. But standing alongside Las Vegas, Vancouver, Casablanca, San Francisco, LA...

Come now. California for the weekend?

Why not? Three nights in SF with Virgin Holidays (01293 456789) will set you back £389.

The 'cash rich, time poor' syndrome?

Don't forget status. Long-haul breaks can cost as much as some people's annual summer holidays.

A weekend's gambling in Las Vegas, for example?

From £339 for three nights with Archers Direct (0870 751 2000). And that's before you've counted your chips.

No break is complete without some serious retail therapy.

Try New York. Two nights from £359 with Crystal (0870 888 0022).

That's what I call a brief encounter.

Can't stop. Got work to do. Ask Brief Encounters (0208 541 2210).

Keeping it short and happy?

Even Bermuda's short. Three nights start at £714, B&B.

fields.headline: Screen writers
fields.standfirst: The Readers' Editor on... why we are here and where we are going
fields.trailText: The Readers' Editor on... why we are here and where we are going
fields.body:
I have spent most of this week talking about the future of the Guardian, not to Russell Grant (although now I am wondering whether I should have consulted him), but to the editor of the Guardian, to the features editor, and to the head and editor of our network of websites, Guardian Unlimited.

It seemed to be an appropriate moment. Throughout the week, to mark the first anniversary of Guardian Unlimited, we have been running a series called Life Online, giving an idea of the ever-expanding range of interests served by the internet and providing itineraries for cyber-excursions. Our own network of sites, now with a new editor and poised for a further leap, has developed remarkably in its short life. It has nearly 700,000 registered users, and more than 10m hits, or pages opened, every month. Is this where the future of the Guardian lies?

Everyone I spoke to agreed on a number of things: that the breathtaking speed of technological development would continue, that we did not know exactly where it was taking us, that both the editorial and commercial nature of the Guardian's activities in, say, five, 10 or 20 years time, were practically impossible to predict.

But they all agreed, too, that the unprecedented nature of the revolution in which we were involved and its uncertainties, had concentrated minds on the identity of the Guardian. We needed to be sure that the liberal values associated with the "dead tree" part of the paper were preserved and reinforced, in the first place, among the Guardian's own staff journalists - of whom there are now more than 350. Otherwise how could these values be carried forward with us?

Everyone agreed that the same set of standards and values should work right across the Guardian's activities as we hope they do at the moment. The many different versions of the Guardian that already exist emerge recognisably from the same stable. There is the main paper; the international edition; the global Guardian which, through an organisation called PressPoint, uses the internet to deliver a printed paper to major hotels world-wide; there is the Guardian online, and the Guardian for the blind. In addition, we put out a daily email news briefing called The Wrap and produce, for subscribers all over the world, the Guardian Weekly.

The editor says that one way of viewing the Guardian is as a factory for content which is then delivered in a variety of ways. The important thing was to ensure that, amid the expansion and diversity, editorial standards were not sacrificed. He felt that this argument inevitably pushed the Guardian towards the integration of the paper and the rapidly developing web network.

The Guardian has a small difficulty here in that journalists working on paper and the staff of the websites work in different buildings - the paper Guardian is largely produced in the main building in Farringdon Road, the electronic Guardian in an adjacent building in Ray Street.

Some staff from Ray Street will soon be working in Farringdon Road, and there is a small queue of journalists from the printed paper now waiting their turn to get some experience of the websites. Groups of journalists from Ray Street have been attending the editor's morning conferences in Farringdon Road throughout this week.

More of the Guardian's specialist journalists may find themselves contributing original material to the electronic Guardian. One idea the new editor of Guardian Unlimited has is to use the Guardian's specialists to introduce and provide the context for special reports on the web on, for instance, GM foods or the NHS, or Labour in power.

It would be prudent, to put it mildly, for journalists on the Guardian to be familiar with developments on the websites. The internet, it is clear, is already playing an important part in developing a new relationship between news organisations and their users. It provides instant easy access to the raw material of news, to breaking news and to the journalists who gather and analyse it. It makes it easier for the activities of journalists to be questioned. The editor of the Guardian says that when you try to look into the future the question you have to ask, in the context of the huge media explosion, is why is the Guardian going to matter? "Ultimately," he says, "it will be because we are trusted and that means that everything coming out under the name of the Guardian has to be of a quality you can trust."

I agree with those who think this is more important than the form of the journalism or the vehicle for it , although I think newspapers, grubby though they may be, will be with us for the foreseeable future. Let us continue for the time being.

fields.headline: Spin city
fields.standfirst: Every decade or so, England's second city tries to reinvent itself without ever coming to terms with its real identity.  Stuart Jeffries goes back to his roots to rediscover what the planners missed
fields.trailText: Every decade or so, England's second city tries to reinvent itself without ever coming to terms with its real identity. Stuart Jeffries goes back to his roots to rediscover what the planners missed.
fields.body:
A few years ago, a very small book was published called Birmingham Is Not A Boring City. On the title page, the word "Not" looked as though it had been added at the last minute in handwriting. Maybe the authors had changed their minds about the title just before it went to the publishers. Out of kindness, or a belated onrush of affection. The second city gets to you that way.

The pub section started like this: "There are very few good pubs in Birmingham. Most of the decent ones have been knocked down or else renovated out of all recognition."

The restaurant section was hardly more reassuring: "Most of the national guides to good food and good restaurants despair of Birmingham. And with good reason." This was before the age of the balti, before that drab stretch of Stoney Lane in Sparkbrook became a magnet for gourmands and for lads determined to shovel down curries as fiery as their vernacular.

And yet despite (perhaps even because) of its reputation, I've always loved this boring city. I love the way it has had a myopic image rethink nearly every decade since that monocled mutineer Joseph Chamberlain strove to make the city into a new Athens.

I love the way its golden-hearted citizens, reviled for their accent and their architecture, still strive oblivious, unrequited, to be loved. I love, though God knows why, the abject poetry of its crumbling brutalist architecture. If I was King Kong, I would climb up the Rotunda and hug it more dearly than he ever managed with the Empire State Building. But only because I don't know any better.

As dusk gathered, I crested a hill just west of Coventry on the M6 and there it was, spreading its welcome embrace almost inconceivably wide, a warming orange street-light glow across the horizon. Birmingham, the Big Heart of England - no matter that it was forever beating out of time with everywhere else.

And when I got closer, the motorway rose up on stilts and I could see the appalling energy of this city - its industry, its human homes, its inhuman roads. Few British cities lay themselves out before the motorist in this unguarded way. But then, for three decades at least this has been a road city, a redbrick Los Angeles. In its time, to be sure, Birmingham has contrived to be many things - Athens, the Venice of the north, the Paris of the Midlands and now, if the Brindley Place redevelopment is anything to go by, Dickensian confection. Birmingham has always had lots of confidence, but never the confidence to be itself.

And then, as I rolled along the Aston Expressway, the Jacobean towers of Aston Hall, incongruous and spectral in the darkening evening, saluted me. On my left, a puff of smoke from the HP Sauce factory told me gnomically that the time of my arrival was propitious but that, if you wouldn't mind, keep your eyes on the carriageway because the looming inner ring road is a difficult beast to master.

But I managed it. The vertiginous yank up the flyover past student tower blocks, the plummet into Great Charles Street Queensway, the jockeying for position around that hilariously named roundabout, Paradise Circus. And this is a very modern paradise: after a monumental fall, after eons of misplaced human effort mangling the divine masterplan with errant schemes, Paradise Circus is what Eden would look like.

That night, I hit the town. There was neon, a world-class concert hall and theatres, appealing pubs and restaurants. Could this be the same city that the early 1980s guide book lampooned?

True, even now some things remain reassuringly the same. At night, the streets seethe with girls who have legs like Cyd Charisse's and accents like Janice Nichols' (don't even pretend you know who I'm on about). And the boys, too, are still as they've always been. For generations, even on the most bitterly cold nights, they have stood under lampposts in shirt sleeves, smoking and exchanging laconic monosyllables. "Ar," says one to his mate. "Ar," says the other more emphatically. "Ar," can mean anything here: "Yes", "No", "Birmingham City 3, Real Madrid 0". Anything.

But otherwise, Broad Street was unrecognisable. They've killed off the worst buildings, scrubbed up the Victoriana and put an awning for tables outside Ronnie Scott's in the fanciful hope that Birmingham might have its own al-fresco dining culture.

The next day, as I wandered through the morning streets, they were tearing apart the Bank of England building, once 1970s state-of-the-art, all chunky concrete and tinted windows. At the bottom of Bridge Street, there was a derelict multi-storey car park where shoppers, dreamers, lovers had laughed, cried, sweated, but finally abandoned. Everywhere ruin: I stood at the foot of an underpass below the Rotunda, and saw tiles missing, paint chipped and light fixtures trashed. As shoppers jostled me, a few tears welled up for the Birmingham that is dying and, I know, deserves no reprieve.

I rushed for solace to the reliably wonderful City Art Gallery and Museum. There (until February 28) is an exhibition called Visions of Birmingham: the planners' dream and the peoples' reality, 1900-2030. Herbert Manzoni, city engineer and surveyor - the man who invented Birmingham's post-war look - is the brutalist villain of this piece. He was to Birmingham what Baron Haussmann was to Paris, though he made neither Duddeston nor Nechells Parisian or gay. As Chris Upton writes in the chapter of his fine history of Birmingham called, What Went Wrong with Tomorrow?, Manzoni was hardly a sentimentalist, nor did he have a monumental sensibility: he bulldozed the old and replaced it with buildings whose lifespan, he reckoned, should not be more than 20 years. The catalogue of his unfeeling demolitions makes the crime of the Euston Arch seem paltry indeed.

What went wrong with tomorrow? In the bombastic post-war vision, this became a second city where people came second and cars first. It became a place where underpasses were filled with bad smells and worse buskers, while above traffic as often as not sat in rush-hour gridlock.

Another tomorrow is looming: the Bull Ring, so loved and so derided, is to be destroyed. St Martin's, that eternally black-spired church amid the market stalls, is to become the focus of a new square. Nearby, Birmingham is to have a department store to rival Rackhams. On and on: forward into a tomorrow that will surely be better than Birmingham has ever been.

The canals were waiting to be remarketed and cleaned within an inch of their lives, the showpiece of the new Birmingham. Look on these canals, vainglorious Venetians, and despair! Look at these new squares behind the canals, bumptious Barcelonians, and see the intimations of your cultural eclipse! This shall become a boulevarding city with fine pastries, multilingual businessmen barking into mobile phones over ristrettos at Gas Street Basin. This, at least, is Birmingham's latest notion. The marketing people are billing Birmingham as "Europe's meeting place", which may be as tragically bombastic as anything Manzoni proposed, but shows that someone still has a vision.

But why would you come to Birmingham for a short break? After all, any big British city you can think of is more charming. And Birmingham will never be Bath, York or Stratford. For which, much thanks. You could go there to avoid the tourists, though, for a spot of poignant industrial archaeology or, perhaps, for something much more engaged than the worthless tourism that characterises what goes on in Britain year in year out. You should go to Birmingham to see the drama of a city, all-too-visibly, in an eternal struggle with itself.

In this article, after all, we've only scratched the surface of the city centre ... 48 hours? A lifetime wouldn't be enough time to get to grips with this place.

Restaurants

1 Bank Brindley Place (0121-633 4466). Just like the one in London, but with friendlier service.

2 LeftBank Broad Street (0121-643 4464). One of the posh new eateries in this spruced-up area.

3 Royal Al-faisal Tandoori Restaurant 130-140 Stoney Lane, Sparkbrook (0121-449 5695/8902) One of the great balti houses.

4 Chung Ying 17 Thorp Street (0121- 666 6622) and 16-18 Wrottesley Street (0121- 622 5669) Excellent Cantonese.

5 Le Petit Blanc Oozells Square (0121-633 7333) Achingly-posh new restaurant in achingly-trendy square.

Bars and clubs

1 Ronnie Scott's Broad Street (0121-643 4525) Like the Frith Street original, with a more appealing clientele.

2 Dome II Horsefair (0121- 622 0444). Just the place to large it in a big millennium style.

3 Fiddle and Bone 4 Sheepcote Street (0121-200 2223). One of the better bars along the canal in Brindley Place.

4 The Old Joint Stock 4 Temple Row (0121-200 1892) Elegant boozer quite unlike the old-style Birmingham pub.

5 Medicine Bar The Custard Factory, Gibb Street (0121-693 6001). The place to have a drink after you've arrived on the coach.

The practicals

Stuart Jeffries stayed at the Hyatt Regency Hotel (0121-643 1234), where a double room costs from £117 per night including breakfast.
fields.bodyText: A few years ago, a very small book was published called Birmingham Is Not A Boring City. On the title page, the word "Not" looked as though it had been added at the last minute in handwriting. Maybe the authors had changed their minds about the title just before it went to the publishers. Out of kindness, or a belated onrush of affection. The second city gets to you that way. The pub section started like this: "There are very few good pubs in Birmingham. Most of the decent ones have been knocked down or else renovated out of all recognition." The restaurant section was hardly more reassuring: "Most of the national guides to good food and good restaurants despair of Birmingham. And with good reason." This was before the age of the balti, before that drab stretch of Stoney Lane in Sparkbrook became a magnet for gourmands and for lads determined to shovel down curries as fiery as their vernacular. And yet despite (perhaps even because) of its reputation, I've always loved this boring city. I love the way it has had a myopic image rethink nearly every decade since that monocled mutineer Joseph Chamberlain strove to make the city into a new Athens. I love the way its golden-hearted citizens, reviled for their accent and their architecture, still strive oblivious, unrequited, to be loved. I love, though God knows why, the abject poetry of its crumbling brutalist architecture. If I was King Kong, I would climb up the Rotunda and hug it more dearly than he ever managed with the Empire State Building. But only because I don't know any better. As dusk gathered, I crested a hill just west of Coventry on the M6 and there it was, spreading its welcome embrace almost inconceivably wide, a warming orange street-light glow across the horizon. Birmingham, the Big Heart of England - no matter that it was forever beating out of time with everywhere else. And when I got closer, the motorway rose up on stilts and I could see the appalling energy of this city - its industry, its human homes, its inhuman roads. Few British cities lay themselves out before the motorist in this unguarded way. But then, for three decades at least this has been a road city, a redbrick Los Angeles. In its time, to be sure, Birmingham has contrived to be many things - Athens, the Venice of the north, the Paris of the Midlands and now, if the Brindley Place redevelopment is anything to go by, Dickensian confection. Birmingham has always had lots of confidence, but never the confidence to be itself. And then, as I rolled along the Aston Expressway, the Jacobean towers of Aston Hall, incongruous and spectral in the darkening evening, saluted me. On my left, a puff of smoke from the HP Sauce factory told me gnomically that the time of my arrival was propitious but that, if you wouldn't mind, keep your eyes on the carriageway because the looming inner ring road is a difficult beast to master. But I managed it. The vertiginous yank up the flyover past student tower blocks, the plummet into Great Charles Street Queensway, the jockeying for position around that hilariously named roundabout, Paradise Circus. And this is a very modern paradise: after a monumental fall, after eons of misplaced human effort mangling the divine masterplan with errant schemes, Paradise Circus is what Eden would look like. That night, I hit the town. There was neon, a world-class concert hall and theatres, appealing pubs and restaurants. Could this be the same city that the early 1980s guide book lampooned? True, even now some things remain reassuringly the same. At night, the streets seethe with girls who have legs like Cyd Charisse's and accents like Janice Nichols' (don't even pretend you know who I'm on about). And the boys, too, are still as they've always been. For generations, even on the most bitterly cold nights, they have stood under lampposts in shirt sleeves, smoking and exchanging laconic monosyllables. "Ar," says one to his mate. "Ar," says the other more emphatically. "Ar," can mean anything here: "Yes", "No", "Birmingham City 3, Real Madrid 0". Anything. But otherwise, Broad Street was unrecognisable. They've killed off the worst buildings, scrubbed up the Victoriana and put an awning for tables outside Ronnie Scott's in the fanciful hope that Birmingham might have its own al-fresco dining culture. The next day, as I wandered through the morning streets, they were tearing apart the Bank of England building, once 1970s state-of-the-art, all chunky concrete and tinted windows. At the bottom of Bridge Street, there was a derelict multi-storey car park where shoppers, dreamers, lovers had laughed, cried, sweated, but finally abandoned. Everywhere ruin: I stood at the foot of an underpass below the Rotunda, and saw tiles missing, paint chipped and light fixtures trashed. As shoppers jostled me, a few tears welled up for the Birmingham that is dying and, I know, deserves no reprieve. I rushed for solace to the reliably wonderful City Art Gallery and Museum. There (until February 28) is an exhibition called Visions of Birmingham: the planners' dream and the peoples' reality, 1900-2030. Herbert Manzoni, city engineer and surveyor - the man who invented Birmingham's post-war look - is the brutalist villain of this piece. He was to Birmingham what Baron Haussmann was to Paris, though he made neither Duddeston nor Nechells Parisian or gay. As Chris Upton writes in the chapter of his fine history of Birmingham called, What Went Wrong with Tomorrow?, Manzoni was hardly a sentimentalist, nor did he have a monumental sensibility: he bulldozed the old and replaced it with buildings whose lifespan, he reckoned, should not be more than 20 years. The catalogue of his unfeeling demolitions makes the crime of the Euston Arch seem paltry indeed. What went wrong with tomorrow? In the bombastic post-war vision, this became a second city where people came second and cars first. It became a place where underpasses were filled with bad smells and worse buskers, while above traffic as often as not sat in rush-hour gridlock. Another tomorrow is looming: the Bull Ring, so loved and so derided, is to be destroyed. St Martin's, that eternally black-spired church amid the market stalls, is to become the focus of a new square. Nearby, Birmingham is to have a department store to rival Rackhams. On and on: forward into a tomorrow that will surely be better than Birmingham has ever been. The canals were waiting to be remarketed and cleaned within an inch of their lives, the showpiece of the new Birmingham. Look on these canals, vainglorious Venetians, and despair! Look at these new squares behind the canals, bumptious Barcelonians, and see the intimations of your cultural eclipse! This shall become a boulevarding city with fine pastries, multilingual businessmen barking into mobile phones over ristrettos at Gas Street Basin. This, at least, is Birmingham's latest notion. The marketing people are billing Birmingham as "Europe's meeting place", which may be as tragically bombastic as anything Manzoni proposed, but shows that someone still has a vision. But why would you come to Birmingham for a short break? After all, any big British city you can think of is more charming. And Birmingham will never be Bath, York or Stratford. For which, much thanks. You could go there to avoid the tourists, though, for a spot of poignant industrial archaeology or, perhaps, for something much more engaged than the worthless tourism that characterises what goes on in Britain year in year out. You should go to Birmingham to see the drama of a city, all-too-visibly, in an eternal struggle with itself. In this article, after all, we've only scratched the surface of the city centre ... 48 hours? A lifetime wouldn't be enough time to get to grips with this place. Restaurants 1 Bank Brindley Place (0121-633 4466). Just like the one in London, but with friendlier service. 2 LeftBank Broad Street (0121-643 4464). One of the posh new eateries in this spruced-up area. 3 Royal Al-faisal Tandoori Restaurant 130-140 Stoney Lane, Sparkbrook (0121-449 5695/8902) One of the great balti houses. 4 Chung Ying 17 Thorp Street (0121- 666 6622) and 16-18 Wrottesley Street (0121- 622 5669) Excellent Cantonese. 5 Le Petit Blanc Oozells Square (0121-633 7333) Achingly-posh new restaurant in achingly-trendy square. Bars and clubs 1 Ronnie Scott's Broad Street (0121-643 4525) Like the Frith Street original, with a more appealing clientele. 2 Dome II Horsefair (0121- 622 0444). Just the place to large it in a big millennium style. 3 Fiddle and Bone 4 Sheepcote Street (0121-200 2223). One of the better bars along the canal in Brindley Place. 4 The Old Joint Stock 4 Temple Row (0121-200 1892) Elegant boozer quite unlike the old-style Birmingham pub. 5 Medicine Bar The Custard Factory, Gibb Street (0121-693 6001). The place to have a drink after you've arrived on the coach. The practicals Stuart Jeffries stayed at the Hyatt Regency Hotel (0121-643 1234), where a double room costs from £117 per night including breakfast.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Namibia

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Namibia
fields.standfirst: Chris McIntyre
fields.trailText: Chris McIntyre.
fields.body:
I was working in Zimbabwe in 1989, and Namibia seemed a very distant land which hardly anyone had visited. I went with a friend on a very short trip and now go back for two or three weeks each year.

It has the landscape and game of Africa, deserts that make you think of Lawrence of Arabia, and a first-world infrastructure - truly breathtaking scenery, and the phones work.

The best place of all is Sossusvlei in central Namibia. There are huge, apricot-coloured dunes, reputed to be the tallest in the world, though who goes around measuring the height of sand dunes? Around them is a white clay pan dotted with beautiful, old, feathery acacia trees.

Namibia has one of the lowest population densities in the world, so you don't see many people, but those you do meet are friendly and very ethnically diverse, from Bushmen in the Kalahari, Bantu in the north and white settlers of German and Afrikaans descent.

Tourism is taking off, but not package tourism or beach holidays because, although Namibia has 1,000 miles of coastline and sandy beaches, a current comes straight off the Antarctic, so the sea is bitterly cold. It also has very few big hotels, so it only attracts small groups of individual travellers.

The farmers who used to struggle to raise cattle in a semi-desert with very low rainfall have realised that keeping game and providing accommodation for tourists provides a much better livelihood. Namibia has the world's highest population of cheetahs, but farmers buy in zebra, antelopes and even lions. A small farm in Namibia is at least 100 sq km, so game and tourists can wander around very freely.

You need to plan an itinerary before you go because it could be 100 miles to the next guesthouse.

I love the feeling that I could be 50km away from the next human. In some areas, the gravel retains tracks for 50 years, so if there are no footprints, you can be fairly certain you are the first person to stand there.

 Chris McIntyre will be speaking about a driving trip around Namibia at Independent Traveller's World 2000, in London, on January 29, at 1pm. Call 0800 3280888.

fields.headline: Mystery of the Mayans
fields.standfirst: Why did an empire built when the Romans were still emerging from the swamp suddenly collapse? Where did the thousands of inhabitants go when they abandoned their cities? How did their descendants survive the conquistadors?  Nick Davies goes into the jungle to unravel an historical conundrum
fields.trailText: Why did an empire built when the Romans were still emerging from the swamp suddenly collapse? Where did the thousands of inhabitants go when they abandoned their cities? How did their descendants survive the conquistadors? Nick Davies goes into the jungle to unravel an historical conundrum.
fields.body:
Once, the world was full of mysteries, some of them frightening, some of them wonderful, some of them merely fascinating. Now, it can be a banal and predictable place, the tracks of daily life so well-beaten and defined, our culture awash with the imbecile obvious, our existence suffocating in safety. But mysteries remain.

On first acquaintance, the mystery of the Mayans of Guatemala can seem simply bizarre, as it was when I first encountered Maximon the god. He was easy enough to find. We left the main street of the village; followed the cobbled sidelanes, littered with scraps of paper and rotting banana skins; stopped at the scruffy grocer's shop with the blackboard sign outside; took the side alley into the muddy courtyard; and, sweeping back the grubby curtain on the little outhouse door, we entered the dimly-lit home of Maximon, eldest of the elders, wisest of the wise, god.

Maximon is a life-sized model of a man with a golden face and beard, who wears a western jacket and a brown flat hat and who sits on a chair on a concrete floor with several plastic pots of flowers before him and a collection of balloons and old Christmas decorations in the ceiling above.

This morning, he was busy. A middle-aged man, whose face was creased with fatigue, was kneeling before him in the darkness, talking rapidly, arguing his case for a favour, while two attendants tipped Maximon back in his chair, poured a long slug of rum down his wooden throat, placed him upright again and pushed a cigarette, alight and smoking, between his wooden lips. The middle-aged man lit candles and then retreated to await the result of his gifts.

What is important about Maximon is that he is there at all. He is a pagan god and yet he survives in a Guatemala, whose official religion is high-octane, high-church Roman Catholicism; and he survives not only in this dusty backroom in the western highlands and not only in the popular faith of Mayan Indians, but also in the faith of the Spanish-speaking Ladino population, whose antipathy to the Indians has been infiltrated by a reluctant respect for their intricate beliefs. They go regularly to Mayan shamans, who will draw on all kinds of ancient magic, including the sacrifice of small animals, to give them power.

And this is the real mystery of the Mayans - their survival, for their history is one of breathtaking destruction. They have been the victims of two terrible hypocrisies. In 1523, in the name of the Catholic God of love, Spanish invaders slaughtered them in their thousands, enslaved the survivors, accidentally infected them with smallpox and typhus and measles, and then unleashed their priests who used fire and the sword to purge their beliefs and to destroy every available artefact of their civilisation. In a single day in July 1562, a Spanish bishop advanced the cause of his God by ordering the collection and destruction of every Mayan manuscript and work or art that could be found, the treasure of 4,000 years of civilisation.

Mayans died in such numbers that their population did not return to its pre-conquest level until the 1950s, by which time the second great hypocrisy was descending upon them.

In June 1954, in the name of democracy and freedom, US President Dwight D Eisenhower authorised a coup to unseat the elected government of Guatemala, which was alarming American corporations by redistributing land to the Mayan peasantry. The director of the CIA, who ran the coup, was Allen Dulles; he also happened to be a director of the United Fruit Company, whose massive land holdings in Guatemala were most at risk from the progressive government. That coup cast Guatemala into 42 years of instability and military government, which restored land to the US corporations, executed their opponents and banned left-wing parties.

When socialists threatened to recapture power in 1963, President John F Kennedy, in the name of democracy and freedom, authorised another coup and, when Mayan peasants organised armed resistance, Washington's puppets embarked on a strategy of terror to suppress all opposition. In the ensuing civil war, which ended only in 1996, some two million Guatemalans, most of them Mayans, fell victim to massacre, assassination, rape, abduction, torture, disappearance, enforced exile and displacement, almost all of it supported by military aid from the most powerful country on earth. And yet the Mayans survive.

And the strangest, most eery, most powerful symbol of their survival (far more potent than Maximon and his strange rituals) lies far away in the north of the country, in the dense, screeching jungle of the Peten region, tangled in among the jumble of breadnut trees and creepers, most of it still buried under layers of encroaching vegetation - the lost cities of the ancient Mayan kings. Truly, these are mysterious places.

You fly from Guatemala City for just under an hour to the island city of Flores, which sits in the flat blue middle of Lake Peten Itza. The dusty hall of the airport is full of would-be guides; you find one and, together you drive back into history.

We drove south-west for more than an hour until we came to a huddle of houses called Sayaxche, a natural crossing point on the banks of the wide, brown Rio Pasión, where there was a collection of amazingly long canoes with thatched roofs. We took one out on to the river and headed deep into David Attenborough country - crocodiles bellyflopping off the banks, hummingbirds and kingfishers and toucans sweeping across the water and, on each side, the immense confusion of greenery tumbling down to the river's edge. Every so often, we passed groups of thatched houses in clearings or saw fishermen feeding lines into the water. Then we came to Ceibal.

Walking into the jungle was only slightly alarming. You watch your feet for snakes on the path and you need to be warned that in the trees, there are howler monkeys who assert themselves by imitating the roar of jaguars, a really blood-chilling sound but harmless. There are tarantulas who nest in holes in the ground but they refuse to come out, even when your guide pokes a stick in to try to prove that the spiders will sit on your shoulder without biting. Mostly, the whole place is deeply exciting and it is the fact that every inch of it is slithering with life that makes it so striking and, just as you have absorbed all this, you realise you are in the middle of a ghost city.

Here, in a clearing, is a circular pyramid, grey stone steps leading to a flat platform. It has sat here for a thousand years; at one point, it was completely overwhelmed by vegetation; and yet the edges of the stonework are still sharp, the surface of the platform is still intact. And here, in another, much bigger clearing is a larger, rectangular pyramid and at its feet, like a row of stone doors, there stands a collection of stelae. They are flat sheets of rock, each of them carved with hieroglyphs and with the image of a man, and each of these men is different in clothing and attitude and, most of all, in facial appearance. These are real images of the past, standing alone in the middle of this jungle, snapshots of the lost kings who once ruled central America.

Now, the mysteries begin to unfold. Where did these people come from? There are Guatemalans who will tell you they came from Israel or Atlantis or even Venus, but their facial appearance, their languages - which are built out of single syllables with multiple tones - and, most striking, their continuing habit of bowing from the waist in greeting or gratitude all suggest they are migrants from somewhere much nearer China. They were sophisticated people. In so far as the hieroglyphs and the stelae have been decoded, they reveal a people who were tracking the stars and measuring time and developing art and mathematics while the Romans were still emerging from the swamp.

T here was also a cruelty to them. The stelae tell of wars, of the capture and slaughter of prisoners and of the public sacrifice of enemies, sometimes by decapitation, sometimes by the slicing removal of a beating heart. In the bushes in Ceibal, there is a mound of soil and root that has grown over an ancient ball court, where - if the decoding of hieroglyphs is to be believed - Mayan kings played a game slightly like basketball against their vanquished enemies before handing them over to the priests to be pitched into their journey through the underworld.

The more you peer through the vegetation, the more of these mounds you see - palaces, temples, pyramids, water reservoirs, more stelae lying drunkenly in the undergrowth, the remains of a city that once housed some 10,000 people. Where did they go? Why - 500 years before the Spanish arrived - did they suddenly abandon the city? And all this is nothing compared with the ruins of Tikal, several hours to the north.

When you first come through the tall trees at Tikal and you see in front of you the Temple of the Great Jaguar, climbing up towards the sky, layer upon layer of stonework, crowned with the statue of a seated man with a serpent upon a throne, and when you reach into your imagination and restore the bright red and green and cream paint with which it was once decorated and you conjure up the crowd of Mayan men and women, milling down below, and you hear the sound of their excitement as the priest steps out on to the platform at the dizzy peak of the pyramid to begin the ritual that will grant them power and favour, you know you are gazing up at the architecture of pure power. It belittles everyone beneath it.

And then you turn and you see, several hundred yards away to the west, the Temple of the Masks, soaring to an equal height and, in between them, to the north, the two-and-a-half-acre acropolis of temples and burial chambers and then, to the south, the maze of palaces, linked by a burrow of passages, and you know you are looking at the hub of an awesome empire. It began to grow some 3,000 years before the birth of Christ and spread eventually across a vast acreage of territory, into what is now El Salvador and Honduras and southern Mexico. It rose and ruled and then collapsed 500 years before any European ever set eyes on it. And no one knows why.

The archaeologists can date its demise to the end of the 9th century AD, by dating the fragments of pots they find in the ruins. Simply, there are none after that. Perhaps the city was hit by an earthquake or the fall-out from a volcano, but there is no geological sign of that. Perhaps there was some kind of rebellion and the power-elite were slaughtered. But why would the successful rebels then abandon the city they had won? Perhaps, the Mayan kings were the first power to succumb to a rebellion by their own environment; some believe they tore up too much of the rain forest, that the topsoil blew away and slipped into their water reservoirs, hurling them into starvation and drought.

It is clear that they lost everything. When Tikal and Ceibal and the other cities were abandoned, the Mayans scattered across central America and, although they survived, they never again built such vast monuments. Their beliefs flowed underground, bubbling up in the rituals of the shamans, on the walls and altars of the Roman Catholic churches where their own religious images have crept in among the madonnas and the crosses, and in the dim-lit home of Maximon, where, beneath the bizarre addition of rum and cigarettes, supplicants are using ritual that was born thousands of years ago in a kingdom in a jungle that continues to conceal a mass of mysteries.

The practicals

Hayes and Jarvis (0870 8989890 and Res@ Hayes-Jarvis.com), offers tailor-made six-night trips of the Mayan sites from £979. They also travel to Guatemala as part of packages with Mexico, Belize, Honduras and Costa Rica. A 14-night tour of Mayan sites in Mexico and Guatemala starts at £1,445; a 14-night trip to Guatemala and Costa Rica starts at £1,899.
