The more you peer through the vegetation, the more of these mounds you see - palaces, temples, pyramids, water reservoirs, more stelae lying drunkenly in the undergrowth, the remains of a city that once housed some 10,000 people. Where did they go? Why - 500 years before the Spanish arrived - did they suddenly abandon the city? And all this is nothing compared with the ruins of Tikal, several hours to the north. When you first come through the tall trees at Tikal and you see in front of you the Temple of the Great Jaguar, climbing up towards the sky, layer upon layer of stonework, crowned with the statue of a seated man with a serpent upon a throne, and when you reach into your imagination and restore the bright red and green and cream paint with which it was once decorated and you conjure up the crowd of Mayan men and women, milling down below, and you hear the sound of their excitement as the priest steps out on to the platform at the dizzy peak of the pyramid to begin the ritual that will grant them power and favour, you know you are gazing up at the architecture of pure power. It belittles everyone beneath it. And then you turn and you see, several hundred yards away to the west, the Temple of the Masks, soaring to an equal height and, in between them, to the north, the two-and-a-half-acre acropolis of temples and burial chambers and then, to the south, the maze of palaces, linked by a burrow of passages, and you know you are looking at the hub of an awesome empire. It began to grow some 3,000 years before the birth of Christ and spread eventually across a vast acreage of territory, into what is now El Salvador and Honduras and southern Mexico. It rose and ruled and then collapsed 500 years before any European ever set eyes on it. And no one knows why. The archaeologists can date its demise to the end of the 9th century AD, by dating the fragments of pots they find in the ruins. Simply, there are none after that. Perhaps the city was hit by an earthquake or the fall-out from a volcano, but there is no geological sign of that. Perhaps there was some kind of rebellion and the power-elite were slaughtered. But why would the successful rebels then abandon the city they had won? Perhaps, the Mayan kings were the first power to succumb to a rebellion by their own environment; some believe they tore up too much of the rain forest, that the topsoil blew away and slipped into their water reservoirs, hurling them into starvation and drought. It is clear that they lost everything. When Tikal and Ceibal and the other cities were abandoned, the Mayans scattered across central America and, although they survived, they never again built such vast monuments. Their beliefs flowed underground, bubbling up in the rituals of the shamans, on the walls and altars of the Roman Catholic churches where their own religious images have crept in among the madonnas and the crosses, and in the dim-lit home of Maximon, where, beneath the bizarre addition of rum and cigarettes, supplicants are using ritual that was born thousands of years ago in a kingdom in a jungle that continues to conceal a mass of mysteries. The practicals Hayes and Jarvis (0870 8989890 and Res@ Hayes-Jarvis.com), offers tailor-made six-night trips of the Mayan sites from £979. They also travel to Guatemala as part of packages with Mexico, Belize, Honduras and Costa Rica. A 14-night tour of Mayan sites in Mexico and Guatemala starts at £1,445; a 14-night trip to Guatemala and Costa Rica starts at £1,899.

webTitle: Africa is raring to show off its stars

fields.headline: Africa is raring to show off its stars
fields.standfirst: The Nations Cup will draw a host of scouts from the clubs who curse it: Tournament guide Nations Cup essentials
fields.trailText: The African Nations Cup kicks off in Accra today and, though for Arsène Wenger it may be a distraction that robs him of a star player, for the joint hosts Ghana it is a chance for a generation of young players, led by Bayern Munich's mighty defender Samuel Osei Kuffour, to come of age.
fields.body:
The African Nations Cup kicks off in Accra today and, though for Arsène Wenger it may be a distraction that robs him of a star player, for the joint hosts Ghana it is a chance for a generation of young players, led by Bayern Munich's mighty defender Samuel Osei Kuffour, to come of age.

The Ghana team that opens the tournament against Cameroon is built around a nucleus of players who won the world under-17 championship in 1991, were runners-up two years later, picked up the Olympic bronze in Atlanta and were runners-up in the world under-20 championship in 1993. After years of under-achievement at senior level, expectation is high.

The last sight of Kuffour for many people will have been of him beating the Nou Camp turf in anguish as Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's late, late goal snatched the European Cup from Bayern Munich's grasp.

Despite that disappointment Manchester United sounded him out after the final but the interest came to nothing (United ended up buying Mickael Silvestre instead). Arsenal have also inquired and Giovanni Trapattoni, his first manager at Bayern, tried to lure him to Fiorentina but not even a bid of £12m would persuade the German champions to part with him. It is a long way from 1991 when his mother sold the family television to buy him his first pair of boots for his under-17 call-up.

Kuffour's composed performances are setting a new standard for African defenders, who have tended to adopt the uncompromising style of Cameroon's Daniel Massing, whose infamous assault on Claudio Caniggia of Argentina earned the first red card of the 1990 World Cup. Previous Nations Cups have featured some X-rated tackling.

"Those double-footed tackles are still there," says Chelsea's Celestine Babayaro, a certain starter for the other hosts Nigeria. "But a lot of the top players play in Europe now and know what it's like to take it easy." Clearly nobody has told Milan's Taribo West, who will also be on duty for Nigeria.

Despite boasting two of Africa's top players, Abedi Pele and the former Leeds striker Tony Yeboah, during the 90s Ghana were left kicking their heels as Cameroon and Nigeria put African football on the world map. That the two stars nursed a bitter feud for years did not help team morale.

Now under the coach Giuseppe Dossena, a non-playing member of Italy's 1982 World Cup-winning squad, the team has a more solid look about it, with Charles Akunnor captaining from midfield.

"The team is now composed mainly of players who were together at junior level," Kuffour told African Soccer. "But most importantly we are pushed forward by our desire to break away from the under-achievements of the past."

If Ghana do win they will have to do so in Lagos, in front of the fans of their arch-rivals Nigeria, who are co-hosting the competition despite the fact that Ghana and Nigeria are separated by 150 miles and two countries (the arrangement was cooked up when Zimbabwe was stripped of the tournament last year).

Nigeria, led by Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu, must fancy their chances. But a late change of manager and the sacking of the head of the Nigerian FA days before the start of the tournament suggest the off-field problems that preceded their World Cup debacle against Denmark in Paris may still have an effect.

Cameroon will again be strong and Morocco, unlucky in the last World Cup, stand a good chance, aided by the skills of Coventry's Moustapha Hadji and Youssef Chippo. Egypt are unlikely to be the first holders to retain the title.

At the same time as European clubs complain about the disruption the Nations Cup causes, there will also be no shortage of scouts offering contracts to promising young players. Kuffour shows what can be achieved, but a team-mate of his from the 1991 under-17 side is an example of the pitfalls that also lie in wait.

Nii Lamptey was one of the world's most sought-after teenagers. Somewhere along a journey that took him to Aston Villa and Coventry, as well as the Netherlands, Italy, Turkey and Argentina, it all went wrong. Still only 24, he is trying to rebuild his career in the German second division.

fields.headline: In a strange land
fields.standfirst: Zadie Smith's White Teeth reveals a major new talent
fields.trailText: Zadie Smith's White Teeth reveals a major new talent
fields.body:
White Teeth
Zadie Smith
Hamish Hamilton, £12.99, 480pp

A debut with the zest and ambition of White Teeth is customarily hailed as the arrival of a new "voice" in fiction. Yet the ear is as gratifying as the voice in this poised and relentlessly funny first novel. Zadie Smith's terrain is the English metropolis - concentrated in an area of north-west London from Marble Arch to Cricklewood - where she tunes in to a Babel of voices, registering the changes wrought in the language and landscape by the unfolding epic of post-war migration.

At its heart are two generations of two families: one white-and-Jamaican and the other Bangladeshi. Their self-styled heads are Archie Jones, a Brighton-born specialist in the folding of direct-mail leaflets, and Samad Iqbal, a Bengali Muslim biology student turned waiter with whom Archie once shared a second world war tank. The old mates' conflicts with their younger wives - Clara, "from Lambeth (via Jamaica)", and Bangladesh-born Alsana - and their "second-generation" children form the core of a novel with a bizarrely complex plot and a prodigious cast. Its characters embrace Jehovah's Witnesses, halal butchers, eugenicists, animal-rights activists and a group of Muslim militants who labour under the unfortunate achronym KEVIN.

Samad is trapped between his religious duty and secular temptations, such as his twin sons' music teacher Poppy Burt-Jones, who delights in his resemblance to Omar Sharif. He attacks Alsana (who sews leather garments for a Soho shop called Domination) for wearing sari-and-trainers, but himself sports tracksuit and baseball cap, his speech inevitably marked by 20 years in England. To Samad, "tradition was culture and culture led to roots. That didn't mean he could live by them, abide by them or grow in the manner they demanded, but roots were . . . the ropes one throws out to rescue drowning men." He fights against the Anglicisation of his twins Magid and Millat and the white lovers who will spawn unrecognisable grandchildren. "It makes an immigrant laugh to hear the fears of the nationalist, scared of infection, penetration, miscegenation, when this is small fry, peanuts , compared to what the immigrant fears - dissolution, disappearance ."

This fear drives him to the folly of sending one twin, Magid, "home" to Chittagong to make a proper Muslim of him, while the remaining, bereft twin Millat - for want of an air fare - grows into a terminally confused sexual magnet, a "rude-boy, badman", who ends up in the arms of KEVIN. Samad's experiment is doomed: "The one I send home comes out a pukka Englishman, white suited, silly wig lawyer. The one I keep here is fully paid-up green bow-tie wearing fundamentalist terrorist. I sometimes wonder why I bother."

Meanwhile in the Jones household, as Clara improves herself through the Open University's "isms and schisms", her daughter Irie falls in love with Millat, while battling the recalcitrant African follicle with a disastrous pursuit of hair "flickability". "There was England, a gigantic mirror, and there was Irie, without reflection. A stranger in a stranger land . . . This belief in her ugliness, in her wrongness, had subdued her." Irie abandons her longing to be English in favour of finding her roots in an Edenic Jamaican "homeland"- eventually finding freedom in the idea that belonging is really "some long, dirty lie".

Smith finds comedy in surprising places (shopkeeper Mo's habitual encounters with racist thuggery "had brought him more securely within the folds of his faith than even a visitation from the angel Jabrail could have achieved"). Yet this is also a novel of ideas, which tracks - over more than a century - the ineluctability of the past and of cultural and racial hybridity. While Samad finds refuge in the memory of his illustrious great-grandfather Mangal Pande, said to have fired the first shot in the Indian Mutiny of 1857, the ubiquity of fag-ends in a north London school triggers a disquisition on the English tobacco planter who impregnated Clara's grandmother, and the dangers of "a little English education" on stolen land. As for purity, Alsana says: "You go back and back and back and it's still easier to find the correct Hoover bag than to find one pure person, one pure faith, on the globe. Do you think anybody is English? Really English? It's a fairy-tale."

History most evidently repeats itself in the array of well-meaning but patronising "bleeding-heart liberals", whom the novel flays. They are epitomised by the Chalfens, English to the bone (though third-generation, via Germany and Poland), whose matriarch feels no embarrassment at referring to her guests as "brown strangers". Her inquiry, "You look very exotic. Where are you from?", provokes Millat into assuming a "bud-bud-ding-ding cornershop accent": "Oh, you are meaning where from am I originally " - his answer is: "Whitechapel, via the Royal London Hospital and the 207 bus." The novel does, however, find a white anti-hero in Archie, who emerges as a naive believer that "people should just live together". The novel opens with him being saved from suicide by a halal butcher whose entrance his car is blocking ("No one gases himself on my premises. We are not licensed"). It is the immigrant who grants Archie his "extra time", and Archie responds with dim-witted goodwill.

Although Irie finds no reflection of herself in England or its art, Zadie Smith herself is steeped in her forerunners. She has imbibed Edward Said ("Involved is neither good nor bad. It is just a consequence of living, a consequence of occupation and immigration, or empires and expansion"), while Salman Rushdie's influence pervades the chattily intrusive narrative voice. And whether pilfering or in playful homage, the novel carries echoes from the migrant, or "post-immigrant", literature of such as Sam Selvon, Caryl Phillips, Michael Ondaatje, and Hanif Kureishi. Smith plays with familar literary figures - four generations of resilient Jamaican women, a Muslim's battle between "corruption" and faith, control-freak migrant fathers, self-liberating migrant wives, the young Asian lesbian, the second-generation rebel - yet rolls them into her own idiosyncratic, and deeply felt, epic.

This is a serio-comic novel of great verve and distinction which offers its own corrective to England's distorting mirror, lending a keen ear to the fertile - often ignored - polyphony of postcolonial London. Clara's Jamaican lilt ("Sno prob-lem. If you wan' help: jus arks farrit") joins Archie's "wachya gunnadoo?", the cockney of "somefin'" and "sommink" alongside the ubiquitous playground argot of Jamaican and American. Scathingly irreverent without being flippant, engaged yet amused, its buoyant optimism perhaps reflects the fact that its author was born only in the late 1970s, a child of a more relaxed racial climate than that of her literary forebears. Its final image is the escape of a small brown laboratory mouse, which may be genetically programmed to turn albino-white, but which gladly seizes its freedom and runs with it.

fields.headline: Should the internet be regulated?
fields.trailText:
Dear Chris,
I'm a huge fan of the internet. It is a tremendous human achievement which promises to enrich our lives in all sorts of ways. However, as with many emerging technologies, the internet has brought a few problems in its wake. Bad guys, mad guys and criminals are exploiting its fluidity and potential for anonymity in ways that none of the net's inventors foresaw or intended, and which no civilised society can ignore for long.
fields.body:
Dear Chris,
I'm a huge fan of the internet. It is a tremendous human achievement which promises to enrich our lives in all sorts of ways. However, as with many emerging technologies, the internet has brought a few problems in its wake. Bad guys, mad guys and criminals are exploiting its fluidity and potential for anonymity in ways that none of the net's inventors foresaw or intended, and which no civilised society can ignore for long.

In the USA, so far, over 200 men have been sentenced to prison terms for the attempted or actual "sexual solicitation" of minors where the internet played a part in the crime. In the UK, we had the Gary Glitter case, and there are more in the pipeline, even if those involved are not quite so famous.

So it all seems fairly obvious to me. Stand by and do nothing and we risk the emergence of a thousand virtual Mary Whitehouses, who have little stake in the internet, demanding that politicians "do something" to "protect our children" or "get rid of the filth". In Australia, such pressures have already been at work, and it is not hard to imagine how they might take off here.

Attempting to censor the internet's content is not the answer - even if it were possible. However, the industry can and should do more to empower internet users to protect themselves and their loved ones. Inevitably this means we need more and better filtering tools, but that's just another way of saying we need to give people more power and choices about how they use the internet. Now who could possibly be against that?

Yours,
John Carr
Internet consultant
NCH - Action for Children

Dear John,
I agree that internet users need improved technologies. Not just better tools to allow us to exclude material, but better search engines, more usable sites, and faster access. We should have more power to make choices about the internet.

However, "industry self-regulation" has already led to regulatory quangos and internet service providers closing sites and censoring newsgroups. We cannot have the power to make choices about material on the internet if someone else has already decided that we cannot see it.

I know you will probably want to talk about children and pornography in an attempt to justify blocking content - it's the oldest trick in the censor's book - but I'm not just talking about this. Perfectly legal forums have been closed by ISPs, including a news site about Basque separatism, a Northern Ireland discussion group and a site criticising Britain's judicial system. All in the name of "self-regulation". The truth is, users are not permitted to regulate what they see; someone else does it for them. Plain old censorship in sheep's clothing.

Yours sincerely,
Dr Chris Evans
Founder
Internet Freedom

Dear Chris,
"Self-regulation" as it exists in the UK internet industry is no more than an organised attempt to ensure that our existing laws are upheld in cyberspace. You may not like those laws, but that's a separate issue. Any ISP that goes beyond what the law requires is doing so in its own name.

The logic of your argument is that ISPs are compelled to carry anything their customers serve up to them: a sort of enforced libertarianism. To do that you would have to give ISPs legal immunity should something go wrong later. Anything short of this takes you back to a position where somebody has to make judgments about what is or is not acceptable - and then you have a self-regulatory system again.

Every branch of our media has some sort of regulatory framework. Why should the internet be any different? And by the way, I thought your comments about children and pornography were rather trite. There are problems. They are not being conjured up from nothing as a ruse to justify greater oppressive controls. To paraphrase Orwell, just because it appears in the Daily Mail doesn't mean it isn't true.

There was a time, not so long ago, when the internet was the exclusive possession of a rarefied group within our universities and research communities. But the internet has moved from the ivory tower to the high street. It takes a rare kind of myopia to believe that the rules that applied in that prelapsarian idyll can survive intact following prolonged contact with the ruder, larger world.

Dear John,
As I have explained, self-regulation has led to ISPs going well beyond the law in removing perfectly legal material. I don't think they are motivated by commercial assessment. There is little evidence that ISPs are losing revenue by failing to censor customers. On the contrary, they lose revenue by closing their accounts. I think they are motivated out of fear of being branded morally irresponsible in a climate where political correctness is the watchword of business.

ISPs are not accountable for what internet users transmit, any more than the post office is responsible for what I write in my letters, or BT is responsible for what I say on the phone. I do not expect them to monitor the contents of my writings and conversations in the name of self-regulation. This is not enforced libertarianism, it is common sense.

What we are permitted to read or see should not be decided by ISPs. The only people that should make judgments about material are readers themselves. We are no less able to make up our own minds than the academics in ivory towers to which you refer. This is the irony of "self-regulation": it's really about someone else deciding what we should see and nothing to do with making judgments for ourselves.

Yours sincerely,
Chris

Dear Chris,
I think we have come full circle. Either you believe the internet should have no barriers or restraints in terms of what might be published on it, or you accept that there should be some rules. If you accept that there ought to be some rules, you have one more decision to make: do you simply leave it at that, or do you try to establish some means of giving effect to the rules? In real life, sadly, the former isn't tenable. It merely gives a licence to abusers.

Thus while we might argue about what the rules ought to be, once you concede the point, all that remains is a decision about how you give effect to them. That inevitably means giving someone the power or the duty to make prior decisions. In the UK we have decided to let the industry do it itself. Doubtless if that is found to be unsatisfactory, it can be revisited. So far, in relation to illegal publications on the web, the system seems to be working. But there is a great deal else that needs to be done before the internet can truly be said to be acceptable in the mass market it seems to want to occupy.

In the end I believe that everyone should have a personal internet that suits them. If you want to revel in the anarchic, romantic notions of what you think the internet once was, then that's OK with me. But please don't make me or my children share it with you. Let us make our own decisions about what comes into our home, in the same way our family does about what videos we rent, and where we go for our holidays.

Yours,
John

Dear John,

The Internet Watch Foundation, on whose board you sit, is a good example of an organisation that prefers to make these decisions for us.

Whilst the IWF is funded by the internet industry, they have the backing of the department of trade and industry, the home office and the police. Their de facto powers far exceed those of the police. They advise ISPs to remove material and ISPs consistently comply. Research conducted for the Institute of Economic Affairs reveals that in the UK 94% of this material is considered by neither judge nor jury.

As a consequence, over 9,000 items have been removed from the net despite only 24 successful prosecutions. In their latest announcement the IWF will regulate "criminal racist content". There is no such category under UK law. Presumably the IWF is going to invent new reasons for removing content from the net.

As a non-governmental organisation, the IWF is not accountable to the general public. Net users do not elect board members. Judgments are not made by juries. There's no form of redress for those whose freedom of expression is curtailed. It all makes Mary Whitehouse look pretty tame, don't you think?

Yours sincerely,
Chris

webTitle: Backbiting and bitterness at the TS Eliot Prize ceremony

fields.headline: Backbiting and bitterness at the TS Eliot Prize ceremony
fields.trailText: The British Library was caught on the hop slightly when it played host to the TS Eliot Prize earlier this week, after organisers underestimated poets' collective fondness for the grape.
fields.body:
 The British Library was caught on the hop slightly when it played host to the TS Eliot Prize earlier this week, after organisers underestimated poets' collective fondness for the grape.

It doesn't do to run out of wine when your guests are known for their tetchiness in the absence of a drop or two, but fortunately the long-suffering Poetry Book Society poured a couple of hundred quid into the coffers and normal service was resumed.

In this small, precarious and financially unrewarding zone of literature, "normal" tends to mean backbiting and bitterness: "think 50 lab rats and a few specks of food," one observer noted. Which is why, presumably, opinions were somewhat divided on the merits of the winning volume, Billy's Rain, by the dashing Hugo Williams, which beat Tom Paulin and CK Williams. Williams (H not CK) recently lamented the chilliness of his flat, observing that he often nipped into the street in order to warm up, and one hopes the £5,000 winning cheque might buy the odd two-bar fire, or at least some thermal undies.

 One poet not joining the scrum at the bar was Glyn Maxwell, whose new volume has been rejected by Paul Keegan at Faber, prompting howls of anguish from the Welwyn Garden City boy's acolytes. One view on this is that the extraordinary length of the new work (400 pages, at a conservative estimate) did not help its cause. Take note, Glyn: slim is where it's at.

 And to the literary equivalent of the first swallow of summer. Time Out's Brian Davis, reviewing a novel entitled The Keepers of Truth by Michael Collins, has hailed it as "The best I've read this year". That was on January 12, so while Mr Davis's critical judgment might be literally true, it's not saying an awful lot (unless, of course he wrote it last year and no one noticed). Expect predictions for the winner of the Booker Prize from him and others in the next few weeks.

fields.headline: This side of paradise
fields.standfirst: David Newnham discovers the unlikely birthplace of the 'green belt', social housing and the National Trust in a quiet Fenland town
fields.trailText: David Newnham discovers the unlikely birthplace of the 'green belt', social housing and the National Trust in a quiet Fenland town.
fields.body:
Wisbech, capital of the Fens, said the sign. But would it have a shop that sold fenugreek? Yes and no.

'Fenugreek?' said the woman behind the counter. She wasn't happy. 'I've got fenugreek,' she confessed. 'But I don't like selling it.'

She found a packet of brown powder and, somewhat grudgingly, began pouring it out. 'It'll take weeks to get rid of the smell,' she moaned. 'The shop will smell, and my clothes... When I go home tonight, my husband will say, 'You've been selling that fenugreek again.' Now, how much did you say you wanted?'

Twenty years on, my guilt has all but vanished. And so, too, has the tiny spice shop, snuffed out, I guess, by the new shopping precinct, where everything comes tightly sealed, and the only smell is of money.

And not too much of that, these days. Straddling the Nene on the last leg of its journey to the Wash, Wisbech is reckoned to be the most architecturally distinguished town in Cambridgeshire outside Cambridge itself. But there's a rash of whited windows in the handsome shopping streets.

Not that you'd notice anything amiss on North Brink. This great curve that clasps the brown river has been compared to a Dutch canal front - even to the banks of the Liffey in Dublin. Centre stage is Peckover House, 18th-century home to something you might consider an oxymoron, a Quaker banking family.

At South Brink, across the eddying water from the Peckovers, there once lived another banker. James Hill was his name, and he had a daughter called Octavia. 'Come in,' says Ann Clayton. She has turned out especially to open the Octavia Hill Birthplace Museum for me - the museum that her husband Peter founded five years ago to celebrate the life and works of the banker's daughter.

'In the beginning, nobody wanted to know,' says Mrs Clayton. 'Now people come here from all over the world.'

This town never was sure about the Hills. In 1837, James and his wife Caroline set up the Wisbech Infant School, where, instead of religion, poor children were taught 'the impor tance of truth, justice and mutual kindness and forbearance' (it soon became known as the 'Infidel School', and today survives only as the foyer of the Angles Theatre). And if all that didn't make him unpopular enough, James would organise marches to comandeer land for the poor. Then, in 1840, he went bankrupt, and Octavia was obliged to begin a rather different life on the banks of the Thames.

That's how it all began. At 14, she was already helping at a Ragged School. One day, a little girl took Octavia to her home in Paradise Place in Marylebone, and showed her the true texture of poverty. Home was one room to an entire family, with a lodger sleeping in the corner (they have recreated the slum in the museum basement).

'From that day,' says Mrs Clayton, 'she never dressed up. She kept a dowdy look, because she had seen the squalor and the horror.'

Octavia was to revolutionise the provision of housing for the poor - not only in Britain, but globally. And for her, that meant more than providing decent, affordable homes.

'Her style,' writes Peter Clayton in a biographical booklet, 'was patrician but not patronising. She would not, for instance, go into a tenant's home without being invited.'

And she didn't stop with housing. By the time she died in 1912, she had secured countless urban parks, invented the concept of the 'green belt' and more or less founded the National Trust.

The river is ebbing now, surging through the little port to which this town owed its former prosperity. Here and there, the window of a vacant shop front offers free advertising space to anyone with a glue-pot. One poster crops up time and again. 'Hirameka Hi-Fi,' it says. 'Super noisy teenage punks. Upstairs at the Angles Theatre.'

The Angles Theatre? Doesn't that ring a bell? Ah yes. The Infidel School.

 The Octavia Hill Birthplace Museum is open March to October, and throughout the year by appointment. Call 01945 476358 for details.

webTitle: In memoriam: big-bottomed Bobby on green baize

fields.headline: In memoriam: big-bottomed Bobby on green baize
fields.trailText: It's the end of the road for Subbuteo. Charles Burgess goes down memory lane.
fields.body:
In a corner of my mother's house is a pin-sharp picture, taken by me, of Bobby Charlton scoring the winning goal of the 1970 World Cup. The balding maestro is bent forward, having just unleashed one of his trademark screamers from outside the box, and the ball has just hit the net, top right corner, a fraction of an inch from the despairing hand of the hapless Brazilian keeper Felix.

And the extraordinary thing about Bobby's goal was that he had broken his leg in the semi-final, a horrendous injury which had seen him poleaxed and his leg sheared off just below the knee.

But it was a common enough injury in those days and he had made a miraculous recovery thanks to modern medicine. Doctors had literally glued his leg back on and he was raring to get back into the action.

It was a brilliant World Cup. The whole thing was played in a week, on one pitch which stood up remarkably to the pounding and before every game was in pristine condition, as if it had been ironed.

This being 30 years ago, not all the countries who took part had the money to buy their own shirts, and in a magnanimous gesture that is hard to comprehend in today's greedy game, four countries, England, Brazil, Italy and Russia, lent their kit to the other competing nations. Not that this stopped the full pomp before a game when both teams would line up for a variety of national anthems - mostly God Save The Queen.

Meticulous records were taken: teams, substitutions, crowd numbers (always huge) and goals and their times (always in the first 15 minutes).

I looked up Charlton yesterday. He doesn't look a day older than when he was in his prime and he still bears the scars, scarcely healed, of that dreadful injury sustained on a dining-room table on the outskirts of Carlisle all those years ago.

Don't believe all that nonsense about him living in the north. He moved to London with me and has lived with the rest of the team in the team box ever since.

England live cheek-by-jowl with the other teams, some torchlight-strength floodlights - it was always more fun with the curtains closed - and a reduced-size replica of the Jules Rimet trophy which Bobby Moore received in triumph in 1970 (as well as 1966). It is no longer in its presentation box as that was torn and, I think, partly eaten by a two-year-old several years ago. It was an extraordinary time for football. Carlisle United, who lent Italy their shirts for the World Cup, were regular winners of the FA Cup, where in the final they often beat Manchester United, who lent their shirts to Russia.

The game was in anarchy. There was a rule book but most managers made up their own. Purists insisted that the flick with the outside of the index finger running along the turf was illegal and that the man had to be pinged.

There was trouble too with goalkeepers, who kept on jigging around until both managers agreed this had to stop.

As with so many other things, it was girls who put a stop to our shortlived time in charge of some of the world's great players and some who are still our local heroes.

And now a confession. That picture I described at the top: it's not real. Sure, Charlton scored the goal but as the manager of England I did not get my camera out in time. So it is in fact a recreation. The ball in the top corner of the net was fixed there with Sellotape, and Charlton and Felix were held in place by Plasticine.

But now it seems there will not be any more world tournaments for those who do not possess those green boxes in the attic. Like my sons, most young people can play football on a pc, with real crowds, noises and incredibly realistic action highlighted by real-life Motson tapes (he was never as good as Wolstenholme).

The new owners of Subbuteo, invented in 1947 by Peter Adolph in Tunbridge Wells, are hanging up their plastic players with weighty bottoms for the last time at the end of the month. Their love for the game has gone and with it goes another bit of childhood. But don't worry, Bobby, you can play for my team for ever.

webTitle: Introduction: Should the internet be regulated?

fields.headline: Introduction: Should the internet be regulated?
fields.body: The British public thinks internet service providers should regulate content online, according to an Independent Television Commission poll published this week - and later this month the Internet Watch Foundation will announce plans to build on the existing self-regulation framework. But is any form of regulation really possible? Even if it is, is it desirable? Is the anarchic spirit of the net an essential guarantee for freedom of speech or does it merely give a licence to those who wish to abuse it? Read this week's Saturday Review debate - in which John Carr of NCH Action for Children and Chris Ellison of the pressure group Internet Freedom tackle the question - and then tell us what you think.

webTitle: Haider wins support as coalition talks fail

fields.headline: Haider wins support as coalition talks fail
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider, the controversial leader of Austria's far right Freedom party, is poised to make huge political gains after coalition talks between the socialists and conservatives collapsed yesterday in disarray following months of tortuous wrangling.
fields.body:
Jörg Haider, the controversial leader of Austria's far right Freedom party, is poised to make huge political gains after coalition talks between the socialists and conservatives collapsed yesterday in disarray following months of tortuous wrangling.

The Freedom party (FPO) surged into second place in October's inconclusive elections on an anti-immigration platform.

Since then, desperate attempts have been made by the political establishment to keep the FPO out of government.

But in the past week public opinion has turned against the ruling parties, and the FPO's popularity has soared to an all-time high of 32% - 3% above the leading Social Democrats, and 5% above the FPO's standing in the election.

Political analysts say that if new elections were held today the FPO would probably win.

The breakdown of the traditional hegemony which has dominated Austrian politics since 1945 has boosted Mr Haider's hopes of fulfilling his long-held ambition - to become chancellor.

Speaking yesterday in the province of Carinthia, where he is governor, Mr Haider said of the stalled talks: "Why will no one give Jörg Haider a chance? The FPO is at present the only stable element."

He has told President Thomas Klestil, who has been leading coalition talks, that in contrast to the bickering mainstream parties he could present a "perfect government programme" within a week.

He has said he would be prepared to form a coalition with either the socialists or the conservatives. Both have so far refused to work with him.

In an attempt to salvage the situation, Viktor Klima, the acting Austrian chancellor and leader of the Social Democrats, yesterday said he would try to form a minority government led by his party.

The Green party, with 14 seats, has said it would be prepared to join the government.

But the FPO and the conservative People's party have said they will not tolerate a minority administration.

President Klestil is determined to keep Mr Haider out of negotiations, aware of the potential damage to Austria's international image if the FPO gets into government.

Mr Haider, the son of a Nazi officer, has received notoriety for a series of pro-Hitler comments he has made. In 1991 he was voted out of office as governor of Carinthia for praising Hitler's employment policies.

He mixed with SS veterans at their annual gathering, lauding them as "men of character", and described Nazi concentration camps as "punishment camps".

During his election campaign he employed the slogan Überfremdung (overpopulation by foreigners) - a term used by the Nazi propaganda minister, Joseph Goebbels.

Israel's foreign minister, David Levy, has warned that if the Freedom party entered government he would consider breaking off diplomatic relations with Austria.

In response to that and similar negative reactions from abroad, Mr Haider said: "I can't take them seriously."

But in an effort to gain respectability with the international community, Mr Haider went on a charm offensive in London, Paris and New York to face his critics.

In November he apologised for his remarks for the first time at a rally in Vienna.

Asked this week what he would do if he failed to become chancellor this time round, he smiled and said: "I've been in politics for 20 years, so what's another two or four going to matter?"

fields.headline: Sam smiles
fields.standfirst: There is a precedent, of course, but it is pretty unusual for a theatre director to go to Hollywood and make a debut movie that is talked of as a surefire Oscar winner. Dizzying stuff. But, for all the doors American Beauty may open for him, Sam Mendes says his real business is back home in Britain. By Simon Fanshawe
fields.trailText: There is a precedent, of course, but it is pretty unusual for a theatre director to go to Hollywood and make a debut movie that is talked of as a surefire Oscar winner. Dizzying stuff. But, for all the doors American Beauty may open for him, Sam Mendes says his real business is back home in Britain. By Simon Fanshawe
fields.body:
Sam Mendes - like American Beauty, the film he has directed - is not what he seems. The echoes between the soul of the film and the man himself are the reason why the film is already being spoken of as a classic. Because, for his screen debut, Mendes - renowned for precise and cool theatrical productions - has made a highly emotional movie. His response to the first draft of the script was, he says, "instinctive". It was also, as it turned out, another example of his canny ability to make precisely the right choice.

Mendes is the man who reinvented the musical Cabaret, making it a massive hit in London - at the Donmar Warehouse, where he is artistic director - and on Broadway, by rescuing it from designer decadence into contemporary, sparkling musical terror; the man who has already, in little more than a decade, created two landmark Shakespeare productions, with his Tempest and Othello; who, before he was 24, had already achieved two popular classic hits in the West End (London Assurance, with Paul Eddington, and The Cherry Orchard, with Judi Dench); and who also notched up - hallmark of all bright young directors in the 90s - a pension-earning Cameron Mackintosh musical, in his case Oliver!

Serious people who have already caught American Beauty in the US, or at the gala screening that closed last year's London Film Festival, will tell you that it is a triumph and, in all likelihood, an Oscar winner. And they're right. The normally restrained Washington Post frothed, "One of the year's finest pictures... hilarious, painful and achingly tender." The blousy LA Times: "A hell of a picture." The New York Times simply called it "a triumph".

Which, in a way, is odd, because the film cuts at the heart of modern America, of which the media is so much a reflection, stripping away the pretence of well-being layer by layer, all the way through black comedy to poignancy. Kevin Spacey, co-star with Annette Bening, says, "People ask, 'How does a thing like Columbine, Colorado happen?' I think this movie answers that question." And, somehow, that's nothing like as far-fetched as it might be from another actor about another film. What Spacey means about the Columbine school massacre is that, when the soul becomes a shopping mall, when to live is to own things, it is hardly surprising if kids turn to murder. American Beauty manages to be both hilarious and dark about that crisis in spirit.

Through the dissolution of a suburban marriage - by way of boredom, lovelessness and the fact that, when the wife's pruning shears match her gardening gloves, it is no accident - the film suggests there is beauty next to you, that you can reach out and touch it, that people are not what they seem and that everyone's life is infinitely more interesting than they think it is. I should add that the most beautiful sequence in the film is several minutes of a plastic bag blowing in the breeze. And yet the movie is seductive and intelligent, clear-eyed and unsentimental, and tells many stories - of the couple, of their next-door neighbours, of the two children of the two families who find in each other a soulmate, of real estate, of suburbia, of sexual identity, of teen beauty and of murder - confidently cutting from one to another within a deceptively simple framework that defies easy categorisation. Whodunnit? Love Story? Comedy? Teen Angst? Live Action Cartoon? Surreal Fantasy? Or just, The American Condition at the Turn of the Century?

Spacey and Bening are the Burnhams. He is a wilfully disillusioned adman, pathetic and admirable in equal part, who whacks off in the shower (the day goes downhill from then on), blackmails his boss when he is sacked and embarrassingly drools over his daughter's best friend. She, on the other hand, is an estate agent and a gloss-painted worshipper at the altar of material achievement.

Mid seduction: "Lester, you're going to spill beer on the couch."

"So what? It's just a couch."

"This is a four-thousand-dollar sofa upholstered in Italian silk. This is not 'just a couch'." Collapse of not only this seduction, but of the prospect of any more, ever.

At the heart of the film are the two children, Ricky and Jane, played by Wes Bentley and Thora Birch. The former is certainly a teenage dope dealer and apparently a voyeur, a weirdo who films everything including the girl next door, a dead bird and the signature plastic bag. "Sometimes," he says, "there's so much beauty in the world I feel like I can't take it... and my heart is going to cave in."

As Mendes says, "Ricky is the film's conscience, its soul. At first, you think he is a voyeur, but you realise that Ricky is using his camera to reach out and touch people, not just to record... it's his way of reaching out." When talking to Mendes, you do feel that Ricky and he might have much in common.

Dark and rather cuddly, with good looks that betray his distant Portuguese ancestry, Mendes is a lot younger-looking than his 34 years. His voice is standard public-school posh, with no concessions to Royal Court street-smart: no aitches dropped, no donkey jackets worn. He is exceptionally polite, softly spoken, not given to excess or exaggeration; only occasionally does he raise his voice. He is warm, yet always gives an impression of self-control, so you could kid yourself that he is unemotional. And there is a certain watchfulness about him, which you might assume in a director, but they're not all like that. The overwhelming impression is that Mendes is very self-contained.

When I arrive at the offices of the Donmar Warehouse, he sits for 10 minutes or so at his desk in the open-plan office, completely absorbed in his correspondence, while we, the admin staff and I, gossip like hens in a coop not 10ft away. The actor Simon Russell Beale, one of Mendes's closest collaborators, having played Iago and Ariel for him, recounts one of the rehearsals for the Tempest at the RSC some years ago. "He stopped the rehearsal because he knew the ending just wasn't working. And then he sat for 45 minutes in the stalls, completely on his own, just thinking. For 45 minutes. You could see his brain working. We were all chatting on the stage. And then he came up with the solution."

Mendes was born in 1965, an only child. His parents, Peter and Valerie, were a university lecturer and a children's story writer. He went to Magdalen College School in Oxford, then to Cambridge, where he graduated with a first. Despite having staged what he describes as "several terrible productions" at university, he speedily got a job at the Chichester Festival Theatre, and within no time at all was running the nascent Minerva Studio for its first season.

Then, when he was barely out of shorts, he took over from a senior director who dropped out of a production of London Assurance and graduated to the West End. He had the two hits there by 1989 and was becoming known as something of a wunderkind . He joined the RSC, and in 1992 started to run the Donmar, which he has programmed with an eclectic mix, from Stoppard and Sondheim to Shakespeare. He has encouraged new writing with the Four Corners season (plays drawn from the four countries of the British Isles) and launched into West End successes such as The Rise & Fall Of Little Voice, Company and The Glass Menagerie.

The work that Mendes has produced is not grand and conceptual, but draws its impact from his ability to match actor and text. Critics always praise him for finding the sense within plays, rather than looking for spurious relevance or loading them with contemporary devices. What makes him stand out is his clarity of purpose. Russell Beale says of Mendes's first show at the RSC, Troilus & Cressida, "Sam analysed the pitfalls of young directors needing to show off and completely avoided them. What he did was just very clear and very simple." "You're creating an alternative universe," is the way the director himself puts it, "so you're simply telling a story."

Apart from his directing, there is an entrepreneurial side to his work. He has been credited with turning the Donmar Warehouse into "the sexiest theatre in London", perhaps because he attracts top-rate performers for bottom-rate money. They come to the Donmar for kudos or to reinvent their careers. The success of David Hare's The Blue Room, for example, transformed Mrs Tom Cruise into Nicole Kidman. And, like his contemporary Stephen Daldry, former artistic director of the Royal Court, Mendes' charm and ability to network are considerable. On the other hand, he has no appetite for public campaigning: "I'll always help the theatre world achieve greater strength, but I don't want to be a spokesperson for the arts."

He had a longish relationship with the madly talented Jane Horrocks, and was subsequently linked with Calista Flockhart and Rachel Weisz. The casting of Nicole Kidman in an artistically disappointing but publicity heat-seeking production of Hare's play made him noticed further afield than the London theatre world and gave him an aura of glamour. Next thing, he was being asked by Steven Spielberg to make the film everybody is tipping to win this year's Oscar for best picture. All very a,b,c. All very silver-spoon-in-the-mouth. But hardly predictable, even for a middle-class, privileged boy, who plays cricket in Harold Pinter's cricket team, The Gaieties.

What fascinates about Mendes is his preter- natural confidence. How can you direct Judi Dench at 23? How can you deal with Spielberg on your first film? How do you make such clear choices in life and in art?

He stumbles in his answer. "I am very resistant... there are so many things going through... I don't think there is one thing in particular. You're forced to come up with key moments that kind of spur you on and then you begin to believe them yourself. Directing is such a strange thing to do with your life." There is the sense behind everything he says that his own palpable solitariness, within his charming and clubbable exterior, is not up for examination. Yet he seems to have put it on screen in American Beauty. "There's no doubt that I found myself drawn to the script because I felt very personal about it. Directing is a very solitary job, in the sense that you never meet other directors. One of the things about running this building is that I get to see other directors work, so I am always learning."

But he's only 34, and he has already achieved an enormous amount. How does he do it? Not just by watching others. "There is nothing in my upbringing that explains why I do what I do." And then he says later, "A great deal of it is buried in my youth. I was very bad academically at school. I didn't concentrate. I scraped through my O-levels and just got into sixth form, and then decided that, 'Hang on, I'd better take control of my own life.'

I don't like talking about this much, because I feel responsible to my parents. I find it unfair to them." It is a matter of record that his parents divorced when he was five. But he elaborates and says, "My life was turned upside down on many occasions, to the point where, if I didn't take control of my life, I would have just taken a lot of drugs or something." And then he says, "the periods of calm and the periods of turmoil with each of my parents were the single most determining thing of my childhood. I took control of my life when I was 16 and kind of said, 'Stuff that. I am not going to depend on anyone else again.' Nothing can compete with the fear that everything stable in your life is out of control. Nothing's frightening after that. Not even Cameron Mackintosh!"

So he spent his childhood being a skilled cricketer, watching movies and reading, sheltering from the uncertainty. He says he was "a troubled fantasist who told stories to himself". But, in the midst of it all, he seems to have developed one skill, alongside his confidence and the decision to take control of his life. He is remarkably relaxed one-to-one. "I mainly spent my life," he explains, "with one other person, my mother." And this has lead to a great ability with actors. "I love actors; I have great respect for them." He has unlimited willingness to communicate with them precisely in a way that they understand. "I will go out and find what they need. My language to each of them has to suit their brain."

Russell Beale tells a story: "He stayed with me in Stratford during the technical run of Troilus & Cressida, and I saw him one night with his notebook. He had just scrawled things like 'shit' or 'crap' or 'wrong' quickly during the run-through. But then he spent hours at night sitting up translating each point differently into something each actor could understand."

Mendes knows this about himself. "I am not a masterclass director," he says. "I am not a teacher. I am a coach. I don't have a methodology. Each actor is different. And on a film set you have to be next to them all, touching them on the shoulder saying, 'I'm with you. I know exactly how you're working. Now try this or that...'"

He illustrates: "Kevin Spacey likes to joke and piss about and do impersonations right up to the moment of action, on his mobile phone to his agent or whatever. The more relaxed, the more jovial he is, the more he's not thinking about what he does. When you say, 'Action', he's like a laser beam. His relaxation leads to spontaneity. So to Kevin you're saying, 'Give me a Walter Matthau impersonation.'" Annette Bening, on the other hand, "is on her Walkman half-an-hour before the cameras roll, cutting off the set, focused down, listening to music that the character would listen to". His conclusion on his own method is simple: "All I know is that I operate by going out to each of them and trying to learn the territory in which they operate."

The script for American Beauty really came to him thanks to two productions: Oliver! and Cabaret. Spielberg had seen Oliver! in London and says now that "it was a visual candy-store, and I sort of banked his name in my mind". In 1998, Mendes's production of Cabaret opened in a converted nightclub in New York, and the producers of American Beauty, Bruce Cohen and Dan Jinks, saw it, as did Spielberg, whose company Dreamworks had just bought Alan Ball's script, then titled American Rose, from them.

There were other directors' names in the frame, but Spielberg approached Mendes, asking him to lunch. "I stuffed my face while he sipped a mud-coloured health shake," says Mendes. He read Ball's screenplay and was immediately taken. "It was incredibly multi-layered, but it made me laugh. Then I read it again, and it was full of sadness and loneliness, about imprisonment and escape. Then there was this theme of beauty running through it, and it was so many different things and I just didn't know how Alan [Ball] had done it. And that really fascinated me."

He storyboarded the whole film during the run of Blue Room at the Donmar. He had very clear ideas about what it should look like. When you hear him say, "I enter things visually before I enter them emotionally", it explains much of his work in the theatre, its completeness and unity of style and text. At times, the look of American Beauty has the remorselessly logical illogicality of a Magritte.

There is a moment when the young cheerleader, with whom Lester has decided he is in love, opens her blouse and scores of rose petals cascade out. At another moment, she is submerged in a bath full of them. At these moments, a touch of the surreal hovers a foot above the real. But at other times, the film has the still symmetry of an Edward Hopper. "I wanted a very composed, peaceful visual style to tell a story that was full of emotional tumult," he says. "And I realised, when I was cutting it, that I had made an even more emotional film than I thought I was making. In fact, the film I read, the film I thought I was making, and the film I actually made, are three different things."

It was an immaculate script by Ball, a co-executive producer and writer on the sitcom Cybill and co-writer of Grace Under Fire. But it was honed during filming. First, in editing, Mendes managed both to guide the story and to throw the audience a loop. For instance, he added an opening pre-title scene to create the first of several McGuffins, as Hitchcock called red herrings, in which the kids are filmed solemnly and quietly agreeing to kill Jane's father. The next thing you hear is the original opening, a voiceover from Spacey, as the father, saying, "My name is Lester Burnham... I am 42 years old. In less than a year I will be dead." A whodunnit?

The second factor, which made a big difference for many of the actors, was that Mendes, with his theatre background, gave them two weeks' rehearsal. This gave actors, especially the younger ones, time to develop considerable depth and the company a sense of family, which shows in the ensemble of the finished movie. "We sat around a table for much of the time, because I didn't want them to move. You don't want them to shoot their wad eight weeks before they're in front of the camera. But I was trying to fill up their petrol tanks with emotions and tapping into their imaginations."

The other smart thing Mendes did was to hire one of the great cinematographers, 72-year-old Conrad L Hall, who won an Oscar for Butch Cassidy And The Sundance Kid. Mendes simply says of him, "Conrad is a great man. He embraced my storyboard and made it happen." But not immediately. After three days of shooting, Mendes had a crisis: he hated what he had shot. He responded with typical surefootedness.

"Everyone was being too theatrical, telling it to the audience. The thing that was lucky was that I had got everything wrong. I made every wrong artistic choice. If I'd got it just a bit wrong, I might have just tried to adjust a little. But, because it was everything, I said, 'This is not what I wanted it to be.'" Fortunately, the studio agreed. He asked if he could shoot the scenes all over, and they said yes. "Frankly, they were relieved that I thought it was crap, too!"

Mendes could now be on the brink of a movie career. However, he will not be moving to Hollywood. "Nothing that goes on in Hollywood throws anything that goes on here in the shade." Mendes loves his Donmar Warehouse. It's family and home. "I made that film, and went there, because it was an American script. I didn't go to LA saying, 'I must make a film.' It has plot and characters, and is not just another attempt to second-guess the mass audience." He is working himself up. For the first time, the quietish, genial air starts to slip.

"I have no desire to live in Hollywood. I found there an industry with thousands and thousands of craftspeople who are simply the best in the world at their job and are prepared to drop their rates for a project they really love. But I am telling you, and I have worked there, we should concentrate on what we do well here." It's now a well-argued torrent.

"What's happening here is that newspapers have consistently relegated theatre, ballet, visual arts to the bottom of the page. And always above it is film and rock music. But I'm telling you now, stop obsessing - and this is ironic coming from me - about American film. The Observer film section is 16 pages long, and you have to search through the back pages of the Review to find theatre. And it is advertised as 'What really goes on in Tinseltown'. Who fucking cares? We have so much richness of talent here. And that's why I am back here. Because it's a fucking great place to work."

For the first time in four years, Mendes has no idea what he is going to do next. There were plans to do Hamlet with Russell Beale, but he had to shelve them because of the film. He was to have directed Sondheim's new musical, Wise Guys, but it's not ready yet. Having directed Kidman on stage, he moves in the movie stratosphere now, with an Oscar nomination a racing certainty. He even spent New Year's Eve on the Cruise/Kidman yacht moored in Sydney harbour. But he will return to Britain to see American Beauty open at the end of this month, and then set about taking the Donmar off in another direction.

He has no game plan for the theatre. He is "a great believer in retrospective policy. Do the play," he says, "and then say it was your policy. Don't make any great announcements. We're very light on our feet at the Donmar. We're a maverick theatre. Always have been." And Mendes will certainly be around for the next three years or so to see what his policy was once he's done it. Even if American Beauty wins the Oscar. Which it should. Shouldn't it? Mendes shrugs and smiles contentedly
