At first, you think he is a voyeur, but you realise that Ricky is using his camera to reach out and touch people, not just to record... it's his way of reaching out." When talking to Mendes, you do feel that Ricky and he might have much in common. Dark and rather cuddly, with good looks that betray his distant Portuguese ancestry, Mendes is a lot younger-looking than his 34 years. His voice is standard public-school posh, with no concessions to Royal Court street-smart: no aitches dropped, no donkey jackets worn. He is exceptionally polite, softly spoken, not given to excess or exaggeration; only occasionally does he raise his voice. He is warm, yet always gives an impression of self-control, so you could kid yourself that he is unemotional. And there is a certain watchfulness about him, which you might assume in a director, but they're not all like that. The overwhelming impression is that Mendes is very self-contained. When I arrive at the offices of the Donmar Warehouse, he sits for 10 minutes or so at his desk in the open-plan office, completely absorbed in his correspondence, while we, the admin staff and I, gossip like hens in a coop not 10ft away. The actor Simon Russell Beale, one of Mendes's closest collaborators, having played Iago and Ariel for him, recounts one of the rehearsals for the Tempest at the RSC some years ago. "He stopped the rehearsal because he knew the ending just wasn't working. And then he sat for 45 minutes in the stalls, completely on his own, just thinking. For 45 minutes. You could see his brain working. We were all chatting on the stage. And then he came up with the solution." Mendes was born in 1965, an only child. His parents, Peter and Valerie, were a university lecturer and a children's story writer. He went to Magdalen College School in Oxford, then to Cambridge, where he graduated with a first. Despite having staged what he describes as "several terrible productions" at university, he speedily got a job at the Chichester Festival Theatre, and within no time at all was running the nascent Minerva Studio for its first season. Then, when he was barely out of shorts, he took over from a senior director who dropped out of a production of London Assurance and graduated to the West End. He had the two hits there by 1989 and was becoming known as something of a wunderkind . He joined the RSC, and in 1992 started to run the Donmar, which he has programmed with an eclectic mix, from Stoppard and Sondheim to Shakespeare. He has encouraged new writing with the Four Corners season (plays drawn from the four countries of the British Isles) and launched into West End successes such as The Rise & Fall Of Little Voice, Company and The Glass Menagerie. The work that Mendes has produced is not grand and conceptual, but draws its impact from his ability to match actor and text. Critics always praise him for finding the sense within plays, rather than looking for spurious relevance or loading them with contemporary devices. What makes him stand out is his clarity of purpose. Russell Beale says of Mendes's first show at the RSC, Troilus & Cressida, "Sam analysed the pitfalls of young directors needing to show off and completely avoided them. What he did was just very clear and very simple." "You're creating an alternative universe," is the way the director himself puts it, "so you're simply telling a story." Apart from his directing, there is an entrepreneurial side to his work. He has been credited with turning the Donmar Warehouse into "the sexiest theatre in London", perhaps because he attracts top-rate performers for bottom-rate money. They come to the Donmar for kudos or to reinvent their careers. The success of David Hare's The Blue Room, for example, transformed Mrs Tom Cruise into Nicole Kidman. And, like his contemporary Stephen Daldry, former artistic director of the Royal Court, Mendes' charm and ability to network are considerable. On the other hand, he has no appetite for public campaigning: "I'll always help the theatre world achieve greater strength, but I don't want to be a spokesperson for the arts." He had a longish relationship with the madly talented Jane Horrocks, and was subsequently linked with Calista Flockhart and Rachel Weisz. The casting of Nicole Kidman in an artistically disappointing but publicity heat-seeking production of Hare's play made him noticed further afield than the London theatre world and gave him an aura of glamour. Next thing, he was being asked by Steven Spielberg to make the film everybody is tipping to win this year's Oscar for best picture. All very a,b,c. All very silver-spoon-in-the-mouth. But hardly predictable, even for a middle-class, privileged boy, who plays cricket in Harold Pinter's cricket team, The Gaieties. What fascinates about Mendes is his preter- natural confidence. How can you direct Judi Dench at 23? How can you deal with Spielberg on your first film? How do you make such clear choices in life and in art? He stumbles in his answer. "I am very resistant... there are so many things going through... I don't think there is one thing in particular. You're forced to come up with key moments that kind of spur you on and then you begin to believe them yourself. Directing is such a strange thing to do with your life." There is the sense behind everything he says that his own palpable solitariness, within his charming and clubbable exterior, is not up for examination. Yet he seems to have put it on screen in American Beauty. "There's no doubt that I found myself drawn to the script because I felt very personal about it. Directing is a very solitary job, in the sense that you never meet other directors. One of the things about running this building is that I get to see other directors work, so I am always learning." But he's only 34, and he has already achieved an enormous amount. How does he do it? Not just by watching others. "There is nothing in my upbringing that explains why I do what I do." And then he says later, "A great deal of it is buried in my youth. I was very bad academically at school. I didn't concentrate. I scraped through my O-levels and just got into sixth form, and then decided that, 'Hang on, I'd better take control of my own life.' I don't like talking about this much, because I feel responsible to my parents. I find it unfair to them." It is a matter of record that his parents divorced when he was five. But he elaborates and says, "My life was turned upside down on many occasions, to the point where, if I didn't take control of my life, I would have just taken a lot of drugs or something." And then he says, "the periods of calm and the periods of turmoil with each of my parents were the single most determining thing of my childhood. I took control of my life when I was 16 and kind of said, 'Stuff that. I am not going to depend on anyone else again.' Nothing can compete with the fear that everything stable in your life is out of control. Nothing's frightening after that. Not even Cameron Mackintosh!" So he spent his childhood being a skilled cricketer, watching movies and reading, sheltering from the uncertainty. He says he was "a troubled fantasist who told stories to himself". But, in the midst of it all, he seems to have developed one skill, alongside his confidence and the decision to take control of his life. He is remarkably relaxed one-to-one. "I mainly spent my life," he explains, "with one other person, my mother." And this has lead to a great ability with actors. "I love actors; I have great respect for them." He has unlimited willingness to communicate with them precisely in a way that they understand. "I will go out and find what they need. My language to each of them has to suit their brain." Russell Beale tells a story: "He stayed with me in Stratford during the technical run of Troilus & Cressida, and I saw him one night with his notebook. He had just scrawled things like 'shit' or 'crap' or 'wrong' quickly during the run-through. But then he spent hours at night sitting up translating each point differently into something each actor could understand." Mendes knows this about himself. "I am not a masterclass director," he says. "I am not a teacher. I am a coach. I don't have a methodology. Each actor is different. And on a film set you have to be next to them all, touching them on the shoulder saying, 'I'm with you. I know exactly how you're working. Now try this or that...'" He illustrates: "Kevin Spacey likes to joke and piss about and do impersonations right up to the moment of action, on his mobile phone to his agent or whatever. The more relaxed, the more jovial he is, the more he's not thinking about what he does. When you say, 'Action', he's like a laser beam. His relaxation leads to spontaneity. So to Kevin you're saying, 'Give me a Walter Matthau impersonation.'" Annette Bening, on the other hand, "is on her Walkman half-an-hour before the cameras roll, cutting off the set, focused down, listening to music that the character would listen to". His conclusion on his own method is simple: "All I know is that I operate by going out to each of them and trying to learn the territory in which they operate." The script for American Beauty really came to him thanks to two productions: Oliver! and Cabaret. Spielberg had seen Oliver! in London and says now that "it was a visual candy-store, and I sort of banked his name in my mind". In 1998, Mendes's production of Cabaret opened in a converted nightclub in New York, and the producers of American Beauty, Bruce Cohen and Dan Jinks, saw it, as did Spielberg, whose company Dreamworks had just bought Alan Ball's script, then titled American Rose, from them. There were other directors' names in the frame, but Spielberg approached Mendes, asking him to lunch. "I stuffed my face while he sipped a mud-coloured health shake," says Mendes. He read Ball's screenplay and was immediately taken. "It was incredibly multi-layered, but it made me laugh. Then I read it again, and it was full of sadness and loneliness, about imprisonment and escape. Then there was this theme of beauty running through it, and it was so many different things and I just didn't know how Alan [Ball] had done it. And that really fascinated me." He storyboarded the whole film during the run of Blue Room at the Donmar. He had very clear ideas about what it should look like. When you hear him say, "I enter things visually before I enter them emotionally", it explains much of his work in the theatre, its completeness and unity of style and text. At times, the look of American Beauty has the remorselessly logical illogicality of a Magritte. There is a moment when the young cheerleader, with whom Lester has decided he is in love, opens her blouse and scores of rose petals cascade out. At another moment, she is submerged in a bath full of them. At these moments, a touch of the surreal hovers a foot above the real. But at other times, the film has the still symmetry of an Edward Hopper. "I wanted a very composed, peaceful visual style to tell a story that was full of emotional tumult," he says. "And I realised, when I was cutting it, that I had made an even more emotional film than I thought I was making. In fact, the film I read, the film I thought I was making, and the film I actually made, are three different things." It was an immaculate script by Ball, a co-executive producer and writer on the sitcom Cybill and co-writer of Grace Under Fire. But it was honed during filming. First, in editing, Mendes managed both to guide the story and to throw the audience a loop. For instance, he added an opening pre-title scene to create the first of several McGuffins, as Hitchcock called red herrings, in which the kids are filmed solemnly and quietly agreeing to kill Jane's father. The next thing you hear is the original opening, a voiceover from Spacey, as the father, saying, "My name is Lester Burnham... I am 42 years old. In less than a year I will be dead." A whodunnit? The second factor, which made a big difference for many of the actors, was that Mendes, with his theatre background, gave them two weeks' rehearsal. This gave actors, especially the younger ones, time to develop considerable depth and the company a sense of family, which shows in the ensemble of the finished movie. "We sat around a table for much of the time, because I didn't want them to move. You don't want them to shoot their wad eight weeks before they're in front of the camera. But I was trying to fill up their petrol tanks with emotions and tapping into their imaginations." The other smart thing Mendes did was to hire one of the great cinematographers, 72-year-old Conrad L Hall, who won an Oscar for Butch Cassidy And The Sundance Kid. Mendes simply says of him, "Conrad is a great man. He embraced my storyboard and made it happen." But not immediately. After three days of shooting, Mendes had a crisis: he hated what he had shot. He responded with typical surefootedness. "Everyone was being too theatrical, telling it to the audience. The thing that was lucky was that I had got everything wrong. I made every wrong artistic choice. If I'd got it just a bit wrong, I might have just tried to adjust a little. But, because it was everything, I said, 'This is not what I wanted it to be.'" Fortunately, the studio agreed. He asked if he could shoot the scenes all over, and they said yes. "Frankly, they were relieved that I thought it was crap, too!" Mendes could now be on the brink of a movie career. However, he will not be moving to Hollywood. "Nothing that goes on in Hollywood throws anything that goes on here in the shade." Mendes loves his Donmar Warehouse. It's family and home. "I made that film, and went there, because it was an American script. I didn't go to LA saying, 'I must make a film.' It has plot and characters, and is not just another attempt to second-guess the mass audience." He is working himself up. For the first time, the quietish, genial air starts to slip. "I have no desire to live in Hollywood. I found there an industry with thousands and thousands of craftspeople who are simply the best in the world at their job and are prepared to drop their rates for a project they really love. But I am telling you, and I have worked there, we should concentrate on what we do well here." It's now a well-argued torrent. "What's happening here is that newspapers have consistently relegated theatre, ballet, visual arts to the bottom of the page. And always above it is film and rock music. But I'm telling you now, stop obsessing - and this is ironic coming from me - about American film. The Observer film section is 16 pages long, and you have to search through the back pages of the Review to find theatre. And it is advertised as 'What really goes on in Tinseltown'. Who fucking cares? We have so much richness of talent here. And that's why I am back here. Because it's a fucking great place to work." For the first time in four years, Mendes has no idea what he is going to do next. There were plans to do Hamlet with Russell Beale, but he had to shelve them because of the film. He was to have directed Sondheim's new musical, Wise Guys, but it's not ready yet. Having directed Kidman on stage, he moves in the movie stratosphere now, with an Oscar nomination a racing certainty. He even spent New Year's Eve on the Cruise/Kidman yacht moored in Sydney harbour. But he will return to Britain to see American Beauty open at the end of this month, and then set about taking the Donmar off in another direction. He has no game plan for the theatre. He is "a great believer in retrospective policy. Do the play," he says, "and then say it was your policy. Don't make any great announcements. We're very light on our feet at the Donmar. We're a maverick theatre. Always have been." And Mendes will certainly be around for the next three years or so to see what his policy was once he's done it. Even if American Beauty wins the Oscar. Which it should. Shouldn't it? Mendes shrugs and smiles contentedly

fields.headline: The logic of pulp
fields.standfirst: Francis Spufford  finds a sci-fi talent on automatic
fields.trailText: Finity by John Barnes 303pp, Victor Gollancz, £9.99
fields.body:
Finity by John Barnes 303pp, Victor Gollancz, £9.99

John Barnes is a funny one. It is always an advantage for a science-fiction writer to have some body of this-worldly expertise that they can use to tauten their invented worlds. Barnes, unusually, knows about economics - including the parts of economics that free-market libertarians, an important constituency in American SF, wish didn't exist.

He also has a mordant and pessimistic take on human relationships. For him, they almost always have a dark backing. His characters are constantly having their best intentions mangled by their impulses, or else they deny their impulses exist, with equally bad results. This ought to be a recipe for literate, thoughtful science fiction in which the vanity of human wishes, personal and economic, plays a large role. And indeed, that's what his best work is like. A Million Open Doors and its sequel Earth Made of Glass are rich, uneasy, rewarding novels, broadly in the tradition of Ursula Le Guin's Left Hand of Darkness .

But between writing these ambitious books, Barnes pours out pulp. A disaster novel, a sequence of time-travelling "men's adventures" of the sort where smart bullets reduce the bodies of baddies to sacks of strawberry jam. The sadistic material gets shaped for its loud, cold entertainment value. His cleverness doesn't go away, of course. These books are much more inventive than most of their competition. But on the emotional level, they're deliberately dumb.

I'm afraid that Finity belongs to the pulp side of Barnes's output. Set in a 21st century dominated by victorious Nazis, it's about the quest of a group of American expatriates to find out what has happened to their homeland. Why can no one remember any recent event in the former US?

Characteristically, Barnes provides a rare degree of conceptual muscle for his alternative history. The global-sway-of-the-swastika scenario may be bog-standard, but underpinning it with quantum mechanics is not, nor is bracing it philosophically with the "abductive reasoning" of the (real) logician Charles Sanders Peirce. The details of Barnes's world are often lovely, too. His expats live in New Zealand and Australia in picture-perfect recreations of American suburbia, pursuing their tradi tional cottage industries, like the meticulous hand-brewing of Heinz ketchup. Every house has a basketball hoop and a garage, despite the fact that in this oil-poor future no one drives a car.

The separate pleasures given by these inventions do not, however, flow together into much of a story. Our hero is Lyle Peripart, an amiable academic wimp pursued by one ferocious gun-wielding Amazon, and guarded by another, who does unspeakable things to him in the bedroom. Lyle's adventures in search of America are a succession of gore-spattered shoot-outs, winnowing down a cast you never cared about in the first place. For that matter, never, if you read this book, will have you been made to mind so little that the Nazis have taken over the globe. The solution of the mystery, when it comes, is distinctly desultory, confirming the sense that Finity is the work of a writer essentially on automatic pilot. Barnes is a real talent: but read A Million Open Doors , read Earth Made of Glass, not this heartless bagatelle.

fields.headline: Marketing gimmick backfires
fields.trailText: Equitable Life's predicament stems from a marketing gimmick that catastrophically backfired: the so-called guaranteed annuities sold as part of retirement plans until 12 years ago.
fields.body:
Equitable Life's predicament stems from a marketing gimmick that catastrophically backfired: the so-called guaranteed annuities sold as part of retirement plans until 12 years ago.

Annuity rates determine how big an income an individual will receive from the pension fund they have accumulated. The way those who bought pension plans including this option understood it they were promised a guaranteed minimum income when they retired.

The guaranteed annuities typically promised to pay annual incomes of 11% or more of the fund at retirement. In those days it was not considered reckless to offer such a pledge. Standard annuity rates averaged around 13% in the 1970s, and even as recently as a decade ago they hit about 16%.

But now the typical rate for a man at 65 is between 8% and 9%.

"It was sold initially as more of a marketing concept - guaranteeing you something at the end of the day," said Peter Quinton at independent retirement income specialist the Annuity Bureau.

"It was never conceived that annuity rates would drop down to the levels they have dropped down to and that these guarantees would have to be honoured," he said.

webTitle: Fresh options for those in a web of bad debt

fields.headline: Fresh options for those in a web of bad debt
fields.standfirst: Are you finding it a struggle to persuade a high street lender to help you? The internet  now offers an alternative.
fields.trailText: Are you finding it a struggle to persuade a high street lender to help you? The internet now offers an alternative.
fields.body:
The internet is making life easier for people with problems getting a mortgage from a traditional high street lender. More than eight million people - one in four of the adult population - have had difficulty obtaining credit from high street banks and other lenders, according to estimates.

This may be because they have had debt problems or have county court judgments registered against them. Some may have been living overseas and so have not built up a credit history in the UK.

Until fairly recently, mortgage information on the internet aimed at so-called "non-status" borrowers has been fairly scanty. But now several mortgage companies are expanding their coverage of this sector.

Some internet sites allow people to input their details and find out which products might be appropriate for them, or even check their "credit score".

Using the net may also suit those borrowers who would feel uncomfortable sitting down face-to-face with a financial adviser and talking about problems they have suffered in the past, says Anthony Webb at online firm Independent Mortgage Brokers (www.mortgage-brokers.co.uk). The net allows people to browse the different deals available from the privacy of their home and apply online.

Kensington Mortgage Company, which claims to be the UK's largest lender serving borrowers "who don't fit the mould," recently moved on to the internet.

Its site (www.kmc.co.uk) carries details of almost 20 loans. Its standard variable rate is 6.95% but there is a loading of between 2% and 4.5% depending on the type of loan and the amount of adverse credit the borrower has racked up, giving a current payment rate ranging from 8.95% up to 11.45%.

Another big name in this field is Paragon Mortgages. At its website (www.paragon-mortgages.co.uk) potential borrowers can type in their basic details to find out quickly if the company would be prepared to lend to them.

While some of the mortgages in this sector can be pricey, Paragon's Freshstart loan is one of the better value offerings on the market. It is available both to people buying a new property and those looking to remortgage.

However, it is aimed at those who have experienced "an isolated period of adverse credit", rather than those with a long history of debt problems.

Freshstart is priced at Paragon's standard variable mortgage rate (currently 7.35%), and there is a 1% loading for the first three years which is then removed "provided the account is well-conducted during that time". Ray Boulger at mortgage broker John Charcol says that for those who qualify for it, Freshstart can offer good value. The loading is "quite modest" and there is a guarantee that you will revert to the standard rate after three years as long as there have been no problems, he adds.

John Charcol recently launched its own online mortgage website (www.charcolonline.co.uk), where borrowers can browse through a range of deals. It carries details of a few impaired credit loans already, with more due to be added in the coming weeks.

One of the few high street names in this market is Bristol & West, which offers three "Re-Start" mortgages aimed at borrowers at the lower end of the credit impaired spectrum able to stump up a deposit of at least 25%.

It will lend to those with any number of county court judgments, provided they do not exceed £10,000 in total, and to discharged bankrupts.

From Monday it is offering a deal where you pay 0.6% on top of the standard variable rate (currently 7.24%) for one year, after which you go on to the bank's standard rate.

For full details go to (www.bristol-west.co.uk). Online application is not yet available but borrowers can register to join its e-mailing service.

It's vital to shop around when looking for a mortgage, and this applies particularly to people with credit history problems. Just because one high street bank has rejected you, this doesn't mean they all will. For example, if you have two county court judgments registered against you but neither is very big and both have been settled, you may well be able to get a mortgage from a mainstream lender, says Ray Boulger.

fields.body:
Cider: The Forgotten Miracle
James Crowden
Cider Press 2, £12.95

Poetry: not so much the poems within (though the apple haiku are crisp and fruity) as the affection for an almost gone world of specific, local - and therefore uncommercial - knowledge. Just the listings for apples (Sweet Coppin, Brown Snout) are names for small pleasures, slow-growing, hard-got and effortfully pressed. Rambles well, as if Crowden had sipped a couple of cider brandies, a fine aromatic native spirit for the revival of which he makes a passionate plaint. The book is printed and decorated to a standard no major publisher would dare to produce for less than 50 quid: in all, a few acres of Somerset dense with the past but untainted by the heritage industry.

American Beauty
screenplay by Alan Ball
FilmFour, £7.99

Terrifying, and that's just on the page. Reads like a murderous, tragic episode of The Simpsons, except that Homer and Marge have some love left and are in far less of a social and spiritual mess than are the Burnhams in the script. This is almost a companion volume to Naomi Klein's No Logo (reviewed last week): she wrote about how a culture of lies, personal and corporate, of consumption and idealisation of appearance over content is created and sustained. This is a fable about what that does to the little people with rose-gardens in the burbs.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Roger Cook gets into trouble again, plus The End Of The Affair
fields.body:
Dangerous Ground, written and read by Roger Cook (HarperCollins, £8.99, 180 mn)

With Checkpoint , Roger Cook pioneered the radio investigation genre in which dogged reporter weekly fronts up a villain. The joy was listening to him dodge the ensuing violence, because it was all done in sound. The move to The Cook Report on telly spoiled this fun, but it's been a heck of a ride. Quality yarns.

The End of the Affair, by Graham Greene (Chivers, £14.95, 390 mn, unabridged)

Not just the end, but the whole sorry history of this extra-marital wartime London fling. It's a devil of a novel to read aloud. Michael Kitchen aptly uses a thick brush for an intense performance. For some tastes, his pauses and plunges will seem excessive, but it is a fine portrayal of obsession.

fields.headline: The List
fields.trailText: Gina Kolata in search of the 1918 virus, plus A Slender Thread, The Power of Ideas and Madder Music, Stronger Wine
fields.body:
Flu
Gina Kolata
Macmillan, £12.99
Buy it at BOL

Enough already with your sniffles and your fey moaning: if you want to know what flu can really be like, read this fascinating scientific history of the 1918 pandemic, which killed between 40 million and 100 million around the globe. Kolata also follows the team of modern scientists on their quest to find a complete copy of the virus, buried inside a victim in the Alaskan ice. They are now analysing its genes and hoping to discover quite why it was so successful, because another pandemic is coming, sooner or later. Hiding in bed won't help.

A Slender Thread
Stephen Venables
Hutchinson, £17.99

Gripping mountaineering yarn wherein Venables, abseiling down from the peak of a remote Himalayan mountain at night, suddenly hears "the trivial, jocular ping of a steel peg ripping from the rock above me". He falls 300 feet, smashing his legs to bits. His fellow climbers, including Chris Bonington, have to attempt a rescue on a treacherous icefield with hardly any food and only a rudimentary first-aid kit. Even now, Venables says "it is good sometimes to trespass high in the sky". Nutter.

The Power of Ideas
Isaiah Berlin, ed Henry Hardy
Chatto, £20

In a world where ideas have little place in public discourse save debasedly among the barking fauna of conceptual art, it's good to be reminded that, as Berlin paraphrased Heine in 1958, "philosophical concepts nurtured in the stillness of a professor's study could destroy a civilisation". This foxy collection of his shorter essays includes the delightfully reasonable "The Purpose of Philosophy" (echoing Conrad in its concluding image of throwing light on a struggle in the dark), lucid exegeses of Marx's philosophy and Romanticism, and the classic statement of Berlin's Zionism, "Jewish Slavery and Emancipation".

Madder Music, Stronger Wine: The Life of Ernest Dowson, Poet and Decadent
Jad Adams
IB Tauris, £19.95
Buy it at BOL

Emblematic poet's tale of a man who composes pungent lyrics of pleasure and guilt, drinks madly, falls in love with an 11-year-old girl and dies in rags of consumption at 32. Adams's biog is also a loving snapshot of the cafes and poses of the Victorian decadents, as well as an alarming demonstration of the continuing relevance of one commentator's view: "He affords altogether the most discouraging example of the inutility of conscientiousness in modern English literature that one can find."

fields.headline: Small press
fields.trailText: A theatrical tour with Bram Stoker
fields.body:
Snowbound: The Record of a Theatrical Touring Party, by Bram Stoker (Desert Island Books, £14.99)

As well as writing the world's most famous horror novel, Stoker was a man of the theatre (indeed, the Count was based on his one-time boss Henry Irving). This little story, first published in 1908, is about a group of touring players stuck on a train. It is the latest discovery of Desert Island Books, founded eight years ago in Westcliff-on-Sea by vampire scholar Clive Leatherdale. Though it pays the rent with local soccer club histories, the heart of this one-man-and-his-bat business is the Desert Island Dracula Library, which numbers among its treasures a previously unknown Stoker novel The Primrose Path , due to be broadcast on Radio 4's Book At Bedtime from March 13.

 Desert Island Books are at www.desertislandbooks.com

fields.headline: Jewels of the cyber-slushpile
fields.standfirst: Oliver Burkeman finds out what publishers think of the internet revolution
fields.trailText: Oliver Burkeman finds out what publishers think of the internet revolution
fields.body:
The bookselling revolution wrought by the internet has been so astoundingly successful that it fails to astound much these days: with Amazon's revenues predicted to exceed $2bn this year, the numbers are fast becoming meaningless. But at the other end of the publishing cycle - the grubby, unglamorous business of actually getting writing into print - another, quieter revolution is taking place, the ramifications of which may ultimately prove far greater.

But the revolutionaries' more modest initial aim is to transform the relationship between writers and editors - the stated purpose of Authorlink, a website operated from Dallas which rates and promotes new authors directly to the computer screens of US editors. Since its inauguration in 1996, 58 titles have made the leap from the site to the shops. Last year, Penguin Putnam signed novice author June London from the site, while fantasy writer Carol Berg moved from Authorlink to HarperCollins for a reported six-figure advance.

Editors at major British publishing houses react with thinly disguised horror to the suggestion that they might waste valuable talent-spotting time surfing the web. "This is the nightmare come true for publishers," says Philip Gwyn Jones, editor of HarperCollins's Flamingo imprint. "The slush pile is out there. Why anyone would want to stay on some of these sites for more than two or three sentences defeats me."

Nevertheless, there are signs that all this may be starting to change. Stories like Melisse Shapiro's are becoming increasingly common: Shapiro, having failed in 1996 to interest New York publishers in her novel Lip Service, established a website offering the initial chapters for free and the entire work via a secure download for $10. Fiction sites reviewed it, a buzz developed, and last April, trade publisher Pocket Books offered her in excess of $100,000 for the book and an initial hardback print run of 25,000.

"As this industry shrinks, and becomes more competitive, you can't afford to ignore any opportunity," says Dan Slater, an editor at Penguin Putnam's New American Library. "You're always going to be sifting through a lot of coal before you find a diamond, and the web hugely increases the chances of finding those diamonds. But there's a lot of worry in the industry, a lot of fear, about what the internet will bring."

That fear may be justified: some developments in web publishing are indeed starting to make jobs such as Slater's look a little precari ous. Online bookseller Fatbrain's eMatter brand is a case in point. For a one-dollar fee, authors can post their works on the site and set their own list price. Fatbrain handles credit-card transactions, and author and bookseller split the proceeds 50/50.

But isn't this simply vanity publishing? Well, Fatbrain, for one, is beginning to attract established authors as well. Last year, Catherine Lanigan - author of Romancing the Stone and The Jewel of the Nile - made her latest book, Miracles Are Golden, available exclusively as eMatter; her out-of-print early works are also downloadable.

It's democratic, exhilarating, cutting-edge - but unfortunately, except in atypical cases such as Lanigan's, it's not really profitable just yet. "There still needs to be a breakthrough in online fiction, something that will be globally successful and force people to invest in it," says Jon Buscall, whose 1999 novel College.com - a whodunnit set on a university campus curiously similar to the University of East Anglia, where Buscall gained an MA in creative writing - was submitted and edited entirely by email.

"I don't think straight literary fiction on the net is going to work, but hypertext, hybrid fiction and personal journals, and work from people who are fluent in coding, rather than from conventional creative-writing backgrounds, are all going to be very exciting. There's such a large amount of dross out there - but there are also some very, very good things."

fields.headline: Scroll to the future
fields.standfirst: Will the internet revolutionise books?  Giles Foden  wonders if the past might show us the way web literature will go
fields.trailText: Will the internet revolutionise books? Giles Foden wonders if the past might show us the way web literature will go
fields.body:
It is a fair bet that the founding father of modern literary studies, I A Richards, would not have been a fan of books on tape. "We have not yet fathomed," he wrote in Principles of Literary Criticism (1924), "the more sinister potentialities of the loudspeaker."

He wasn't alone in voicing such worries. Every technology has had its literary Cassandra. The onset of the cinema was greeted with horror by F R Leavis, for example. For T S Eliot, part of being the harbinger of modernism was to have a horrified fascination with machine culture. And to W B Yeats - even though he fancied himself a "clockwork nightingale" in his poem "Sailing to Byzantium" - all machines, even the printing press, were anathema.

But at the sharp, local end of writing, things mechanical were already moving on apace. Eliot's sometime collaborator, Ezra Pound, had discovered the virtues of the typewriter in the staccato modulations of imagist poetry. Today, we can say that the computer, like Pound's qwertyuiop before it, has had a discernible material effect on the English language over the past decade.

We might talk, for instance, of the effect of block moves on narrative prose, of editorial cut-and-paste and other manoeuvres. But the greatest effect of the computer has been sheer prolixity, as more and more words are tumbled out - often with far less thought than before. Nowhere is this more apparent than on the internet.

Photocopying and faxes speeded up the verbal economy, but that is nothing to what is happening in the digital network society. How will works of literature adapt? Is this the era of what Michael Heim, author of The Metaphysics of Virtual Reality, has called "frictionless writing"? Frictionless in the sense that ideas flow directly onto the screen with little of the mediation traditionally associated with literary art.

But what if the internet were really a fantastic opportunity for writers, not just as a reference tool, but as a publishing medium and imaginative resource? Far from being the gateway to pixellated vacancy, the computer screen and the other "windows" playing upon it might provide enlightenment for writers and readers alike.

It is an enticing prospect, but in an infomaniac world, it's as wise to be sober. People do "publish" things on the net: but can you call even the best of it "literature"? Can you, at a time when copyright is under threat from unpoliceable electronic duplication, even call it "publishing"? It may be that literary value, at best a slippery concept, really has no place at all in the digital age.

Yet companies such as Online Originals, BiblioBytes and Massachusetts software house Eastgate Systems are now offering first-time publication on the net (though why not just do it yourself?). In Patricia le Roy's The Angels of Russia, last year's Booker Prize accepted its first electronic submission. BT has launched the search for the first e-laureate, while the Gutenberg Project continues to commit the texts of literary classics to the internet.

Authors such as Ruth Rendell and John Updike have begun novels on the net to be completed by others. Both ventures took the form of competitions, with up to 16,000 people offering contributions to Updike's novel daily. On Amazon.com and its UK subsidiary, you can pick up readers' "literary criticism", while online magazines such as Slate and Salon offer classy writing that is often bought up and repackaged by old-fashioned print media.

It seems, then, as if there is an explosion of interest in electronic literature - but getting a handle on what is actually useful and valuable about it remains difficult. Perhaps the best strategy is to look at other moments of great change in printing and publishing.

Chief among these would be the publication of Gutenberg's Bible (c. 1456), Caxton's Recuyell of the Historyes of Troye (1474), and Tyndale's New Testament (1525). The most significant development was not a publication at all, but the lapse of the licensing act of 1697 - before which anything that was to printed had to be submitted to the monopoly of the Stationer's Company. Later came the copyright act of 1710, which for the first time vested legal ownership of the text in the author.

Out of this brief history comes the lesson that political and theological control were more important than technical advances. It was a century after Caxton made it technically feasible that the Bible was allowed to be printed in English. Tyndale, its first translator, was harried and eventually killed for his work.

The significance of these developments for the internet today is that it all comes down to authority: who will determine what reaches the public and arrange it into a hierarchy of value? In the electronic era, the answer seems to be: anyone at all.

It sounds nicely democratic, but the fact is that literature, and the establishment of the canon which bodies out that word, has nearly always been the preserve of a minority whose Leavisite "scrutiny" has determined which works have lasted and which have been discarded.

However unfashionable it may sound, it is still true that people need "authority" to avoid information overload and low-quality material. There are other issues, including the transmission of dangerous, inflammatory and subversive material. These questions of authority will be one of the main factors that the net has to address.

One of the ways in which literary authority was exercised in the past was reviewing, ever since Dr Johnson took his seat in St John's Gatehouse on London's Clerkenwell Road - in a building which would, ironically, later become home of the Times Literary Supplement. Johnson was contributing to Edmund Cave's Gentleman's Magazine. Founded in 1731, it was a miscellany (actually giving us the word "magazine", from its earlier sense of "storehouse"), with most of its articles, except for Johnson's reviews, filched from elsewhere. This is certainly one area in which the internet is returning to its roots (Cave was the Rupert Murdoch of his time, a millionaire and the first media baron), insofar as the abstraction, sampling and revamping of text is a mainstay of electronic journalism.

But what about literature, when "content" is laden, for better or worse, with apparently ineffable values? Will the new technology, like other social changes before it, enable new genres or works of art - in the same way that the growth of the Elizabethan playhouses (and new laws permitting public entertainment) enabled Shakespeare, or the exponential increase in literacy during the Industrial Revolution enabled the growth of the novel?

Although its length means it is fated never to be an electronic genre, the novel is certainly one of the art forms which, in works such as William Gibson's Neuromancer and many others, has capitalised on the imaginative possibilities of cyberspace and virtual reality. Even poetry, most Parnassian of genres, has drawn on the metaphor of the computer in the work of writers such as Paul Muldoon, John Burnside and Cahal Dallat. Douglas Coupland, meanwhile, has in his novel Microserfs chronicled the lifestyles and psychology of the Silicon Valley generation.

If there is to be a genuine electronic literary genre, it will be heavily circumscribed by attention span. No one will read on screen, in comfort, anything much longer than 800 words. About 250 to 400 words seems more realistic. Forget epics, we're talking epigrams, Beckettian dramaticules, or prose poems following the model of Baudelaire and Rimbaud.

Verse itself doesn't seem much of a runner, as free-flowing text seems to militate against fixed line-endings: there is always "the glyph", the moment when the machine seems to take over. In other contexts, however - such as the manipulation of narrative outcomes by artificial intelligence in conjunction with reader interaction - the glyph (the term comes from an engraving process) might just be a benefit.

Hypertext fiction, whereby a choice of links determines patterns of story, seems a positive, Shandyesque way to go. But it is still an emergent form. It is also very clumsy, although the development of Storyspace, a new program by Eastgate Systems, looks promising.

The style of any important author to emerge from the internet seems likely to be both gnomic and cultic. He or she will become famous from the grass roots, as more people hit the hallowed site. Though they will soon pick up on the word of mouth, or word of mouse, publishers and newspapers, those traditional arbiters of literary taste, will get there too late.

Most internet authors, however, will remain obscure. Though there is, one supposes, always the chance of revival and fame in posterity, based perhaps on a new bibliographical specialism in the retrieval of dead texts from hard disks and long-forgotten network loops.

One cult author from the past who laboured without recognition all his life was William Blake, and his example in illustrating his own poems gives us another clue as to what might happen to literature on the net - the emergence of a kind of multitasking author, adept not just in hypertext mark-up language and Java (the languages used to create web pages) but in a host of dynamic animation techniques for manipulating both words and images. This person is more likely to emerge from the field of computer games than from traditional literary proving grounds.

Whether these moving illuminated manuscripts will be called literature is debatable. The key point is that convergence between technologies will go hand in hand with a collapsing of divisions between art forms - just as, in the academy, various disciplines have begun to collapse into Cultural Studies.

One person's collapse, however, is another's hypertext link - a creative opportunity, in other words - and if it remains true that people won't stop reading the printed book in the near future, it is also true that they will avail themselves of whatever the internet might produce. And where readers go, authors will follow, taking advantage of whatever technology can effect the transaction. Even that high priest of reaction T S Eliot, after all, came round to the loudspeaker in the end, recording The Waste Land for posterity in his thin, reedy voice.

It sounds nicely democratic, but the fact is that literature, and the establishment of the canon which bodies out that word, has nearly always been the preserve of a minority whose Leavisite "scrutiny" has determined which works have lasted and which have been discarded. However unfashionable it may sound, it is still true that people need "authority" to avoid information overload and low-quality material. There are other issues, including the transmission of dangerous, inflammatory and subversive material. These questions of authority will be one of the main factors that the net has to address. One of the ways in which literary authority was exercised in the past was reviewing, ever since Dr Johnson took his seat in St John's Gatehouse on London's Clerkenwell Road - in a building which would, ironically, later become home of the Times Literary Supplement. Johnson was contributing to Edmund Cave's Gentleman's Magazine. Founded in 1731, it was a miscellany (actually giving us the word "magazine", from its earlier sense of "storehouse"), with most of its articles, except for Johnson's reviews, filched from elsewhere. This is certainly one area in which the internet is returning to its roots (Cave was the Rupert Murdoch of his time, a millionaire and the first media baron), insofar as the abstraction, sampling and revamping of text is a mainstay of electronic journalism. But what about literature, when "content" is laden, for better or worse, with apparently ineffable values? Will the new technology, like other social changes before it, enable new genres or works of art - in the same way that the growth of the Elizabethan playhouses (and new laws permitting public entertainment) enabled Shakespeare, or the exponential increase in literacy during the Industrial Revolution enabled the growth of the novel? Although its length means it is fated never to be an electronic genre, the novel is certainly one of the art forms which, in works such as William Gibson's Neuromancer and many others, has capitalised on the imaginative possibilities of cyberspace and virtual reality. Even poetry, most Parnassian of genres, has drawn on the metaphor of the computer in the work of writers such as Paul Muldoon, John Burnside and Cahal Dallat. Douglas Coupland, meanwhile, has in his novel Microserfs chronicled the lifestyles and psychology of the Silicon Valley generation. If there is to be a genuine electronic literary genre, it will be heavily circumscribed by attention span. No one will read on screen, in comfort, anything much longer than 800 words. About 250 to 400 words seems more realistic. Forget epics, we're talking epigrams, Beckettian dramaticules, or prose poems following the model of Baudelaire and Rimbaud. Verse itself doesn't seem much of a runner, as free-flowing text seems to militate against fixed line-endings: there is always "the glyph", the moment when the machine seems to take over. In other contexts, however - such as the manipulation of narrative outcomes by artificial intelligence in conjunction with reader interaction - the glyph (the term comes from an engraving process) might just be a benefit. Hypertext fiction, whereby a choice of links determines patterns of story, seems a positive, Shandyesque way to go. But it is still an emergent form. It is also very clumsy, although the development of Storyspace, a new program by Eastgate Systems, looks promising. The style of any important author to emerge from the internet seems likely to be both gnomic and cultic. He or she will become famous from the grass roots, as more people hit the hallowed site. Though they will soon pick up on the word of mouth, or word of mouse, publishers and newspapers, those traditional arbiters of literary taste, will get there too late. Most internet authors, however, will remain obscure. Though there is, one supposes, always the chance of revival and fame in posterity, based perhaps on a new bibliographical specialism in the retrieval of dead texts from hard disks and long-forgotten network loops. One cult author from the past who laboured without recognition all his life was William Blake, and his example in illustrating his own poems gives us another clue as to what might happen to literature on the net - the emergence of a kind of multitasking author, adept not just in hypertext mark-up language and Java (the languages used to create web pages) but in a host of dynamic animation techniques for manipulating both words and images. This person is more likely to emerge from the field of computer games than from traditional literary proving grounds. Whether these moving illuminated manuscripts will be called literature is debatable. The key point is that convergence between technologies will go hand in hand with a collapsing of divisions between art forms - just as, in the academy, various disciplines have begun to collapse into Cultural Studies. One person's collapse, however, is another's hypertext link - a creative opportunity, in other words - and if it remains true that people won't stop reading the printed book in the near future, it is also true that they will avail themselves of whatever the internet might produce. And where readers go, authors will follow, taking advantage of whatever technology can effect the transaction. Even that high priest of reaction T S Eliot, after all, came round to the loudspeaker in the end, recording The Waste Land for posterity in his thin, reedy voice.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: Cardiff Urban grit, plus The Fencing Master, Mary Lavelle, and City of Light
fields.body:
Five Pubs, Two Bars And A Nightclub
John Williams
Bloomsbury, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Whether the Welsh want their own Irving Welsh is a moot point, but seekers for Cardiff urban grit need look no further than Williams's Butetown fantasy. His tales come hard, fast and funny. There's Kenny Ibadulla, who transforms the ground floor of his nightclub into a Nation of Islam mosque only to find himself out-scammed by the men with the suits and bowties. Maria and her pimp, Bobby are even bigger losers: against the odds they pull off a drugs haul, only to blow it all on a holiday. Even though the sneaking feeling lurks that Williams is exploiting a gap in the literary landscape, he has created an endearing cast of homegrown dreamers.

The Fencing Master
Arturo Pérez-Reverte
Harvill, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Jaime Arstarloa is a man of honour who lives by teaching the art of swordsmanship. A revolution is fermenting around him and the pistol may have rendered fencing out-moded, but the Fencing Master remains locked into the certainties of the past until a young woman demands that he teach her his secret 200-escudo thrust. Constructed with precision and elegance to echo the parry and thrust of a fencing match, Pérez-Reverte's novel goes beyond the obvious, erotic notions of sword-play between the sexes. However, the political machinations of 19th-century Spain are a lacklustre opponent until the duel is more than halfway through, and as a character Arstarloa only comes to life with a foil in his hand.

Mary Lavelle
Kate O'Brien
Virago, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Before there was Edna there was Kate O'Brien. Both roused the Catholic church to ban their books by writing of sexual awakening with unflinching honesty. Mary Lavelle , the story of an Irish governess who forsakes her solid young man back home for the married son of her employers, is in a way a romantic novel. Mary blossoms under the Spanish sun and Juan, the man she falls for, is a dashing hero of sorts. O'Brien writes with empathy for the compromises which marriage demands and her prologue, charting the progress of her heroine's trunk over the Pyrenees, gives a taste of the sharp-eyed writing to come.

City of Light
Lauren Belfer
Sceptre, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Belfer pours out her metaphors with as much force as the Niagara Falls, the focal point of this historical blockbuster. Centre stage is Louisa Barrett, an American Jean Brodie, educating her girls to lift their eyes beyond marriage. Her project is contrasted with the menfolk's plan to illuminate the city by constructing a mammoth hydro-electric dam. Public propriety is thrown into relief by private hypocrisy as Ms Barrett delves into the death of the dam's engineer. The accuracy with which Belfer hits contemporary concerns makes for a didactic read.

fields.headline: Udder genius
fields.standfirst: A Swiss novel about cows?  Michael Hofmann  loved it so much he translated it
fields.trailText: A Swiss novel about cows? Michael Hofmann loved it so much he translated it
fields.body:
Over Christmas of 1983, I was asked to look at a German book and recommend whether it was worth publishing in English. It was a first novel, Blosch, by Beat Sterchi (neither name meant anything to me), and it and he were actually Swiss.

On the cover was a photograph of a hulking, rather uncommunicative-looking (no smoke, no people, no windows) farmhouse and out-buildings and, on the back, was the author, a chiaroscuro lumberjack with beard and plaid shirt. The book was over 400 pages long, and was named after its principal character, a red cow - "Blosch" is cognate with the English "blush." It had a three-page glossary of Swiss terms at the end, and I thought something along the lines of "ho-hum".

A few days later, gripped and shaken and in no doubt that I had read a masterpiece, I covered several pages with my report, including, from memory, the sentence "I doubt whether you will be offered a better book from the German in the next eight or 10 years." With hindsight, it was the merest understatement, though I was desperately trying to stick my neck out.

A month or two afterwards, I learned that some other people had read and admired the book as well, that the publisher - Faber - had duly bought it, and that, I supposed, was that. I felt like a cog in a satisfactorily working machine. The thing was underway, and I had done my bit.

It wasn't quite that straightforward. The thing, for some reason, hung around. I rang the publisher for news on "the Swiss novel," and there wasn't any. Faber hadn't done any books from the German, not for a long time, and kept no tabs on German translators - or perhaps the translators took fright at this epic set on a dairy farm and an abattoir, about the cow, Blosch, and the Spanish Gastarbeiter, Ambrosio, about milk, and about blood. I wasn't interested myself, because I thought of myself, a poet and reviewer, as working at the more delicate end of things. In any case, I hadn't done much of anything. I would be squashed flat by a book like Blosch.

Still, I felt sorry for the author who had sold his book - years ago now - to a renowned English publisher, but was no nearer to seeing it in print. If the book was as good as I'd said it was, why didn't I translate it - even though I could imagine no one less qualified to do so? Then again, the one qualification I did have was admiration. In the end, my certainty about the book prevailed over my doubts about myself.

Through 1986 and 1987, I made my way through the book. Sterchi kindly shipped me some of his (English language) materials and drew me the odd diagram. I did various minor bits of research, kept a finger in the "cow" entry of the Encyclopaedia Britannica, read Upton Sinclair's Chicago stockyard novel, The Jungle, but largely trusted to what was in front of me. When I was done, I thought I knew enough in theory to slaughter an animal myself.

Translation, by its nature, tends to abstract and to distance. Something that was once, at least potentially, experienced and lived becomes second-hand. Countervailing notions like method translating or Author Heritage Tours for translators seem both hopeless and demeaning. I had the distressing sense of having taken a book that was made out of blood and bone and milk and, for all my best endeavours, made it into one of words.

But I could also see that I was inclined to over-estimate the experienced side of the book - because that was what I couldn't match - against its literary side: and this was after all a book that borrows its first sentence from Marquez, its techniques of catechism and multiple dialogue from Joyce, whose most obvious antecedent was Moby-Dick, and whose language sent me back to Macbeth, to mediaeval hunting scenes, or to the Chorus of Sophocles' Antigone: "Wonders are many, and none is more wonderful than man."

When it came to getting the book out, I was in a hurry. It was fully five years since the German edition, and I didn't want to waste any more time. The earliest possible date was a Monday in October, 1988; some voices counselled against, suggesting waiting till January, but I was full of the book and unafraid of anything. The shortlist for the Booker Prize was announced that day? Well, let it! I thought Blosch would see off "the native competition." I couldn't imagine the reader who would fail to be knocked out by it.

What happened was predictable to everyone, except me. First with the Booker (that fools' comparative), then with the run-up to Christmas, Blosch barely got a look-in. (Also, I quite failed to anticipate the effect of three alien words, Blosch, Beat and Sterchi on the cover.

It sold a couple of hundred copies. In the New Year, I chased around and managed to drum up a few more reviews, but, by then, it was too late. It wasn't in the shops, except in remainder stores, where there were little piles of it marked down to £1.99. There was no time for word of mouth to take effect (though I think it is a book that people talked about). There was - I think uniquely for a Faber novel in the 1980s - no paperback; the sales "didn't justify" one.

Incredibly, its publication in the US was similarly blighted: the day it came out there (in 1990) was the day the remaining staff of Andre Schiffrin's "old" Pantheon took their hats, in solidarity with their boss, who had been sacked. A stupid and ill-natured review in the New York Times did the rest. Essentially, the book was twice stymied by the rhythms and dynamics of publishing - the industry that makes and sells books.

There are hard-luck stories everywhere. What makes Blosch - or, now belatedly, The Cow - worth talking about is, firstly, its own uncompromising magnificence as a work of art, and secondly, the - unpredicted and unpredictably unhelpful - topicality of its subject. In the ten years of its unavailability, there probably wasn't a day when the newspapers didn't carry a story about meat, about beef, about health, about the interconnected lives of human beings and domestic cattle, about the ominous initials BSE, CJD and the rest of them.

All this is anticipated, contextualised, made sense of, sung, you could almost say, in The Cow. One particular Saturday, I remember a gruesomely beautiful photograph in the Independent of smoke and charred, angular limbs; just as flesh is grass, it seemed to say, so bone is wood. It was of cattle being incinerated, the very act and image that The Cow ends with.

Throughout this time, I've often thought more about Moby-Dick, published in 1851, "a book about a whale," not many takers. Then I thought: what if the 1850s and 60s had experienced a tremendous upsurge of interest in whales... You get the point. If the new paperback of The Cow stays on the shelf, one would have to conclude that people do their serious reading in newspapers, and that the time for novels ambitious enough to want to intervene in their lives is that much nearer to being past.

Buy it at BOL

fields.headline: The perverse relevance of Spenser
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard finds a useful way to spook the children with Edmund Spenser's Shorter Poems
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard finds a useful way to spook the children with Edmund Spenser's Shorter Poems
fields.body:
The Shorter Poems, by Edmund Spenser, ed Richard A McCabe (780pp, Penguin Classics, £11.99)Buy it at BOL

A somewhat perverse choice, you might think: Spenser was a wilfully archaic poet, old-fashioned even in the late 16th century, dragging back words into the language that had fallen out of use (or inventing words that sounded as if they had), so that he had to supply glossaries to his own poetry; surely he has nothing to say to us as we thrust boldly into the glorious future?

Well, even if he didn't, that would be reason enough to recommend him. We are in horrible thrall to contemporaneity, to "relevance", and to find something that has escaped the attention of dimwit and craven modernisers is reason enough to celebrate. (It was, incidentally, the 400th anniversary of Spenser's death last year, but I don't recall anyone alerting us to this.)

But the funny thing is that there are some works which are always going to be relevant, in small, unforeseen ways. And before I get to that, I should also say (in case you think I am being a gigantic literary snob) that one of the great things going for this book is that it is not The Faerie Queene, a work that I took one look at, towards the beginning of my undergraduate years, and decided that I would have to work around it, as it were, to get my degree.

The FQ is still a gap in my reading (and not just mine), but at least I and others intimidated by its inordinate length can take comfort in the knowledge that Spenser wrote other stuff, all of it shorter - and all of it in this volume.

So, as to relevance: well, messages of impending disaster, or warnings of the reversals that fate has in store for everyone on earth, are always going to be relevant; and the first 22 poems here, which come under the general title "A Theatre for Worldlings", catalogue the visions Spenser had of beauty being torn apart, wealth and power being laid waste; not just warnings about the uselessness of vanity and deserved destruction, but of the way everything in this world, good or bad, is torn down.

The language of these poems, by the way, is simple enough that they can be read, with a little bit of vocabulary-tweaking here and there, to a small child; if you want to spook and depress that small child, that is. (I say it's never too early to use literature to do such a thing.)

Perhaps I got the idea from the fact that the woodcuts used to illustrate the original edition are reproduced here: not only beautiful in themselves, they are useful and integral to the text (you can find much if not all of this stuff on the internet but it doesn't come with the nice piccies). As for the rest of the collection, you have "The Shepheardes Calender", a mixture of bold allegory (Spenser was risking his neck in offering Queen Elizabeth his opinions on her virginity) and charming lyrical complexity; "Mother Hubberds Tale", satire directed at the contemporary court and which - as it considers grasping, dishonest schemers - is still loosely applicable today.

There is love poetry, occasionally astonishing ("Venomous toung tipt with vile adders sting,/ . . . from which a spring/ of poyusoned words and spiteful speeches well . . ." - you will notice the original spelling is kept, we're not being treated like idiots here), translations from Petrarch, and everything you might expect from the man who, had Shakespeare not lived, would be the country's equal number one poet, along with Chaucer. So there you go. You now have no excuse not to have an edition of Spenser in the house.

webTitle: From the Grail to the Globe

fields.headline: From the Grail to the Globe
fields.standfirst: Susan Cooper explains the pull of myth and magic to Julia Eccleshare
fields.trailText: Susan Cooper explains the pull of myth and magic to Julia Eccleshare
fields.body:
Steeped in Arthurian legend and Celtic history, the five interlocking novels that make up Susan Cooper's classic fantasy sequence The Dark is Rising represent a powerful reworking of the quest for the Holy Grail. As "they of the light" battle it out with the Dark forces, they are helped by three children who become the human agents of the quest.

Nothing particularly original in that, but through the 60s and 70s - as the books were published - Cooper's intense descriptions of the Welsh countryside, combined with her ability to lift the story to some unnervingly dramatic highs, put her at the forefront of the influential band of fantasy writers who dominated children's fiction at the time on both sides of the Atlantic.

Two decades later, she's back on form. Her most recent children's book, King of Shadows , is a time-slip story about a boy actor from an American theatre company who visits the Globe in 1999 and finds himself working with Shakespeare in 1599. Cooper's descriptions of the theatrical world of the time, combined with her ability to convey the extraordinary character of Shakespeare, put the book right up there with The Dark is Rising .

The time-lapse between the novels is not as surprising as it sounds, given that Cooper never intended to be a children's writer and, even now, describes herself as someone "who writes books that are published on a children's list", as if not entirely sure that is where she really belongs.

"Initially," she explains, "my idea was to write a story about Shakespeare's repressed homosexual relationship with one of his boy actors - but then the boy, Nat, got stronger, and by the second chapter I knew that it was a children's story."

She traces her fantasy writing back to her days at Oxford, where she was the first woman editor of the student newspaper, Cherwell, and wrote about the disappearance of magic from our sensibilities. "I now see it as kind of prophetic, given my subsequent children's books, but then the idea of writing for children had never occured to me."

Instead, straight from university, she was taken on by Ian Fleming, then running the Atticus column for the Sunday Times , where she spent "a blissful seven years, writing, writing, writing." Her first book, Mandrake , was an adult novel with the then very futuristic setting of 1980.

She got her introduction to children's fiction via a competition designed to find an adventure in the spirit of E Nesbit - but the resulting book was turned down by 25 publishers before being published in 1965 and becoming the foundation stone of The Dark is Rising .

She might have continued to juggle novels with a journalistic career had she not been sent on a reporting trip to the US, where she met and married a professor 20 years her senior with teenage children. "Instead of a having a job, I became a stepmother and wife in a Boston suburb and I was terribly, terribly homesick."

But her writing didn't stop altogether. She began a weekly column for a Welsh paper about life in the US, and was asked to edit the essays of J B Priestley - a friend from her Sunday Times days.

It was Priestley who urged her not to despair, assuring her: "You'll write better about a place when you're away from it." The result was Dawn of Fear , an autobiographical novel about growing up in the Buckinghamshire countryside in the second world war, which she thought was for adults but was "repositioned" for the children's market by her publisher.

Four of the books in her Dark is Rising quintet poured out between 1973 and1977, after she had a brainwave while she was out cross-country skiing. She had been re-reading one of her earlier books, Over Sea, Under Stone , and it suddenly occured to her that she could write more books that connected with it. "When something like that happens, your mind goes into overdrive. I wrote the last half-page of the last book and I got into it in such a way that it worked, almost without change."

"Writing," she says, "is a closed room with a door without a handle. Just occasionally that door opens and you can get in. Writing four books like that was like writing a symphony. It had a very clear shape. For me, it was reliving a past I couldn't get back to. I wrote continuously. I wrote as soon as the children went to school and stopped when they came home. The books were in my head all the time. They protected me from reality." Even 20 years on, the intensity of that writing drive is evident as she talks.

Unwittingly, her books placed her alongside a group of Oxford contemporaries - Alan Garner, Penelope Lively, and Jill Paton Walsh - all of whom were influenced by the myths and legends of the early English writing that had been at the heart of their course. She says: "It was only much later, when Alan Garner and I met, that we realised we must have been in the same room at the same time, some time during our years in Oxford."

Despite, or perhaps because of, the success of her children's books, Cooper stopped for 10 years - turning instead to screenplays and TV adaptations. "In screenwriting," she explains, "you are a bricklayer making a wall. You hope it is a good wall. You also have to work a lot with other people. I liked that for a time but then I have to go off on my own and take control again." King of Shadows is proof that Susan Cooper is back in control.

fields.headline: Big in crime
fields.standfirst: For years now, a touch of noir has been the perfect accessory for all hip crime writers. We've had country noir, blue-collar noir, New York and LA noir, girlie noir, London noir. Since the death of Derek Raymond, however, James Ellroy is the only contemporary crime author whose books actually deserve the epithet. Until now.
fields.trailText: For years now, a touch of noir has been the perfect accessory for all hip crime writers. We've had country noir, blue-collar noir, New York and LA noir, girlie noir, London noir. Since the death of Derek Raymond, however, James Ellroy is the only contemporary crime author whose books actually deserve the epithet. Until now. God is a Bullet , by Boston Teran (Macmillan, £10) assigns its author to the pantheon of darkness in one effortless swoop. If you read a bleaker book this year, I'd be surprised. This searing debut novel is set in the feral wasteland of the Southern California desert and the badlands of Mexico. The kidnap of a 14-year-old girl and the massacre of her mother and stepfather by a satanic cult set the girl's father, cop Bob Hightower, off on the trail of cult leader Cyrus, who makes Charles Manson look like a school truant. His only hope is Case Hardin, a female ex-drug addict and cult member. Their quest turns both surreal and savage and becomes a gripping headlong dive into the hard-bitten world of junkies, child pornography rings and ritualistic violence. It's a roller-coaster of an experience, noir as a purging metaphysical experience that will take your breath away. Fans of genteel, cosy crime should read this haunting offspring of Sam Peckinpah and Jim Thompson with caution.

Their quest turns both surreal and savage and becomes a gripping headlong dive into the hard-bitten world of junkies, child pornography rings and ritualistic violence. It's a roller-coaster of an experience, noir as a purging metaphysical experience that will take your breath away. Fans of genteel, cosy crime should read this haunting offspring of Sam Peckinpah and Jim Thompson with caution.

Equally frenetic, but for a very different reason, is Motherless Brooklyn , by Jonathan Lethem (Faber, £9.99) in which the involuntary sleuth, Lionel Essrog - aka the Human Freakshow - suffers from Tourette's Syndrome, which results in an uncontrollable urge to shout out nonsense, touch every surface in reach, rearrange objects, etc . . . Spurning drugs which could dim his perception, and finding that his appearance is an invisible disguise, Lionel is drawn into investigating the mysterious death of Frank Minna. Frank was Lionel's saviour from an orphanage and the case is very personal indeed. Lethem already has a reputation in science fiction, and his venture into the mystery genre is assured, witty, a love song to his native Brooklyn and full of sparkling dialogue and plot twists. But what impresses most is his affection for his highly fallible characters. A fascinating adventure, already on its way to the screen, where Edward Norton plans to direct and star as the hapless Lionel.

Buy it at BOL

Afterburn , by Colin Harrison (Bloomsbury, £9.99) tells the tale of a Vietnam survivor in his late 50s, whose family has imploded and who is looking for a woman to bear his child. Enter the voluptuous and obligatory femme fatale with dangerous links to the mob. Soon, a relentless plot is in motion, racing from Wall Street and Hong Kong high finance to the criminal underworld, highlighting a fascinating set of characters under pressure and high-octane drama. An impeccably literate thriller by the author of Manhattan Nocturne.

Buy it at BOL

Eliot Patison's The Skull Mantra (Century, £10) blends a headless corpse, a disgraced investigator and a conspiracy of silence into a cocktail of action adventure set in Tibet. Political and religious intrigue, sorcerers, corrupt Chinese officials, American mining industrialists and evocative landscapes crowd the pages in what is unambitiously just a great read, in the tradition of Lionel Davidson's classic Rose of Tibet.

fields.headline: Loveless sex for six
fields.standfirst: Carrie O'Grady on William Sutcliffe's The Love Hexagon, a chilly tale of modern relationships
fields.trailText: Carrie O'Grady on William Sutcliffe's The Love Hexagon, a chilly tale of modern relationships
fields.body:
The Love Hexagon
William Sutcliffe
Hamish Hamilton, £9.99, 216pp

The love triangle, having fuelled a thousand romantic dramas and comedies over the years, is dead. Three players just aren't enough any more. Consider the hexagon the upgraded 90s version.

William Sutcliffe has perfected a very valuable skill: he is able to expose the weaknesses, ignorance and unwitting hypocrisy of his twentysomething characters without making us hate them. Or him. In fact they often strike a chord of guilty recognition. It's hard not to feel a sneaky sympathy for Dave, the narrator of his second novel Are You Experienced? - a cynical young Londoner who spends his tour of India despising both the pseudo-spiritual Western backpackers and the poverty-stricken Indian beggars he meets. His happiest days are spent in the hotel with the best dope.

The six participants in The Love Hexagon are a little older and colder than Dave. Guy and Lisa are locked in a stable, miserable relationship, while Graham, Helen, Keri and Josh are miserably single. If this were an old-fashioned sort of hexagon, all would be well that ended well, and our sextuplet would be joyfully paired off by the time the curtain fell. But this is the new, post-This Life hexagon; the process of pairing off is fairly random, occasioned by alcohol, lust and availability. Since all six characters are more or less equally unpleasant, it's difficult to get worked up about who ends up with whom. Difficult even for them: one woman, on receiving a lover's proposal, accepts ("OK," she says, "All right") because she believes marriage will make her feel better and her ex-boyfriend feel worse.

The Love Hexagon is full of such scathing observations. The loveless, opportunistic world of modern relationship-hunting is expertly picked apart - I defy anyone who has ever been single not to recognise echoes of their more callous moments. But Sut cliffe has made a curious choice: having created his hexagon, he looks down on it from a great height, seeing it with razor-sharp clarity but never descending to its level. The result is a narrative that reads more like an outline for a week's worth of prime-time TV soap than a novel. "Lisa decided to stage a matchmaking meal which, she felt sure, couldn't fail," reads a typical passage. "Guy thought this was a disastrous idea . . . Although Guy had never met him, something in the naggingly flattering way Lisa always described Josh had given Guy the firm impression that he was a dick." And so on. Only in the brief passages of dialogue - disappointingly rare - are we treated to the caustic humour that made Are You Experienced? such a success.

Instead, we're left with a series of psychological snapshots, a chilly exposé of the modern mindset. Now that we've looked behind the scenes, let's hope William Sutcliffe comes back to earth for his next novel and gives us a bit of a show.
