fields.headline: Absolutely fabulist
fields.standfirst: Raised in colonial Egypt, she was an Oxbridge 'It Girl' who, inspired by myth, fashion, fairy tales, religion and cartoons, became a cultural historian.  Nicholas Wroe on a writer who applies high learning to low culture and is now turning her attention to psychic research
fields.trailText: Raised in colonial Egypt, she was an Oxbridge 'It Girl' who, inspired by myth, fashion, fairy tales, religion and cartoons, became a cultural historian. Nicholas Wroe on a writer who applies high learning to low culture and is now turning her attention to psychic research
fields.body:
Every now and again, some television producer rummages through the archives of University Challenge for ancient contests featuring now-famous people. Seeing a hirsute Clive James or a slender Stephen Fry being youthful and brilliant is always good value viewing. Marina Warner was at Oxford in the mid-60s and also appeared on a television quiz show. But she was not quizzed by a brightly earnest Bamber Gascoigne for the honour of her college. Instead the young Marina, a student of French and Italian, the first female editor of Isis, and, it was said, the prettiest undergraduate of her generation, was confronted by the gurning features of Hughie Green, and she competed for hard cash.

The programme Double Your Money (the Who Wants to be a Millionaire of its day), had sent a team of researchers to Oxford to recruit young contestants. "But they never did it again," laughs Warner, who chose Greek myths as her subject. "The questions were so elementary that we all cleaned up."

The actress Diana Quick was a contemporary and remembers it well. "She was on week after week. The show would start with Marina in this glass booth and Hughie Green would ask her, 'do you want to double your money'? She eventually got up to £500 before she stopped, which was very acute because she knew the next question would be impossible. It was a fortune. I was living on £10 a week and I could comfortably run a car and a flat on that. She took the money and went to Paris for the weekend. It seemed unutterably glamorous when she came back wearing a blue fun-fur coat and carrying a basket of oysters."

Looking back, Warner's interest in myths and her stylish facility for applying high learning to low culture provided a pretty big clue as to her future direction. Ever since, as novelist, teacher, polemicist and cultural historian, her work has consistently circled round the same linked areas: how myths, fairy tales and symbolism continue to resonate in modern culture, the role of iconography in our lives, and the representation of women.

"What is amazing about Marina is that she is, in the quintessential European sense of the term, a brilliant intellectual," says the publisher Carmen Callil. "But what makes her so interesting is that she eternally applies her material to everyday things and life as it is now. Her connections are so exciting and relevant that they allow you completely to relate to what she is saying".

That is not to say that either her subject matter or her approach meets with universal approval. Following the publication of her book about fairy tales, From The Beast to the Blonde, the historian Noel Malcolm mocked: "Once upon a time, there was a very clever girl called Marina," he wrote, "who read lots and lots of books. Every book seemed to connect up with every other book, and they all told her something about images of womanhood in cultural history."

Camille Paglia, who, like Warner, is also often described as an academic feminist cultural critic, offers little sisterly support. "She's a slick socialite with a sentimental ladies' magazine sensibility," claims Paglia. "Neither I, nor anyone I know, takes her seriously."

But many other academics are more generous. Marilyn Butler has praised Warner's ability to unearth "genuine topics". Gillian Beer has called her, "a rare bird indeed, the freelance writer of considerable powers, not caught up in the academic web". Roy Foster, Carroll Professor of Irish History at Hertford College, Oxford, and biographer of Yeats, has known her for more than 20 years.

"She's rated very highly indeed [as an academic]. But she prefers to be an independent scholar than to hold an academic post, which would be hers for the asking. It has enabled her to write more and to write over a wider range. She's had a more successful life as an independent scholar than is the norm. She is a phenomenon in that way."

This month sees the publication of the paperback edition of her book No Go the Bogeyman. While From the Beast to the Blonde majored on representations of feminine evil in fairy tales, Warner says this book began, "with the problem of men". In it she explores the forms and functions of ogres ancient and modern. This meandering journey into our fears and the "strategies of imagination" we employ to face and, hopefully, overcome them, starts with a piece about cannibalism and ends with a marvellous chapter on bananas. There are endless intriguing oddities, such as the mayor of Bogota dressing his traffic police as clowns to defuse an epidemic of road rage - it apparently worked.

The book shows her seemingly all-embracing geographical and historical sweep of understanding of the world and appreciation of the forces that shape it. When Ursula le Guin reviewed the book of her 1994 BBC Reith Lectures, Six Myths of our Time, she noted with awe that Warner's thinking on the contemporary uses and dimensions of fiction, myth and the imagination, "takes her from Keats to King Kong to cannibalism, from welfare mothers to male bonding to child pornography to patriotism".

It is no real surprise then that, despite her fiercely clipped accent and almost archetypal English-establishment lineage - the Warner stand at Lord's cricket ground is named after her grandfather, Sir Pelham - parochialism was programmed out of Marina from the beginning. She was born in London, but brought up in Cairo by her Italian mother, Emilia, and English father, Esmond. She has a younger sister, Laura, who is now an art critic.

During the war Esmond Warner had been in the 8th Army in Egypt. He was in the same regiment as the owner of WH Smith, and Warner, impressed by the cosmopolitan and literary atmosphere of Cairo, suggested that a bookshop would thrive there. WH Smith agreed and Esmond opened up a wholesaler for them in the city.

"Of course we were expats and colonials," explains Marina, "but from a child's point of view it was very glamorous. We could see the pyramids from our terrace. I remember being too small to climb up and being helped up on to these huge stones. We holidayed in Alexandria in the summer. We overlooked the Nile and used to watch the boats. I remember my parents going out a great deal with my father in a dinner jacket and mother in very fancy dresses."

In what sounds like a neatly prophetic tableau of her glitzy literary life to come, in the evenings she would sit between her father, who was reading the Times Literary Supplement, and her mother, thumbing through Vogue. She enjoyed gossiping in "kitchen Italian" with the servants, and expresses some pride that she had a black nanny from the Sudan when so many other expat families "shipped in white nannies from England".

However, the Egyptian idyll ended in 1952 when the family were forced to leave after her father's warehouse was burned down in the first nationalist riots. Warner recalls her father being "devastated" by the fire and his despair being transmitted to the rest of the family. She has not returned to Egypt since, although when she was recently in Israel she says she had a rather "Proustian moment", when listening to the sounds of an Arab market: "I felt an incredible happiness."

The colourful Cairo social scene also brought the family into contact with some louchely exotic figures. A close friend was the spy Donald Maclean, who worked at the embassy. Warner recalls: "When he vanished my mother visited his wife in the London clinic where she had just had an operation. My mother was saying how ghastly it all was and Melinda Maclean was lying there saying it was all awful and she couldn't believe it. The next day she had gone too. She had this perfect front."

Another family friend is Lord Longford, who was at prep school with Marina's father and is her godfather. "My father was a rather tweedy type who thumped his Daily Telegraph throughout the 60s and 70s [complaining] about the unions and Harold Wilson," Warner says. "So you can imagine his chagrin that first of all his closest friend should become a socialist, but then also a Catholic. But they remained fast friends.

"My father used to chuckle a lot about it. 'Ha ha, what is Frank up to now with another murderess?', stuff like that. [Longford] really does believe in the sinner who repents. I once heard an Egyptian woman saying to him that she thought it was rather good that thieves had their hands cut off under Sharia law. I thought this was going to kill him."

Although Esmond Warner was an Anglican, he was happy that Marina should be brought up Catholic, as it was, "a good religion for a girl". By which he meant, explains Warner, "that it was demure and chaste and ladylike". She now say she is "bored" with her Catholicism, "I wish I could invent another family romance."

But while she left the church long ago, its mind-set still exerts a powerful tug. "I've read a lot of the Pope's writings. He is very good at bringing an audience to him by picturing how the meek shall inherit the earth, and then suddenly these strictures will come out focused upon women's bodies.

I think the unborn children, these non-existent people, are standing in for the real 20th century ghosts who were the people not helped by the church. It is important that he comes from Poland. It reads to me like a psychological switch from one lot of hauntings to another."

After the family returned from Cairo they had a short spell in London before moving to Brussels. Marina was sent to the convent of St Mary's in Ascot, and has awful memories of commuting. "They put a sign saying 'unaccompanied minor' round my neck, and as it always seemed to be foggy at Heathrow I would have to stay for days on end with these distant acquaintances who would have to put me up until the fog lifted."

Sister Christina Kenworthy Browne taught Warner and recalls her as, "very clever in a very gifted class. Sarah Hogg was in the same year, but [Warner] was the sort of child whose work you wanted to look at first, you knew it would be interesting. She also had a deep sense of the spiritual. She was interested in symbolism and so on even then. Her troubled Catholicism wasn't evident at school but I think it was boiling underneath."

In Egypt, Warner had spoken French at school and only spoke English to adults. "So I was quite badly teased for this stilted way of speaking. I had no school idiom or slang at all and must have sounded horribly pompous." And although not initially happy there - when her old headmistress recently died she still had "mixed feelings" read ing the obituary in the Times - she grew used to school and began to love some subjects.

"And I was well taught. It did shape me intellectually, and it probably enhanced my feeling for paintings, because as a religion it does love a graven image. But I had lots of struggles with faith. The whole thing was a struggle with a lot of talk about sexual liberation, although that is a phrase that sounds as though it should be in an antique box now."

Warner went up to Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford at 17, which she now thinks was too young. Diana Quick remembers her as, "very stylish and confident, and as she knew lots of people before she came up she had a ready-made social circle. While she had a great time socially, she always had a phenomenal capacity for hard work. I remember an edition of Isis she did with an amazing golden cover which was fantastically glamorous for a university rag."

Tariq Ali was head of the Oxford Union, and the Monty Python crowd were a few years ahead of her, but she says for the most part she found Oxford stifling. "They weren't used to undergraduates who were modern women, and the sense of decorum was oppressive. It was assumed that any woman who was interested in clothes must be a silly goose. Now one is used to meeting a woman with a first in philosophy wearing the latest nose ring, or whatever. In those days if you went to a tutorial in a mini skirt it meant you weren't serious about study."

After university she was offered a job on the Daily Telegraph, where she won an award for young journalist of the year before moving on, aged 23, to be the features editor on Vogue. She interviewed the 60s guru, Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, and the artist MC Escher. As the house photographers were Snowdon, Bailey and Beaton, getting high-profile subjects was no problem. "And all I really had to do was write an extended photo caption," Warner says. "It was wonderful."

At this time she wrote her first novel, but it was rejected by Cecil Day Lewis, then at Chatto & Windus. "He called me in and said it was good but not good enough to publish. He suggested I try non-fiction." Her first book was a biography of the last Chinese Empress, Tz'u-Hsi, chosen because she had always been interested in Chinese culture. In a very Warner-esque way she was originally turned on to it by all that odd Chinoiserie in the Rupert Bear cartoon strip.

She eventually left Vogue in 1971 to go to America with her boyfriend, the journalist William Shawcross, whom she had met at Oxford. "I had to get married to go with him," she explains. "We wouldn't have got married unless we had to, for practical reasons, but also I didn't want to give up my job without some sort of security, so I suppose in that sense I was a bourgeois."

Shawcross was writing speeches for Senator Edward Kennedy, but soon the Watergate story erupted, ultimately to bring down President Nixon. A Sunday Times team arrived to stay at their flat, and the journalistic orgy commenced. "William was incredibly excited but I was pretty much left to my own devices," she remembers. "So I spent hours in the Library of Congress reading around eight books a day on the Virgin Mary for my book about the Mary cult, Alone of All Her Sex. I wasn't exactly miserable. I just didn't have anything else to do."

Warner then went with Shawcross to Vietnam, where she witnessed the aftermath of the napalm raid on Trang Bang and actually saw the horribly burned girl captured in the now-famous photograph. While there her research into the model of womanhood thrown up by Mariolatry increasingly became a painful personal voyage of discovery. "The religion I had absorbed and discarded was very different to what I found in the history, in that the cult of Mary had changed so much over the years and served so many purposes."

In 1977 their son, Conrad, was born. (He is currently taking an MA in sculpture at the Slade school of art.) But the marriage broke down a couple of years later, and in 1981, Warner married the painter John Dewe Mathews in a Catholic ceremony abetted by Cardinal Hume, who had been Mathews' housemaster at Ampleforth.

This second marriage ended three years ago. "It was obviously painful but it was the right thing to do," she says. "We'd been married a long time and we had changed. We didn't have any children, which was a great sadness. We both expected to have children, and it was an incredible surprise to me, who spent most of my youth desperately avoiding getting pregnant. I think he is probably better off now, but he is a very gentle man and he wouldn't have done it himself."

Warner's new partner is Nick Groom, an English lecturer at the University of Exeter, at 33 some 20 years her junior. "I was very surprised when we got together," she says. "I thought he was a young friend. But now we squabble like an old married couple."

There have been other changes to her life in recent years. In political terms her impeccable north London liberal activism - she was on the committee of management of the National Council for One-Parent Families, and a leading member of Charter 88 - has been shaken. She was a member of CND and "hung on until Greenham Common was decommissioned. I received these awfully Xeroxed sheets from the rump of the Kentish Town branch right until the end." But now she confesses to being baffled as to whether CND was actually beneficial.

"It was clearly very damaging to the Labour Party, and contributed to its failure. They might have made more headway earlier if they hadn't had such a CND policy. And we might not have had some of the things that have happened under the Conservatives. In some awful way [the Bomb] did seem to have kept the peace. But I had a Bertrand Russell view that it was a wicked thing in itself, and one should not espouse wickedness."

She is attempting to incorporate these themes of confusion - "not political analysis but the human landscape" - in a new novel she is working on. "I find that if I read in the New York Review of Books a piece about how we should go into Kosovo with a land army I'm completely convinced. And then I read somewhere else that it's a disgraceful act of colonisation and imperialism for our trade benefits, and I'm equally convinced."

Carmen Callil places her among the leading trinity of British female writers. "At one time I was publish ing Marina, Antonia Byatt and Angela Carter. They each delivered a new book at about the same time and they were all about fairy stories. When Angie died I told Marina that now her workload would be quintupled. She'd have to do everything that Angie did, as well as all her own stuff. But she has been marvellous. One day she will write a really great novel."

Warner suspects she has entirely different readerships for her fiction and non-fiction but has recently begun to see her work as a series of diptychs. Her first novel, In a Dark Wood, written in 1977, came out after the Virgin Mary book, and featured a vision of Mary when a man has a crisis of faith after falling in love with a boy. "I was dramatising my own departure from Catholicism," she now sees. "The main thing I disputed was its attitude to sexuality."

She then wrote about the various appropriations of the Joan of Arc myth, while in her next novel, The Skating Party, an anthropologist comes across a young girl who has been declared a witch. "She was a modern Joan of Arc and the anthropologist was a 20th century inquisitor. It was a different way of standing back and seeing evil done."

To carry on the diptych idea, The Lost Father can be seen as a companion to her book about state language, Monuments and Maidens, in which she explores how women are used to personify the state and ideas of the state, liberty being one example. In The Lost Father, a family saga set in Italy, women acting as the guardians of the fatherland collude in the "romancing of eternal patriarchal figures".

It was written after the death of her father, when she realised that she had never really spoken to him. "I hadn't talked to him enough about his life and what he felt about things. I was too young, antagonistic and hostile. We'd always end up having a fight about Arthur Scargill instead of me asking him any interesting questions.

"I still regret that, so I made sure I did ask my mother about her life. She had been transplanted from Italy, and I told her I'd seen newsreel footage of when Mussolini asked women to give up their wedding rings as part of the war effort in Abyssinia and they got a ring of iron in return. It turns out my mother went with my grandmother to do this."

Roy Foster calls her fiction "mightily impressive. I'm very fond of The Lost Father and admire her next novel, Indigo, hugely. It was a very brave book to write and very successful in its own terms. She was entering a territory which is highly contested, where all sorts of people have territorial claims; that is the territory of race. But she occupied it with integrity and grace and imagination." Indigo, set on a magical Caribbean island, draws on The Tempest to dissect colonialism, exploitation and slavery.

Warner was particularly delighted when the poet and Nobel laureate Derek Walcott praised the novel. She has proudly kept the notes he used when introducing her at a reading in St Lucia. "They are in this beautiful handwriting with bits of paper stuck all over it as he worked on it. It is a wonderful document."

She acknowledges that her fiction, written in a poeticised language, is not very fashionable - "It comes from my background with French and Italian and is not influenced by American minimalism" - and worries at the lottery that sales of literary fiction can be. "You might put 10 years work into a book and it will sell 500 copies."

So she continues in her self-defined role. Public intellectual? Independent scholar? "I prefer just to be called a writer," she says. "At one time I did want to be attached to an institution. But I've changed my view dramatically, as I think I have now broken through and people don't despise me any more. They used to use the term 'Vogue journalist' as an insult and I wanted to be enfolded and enclosed. I wanted people to say I could be one of them. But now I'm loaded with honorary doctorates and that recognition is comforting." She is presented with another one today from the Tavistock Clinic, the renowned school of mental health training, research and scholarship.

Warner says that the single event that most contributed to this acceptance was when she delivered the 1994 BBC Reith Lectures, only the second woman in 47 years to do so. Her series of talks, Managing Monsters: Six Myths Of Our Time, was a culmination of her work at the time, and the subsequent book has become a set text on cultural studies courses.

Liz Forgan was managing director of BBC radio at the time. "Marina's extremely original way of seeing straight to the heart of contemporary culture through the prism of myth and ancient stories was perfect for us," she says. "And the reaction showed me that we were completely correct in finding a truly original voice. Half the world thought it was wonderful and opened doors that they had always known were there but hadn't thought to open. The other half hated it and thought it was just the wrong womany sound. I was delighted about that."

Warner recalls it as "real head-above-the-parapet stuff, which I don't usually have much stomach for. But I do realise that sometimes you need Janet Daley to say it is all meretricious claptrap. You can't expect to be bland and for everyone to just worship and admire your argument. I have kept my head down to a large extent as I think that, rather than get into spats, you should put all that energy into work.

"My only reservation is that it is a bit of cowardice sometimes. If you look at literary history, it is these rows that changed minds and directions. We have a bit of a tame circle of spite, in which some people write bad reviews about other people. That is not the same as a precipitating a real debate about what fiction, or memoirs, or history should be doing."

In what appears to be something of a departure, she is currently studying various aspects of psychic research: "There are some very distinguished physicists who say that not all the problems have been solved: the known has expanded, but there is still a lot unknown. Some of them are fairly interested in psychic stuff.

"In fact while the bogeyman material is a certain literary strand of a representation of the unknown, there is a parallel strand that comes out of the scientific enquiry culture. They're not exactly woven together, but they do keep step together, in a way. It all provides clues".

An enhanced appreciation of the cultural currents that have shaped the world may equip us better to change that world. "Updike called fairy tales beach glass, because they are worn by time and thrown up on the beach. They are not the monuments of literature, they are the detritus. That exemplifies what I feel about ordinary things. I'm not quite such a Victorian to think that the world is available for classification but it is true that the humdrum and the daily can give clues in a way that the exceptional and the monumental just can't."

Life at a glance: Marina Sarah Warner

Born: November 9 1946.

Relationships: 1971 married William Shawcross (son Conrad born 1977), divorced; 1981 married John Dewe Mathews, separated; current partner Nick Groom.

Education: St Mary's Convent, Ascot; Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford.

Career: Daily Telegraph; features editor Vogue.

Non-fiction publications: The Dragon Empress 1972; Alone of All Her Sex 1976; Queen Victoria's Sketchbook1980; Joan of Arc 1981; Monuments and Maidens1985; Managing Monsters1994; From the Beast to the Blonde1994; No Go the Bogeyman 1998.

Fiction: In a Dark Wood1977; The Skating Party 1983; The Lost Father 1988; Indigo1992; Mermaids in the Basement 1993; Wonder Tales (editor)1994.

 No Go the Bogeyman is published by Vintage at £10.99

Seeing a hirsute Clive James or a slender Stephen Fry being youthful and brilliant is always good value viewing. The actress Diana Quick was a contemporary and remembers it well. "She was on week after week. The show would start with Marina in this glass booth and Hughie Green would ask her, 'do you want to double your money'? She eventually got up to £500 before she stopped, which was very acute because she knew the next question would be impossible. It was a fortune. I was living on £10 a week and I could comfortably run a car and a flat on that. She took the money and went to Paris for the weekend. It seemed unutterably glamorous when she came back wearing a blue fun-fur coat and carrying a basket of oysters." Ever since, as novelist, teacher, polemicist and cultural historian, her work has consistently circled round the same linked areas: how myths, fairy tales and symbolism continue to resonate in modern culture, the role of iconography in our lives, and the representation of women. "What is amazing about Marina is that she is, in the quintessential European sense of the term, a brilliant intellectual," says the publisher Carmen Callil. "But what makes her so interesting is that she eternally applies her material to everyday things and life as it is now. Her connections are so exciting and relevant that they allow you completely to relate to what she is saying". Every book seemed to connect up with every other book, and they all told her something about images of womanhood in cultural history." "She's a slick socialite with a sentimental ladies' magazine sensibility," claims Paglia. "Neither I, nor anyone I know, takes her seriously." But many other academics are more generous. Marilyn Butler has praised Warner's ability to unearth "genuine topics". Gillian Beer has called her, "a rare bird indeed, the freelance writer of considerable powers, not caught up in the academic web". Roy Foster, Carroll Professor of Irish History at Hertford College, Oxford, and biographer of Yeats, has known her for more than 20 years. "She's rated very highly indeed [as an academic]. The winner was Peter Carey's Oscar and Lucinda but Warner shared the stage with Bruce Chatwin, David Lodge, Penelope Fitzgerald and Salman Rushdie, whose entry was Satanic Verses. To carry on the diptych idea, The Lost Father can be seen as a companion to her book about state language, Monuments and Maidens, in which she explores how women are used to personify the state and ideas of the state, liberty being one example. In The Lost Father, a family saga set in Italy, women acting as the guardians of the fatherland collude in the "romancing of eternal patriarchal figures". It was written after the death of her father, when she realised that she had never really spoken to him. "I hadn't talked to him enough about his life and what he felt about things. I was too young, antagonistic and hostile. We'd always end up having a fight about Arthur Scargill instead of me asking him any interesting questions. "I still regret that, so I made sure I did ask my mother about her life. She had been transplanted from Italy, and I told her I'd seen newsreel footage of when Mussolini asked women to give up their wedding rings as part of the war effort in Abyssinia and they got a ring of iron in return. It turns out my mother went with my grandmother to do this." Roy Foster calls her fiction "mightily impressive. I'm very fond of The Lost Father and admire her next novel, Indigo, hugely. It was a very brave book to write and very successful in its own terms. She was entering a territory which is highly contested, where all sorts of people have territorial claims; that is the territory of race. But she occupied it with integrity and grace and imagination." Indigo, set on a magical Caribbean island, draws on The Tempest to dissect colonialism, exploitation and slavery. Warner was particularly delighted when the poet and Nobel laureate Derek Walcott praised the novel. She has proudly kept the notes he used when introducing her at a reading in St Lucia. "They are in this beautiful handwriting with bits of paper stuck all over it as he worked on it. It is a wonderful document." She acknowledges that her fiction, written in a poeticised language, is not very fashionable - "It comes from my background with French and Italian and is not influenced by American minimalism" - and worries at the lottery that sales of literary fiction can be. "You might put 10 years work into a book and it will sell 500 copies." So she continues in her self-defined role. Public intellectual? Independent scholar? "I prefer just to be called a writer," she says. "At one time I did want to be attached to an institution. But I've changed my view dramatically, as I think I have now broken through and people don't despise me any more. They used to use the term 'Vogue journalist' as an insult and I wanted to be enfolded and enclosed. I wanted people to say I could be one of them. But now I'm loaded with honorary doctorates and that recognition is comforting." She is presented with another one today from the Tavistock Clinic, the renowned school of mental health training, research and scholarship. Warner says that the single event that most contributed to this acceptance was when she delivered the 1994 BBC Reith Lectures, only the second woman in 47 years to do so. Her series of talks, Managing Monsters: Six Myths Of Our Time, was a culmination of her work at the time, and the subsequent book has become a set text on cultural studies courses. Liz Forgan was managing director of BBC radio at the time. "Marina's extremely original way of seeing straight to the heart of contemporary culture through the prism of myth and ancient stories was perfect for us," she says. "And the reaction showed me that we were completely correct in finding a truly original voice. Half the world thought it was wonderful and opened doors that they had always known were there but hadn't thought to open. The other half hated it and thought it was just the wrong womany sound. I was delighted about that." Warner recalls it as "real head-above-the-parapet stuff, which I don't usually have much stomach for. But I do realise that sometimes you need Janet Daley to say it is all meretricious claptrap. You can't expect to be bland and for everyone to just worship and admire your argument. I have kept my head down to a large extent as I think that, rather than get into spats, you should put all that energy into work. "My only reservation is that it is a bit of cowardice sometimes. If you look at literary history, it is these rows that changed minds and directions. We have a bit of a tame circle of spite, in which some people write bad reviews about other people. That is not the same as a precipitating a real debate about what fiction, or memoirs, or history should be doing." In what appears to be something of a departure, she is currently studying various aspects of psychic research: "There are some very distinguished physicists who say that not all the problems have been solved: the known has expanded, but there is still a lot unknown. Some of them are fairly interested in psychic stuff. "In fact while the bogeyman material is a certain literary strand of a representation of the unknown, there is a parallel strand that comes out of the scientific enquiry culture. They're not exactly woven together, but they do keep step together, in a way. It all provides clues". An enhanced appreciation of the cultural currents that have shaped the world may equip us better to change that world. "Updike called fairy tales beach glass, because they are worn by time and thrown up on the beach. They are not the monuments of literature, they are the detritus. That exemplifies what I feel about ordinary things. I'm not quite such a Victorian to think that the world is available for classification but it is true that the humdrum and the daily can give clues in a way that the exceptional and the monumental just can't." Life at a glance: Marina Sarah Warner Born: November 9 1946. Relationships: 1971 married William Shawcross (son Conrad born 1977), divorced; 1981 married John Dewe Mathews, separated; current partner Nick Groom. Education: St Mary's Convent, Ascot; Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford. Career: Daily Telegraph; features editor Vogue. Non-fiction publications: The Dragon Empress 1972; Alone of All Her Sex 1976; Queen Victoria's Sketchbook1980; Joan of Arc 1981; Monuments and Maidens1985; Managing Monsters1994; From the Beast to the Blonde1994; No Go the Bogeyman 1998. Fiction: In a Dark Wood1977; The Skating Party 1983; The Lost Father 1988; Indigo1992; Mermaids in the Basement 1993; Wonder Tales (editor)1994.  No Go the Bogeyman is published by Vintage at £10.99

fields.headline: Hammer of the gods
fields.standfirst: Ian Sansom  turns to Fabio Morabito's Toolbox to learn about the metaphysics of tools
fields.trailText: Ian Sansom turns to Fabio Morabito's Toolbox to learn about the metaphysics of tools
fields.body:
Toolbox
Fabio Morabito; trans Geoff Hargreaves; ill Bernard Recaimer
Bloomsbury, 80pp, £9.99
Buy it at BOL

What did you get for Christmas? More stuff? And what exactly do you intend to do with your new herb chopping board and your rich cotton-mix pyjamas? At no other time in the year, and perhaps in no other place than the returns queue at M&S, do TS Eliot's words ring more true: "We are the hollow men/ We are the stuffed men."

There are those who appear to be above and beyond, or beneath, all this frivolous stuff and stuffage, fugitives from our Western law of super-abundance - saints, say, or celebrities, the unlucky, the imprisoned. But none is in fact ever free: the hermit has his hermitage, and the Buddhist monk his begging bowl, just as the rich man must sometimes eat his bread alone. There is simply no such thing as a pure, stuffless life, just as there is really no such thing as super-stuff, or good stuff: stuff is just stuff.

This does not of course prevent us from trying to make things seem special. There is no doubt that particular objects are capable of exciting in us complex sets of feelings - from a young age, for example, we know the comfort of soft toys and dolls - and there is no denying that our experience of things in fact constitutes a large part of our everyday lives. Things provide us with meaning.

This, at least, is what Fabio Morábito appears to be attempting to explain in Toolbox , a series of 12 enthusiastic short essays on tools - titled "Knife", "Hammer", "Screw" etc. Each essay is no more than about 1,500 words. Morábito is a Mexican poet, and his essays - translated from the Spanish by Geoff Hargreaves - add up to prose poems, heavily weighted with hyperbole, metaphor, and metaphysical speculation.

Why are sponges so beautiful, he wonders? Because "every time we squeeze a sponge in the cartilages and tendons of our hands, a secret desire is hinted at, one that never leaves us, a desire to re-invent ourselves from the bottom up, to be different, to be as accessible and light as we were on our first day." Similarly, string is "the first step in the act of delegating", a bag "can't offer any guarantees", a screw is unarguable, scissors are "ambassadors of cold" and a spring is "action in slow motion".

The sophisticated tend to belabour the obvious to the point of the absurd - cf Roland Barthes - and Morábito's breathtaking strenuosities do occasionally make one wince, but he more often hits the nail on the head: a hammer, clearly, when you think about it, is rather profound.

Writing essays about mere tools might seem to be a technique of evasion - a retreat to the shed, or the ivory tower, a way of avoiding writing about more important things, like, say, relationships - but in Morábito's hands tools are a way of understanding people rather than a means of hurting or avoiding them. Things, after all, are deeds, and tools are made by people, for people. And the narration of stuff, therefore, is the narration of lives.

There is probably only one helpful and meaningful criticism of Morábito's work, which has more to do with his sins of omission than his over-exertions. Writing about old-fashioned tools is all well and good, but if we really are serious about understanding ourselves and our things, don't we need books about our current tools for everyday living - photocopiers, tumble-dryers, microwave ovens, ATMs, mobile phones?

But a few words of warning to those honing their aphorisms on digital technology: "You must remember this, a kiss is still a kiss,/ A sigh is just a sigh;/ the fundamental things apply,/ As time goes by." Not only is a kiss still a kiss, but sometimes a personal computer is just a personal computer, as a piece of string is just a piece of string.

webTitle: The devil and the deep red sea

fields.headline: The devil and the deep red sea
fields.standfirst: Jack Straw has dismissed liberals as 'woolly-minded'. The late philosopher Isaiah Berlin, patron saint of liberalism, has been attacked by left and right.  Michael Ignatieff  defends moderation
fields.trailText: Jack Straw has dismissed liberals as 'woolly-minded'. The late philosopher Isaiah Berlin, patron saint of liberalism, has been attacked by left and right. Michael Ignatieff defends moderation
fields.body:
When the old man died in November 1997, he was mourned on both sides of the Atlantic not just as a liberal sage but as the very epitome of a free-spirited mind. His work had been a long, tacit commentary on his extraordinary life, and the central event in both had been the Russian revolution. He had witnessed it himself as a child of eight in the streets of Petersburg, and almost everything he wrote thereafter was a sustained protest against the violence, tyranny, cruelty and oppression given licence by the communist vision of a brighter tomorrow. His greatest essay - Two Concepts of Liberty -was much more than a defence of moderation and pragmatism in politics. It insisted that our most deeply held political values-justice and liberty-contradicted each other. Because they did, no utopia could ever reconcile them in harmony, and because they could not be reconciled, all political judgment entailed tragic choice, not just between good and evil but between competing goods.

As Isaiah Berlin's biographer, I made the innocent-and foolish-assumption that his reputation would not need defending. He never made the same mistake himself. He shrewdly guessed that his stock was riding too high in life. A correction was overdue.

When it came, the only thing that might have surprised him was its indecent haste. He was not even in his grave when Paul Johnson wrote in the New York Times that Berlin had only been a "low-risk philosopher" afraid to challenge the liberal commonplaces of the British elite. A week later, Cambridge don Michael Tanner pronounced that, instead of working against the current of conventional opinion, Berlin had always been that current.

These critics - and there were many more - claimed that their objective was not the man or his thought, so much as the cult of veneration surrounding him. This was fair enough. Obituary writers had called him a "liberal saint", and saints should be fair game. When my biography was published in November 1998, it soon became clear that the real object of the attack was liberalism itself. Why else would Christopher Hitchens have devoted so much vehemence in the London Review of Books to demonstrating that Berlin had been less courageous or consistent than I had made him out to be? Berlin was in Hitchens' line of fire since he seemed to embody all of liberalism's supposed evasions. As Hitchens put it, "There is a sense in which, if you chafe at the present complacently 'liberal' consensus, the reputation of Isaiah Berlin stands like a lion in your path."

There was just one problem. Where was this "complacently liberal consensus"? The L-word had been a term of abuse in American politics since Nixon's election in l968. Hitchens, who has an unequalled talent for mocking the earnest emptiness of the Clinton era, ought to know that whatever the American consensus now is, it is not liberal. As for Britain, the liberal current is squeezed hard between the two tribes, one worshipping Mrs Thatcher, the other praying to Nye Bevan. Berlin had no visiting rights in either camp. Mrs Thatcher thought him much too wet to be "one of us"; Tony Blair's government thought him too individualistic to serve as patron saint of the Third Way.

The idea of Berlin as the high priest of a transatlantic consensus of liberal complacency was a fiction, but a necessary one. For what else but this fiction holds Hitchens' own politics together? Those useful idiots, the liberals, help keep the left in business on both sides of the Atlantic. Besides, Hitchens' attack on Berlin for being the ingratiating friend of the fashionable was a useful pose for anyone wanting to refute the charge that this was precisely what he was himself.

This need to strike poses in relation to liberals is not confined to the left. Norman Podhoretz, one-time editor of Commentary, an influential American monthly of conservative Jewish opinion, criticised Berlin for being a spineless purveyor of moral relativism, for not standing up against the evils of multiculturalism, whatever these may be. Both left and right never fail to pair liberalism with spinelessness. Since my biography chronicles the moments where Berlin showed that liberals have spines, it is pointless to rehearse these again. With respect to Hitchens and Podhoretz, I would be preaching to the deaf. Their need for the caricature of the liberal as mollusc leaves them impervious to demonstration. What they actually mean is not that Berlin failed to choose, but that he did not choose as they would have wished him to.

Then there were the attacks on his intellectual seriousness. All three - Paul Johnson, Christopher Hitchens and Norman Podhoretz - are intellectual entertainers. How odd, then, that they should try so hard to prove that Berlin was nothing better than an entertainer like themselves. Lacking, of course, their fighting virtues. One pauses to recollect what lonely causes these men have defended at the cost of their reputations, what Orwell-like displays of courage entitle them to be so scathing about Berlin's timidities. But of course! They have spent themselves in selfless combat against that overwhelming, suffocating liberal consensus.

Hitchens would say - indeed did say to me - that associating him with Podhoretz's critique of Berlin is a Zhdanovite proceeding. He is referring to Andrei Zhdanov, the cultural commissar of the Stalin era, who specialised in batch denunciations of his enemies linked together by "guilt through association". Hitchens would be sensitive to such proceedings, since this is his own preferred modus operandi.

But in hands less adept than Zhdanov's they result in unintentional comedy, as when Hitchens picked upon Berlin's remark that his liberalism owed much to Lloyd George. Aha! said Hitchens, this must mean Lloyd George, "the patron of Field Marshal Douglas Haig", which then makes Berlin guilty by association, not with Lloyd George's state pensions, but with the massacre at the Somme! Pouncing again on Berlin's approval of Franklin Roosevelt, Hitchens dimly surmises that this must also mean supporting "the originator of the war economy" and the "prime mover of American acquisition of European empires". So if liberals believe in the New Deal, they must also be firm supporters of American imperialism and the national security state. This is not an argument, but a non-sequitur. Many liberals opposed the Vietnam war precisely because they believed an empire abroad was ultimately incompatible with democracy at home.

The technique of guilt by association invariably requires crude misrepresentation in its indictment. Hitchens could only convict Berlin of bloodthirsty support for the Vietnam war on the basis of misquotation from letters about McGeorge Bundy, one of the chief architects of American policy. The letters praise Bundy not for his policies in Vietnam, but for his decision, as president of the Ford Foundation, to fund Wolfson College, the institution Berlin was seeking to establish for graduate education in Oxford.

Of course, Berlin made mistakes. Why deny it? Having myself marched against the war, I would have liked to have seen the great old man arm in arm, with - why not? - Hitchens himself at the head of the demonstrations in which I brought up the rear. But Berlin wasn't there, because he couldn't reconcile his doubts about American policy with his equally strong anti-communism. The same anti-communism led him to impede the academic career in Britain of Isaac Deutscher, the biographer of Trotsky. This loathing for communism and its fellow travellers led him occasionally to betray one set of liberal values for the sake of another. Hitchens never has such conflicts, of course, and so he has no respect for those who struggle to do the right thing.

Anyone younger than 50, anyone who did not cut their teeth on politics in the Vietnam era, might be forgiven for wondering whether any of this matters. Such persons will not much care that I, his biographer, should feel aggrieved that a man I loved should be so traduced, and that a figure of real stature should still be under attack from such pygmies and their poison darts. What may be interesting to people who never knew Berlin is the way these attacks upon him reveal the emptiness of the quarrels inherited from his heyday. It was in the 60s that the new right took up anti-communism and moral fundamentalism as its causes. It was then that the left found its surviving raison d' tre in a loathing for liberal moderation.

What the fate of Berlin's reputation makes so clear is that the ideologies of left and right absolutely required the liberal enemy to give allure to their own poses. But they were poses, and they encouraged a pose in liberals themselves. Liberals came to believe that if they were loathed by both sides, they must be doing something right. Berlin was not immune to this illusion. Being disliked equally by two extremes makes you feel self-righteous, but it doesn't prove you right. Viewing all this through the eyes of a 25-year-old, the whole Kulturkampf of the 60s sounds worn out. The Soviet empire is no more; the left has collapsed; the right is discredited. Liberals might as well confess that we haven't escaped with our reputations unscathed. Liberalism shares the exhaustion of the whole interdependent and collusive trio.

Then the question becomes: in the new configurations that emerge, will there be people who still want to take a sceptical, moderate and wise old Russian Jew as their lodestar? I hope so. Books often have their own revenge on posterity. The volumes of essays he left behind will be read long after the quarrels about his reputation cease to make any sense.

fields.headline: The Saturday Poems
fields.trailText: Timer, Rhetorical Questions and Her News from Hugo William's TS Eliot Award winning collection, Billy's Rain
fields.body:
Timer

The smell of ammonia in the entrance hall.
The racing bike. The junk mail.
The timer switch whose single naked bulb
allowed us as far as the first floor.
The backs of your legs
as you went ahead of me up the stairs.

The landing where we paused for breath
and impatient key searching.
The locks which would never open quickly enough
to let us in.
The green of the paintwork we slid down
as if we had nowhere else to go.

Rhetorical Questions

How do you think I feel
when you make me talk to you
and won't let me stop
till the words turn into a moan?
Do you think I mind
when you put your hand over my mouth
and tell me not to move
so you can "hear" it happening?

And how do you think I like it
when you tell me what to do
and your mouth opens
and you look straight through me?
Do you think I mind
when the blank expression comes
and you set off alone
down the hall of collapsing columns?

Her News

You paused for a moment and I heard you smoking
on the other end of the line.
I pictured your expression,
one eye screwed shut against the smoke
as you waited for my reaction.
I was waiting for it myself, a list of my own news
gone suddenly cold in my hand.
Supposing my wife found out, what would happen then?
Would I have to leave her and marry you now?
Perhaps it wouldn't be so bad,
starting again with someone new, finding a new place,
pretending the best was yet to come.
It might even be fun,
playing the family man, walking around in the park
full of righteous indignation.
But no, I couldn't go through all that again,
not without my own wife being there,
not without her getting cross about everything.

Perhaps she wouldn't mind about the baby,
then we could buy a house in the country
and all move in together.
That sounded like a better idea.
Now that I'd been caught at last, a wave of relief
swept over me. I was just considering
a shed in the garden with a radio and a day bed,
when I remembered I hadn't seen you for over a year.
"Congratulations," I said. "When's it due?"

 These three poems are from Billy's Rain (Faber £7.99), which charts a love affair and this week won Hugo Williams the TS Eliot Poetry Award.

webTitle: Infant classes shrink faster than expected

fields.headline: Infant classes shrink faster than expected
fields.standfirst: EducationUnlimited
fields.trailText: Infant class sizes are falling faster than expected, according to government figures published yesterday as ministers sought to refute Tory claims that they were failing to live up to Labour's manifesto pledges on education spending.
fields.body:
Infant class sizes are falling faster than expected, according to government figures published yesterday as ministers sought to refute Tory claims that they were failing to live up to Labour's manifesto pledges on education spending.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said the number of children in England being taught in classes of more than 30 shrank to 171,000 at the start of the new school year in September.

That was 10,000 fewer than previous estimates and down from 354,000 the previous year and 486,000 at the time of the last election.

"Infant classes of 30 or below was an election pledge. This confirms that we are delivering the goods," he said.

With £600m committed for new classrooms and extra teachers, virtually all under-sevens would be in classes of no more than 30 by September and the programme would be 100% delivered by September 2001.

The new figures included late returns from a survey of local education authorities carried out in September. It showed the average size of an infant class was 24.9 pupils, compared with 25.7 the year before.

Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said the government was using figures for 5-7 year olds to distract public attention from rising class sizes for older pupils.

The row came as the Conservatives launched a fierce attack on the government's spending record.

Ms May used an analysis prepared by statisticians in the House of Commons library to show that planned education spending over the five years since Labour came to power would average 4.7% of national income, compared with an average of 5% over the last five years under the Tories.

"To match their pledge, Tony Blair should be spending an extra £32bn on education, not £19bn. This is a shortfall of an amazing 12.8bn."

Mr Blunkett said the Tory figures ignored the record of spending cuts under John Major. The education budget was cut from 5% of GDP in 1991/2 to 4.7% in 1996/7. According to the public spending programme announced last year, this will have increased to 4.9% by 2001/2. That would fulfil the pledge that education spending should be higher than what Labour inherited.

The grammar school attended by the Tory leader, William Hague, is set to become the battleground for the first ballot under the government's scheme to determine whether local parents want to stop selective education.

Anti-selection campaigners in Ripon, North Yorkshire, said they have obtained the minimum 587 signatures required to trigger a ballot on Ripon grammar school.

Their pro-selection opponents last night asked Mr Blunkett to investigate allegations of malpractice in the collection of the signatures.

fields.headline: Should the internet be regulated?
fields.standfirst:
No: Dr Chris Evans Internet Freedom
Yes: John Carr NCH - Action for Children

Get the most out of the net with Guardian Unlimited's guide to Life online
fields.trailText:
No: Dr Chris Evans Internet Freedom

Yes: John Carr NCH - Action for Children
fields.body:
Dear Chris,
I'm a huge fan of the internet. It is a tremendous human achievement which promises to enrich our lives in all sorts of ways. However, as with many emerging technologies, the internet has brought a few problems in its wake. Bad guys, mad guys and criminals are exploiting its fluidity and potential for anonymity in ways that none of the net's inventors foresaw or intended, and which no civilised society can ignore for long.

In the USA, so far, over 200 men have been sentenced to prison terms for the attempted or actual "sexual solicitation" of minors where the internet played a part in the crime. In the UK, we had the Gary Glitter case, and there are more in the pipeline, even if those involved are not quite so famous.

So it all seems fairly obvious to me. Stand by and do nothing and we risk the emergence of a thousand virtual Mary Whitehouses, who have little stake in the internet, demanding that politicians "do something" to "protect our children" or "get rid of the filth". In Australia, such pressures have already been at work, and it is not hard to imagine how they might take off here.

Attempting to censor the internet's content is not the answer - even if it were possible. However, the industry can and should do more to empower internet users to protect themselves and their loved ones. Inevitably this means we need more and better filtering tools, but that's just another way of saying we need to give people more power and choices about how they use the internet. Now who could possibly be against that?
Yours, John Carr,
Internet consultant, NCH - Action for Children

Dear John,
I agree that internet users need improved technologies. Not just better tools to allow us to exclude material, but better search engines, more usable sites, and faster access.

We should have more power to make choices about the internet. However, "industry self-regulation" has already led to regulatory quangos and internet service providers closing sites and censoring newsgroups. We cannot have the power to make choices about material on the internet if someone else has already decided that we cannot see it.

I know you will probably want to talk about children and pornography in an attempt to justify blocking content - it's the oldest trick in the censor's book - but I'm not just talking about this. Perfectly legal forums have been closed by ISPs including a news site about Basque separatism, a Northern Ireland discussion group and a site criticising Britain's judicial system. All in the name of "self-regulation". The truth is, users are not permitted to regulate what they see; someone else does it for them. Plain old censorship in sheep's clothing.
Yours sincerely, Dr Chris Evans,
Founder, Internet Freedom

Dear Chris,
"Self-regulation" as it exists in the UK internet industry is no more than an organised attempt to ensure that our existing laws are upheld in cyberspace. You may not like those laws, but that's a separate issue. Any ISP that goes beyond what the law requires is doing so in its own name.

The logic of your argument is that ISPs are compelled to carry anything their customers serve up to them: a sort of enforced libertarianism. To do that you would have to give ISPs legal immunity should something go wrong later. Anything short of this takes you back to a position where somebody has to make judgments about what is or is not acceptable - and then you have a self-regulatory system again.

Every branch of our media has some sort of regulatory framework. Why should the internet be any different? And by the way, I thought your comments about children and pornography were rather trite. There are problems. They are not being conjured up from nothing as a ruse to justify greater oppressive controls. To paraphrase Orwell, just because it appears in the Daily Mail doesn't mean it isn't true.

There was a time, not so long ago, when the internet was the exclusive possession of a rarefied group within our universities and research communities. But the internet has moved from the ivory tower to the high street. It takes a rare kind of myopia to believe that the rules that applied in that prelapsarian idyll can survive intact following prolonged contact with the ruder, larger world.
Yours, John

Dear John,
As I have explained, self-regulation has led to ISPs going well beyond the law in removing perfectly legal material. I don't think they are motivated by commercial assessment. There is little evidence that ISPs are losing revenue by failing to censor customers. On the contrary, they lose revenue by closing their accounts. I think they are motivated out of fear of being branded morally irresponsible in a climate where political correctness is the watchword of business.

ISPs are not accountable for what internet users transmit, any more than the post office is responsible for what I write in my letters, or BT is responsible for what I say on the phone. I do not expect them to monitor the contents of my writings and conversations in the name of self-regulation. This is not enforced libertarianism, it is common sense.

What we are permitted to read or see should not be decided by ISPs. The only people that should make judgments about material are readers themselves. We are no less able to make up our own minds than the academics in ivory towers to which you refer. This is the irony of "self-regulation": it's really about someone else deciding what we should see and nothing to do with making judgments for ourselves.
Yours sincerely, Chris

Dear Chris,
I think we have come full circle. Either you believe the internet should have no barriers or restraints in terms of what might be published on it, or you accept that there should be some rules. If you accept that there ought to be some rules, you have one more decision to make: do you simply leave it at that, or do you try to establish some means of giving effect to the rules? In real life, sadly, the former isn't tenable. It merely gives a licence to abusers.

Thus while we might argue about what the rules ought to be, once you concede the point, all that remains is a decision about how you give effect to them. That inevitably means giving someone the power or the duty to make prior decisions. In the UK we have decided to let the industry do it itself. Doubtless if that is found to be unsatisfactory, it can be revisited. So far, in relation to illegal publications on the web, the system seems to be working. But there is a great deal else that needs to be done before the internet can truly be said to be acceptable in the mass market it seems to want to occupy.

In the end I believe that everyone should have a personal internet that suits them. If you want to revel in the anarchic, romantic notions of what you think the internet once was, then that's OK with me. But please don't make me or my children share it with you. Let us make our own decisions about what comes into our home, in the same way our family does about what videos we rent, and where we go for our holidays.
Yours, John

Dear John,
I'm not surprised to hear you say you don't trust individuals to decide for themselves. We should indeed be able to make our own decisions about what comes into our home. The Internet Watch Foundation, on whose board you sit, is a good example of an organisation that prefers to make these decisions for us.

Whilst the IWF is funded by the internet industry, they have the backing of the department of trade and industry, the home office and the police. Their de facto powers far exceed those of the police. They advise ISPs to remove material and ISPs consistently comply. Research conducted for the Institute of Economic Affairs reveals that in the UK 94% of this material is considered by neither judge nor jury. As a consequence, over 9,000 items have been removed from the net despite only 24 successful prosecutions. In their latest announcement the IWF will regulate "criminal racist content". There is no such category under UK law. Presumably the IWF is going to invent new reasons for removing content from the net.

As a non-governmental organisation, the IWF is not accountable to the general public. Net users do not elect board members. Judgments are not made by juries. There's no form of redress for those whose freedom of expression is curtailed. It all makes Mary Whitehouse look pretty tame, don't you think?
Yours sincerely, Chris

webTitle: Scottish tuition fees plan in doubt

fields.headline: Scottish tuition fees plan in doubt
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Proposals to scrap advance payment of tuition fees in Scotland were floundering yesterday after it emerged that they may contravene European law.
fields.body:
Proposals to scrap advance payment of tuition fees in Scotland were floundering yesterday after it emerged that they may contravene European law.

Labour plans to defer payment of the fees by Scottish students in an attempt to keep its fragile coalition with the Liberal Democrats together. But ministers are worried that any deal would open the floodgates for legal challenges from European students studying in Britain and would be unacceptable to Lib Dem backbenchers.

Under proposals being thrashed out by a committee led by the first minister, Donald Dewar, Scottish students would not have to pay the fees until they graduated and found jobs paying more than £25,000 a year. Students from other EU countries would not be entitled to the benefit.

This would leave the Scottish executive open to legal challenges from these student under the European convention on human rights. Last night it emerged that ministers were considering restricting the benefit only to Scottish students at Scottish universities as a way round the problem.

English students in Scotland are not protected by the EU legislation because the devolution anomaly within Britain does not amount to discrimination between one EU state and another. Their having to pay tuition fees no matter what the outcome of any legal challenge could cause a backlash from south of the border.

The only certain way round the legal hurdle would be for the government to waive the £1,000 annual tuition fee paid by the 99,000 European students in Britain. This would leave a bill of almost £100m and would be politically, and financially, unacceptable.

The National Union of Students said it had taken legal advice on the matter but was still keen for the plans to go ahead in Scotland.

webTitle: Parents of bullying victim may sue

fields.headline: Parents of bullying victim may sue
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The parents of a 15-year-old girl who was the victim of a two-year campaign of racist bullying at her school are considering legal action against their local education authority to recover the cost of moving her to a private school.
fields.body:
The parents of a 15-year-old girl who was the victim of a two-year campaign of racist bullying at her school are considering legal action against their local education authority to recover the cost of moving her to a private school.

Debbie Bell was removed from St Michael's Roman Catholic high school in Barnsley, South Yorkshire, after being targeted by a gang of six girls who racially abused and intimidated her.

Her parents, John and Mary Bell, placed her in a fee-paying school and are now being backed by the Commission for Racial Equality in their attempt to force the local council to meet the costs.

St Michael's has recently joined in a new anti-racist campaign, but Debbie, who is of mixed race, described the move as "too little, too late".

Although she now attends the Barnsley Christian school, she said the harassment by the gang had continued.

A spokesman for Barnsley council said: "The LEA is satisfied that its anti-bullying procedures are sound and the appropriate procedures were followed in the case of Debbie Bell. St Michael's made every effort to investigate and follow up allegations that were made of racial harassment."

A spokesman for the CRE said: "We are hoping to reach an amicable settlement with the council over this tragic case."

Mobile phones have created a new form of hi-tech bullying using text messages, it was claimed yesterday. Offenders key in intimidating messages to send anonymously to their victim by withholding their own number.

Martin Watson, head teacher at Lavington school near Devizes, in Wiltshire, ordered all 616 pupils to leave their mobiles at home after a series of threats.

webTitle: Straw to press on with jury trial bill defeated in Lords

fields.headline: Straw to press on with jury trial bill defeated in Lords
fields.standfirst: Are your rights at risk? Find out here
fields.trailText: Both sides in the battle over the right to trial by jury dug their heels in yesterday as Tony Blair and Jack Straw said they would reintroduce the bill defeated this week by the half-reformed House of Lords.
fields.body:
Both sides in the battle over the right to trial by jury dug their heels in yesterday as Tony Blair and Jack Straw said they would reintroduce the bill defeated this week by the half-reformed House of Lords.

The morning after a cross-party coalition of self-confessed "Hampstead liberals" - and even some Hampstead Tories - voted against Mr Straw's plans, the home secretary again told them they were wrong, as he himself had been when he opposed the change before 1997.

He was promptly warned that his criminal justice (mode of trial) No 2 bill would suffer the same fate as the No 1. He declared: "This is one of those issues where many people at first blush take the view I did. But the more you go into it, the more you can see overwhelmingly the case in its favour."

Speaking in east London, the prime minister echoed Mr Straw's insistence that "this is about modernising the criminal justice system. It's about ensuring it is rebalanced in favour of victims and witnesses as well as defendants, while protecting the rights of defendants."

Critics, who include Labour's former liberal home secretary Lord (Roy) Jenkins as well as some high-profile New Labour peers, have called the measure "profoundly undemocratic" and short-sighted, all to save an estimated £100m a year on costly crown court trials.

Yesterday Simon Hughes, Liberal Democrat spokesman and a barrister like Mr Straw, said the government's case - that some defendants in relatively minor theft cases were abusing the ancient right to elect trial by jury and should be dealt with by magistrates - was only "superficially persuasive".

Ministers lost in the Lords, on the very day the Wakeham plan for long term Lords reform was published, by a thumping 222-126 votes, after the Tories changed sides on the issue.

Yesterday Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, tweaked their tail: "Drop this bill completely. After all, it is this government which has said that the current House of Lords has a greater democratic legitimacy than the previous House of Lords. This is their reformed House of Lords."

Critics hope the Commons, especially Labour loyalists, will think hard before passing the No 2 bill this session and, if not, that the Lords will defeat it again. That would allow it to be passed under the parliament acts, but it would be a "very tight timetable", said Mr Hughes.

fields.headline: Madrid car bomb kills soldier
fields.standfirst:
Bombs in Madrid: special report

ETA carries out threat to renew violent struggle for Basque independence
fields.trailText: The Basque separatist group ETA carried out its threat to end a long-running ceasefire yesterday with a car bomb attack that killed a Spanish army officer in the centre of Madrid.
fields.body:
The Basque separatist group ETA carried out its threat to end a long-running ceasefire yesterday with a car bomb attack that killed a Spanish army officer in the centre of Madrid.

Lieutenant-Colonel Pedro Antonio Garcia Blanco, a 48-year-old father of two, died instantly when a car packed with explosives was detonated by remote control as he passed by on his way to work. A 14-year-old girl suffered slight injuries.

It was Spain's first successful terrorist attack since June 1998.

A second explosion, a few minutes later, is thought to have destroyed a getaway car used by the guerrillas.

The first blast yesterday ripped through a central neighbourhood close to the Atletico Madrid football stadium where many military personnel live and which has been the scene of eight ETA attacks. The second bomb exploded close by, next to a kindergarten.

The blasts put paid to any hopes of salvaging a truce, declared by ETA in September 1998, which led to direct talks with the government. With the talks deadlocked, an end to the ceasefire was called on November 28.

Yesterday's murder "was the chronicle of a death foretold", according to a government minister who had warned that it was just a question of time before the killing began again.

"ETA never lies," said the interior minister, Jaime Mayor Oreja. "If it says it's going to do something then it does."

The bombing occurred just four days after Spain's prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, called a general election for March 12 and reiterated that he would not be swayed from the firm stand he has taken on terrorism since coming to power four years ago.

Yesterday he condemned the attack and urged Spaniards to unite against ETA. "When ETA announced it was ending the pause in its terrorist activity, I said ETA was making a mistake," Aznar said on television. "Now is the time to show ETA the consequences of its error."

Mr Aznar authorised informal contacts with ETA when the truce was announced. They led to just one meeting and deadlock. The government promised to move Basque prisoners, in jails across Spain, closer to home and to look at ways of re-integrating members of the group into society if they renounced violence. But Mr Aznar ruled out any political concessions.

Independence-minded Basques were free to pursue their aim of a separate state through existing institutions set up under Spain's democratic constitution, he said. The document, passed in 1978 after General Franco's death, gave Basques and Catalans a large measure of devolution but also guaranteed the unity of the Spanish state.

That wasn't enough for the guerrillas who had been persuaded by the mainstream Basque Nationalist party (PNV), the largest in the region, to abandon violence. Together they demanded formal negotiations based on recognition of Basques' right to self determination, a term taken to mean holding a binding referendum on independence.

To those who accused Mr Aznar of failing to exploit ETA's declining electoral support, dwindling operational capability and concern that they had been isolated as the only major terrorist group in western Europe by the Northern Ireland peace process, he replied that he had no room to manoeuvre short of allowing Basques independence, anath-ema to more than half who want to remain Spanish.

The Basque regional president, Juan Jose Ibarretxe, a member of the PNV, condemned yesterday's attack and announced he was suspending an agreement whereby ETA's political wing worked with the nationalists in the regional parliament. But he also called for dialogue between all parties. "We must not lose hope - the process under way is irreversible," he said.

Arnaldo Otegui, the leader of ETA's political wing, Euskal Herritarrok, and spokesman for those who wanted peace, said he regretted Col Blanco's death. ETA was directly responsible, he added, but all political forces were to blame.

The attack marks a return to tactics used by ETA at the start of the 90s when bombs aimed at military or police targets frequently exploded during rush hour in Madrid. ETA has killed 122 people in the city, and 770 in Spain, since its campaign of violence began in 1968.

When the conservative Popular party came to power in 1996, its local councillors, especially Basque ones, became the main targets.

Protest marches against violence reminiscent of those held after a particularly coldblooded ETA killing in 1997, have been called this weekend. In 1997, 6m people chanted "enough, enough" and many are expected to do so again.

fields.headline: On track
fields.standfirst:
Olympic star leads pack online
onrunning.com
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Brendan Foster, the Olympic athlete turned television commentator, has made his first foray on-line with a website dedicated to athletics, writes John Cassy .
fields.body:
Brendan Foster, the Olympic athlete turned television commentator, has made his first foray on-line with a website dedicated to athletics, writes John Cassy .

Mr Foster's business, Nova International Limited, and Sports Internet, which now specialises in football, statistics and on-line betting, will each own 50% of the site, onrunning.com. It will provide information on big running events from schools level to the Olympic games.

Runners will be able to register for events including the Great North Run, pictured above in 1997 with Liz McColgan, which attracts 40,000 participants. There will be a site selling sports clothing from Mr Foster's View From label. Mr Foster said the site would cater for a group hitherto neglected on the internet.

Sports Internet shares have risen sharply in recent weeks amid speculation of a link with Freeserve or another leading internet service provider. Its contracts to run official websites for 12 Premier League football clubs are seen as attractive to ISPs.

Yesterday profit-taking knocked the shares back by 3.2% to 825p.

fields.headline: Slater collects £69m for web 'critical mass'
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Mark Slater, the 30-year-old son of legendary financier Jim Slater, yesterday raised £69m to plough into fledgling internet businesses.
fields.body:
Mark Slater, the 30-year-old son of legendary financier Jim Slater, yesterday raised £69m to plough into fledgling internet businesses.

Mr Slater, who floated his investment vehicle Internet Indirect in December, issued 200m shares at 35p. The placing was twice oversubscribed.

"The bottom line is that we just want to get on with the job," he said. "Critical mass is very important."

Internet Indirect aims to focus, unfashionably, on companies which are either already profitable or close to making money. The strategy is to invest in companies in areas such as business-to-business e-commerce, media content, software and enabling technologies.

The placing was subscribed by 35 institutional investors, described by Mr Slater as very blue chip. One is computer games business Rage Software, which bought £1m worth of shares and will provide advice on investments in games and software companies.

The new shares dilute Mr Slater's holding in the company from 17% to 6.25%.

Also yesterday, JellyWorks, another internet investment business, announced it had taken stakes in hardware and software firm Com Telco International, digital media TalkCast Corporation and MatchNet, an online dating agency.
