fields.headline: Europe plans dot.com rival
fields.standfirst:
American dominance challenged by '.eu' suffix
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: American dominance of cyberspace will be challenged under plans being considered in Brussels to replace the ubiquitous ".com" suffix with a uniquely-European ending - ".eu".
fields.body:
American dominance of cyberspace will be challenged under plans being considered in Brussels to replace the ubiquitous ".com" suffix with a uniquely-European ending - ".eu".

Erkki Liikanen, the Finnish commissioner for enterprise and the information society, is next month to launch proposals allowing companies and other organisations to have a clearly European identity on the world wide web.

European Union officials say that such a move would allow businesses all over Europe to have their own dedicated internet domain name, dramatically boosting e-commerce within the single market if the proposals are approved.

Websites of EU institutions currently use ".int", which is usually reserved for inter-governmental treaty bodies like Nato and the United Nations.

But ".int", is based in Los Angeles and cannot be used by businesses or cross-border interest groups.

"The feeling is that many companies in Europe are doing business at a cross-border European level and 15 different national monikers don't fit their business strategy," one commission official told the Guardian yesterday. "So '.eu' would be a perfect fit."

In the ever-changing world of domain names, the US has an unshakeable grip on generic ones such as ".gov" and ".mil", though the International Standards Organisation has agreed that ".eu" is a code reserved for the EU, parallel to existing country codes such as ".co.uk", or ".fr".

"If you have a single market of more than 300m people and you've got a European identity and a set of European institutions it flows fairly naturally that companies should be able to identify themselves as being of that market," said Joe McNamee, of Euro-ISPA, a trade association of internet service providers in Brussels.

"If you are a company active in Britain, France or Germany your choices are either to use '.com', which is seen as American, or one of the three relevant country domains.

"But with those each has some difficulty with the other two. So for example if you are using '.co.uk' and you're selling in France you might not get the best reaction."

Mr Liikanen is to begin a series of public consultations to ensure, as businesses and lobbyists report, that there is substantial demand for the change.

Industry sources say they believe if the commission continues to back the idea, ".eu" will be nodded through at the March meeting of Icann, which assigns internet names and numbers.

Member states have warned Mr Liikanen of their concerns about issues such as cyber-squatting and trademark abuse, but the project looks set to roll.

The issue is part of a an initiative called "eEurope An Information Society for All", a key element in plans by commission president Romano Prodi to modernise the European economy.

Mr Liikanen says he wants Europe to learn from the experience of the US, where internet-related companies today account for 2.3m direct jobs - not counting the considerable indirect employment.

webTitle: To Brixton, to meet the brothers

fields.headline: To Brixton, to meet the brothers
fields.standfirst: Boxer takes refuge in police custodyBoxing: special report
fields.trailText: Mike Tyson's status in boxing's heavyweight division may be a matter of debate, but after his visit to Brixton yesterday one thing is certain: the former champion is a better judge of the public mood than Jim Dixon, the leader of Lambeth council.
fields.body:
Mike Tyson's status in boxing's heavyweight division may be a matter of debate, but after his visit to Brixton yesterday one thing is certain: the former champion is a better judge of the public mood than Jim Dixon, the leader of Lambeth council.

On Wednesday Cllr Dixon described Tyson as a "pariah" and said he "was definitely not welcome in Brixton". Yesterday he was proved emphatically wrong as the people of the south London borough turned out to afford Tyson a rapturous welcome.

The boxer brought Brixton to a standstill as he embarked on a chaotic walkabout on the same streets visited in recent years by Muhammad Ali and Nelson Mandela. The 1,000-strong crowd was smaller than that which greeted Ali and Mandela, but the welcome no less enthusiastic.

After a 40-minute walk, mobbed by crowds who were singing, dancing and chanting his name, Tyson had to abandon his tour and take shelter in Brixton police station.

Twenty minutes later, in one of the most incongruous scenes witnessed at the station, a focus for so much of the discontent felt by the local community over the years, Tyson appeared at a top floor window with a megaphone and addressed the crowd.

"They say they don't want me here, right? These council men can't tell me nothin' I don't know about my brothers.

"I have got to go back to training so I would appreciate it if you would let me break out. Thank you very much. Very much. I love you Brixton."

As Tyson lifted a clenched right fist to the cheering crowd, several hundred were raised in reply.

Behind him, his promoter Frank Warren could be seen beaming at the reception his man had received on the sixth day of a trip that had thus far brought only scorn and critical headlines.

The Tyson cavalcade arrived in Brixton shortly after 2pm and stopped in Gresham Road, site of Brixton mosque, which was visited by Ali last year.

Tyson's arrival seemed to catch police under-prepared, and as word spread that he had arrived, reinforcements were quickly called in to protect him from the crowds that flooded into the road, climbed trees and clambered on to the top of buses to catch a glimpse of him.

Before leaving his hotel in Park Lane, central London, Tyson explained why he wanted to visit Brixton.

"There's a lot of people, for my history of Brixton, that murdered people, that went to prison and did some things.

"I've lived there. I've been where these guys have been. You're going to tell someone who's never been where these guys have been and tell them how to live their lives?

"I'm just happy to go there because as a black man anywhere in the world you should always pay homage to the area where your people are."

The idea that Brixton is a haven for murderers did not go down well with local community leaders.

Mike Franklin, chair of the community consultative group for Lambeth, said: "We often have to work against these stereotypes of the area. But every area has its problems and people like me are trying to address those here."

But on the streets the talk was of welcome and forgiveness, and there were few dissenting voices to be heard.

"We like to show Tyson that there are people in Britain who welcome him - he's one of us," said local resident Glen Hilaire.

"We are here to help him lift up his head, move on from his mistakes and get on with the rest of his life."

Gabby Ogbumo, a Brixton resident for 12 years, said Tyson was welcome. "Brixton is a special community and there is a comfort and a welcome here for him.

"Nobody's saying what he did is right but there are a lot worse people around - we had a nail bomb in the High Street last year and nobody has mentioned that man."

In contrast to the criticism Tyson has received from some quarters, Carol Jeffrey, 38, said he was a positive role model. "He means a lot to black kids because he is proof that a black man can fall low but still lift himself up again. Just because Lambeth councillors don't want to see him doesn't mean we don't."

Percy Blake, who arrived in Brixton from the Caribbean in 1962, was less convinced that Tyson's visit merited press attention.

"I hear that 80% of us in Brixton are supposed to have a criminal record," he said. "One more surely won't make much difference."

After Tyson's dramatic exit from the police station in a riot van led by police horses, Mr Dixon stood by his views.

"Tyson still stands for violence against women and makes a clear contrast with great men like Ali and Mandela who the council have welcomed in the past."

But as Mr Franklin had to admit: "He is a hero to people, whether we like it or not."

"We are here to help him lift up his head, move on from his mistakes and get on with the rest of his life." Gabby Ogbumo, a Brixton resident for 12 years, said Tyson was welcome. "Brixton is a special community and there is a comfort and a welcome here for him. "Nobody's saying what he did is right but there are a lot worse people around - we had a nail bomb in the High Street last year and nobody has mentioned that man." In contrast to the criticism Tyson has received from some quarters, Carol Jeffrey, 38, said he was a positive role model. "He means a lot to black kids because he is proof that a black man can fall low but still lift himself up again. Just because Lambeth councillors don't want to see him doesn't mean we don't." Percy Blake, who arrived in Brixton from the Caribbean in 1962, was less convinced that Tyson's visit merited press attention. "I hear that 80% of us in Brixton are supposed to have a criminal record," he said. "One more surely won't make much difference." After Tyson's dramatic exit from the police station in a riot van led by police horses, Mr Dixon stood by his views. "Tyson still stands for violence against women and makes a clear contrast with great men like Ali and Mandela who the council have welcomed in the past." But as Mr Franklin had to admit: "He is a hero to people, whether we like it or not." webTitle: NHS pledge will need 6% a year

fields.headline: NHS pledge will need 6% a year
fields.standfirst: Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The government will have to increase health spending by an unprecedented 6% a year to fulfil Tony Blair's pledge to bring funding of the NHS up to the level in Europe
fields.body:
The government will have to increase health spending by an unprecedented 6% a year to fulfil Tony Blair's pledge to bring funding of the NHS up to the level in Europe, the Guardian can reveal.

Treasury officials are warning No 10 that the prime minister's commitment to spend 5% a year more on health will only close one third of the gap with the rest of the EU.

Whitehall number crunchers working on this summer's comprehensive spending review have spent the week calculating the financial implications of Labour's promises on health which they reckon will mean spending an extra £11bn.

They are aware that a 5% rise would only increase health spending by £4.5bn and take the share of national income accounted for by the NHS to 7.2% from the current level of 6.8%, leaving it well short of the European average of 8%.

To match levels in comparable European economies will require an even larger mobilisation of resources by Gordon Brown. According to the treasury, the government would have to increase health spending by more than 8% a year to compete with Germany and France. Only Ireland spends less on health than Britain.

The realisation that 5% real, inflation-adjusted increases in health spending will not be enough to bring funding of the NHS up to the level in the rest of the EU helps to explain No 10's backtracking over Mr Blair's comments on The Frost Programme last weekend.

Other ministers fear that the scale of the commitment to the NHS will leave little in treasury coffers to meet public concern over transport, education and law and order.

webTitle: Searching for a cure to financial ills of the NHS

fields.headline: Searching for a cure to financial ills of the NHS
fields.standfirst:
John Appleby: Economist says it all comes down to choices - tough ones
Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Poets, said Shelley, are the unacknowledged legislators of mankind; but economists are the unacknowledged legislators of our health service.
fields.body:
Poets, said Shelley, are the unacknowledged legislators of mankind; but economists are the unacknowledged legislators of our health service.

John Appleby, who works for the King's Fund, went into health economics 20 years ago when it was a tiny field. There were five people studying it in his year at York, the only university that offered a degree in the subject. Yet these are the experts whose specialised knowledge determines what is probably the biggest issue in domestic politics today. There are far more health economists working for the big drug companies than for the NHS.

"British health economists are self-selecting," he says. "They are people who didn't like the macro side of economics or the market side. American health economists are much more market-oriented. But in this country when Margaret Thatcher brought in the so-called internal market, suddenly the hospitals were turning to the health economists and asking how to price their services - and all the economists they turned to knew nothing about markets. It is a bit of a relief that government policy has moved away from that area."

As he talks about his work, two ideas are constantly struggling within it. The first is that the big strategic choice to have a taxpayer-funded NHS was the right one, and should be maintained. "In the very long run you can either have a system like the NHS where you pay in advance and everyone can afford it; or you can have another system. There are some big choices here. In this country we have already taken the choice not to go with the market mechanism, and to take the collective insurance route."

But this means, he says, that the crises in the NHS are going to be chronic. "One of the things universal systems are bad at doing is arriving at some equilibrium between what individuals accept and what the system can collectively provide. It's a trade-off. Being fairer and more equitable may bring with it things like waiting lists."

So you are an economist who is meant to be on the side of inefficiency? "Yes, if you caricature economists as people who want to see the most efficient allocation of resources." But that is not really a caricature. It is a large part of the other idea that he keeps returning to: that an economist's job is like a civil servant's - not to make decisions, but to identify the decisions that have to be made.

"Markets privatise rationing decisions. But we are now trying to turn that inside out and expose them in a rather public way." He gives as an example research he did recently to find out what the public really thought about how choices should be made about treating people. "Basically they think the money should go to human beings who are going to have the potential to live longest. Health economists have made themselves quite unpopular by taking this rather utilitarian line - that we should put the money where it can buy most health: we have been told that we discriminate against the elderly and so on. But when you do go on to ask the public, at least hypothetically, they agree."

This sort of knowledge must be a nightmare to politicians, and not only because the health of someone else's mother against that of her child is not going to get the same answer as a real question about the health of a voter's mother versus a stranger's child.

"I once met Robin Cook, when he has the opposition spokeman on health. We were talking about this sort of thing and suddenly he snapped at me 'That's politics. I'm the politician. Leave that for me.' But a lot of economics encroaches on other fields. We are falling into philosophy all the time: how do I understand what my opinion is? How do I know what I think about some matters?" He sounds more comfortable as an an unacknowledged legislator than an executive.

webTitle: Chechen millionaire sets up peace moves

fields.headline: Chechen millionaire sets up peace moves
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The prospect of preliminary peace talks between Moscow and Chechnya may soon be realised through the intermediary figure of a powerful Chechen millionaire.
fields.body:
The prospect of preliminary peace talks between Moscow and Chechnya may soon be realised through the intermediary figure of a powerful Chechen millionaire.

Malik Saidullayev, who heads the pro-Moscow Chechen state council created by the Russian government last autumn, held talks this week with four influential Chechen warlords, who had travelled to Moscow in an attempt to broker peace. He claimed that the four - Sulimi Mamadayev, Salautdin Abalayev and two others whom he refused to name - represented up to 7,000 Chechen fighters.

Elsewhere, mystery still surrounded the fate of the missing Russian general, Mikhail Malofeyev, with the military tersely stating yesterday that General Malofeyev was on neither the lists of the dead nor of those taken prisoner. But a Chechen commander claimed that Gen Malofeyev had been taken prisoner and was undergoing interrogation.

"Malofeyev is absolutely healthy and is answering investigators' questions," Baudi Bakuyev was quoted as saying by the Interfax news agency.

He said the Russian military would soon receive a videotape proving the Chechens were holding the general.

The persuasive Mr Saidullayev also held separate negotiations with Russia's hawkish chief of general staff, Anatoly Kvashnin, yesterday. And, in their aftermath, he has arranged to meet the Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov, at the beginning of next week.

The main aim of the Maskhadov meeting, he said, would be to persuade the Chechen president to cut all ties with the three leading Wahhabi warlords, Shamil Basayev, Khattab, and Abi Barayev.

Mr Saidullayev claimed yesterday that he had the power to unite up to 80% of Chechnya's warlords, although it remains to be seen how well-founded this confidence is.

As casualty figures soar, the acting Russian president, Vladimir Putin, is under mounting pressure to resolve the Chechen conflict well before the March 26 presidential election. Pressure from the west for political negotiations to begin has also intensified, and Mr Maskhadov has repeatedly stressed that he is ready to talk.

But with the army set on pursuing the war to a definitive conclusion and Mr Putin's popularity so closely tied to the military's advances into Chechnya, suggestions of a negotiated settlement have, until now, been rejected.

Chechnya's warlords could be persuaded to switch to the Russian side if they were offered a guarantee of security and a role in the post-war administration, Mr Saidullayev argued.

"We need peace. There were once a million Chechens, but now after two wars... we don't have the people or the resources to fight this war," he said. "After three or four more years of this kind of war, the nation may cease to exist altogether."

fields.headline: Terminological inexactitude
fields.trailText: Smallweed
fields.body:
This week in G2, the Guardian asked several librarians what they watched on TV. The curious thing about the replies was that some of those who had views on the subject unexpectedly commended TV's neglect of libraries. "Should there be programmes with libraries?" Charles Fisher inquired of himself. "No, not really," he replied. "I do like the fact that you don't get any librarians on TV," Carol Cooper confessed. "Not even detectives."

I find this attitude deplorably selfish. Look at it this way: if television gave us more programmes about librarians and actors dressed up as librarians, there would have to be fewer programmes about the police and people dressed up as the police, which at present is most programmes.

I suspect the point about detectives is, anyway, wrong. I don't go in for this kind of fiction myself, but I always understood that most fictional murders took place at house parties, and that house party murders usually take place in the library. For educational reasons, I favour a series in which every episode opens in just such a library where Inspector Stealth is staring hard at a corpse. " I must say," his sidekick, Constable Sidekick, observes, surveying the groaning shelves, "these people seem deuced keen on reading." "And rightly so," the inspector tells him, in terms of Morse-like rebuke, pulling a book from the shelf. "By Jove! Here's a first edition of Aphra Behn."

Apart from a moment when the corpse is carted away to the mortuary, the whole of the rest of this episode would then be taken up with discussing the works of Aphra Behn and how to get hold of them from your library. Stealth, by the way, will be played by John Thaw and Sidekick by Ginger Evans.

Some television producers, hopelessly set in their ways, might recoil from this concept, claiming it lacks excitement. And indeed, it is sometimes said by librarians that their duty (to sit at desks telling people where to find Debrett, the Decameron, or the latest JK Rowling) is sadly lacking in thrills.

But Smallweed has plans for that, too. A second library series would concentrate on the works of paralibrarians, the profession's equivalent of paramedics. It would show them, for instance, parachuting in to the gardens of elderly housebound people with the latest Catherine Cookson or Irvine Welsh. I dare say, to boost the ratings, a librarian devoid of a bra would hang around just long enough to organise a makeover of their bookshelves. In Smallweed's view, this sort of cross fertilisation is far too rarely practised in television and we cannot have too much of it.

According to a BBC reporter, the Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson has been lavishing "fulsome praise" on the RUC, as he explained to the Commons his plans to change it into something else. I fear it is now too late to save the word fulsome from meaning simply "full". You would not catch the Guardian making such a mistake, since those who misuse the word have been soundly rebuked by the Readers' Editor. The rest of the world, unhappily, does not respond to his threats. It was pretty clear from the context that the BBC reporter did not intend to imply that Mandelson was "cloying, causing surfeit, nauseous, offensive, gross, rank, disgustingly fawning". He is not David Frost. But that, even so, was the verdict he gave to the nation.

I have drawn attention several times to the practice of Conrad Black, proprietor of the Daily Thongograph and Spectator, in festooning his publications with people called Johnson. My catalogue has been incomplete. In this week's Spectator, the crossword editor confesses that he is a Johnson too.

Yet another big cup tie (Leicester v Arsenal) is settled by an inane penalty shootout, and this despite Smallweed's compelling proposal for replacing them with a formula which would benefit the game by discouraging clubs from filling their sides with foreign players. The England coach, Kevin Keegan, this week declared his dismay at the implications of this importational tendency for the future of English football. What I proposed was this: where teams are level at the end of extra time, the tie should be awarded to the side whose players were born least far from the ground. At the time this was mindlessly disparaged on the grounds that one could not expect a referee at the end of 120 minutes to demand the players' birth certificates and start computing the relevant distances.

But that objection is now, as Roy Jenkins would say, otiose, disposed of by a brilliant initiative on the part of Guardian Sport. Every Monday, an analysis appears of players' birthplaces. Last Monday, for instance, the featured side was Barnsley. Its players were born an average of 436 miles from its Oakwell headquarters. In Arsenal's case that figure would have been nearer 1,500 and Wednesday's match would have been awarded to Leicester City. I hope to have Kevin Keegan's endorsement by the end of next week.

I was wrong about Churchill using "terminological inexactitude" as a euphemism for "lie". An erudite letter from Cambridge quotes a speech he made in the Commons in 1906 on Chinese labour in South Africa. The contracts involved might not be proper or healthy, he said, but they could not, in the government's view, be classified as slavery in the extreme acceptance of the word "without some risk of terminological inexactitude". The error is corrected in volume two of Randolph Churchill's life of his father (finished by Martin Gilbert). I was hoping to find room this week for some further discussion of haddock sandwiches, but in the interests of historical scholarship I have given terminology pride of place. I await the plaudits of pedants.

webTitle: Hit the kids - but don't smack the pony

fields.headline: Hit the kids - but don't smack the pony
fields.standfirst: "My opinion pols are very clear: practically everyone wants greater protection for foxes than for children - that is the British way"
fields.trailText: "My opinion pols are very clear: practically everyone wants greater protection for foxes than for children - that is the British way"
fields.body:
One of this week's newspaper accounts of the consultation document on the corporal punishment of children said that the government approved of parents smacking their children's bottoms, but only if they did it "in a loving way". I have seldom heard anything more creepy. Anyone who can smack a child in a loving way has something seriously wrong with him or her.

There are many accepted ways of showing love, but smacking has never been one of them. In the normal course of events, a child gets smacked only when it has behaved in such a way as temporarily to forfeit a parent's love. Usually, the smacking is quickly followed by parental feelings of remorse and rapid restoration of the suspended affection, demonstrated by a big hug.

The idea that the smacking itself can be a loving act is most unwholesome. In fact, I find it impossible to justify any form of corporal punishment that is carried out coldly, with the child's improvement as its only purpose. For smacking to be acceptable, there has to be an element of anger involved. The child must have driven its mother or father to a point of exasperation at which no other response seems possible. Smacking is a parental cry for help. It is a message to the child, saying, "Please stop baiting me, please don't wind me up; I just can't handle it any more." And smacking can be effective in getting this message across to the child, provided, of course, it is not overdone. The absolutely essential quality in parents who resort to smacking is to be able to express their anger spontaneously but with instinctive self-control.

Dr Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, clearly disagrees with all that. He shares with many people in this country the traditional view that the corporal punishment of children is a vital disciplinary tool. Commenting on the government's proposal to legislate against it in all its forms except for the infliction of mild pain by hands on bottoms, Dr Fox tried to give the impression that the government wanted to ban smacking, too. At any rate, what he said was, "Smacking children to teach them the difference between right and wrong is often a necessary, if painful, task." This is in line with the claim schoolmasters used to make in the days when they were still allowed to beat their pupils - that the beating hurt them more than it hurt the child. Few people ever believed them then, and few people are likely to believe Dr Fox now when he portrays corporal punishment as a painful parental duty that is only performed for the good of the child.

As the Guardian has chillingly noted, statistics show that at least one child dies in Britain every week from physical injuries inflicted by an adult, whereas in Sweden, where corporal punishment of any kind has been illegal for more than 20 years, only four children have died of such treatment during that entire period. The contrast is startling, and it would seem to reinforce the case of those who would have us follow the example of the six European countries that have already banned smacking. As with the zero-tolerance policy imposed by New York's Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, who claims to have reduced serious crime in the city by clamping down on tiny offences such as dropping litter, perhaps serious assaults on children would be reduced in Britain by banning even the gentle smack on the bottom. It would certainly concentrate people's minds to know that striking a child in any fashion might land them in jail.

On the other hand, there are strong arguments against such a ban. One is that even more British people think parents should be allowed to smack their children than the majority who want to ban fox-hunting. The opinion polls are very clear on this. Practically everyone wants greater protection for foxes than for children. That is the British way. Another reason for keeping smacking legal is that we don't want to criminalise too many parents. The polls showing 85% in favour of the right to smack children over the age of five and 53% in favour of the right to smack children over two suggest that an awful lot of parents must be doing it.

In short, I think that the government's proposals are about right. Striking children with implements of any kind, and hitting them anywhere except on their bottoms, should, indeed, be forbidden. When I was four, I was spanked by my father - the only time I can remember him doing it - for repeatedly disturbing my mother while she was ill. To this day, it is not the spanking but the fact that he did it with a slipper that I resent. When it comes to ordinary smacking, it should be left to the courts to decide when excessive violence is used. But the courts should be especially harsh towards any parent who claims to have done it "in a loving way".
fields.bodyText: One of this week's newspaper accounts of the consultation document on the corporal punishment of children said that the government approved of parents smacking their children's bottoms, but only if they did it "in a loving way". I have seldom heard anything more creepy. Anyone who can smack a child in a loving way has something seriously wrong with him or her. There are many accepted ways of showing love, but smacking has never been one of them. In the normal course of events, a child gets smacked only when it has behaved in such a way as temporarily to forfeit a parent's love. Usually, the smacking is quickly followed by parental feelings of remorse and rapid restoration of the suspended affection, demonstrated by a big hug. The idea that the smacking itself can be a loving act is most unwholesome. In fact, I find it impossible to justify any form of corporal punishment that is carried out coldly, with the child's improvement as its only purpose. For smacking to be acceptable, there has to be an element of anger involved. The child must have driven its mother or father to a point of exasperation at which no other response seems possible. Smacking is a parental cry for help. It is a message to the child, saying, "Please stop baiting me, please don't wind me up; I just can't handle it any more." And smacking can be effective in getting this message across to the child, provided, of course, it is not overdone. The absolutely essential quality in parents who resort to smacking is to be able to express their anger spontaneously but with instinctive self-control. Dr Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, clearly disagrees with all that. He shares with many people in this country the traditional view that the corporal punishment of children is a vital disciplinary tool. Commenting on the government's proposal to legislate against it in all its forms except for the infliction of mild pain by hands on bottoms, Dr Fox tried to give the impression that the government wanted to ban smacking, too. At any rate, what he said was, "Smacking children to teach them the difference between right and wrong is often a necessary, if painful, task." This is in line with the claim schoolmasters used to make in the days when they were still allowed to beat their pupils - that the beating hurt them more than it hurt the child. Few people ever believed them then, and few people are likely to believe Dr Fox now when he portrays corporal punishment as a painful parental duty that is only performed for the good of the child. As the Guardian has chillingly noted, statistics show that at least one child dies in Britain every week from physical injuries inflicted by an adult, whereas in Sweden, where corporal punishment of any kind has been illegal for more than 20 years, only four children have died of such treatment during that entire period. The contrast is startling, and it would seem to reinforce the case of those who would have us follow the example of the six European countries that have already banned smacking. As with the zero-tolerance policy imposed by New York's Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, who claims to have reduced serious crime in the city by clamping down on tiny offences such as dropping litter, perhaps serious assaults on children would be reduced in Britain by banning even the gentle smack on the bottom. It would certainly concentrate people's minds to know that striking a child in any fashion might land them in jail. On the other hand, there are strong arguments against such a ban. One is that even more British people think parents should be allowed to smack their children than the majority who want to ban fox-hunting. The opinion polls are very clear on this. Practically everyone wants greater protection for foxes than for children. That is the British way. Another reason for keeping smacking legal is that we don't want to criminalise too many parents. The polls showing 85% in favour of the right to smack children over the age of five and 53% in favour of the right to smack children over two suggest that an awful lot of parents must be doing it. In short, I think that the government's proposals are about right. Striking children with implements of any kind, and hitting them anywhere except on their bottoms, should, indeed, be forbidden. When I was four, I was spanked by my father - the only time I can remember him doing it - for repeatedly disturbing my mother while she was ill. To this day, it is not the spanking but the fact that he did it with a slipper that I resent. When it comes to ordinary smacking, it should be left to the courts to decide when excessive violence is used. But the courts should be especially harsh towards any parent who claims to have done it "in a loving way".

fields.headline: Hattie Jacques? Phwoar!
fields.trailText: Channel surfing
fields.body:
What can one say of Hattie Jacques? "She was a great gravy maker," said one friend. Can't we do any better than this? "I mean, I've never been able to make gravy in my life, but she had this enormous tin into which she_" Yes, yes. Get on with it. "and she had this enormous spoon and she'd be stirring and putting in pepper_" Is there much more of this? "And she always had a cigarette in her mouth." Mmm, I see. I believe I'm on the point of spotting the punchline. Something to do with fag ash as seasoning, perhaps? And so it turned out. Surely, if you're going to have a programme presumptuously entitled The Unforgettable Hattie Jacques (ITV), you have to do better than this.

Let's try again. In one of the Carry On films (she appeared in 14 of them), Jacques breathed in and filled her matron's starched uni form. Kenneth Williams breathed in through flared nostrils and barely filled his pigeon chest. It was a very arch moment, and four impossibly raised eyebrows rather proved the point. "The younger birds may be soft and tender," Matron told Dr Williams, saucily, "but the older birds have more on them." With that she wafted out. Williams inflated his nostrils still further and eyed her departing back narrowly: "True, and they need a lot more stuffing."

And again, in another Carry On, to sarcastic, elephantine tuba music, Jacques stood sadly on a pair of scales: "Who would have thought that a cow would have made all the difference?" Pah, pah, paaaah, commented the tuba.

Despite the gravy and stuffing, this was an unexpectedly affecting memoir. Best of the talking heads was Bob Monkhouse: "Her career was greatly helped as regards regular employment by her weight," he recognised. He realised, too, though, that her comic talents were hardly exploited: most Carry Ons were written by jokesmiths rather than script writers, by men who couldn't create living, breathing characters to save their lives.

Throughout that career, she was the fat woman on the receiving end of the obvious punchline. Like Mollie Sugden as Mrs Slocombe, Jacques was always the battleaxe, hungry for sex but doomed to a life of frustration. And like Sugden, Jacques was pitted against the pneumatic dolly. For Sugden it was Wendy Richard as Miss Brahms; for Jacques, it was Barbara Windsor as pert as you like in a bikini. Instead of sex, Jacques would have to learn to reconcile herself to a career of put-downs from Bernard Bresslaw and his ilk.

Worse, for 19 years Jacques was Eric Sykes's on-screen sister. As Monkhouse noted, in Sykes she had to create a role for herself; Sykes's scripts only offered a foil for the funny man. Nonetheless, she was still the sex-starved loser: in one scene from Sykes he spotted a lonely hearts ad with a familiar phone number. "Good-looking women don't put their numbers in the paper," said Sykes. Hang on, though. What was that noise? The phone ringing. A call for the good-looking, slender woman whom Jacques had invented for the ad. "Hello," she breathed into the receiver. For that moment she was Marlene Dietrich, though more louche.

Life was not like her screen roles, not like that unlivable existence imagined by male screenwriters. Friends queued up to tell what a sensual sexpot she was in real life, and to reveal that men, unimagined by the writers of Carry On and Sykes, fancied her rotten. Which was nice. She left that eternal faded public- school playboy John Le Mesurier for an entrepreneur called John Scofield. The home-movie footage of her new lover showed him to be a hunk - in winter, square-shouldered and granite-jawed in a camel coat; in summer, a Greek god striding through the surf in negligible trunk. This was the reality, and this was the kind of man Jacques loved. Ironic, eh? Pah, pah, paaah.

fields.headline: Laughter lines
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
So James Boyle is leaving Radio 4 in great shape? Ha ha ha - that's the best joke heard on the network in ages. He clearly hasn't been tuning in to Radio 4's comedies. By the end of last year I had begun to doubt that I would ever again laugh immoderately - hell, even titter - during a radio comedy.

But then, some time over Christmas, coming upon The Comedy Store, I found so many signs of merriment I resolved to squirrel some away for the new millennium. Reader, I've already drawn heavily on my store. But it's a curious fact that the very comic responsible for my laughter over Christmas has caused my disappointment in the New Year. Have I changed - or has he?

The comedian is Boothby Graffoe, who, over Christmas, made the first recorded hilarious joke about Indonesia. When he repeated it in his own show, The Big Booth, it barely registered. Likewise his Johnny Cash spoof song, The Birdman, was un- side-splitting second time round.

Now, you could argue that no joke tastes good reheated. Yet this can't be true, or there wouldn't be such a market for cassettes of old radio comedy programmes.

Graffoe's audience was less inclined towards hilarity, too. And his own performance had slowed considerably, lacking the sharp edge that characterised his Comedy Store gig. But isn't this where the skills of a producer are supposed to come into play?

Just when I was beginning to fear that my stash of old laughs wouldn't last the month, along came Revolting People - a sitcom set in Baltimore in 1770, during the American War of Independence. Imagine pitching that to a controller: who but Woody Allen or Mel Brooks would stand a chance? The extraordinary thing is that Jay Tarses, the chap who plays the hero, shopkeeper Sam Oliphant, and is also co-writer, sounds very like Allen himself.

Indeed, this is Baltimore as seen from Brooklyn. Oliphant is a self-deprecating loser who, as he fends off English troops, tries to avoid telling his daughter that her fiance is a pompous prat, and fails to sell any of his wares. He is all bathos and crisp punchlines. There are some pretty predictable gags, but Tarses is terrific.

More wit came from The O'Show, a comedy sketch show billed as featuring "the cream of Ireland's new comedians". With sketches about decommissioning and confession, they're clearly declaring that nothing is out of bounds. I particularly enjoyed the gag about the website that allows virtual marching for Oranges. Their use of catchphrases is canny, too. "I had you - I don't believe you fell for that", is the gleeful Irish cry whenever they manage to dupe their peers, no matter how solemn the occasion.

Everyone wants to be the new Goodness Gracious Me, but this show has a legitimate claim in that direction. Perhaps Radio 4 comedy is beginning to pick up after all.

Finally, Talk Radio may have relaunched as Talk Sport, but they haven't shed the ranting Derek Hatton. Someone should tell him about the invention of the microphone, for he obviously still believes that the only way for him to be heard in Kilmarnock or Chipping Sodbury is to SHOUT.

fields.headline: Bobbies on the bleat
fields.standfirst: The Royal Ulster Constabulary has always been a ridiculous name Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, announcing the partial implementation of the Patten report on the future of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, told the Commons that he changed its name with a heavy heart. He likes it, but those pesky papists don't.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, announcing the partial implementation of the Patten report on the future of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, told the Commons that he changed its name with a heavy heart. He likes it, but those pesky papists don't.

Mandelson is a consummate Labour politician, always blaming someone else. I'm sure that privately he says, "I agree, but my hands are tied", to whomever he is speaking at the time. He tells us that, if it were up to him, he'd keep the name, but changing it is the only way to get Catholics to join. So, it's their fault, then. Perhaps if Ronnie Flanagan had submitted an alternative recruitment strategy, such as holding Catholics for seven days and forcing them to sign the application forms, the name might have been spared.

Since the name is such a treasured one, let us look at its derivation and connotations. Before partition, its predecessor was the Royal Irish Constabulary. Then Britain faced the problem of a colony in which a clear majority wanted independence. London realised that changing the name of the place to Shropshire would not be enough to persuade the Irish that Britain had a right to rule them. Unfortunately, our answer to the problem was to draw a line through the country, guaranteeing mayhem for the future.

Four counties in the northern province of Ulster had a unionist majority. That would make for a titchy place indeed, so another two were lumped in and the statelet christened Northern Ireland. Three Ulster counties were left out, meaning that, although widely used, Ulster has never been an accurate synonym for Northern Ireland.

Now, are Northern Irish constables royal? What services do they provide by appointment to the Duke of Edinburgh? Here I risk feed ing the fevered imaginings of Mohamed Al Fayed in relation to Diana's fate, so let us concentrate on the Queen. By swearing allegiance to Elizabeth II, how does anyone indicate that they will do their job properly? It might suggest that the person would enjoy the Last Night of the Proms or that they collect porcelain figures from Sunday magazines, but what does it have to do with fighting crime? Surely, at the very least, all Royal pledges should be modernised to incorporate the words "but it's all those hangers-on I don't like". In fact, it would be best if all such oaths were swept away, making it possible for people such as my daughter to join the Brownies.

Speaking of nippers, I notice that Patten's suggested name, the Northern Ireland Police Service, has been changed round to prevent the prospective acronym taking hold. But it's nice to see the word "service" still there, and the RUC shouldn't be worried by it. It doubles as a euphemism for branches of the armed forces, after all.

However, the RUC regards the change as a sop to nationalists, a view to which Mandelson responds by saying that he agrees but his hands are tied. Ken Maginnis, who you could sometimes be forgiven for thinking was the RUC's parliamentary spokesman, fumed that the IRA has not changed its name. Perhaps the IRA should dub themselves the Royal Society for the Eventual Reunification of Ireland, just to see if it persuades unionists to calm down about decommissioning.

Ken Maginnis made an interesting contribution on Radio 5 when the director of public prosecutions announced that no police officers would be prosecuted for making death threats against Rosemary Nelson.He accused Rosemary of disrupting the RUC's investigation of the murder of Robert Hamill. What investigation was that, I wonder? Witnessing a violent assault and allowing the perpetrators to loiter for an hour and then go home must have been a cunning piece of surveillance intended to lead detectives to Mr Big. Gathering no evidence after the attack and waiting until the morning to tape off the crime scene, officers were perhaps encouraging anyone in possession of such evidence to come forward and leave it there - confidentially. Arresting no one for two weeks, detectives must have been waiting for Mr Big to make his move.

The DPP has decided that police involved in this case should also escape prosecution. And both the Nelson and Hamill families, who are demanding judicial inquiries, are up against the fact that the Ulster Unionist party will brook no investigation or criticism of RUC officers under any circumstances. Rather than accept that there are serious questions to be answered in both cases, Blair will calculate whether increasing the confidence of nationalists in the justice system will risk upsetting the UUP too much.

I'm sure that in private, British ministers say that in an ideal world everyone would have all the inquiries they want, but that these things cost money. Blair would probably threaten that the money would have to be diverted from RUC resources. On the evidence, inquiries would offer better value.

Royal Ulster Constabulary
Police Authority for Northern Ireland
The Patten Commission

fields.headline: Tony's terrible week
fields.standfirst:
Blair thought he could spin it all better. Big mistake

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is in his third season as prime minister and the question after this week's events is whether he is going to be a flashy newcomer who ended up not playing for England for as long as he should have.
fields.body:
The locker-room consensus in professional sport is that young players should be judged not on their first and second seasons but on their third and fourth. The rookie with a few unusual shots or exceptional speed can impress early on. But the wily bowler spots that the prodigy is vulnerable to a particular ball, the veteran defender learns where to stand to block a run. The oldsters talk about a player being "found out".

Tony Blair is in his third season as prime minister and the question after this week's events is whether he is going to be a flashy newcomer who ended up not playing for England for as long as he should have. This was the week Blair's trademark talents seemed to abandon him. A politician famous for his control of the media and his party was embarrassed or abandoned by the press over the NHS and Mike Tyson, by his party over trial by jury and the mayor of London and by pretty much everyone over House of Lords reform. Is this just a few bad days in office or a sign that his days are darkening in general?

Politicians' problems and eventual failure often follow from a single weakness which, in psychology, would be called the governing flaw but, in politics, can easily become the un-governing one. What did for Nixon (from Watergate to Cambodia) was a paranoid obsession with secrecy. Most of Thatcher's crises (from Westland to the poll tax) followed from a domineering arrogance which created enemies who would later rise against her.

This Shakespearean rule of political destiny is at its purest in those leaders whose dominant characteristic was an asset while seeking office but became a liability once picked. John Major is a good example. The ability to suggest that he agreed with whoever he was meeting won him the Tory leadership. But this chameleon ideology in office eventually turned every section of the party against him.

Blair may be another who's discovering that the nice bright coat which got him noticed is beginning to chafe. At the heart of the Blair modernisation of the Labour party was the belief that perception matters more in politics than reality. After Kinnock failed to win in 1992 with supposedly voter-friendly policies, Blair and his then-friend Brown explained to colleagues and journalists that it was no good changing policies if you failed to change the perception that Labour was dangerous. Blair's obsession with presentation was the logical result. But what Blair discovered this week is that spin works better for elections - where the currency is promises - than for legislation, where voters expect their hands to be filled as well as their ears.

Most aspects of Blair's terrible week result from the motivating belief that perception overrides reality. Despite knowing what Lord Winston had embarrassingly said about health provision, Downing Street apparently believed that it could create another meaning for his words. Blair's pledge on the NHS in the Frost interview turns out to have been a campaign tactic - the sanctimonious promise - stupidly used to resolve a problem in power.

Another smart presentational method - the Royal Commission on House of Lords reform, chaired with symbolic inclusivity by a Tory, Lord Wakeham - has collapsed at the point where gesture must become effect. And the apparently deliberate attempt to distract newspapers from the NHS crisis by publicising the Mike Tyson immigration decision failed because the tale became another source of hostility.

Admittedly the House Of Lords defeat of the proposal to reduce the right to trial by jury does not immediately seem a problem with presentation. It could even be regarded as the opposite: a willingness to stick with a radical and potentially unpopular policy. Blair's changes to the rights of defendants were a matter of reality rather than perception.

But even that fiasco links to Blair's central weakness. Deranged by his opinion poll performance, he overestimated his presentational skills, his ability to convince doubters. He made this mistake as well in believing that the announcement declaring his opposition to Ken Livingstone as London mayor would hinder his candidacy.

The irony in this is that Blair's approach to the premiership has most often been described as presidential. This meant to imply the identification of a government with an individual and a preference for the egotistical ceremonial over the humbling tussle of the House of Commons.

But - as recent American history has demonstrated - another definition of a presidency is that the leader remains glamourous and even admired but is unable to get anything done and becomes a grinningly impotent figurehead. In America, this results from deliberate checks and balances exacerbated by the tendency of voters to back different parties at state and national level. A US president can at least use this congressional veto as an excuse: I had the idea but they wouldn't give me the money. A pretend president within a parliamentary system is forced to admit: I had the idea but I wouldn't give it the money. Although presidents liked to claim that the buck stopped there, for premiers it really does.

In a speech yesterday, Blair blamed his difficulties on people who disliked change. But - like the young sports star who finds that the circuit has become wise to his flashy originalities - Blair needs to show that he can change his game.
fields.bodyText: The locker-room consensus in professional sport is that young players should be judged not on their first and second seasons but on their third and fourth. The rookie with a few unusual shots or exceptional speed can impress early on. But the wily bowler spots that the prodigy is vulnerable to a particular ball, the veteran defender learns where to stand to block a run. The oldsters talk about a player being "found out". Tony Blair is in his third season as prime minister and the question after this week's events is whether he is going to be a flashy newcomer who ended up not playing for England for as long as he should have. This was the week Blair's trademark talents seemed to abandon him. A politician famous for his control of the media and his party was embarrassed or abandoned by the press over the NHS and Mike Tyson, by his party over trial by jury and the mayor of London and by pretty much everyone over House of Lords reform. Is this just a few bad days in office or a sign that his days are darkening in general? Politicians' problems and eventual failure often follow from a single weakness which, in psychology, would be called the governing flaw but, in politics, can easily become the un-governing one. What did for Nixon (from Watergate to Cambodia) was a paranoid obsession with secrecy. Most of Thatcher's crises (from Westland to the poll tax) followed from a domineering arrogance which created enemies who would later rise against her. This Shakespearean rule of political destiny is at its purest in those leaders whose dominant characteristic was an asset while seeking office but became a liability once picked. John Major is a good example. The ability to suggest that he agreed with whoever he was meeting won him the Tory leadership. But this chameleon ideology in office eventually turned every section of the party against him. Blair may be another who's discovering that the nice bright coat which got him noticed is beginning to chafe. At the heart of the Blair modernisation of the Labour party was the belief that perception matters more in politics than reality. After Kinnock failed to win in 1992 with supposedly voter-friendly policies, Blair and his then-friend Brown explained to colleagues and journalists that it was no good changing policies if you failed to change the perception that Labour was dangerous. Blair's obsession with presentation was the logical result. But what Blair discovered this week is that spin works better for elections - where the currency is promises - than for legislation, where voters expect their hands to be filled as well as their ears. Most aspects of Blair's terrible week result from the motivating belief that perception overrides reality. Despite knowing what Lord Winston had embarrassingly said about health provision, Downing Street apparently believed that it could create another meaning for his words. Blair's pledge on the NHS in the Frost interview turns out to have been a campaign tactic - the sanctimonious promise - stupidly used to resolve a problem in power. Another smart presentational method - the Royal Commission on House of Lords reform, chaired with symbolic inclusivity by a Tory, Lord Wakeham - has collapsed at the point where gesture must become effect. And the apparently deliberate attempt to distract newspapers from the NHS crisis by publicising the Mike Tyson immigration decision failed because the tale became another source of hostility. Admittedly the House Of Lords defeat of the proposal to reduce the right to trial by jury does not immediately seem a problem with presentation. It could even be regarded as the opposite: a willingness to stick with a radical and potentially unpopular policy. Blair's changes to the rights of defendants were a matter of reality rather than perception. But even that fiasco links to Blair's central weakness. Deranged by his opinion poll performance, he overestimated his presentational skills, his ability to convince doubters. He made this mistake as well in believing that the announcement declaring his opposition to Ken Livingstone as London mayor would hinder his candidacy. The irony in this is that Blair's approach to the premiership has most often been described as presidential. This meant to imply the identification of a government with an individual and a preference for the egotistical ceremonial over the humbling tussle of the House of Commons. But - as recent American history has demonstrated - another definition of a presidency is that the leader remains glamourous and even admired but is unable to get anything done and becomes a grinningly impotent figurehead. In America, this results from deliberate checks and balances exacerbated by the tendency of voters to back different parties at state and national level. A US president can at least use this congressional veto as an excuse: I had the idea but they wouldn't give me the money. A pretend president within a parliamentary system is forced to admit: I had the idea but I wouldn't give it the money. Although presidents liked to claim that the buck stopped there, for premiers it really does. In a speech yesterday, Blair blamed his difficulties on people who disliked change. But - like the young sports star who finds that the circuit has become wise to his flashy originalities - Blair needs to show that he can change his game.

fields.headline: England's not for weeping
fields.standfirst: "Apparently, it would bode better for my health if I were to 'kiss and embrace corpses', as the ever-estimable 'other cultures' do"
fields.trailText: "Apparently, it would bode better for my health if I were to 'kiss and embrace corpses', as the ever-estimable 'other cultures' do"
fields.body:
My mother died last week. Shut up at the back, there. I know that you're whispering, "Oh no - she only just stopped banging on about her father dying, and now we're going to be treated to her mum's untimely demise in 50 episodes, too!"

Well, no, you won't be, because it was the shortest, sweetest heart attack in history. This isn't going to be one of my "poor me" pieces, but rather an essay on the elegance and appropriateness of the English way of death, which I think gets rather a bad press these days - not least from George Monbiot in this very newspaper last week.

In my mother's case, her death is also a testament to the devotion of the English working classes to their pet animals. When my father died 14 months ago, one of the last things he said to my mother was to be sure to look after the dog, a cheerful mongrel called Benny. Some months ago, the dog became ill with tumours, which was what my dad had died of. On January 8, Benny joined the majority. On the 10th, my mum followed him.

There seems to be something so inevitable, so cosy, about this that an untoward show of grief would seem selfish and silly. It hurts to be stuck here like a lemon without them but, hey, you have to try and take the long view.

"Are you in shock?" some of my friends have asked me, but I don't reckon I am. I've had a good snivel, alone or with my boyfriend - and you do feel a bit better afterwards, like a radiator that has been bled. However, my very warm, very kind, very working-class extended family made it clear to me within an hour of my mother's death that blubbing en général wasn't the thing to do at all.

"You're going to have to be a bit braver than this, Julie!" snapped my Auntie Dolly, a saint of a woman, when I tried it on when we were driving home from the hospital.

"Y-y-yes," I stuttered like a brave little soldier. Then I blurted, "Auntie Doll, do you believe in an afterlife?"

"No!" came the answer from the front seat. "Once you're dead, you're dead!"

I went mulishly silent at this. "There is too an afterlife!" I thought to myself. I believe very much in life after death, very much in the conventional mode of soft mists and eternal content, and can easily imagine my mum, dad and dog romping through some celestial meadow together, like in some Timotei advert. I suspect that I may have spent too much time at Sunday school as a child, but too late to change that now. It keeps me happy - and, anyway, I'm not the one rushing out in search of grief counselling.

The thing is that not giving in to grief does actually make you feel happier. You know that the dead person wouldn't want you to be sad and - supposing I'm right and there is an afterlife - it's going to be raining on their parade a bit, to say the least, if they're up there having the time of their (after) lives and they can see you, whom they loved, carrying on like Niagara down here, isn't it?

I'd started out whining, "I can't do anything! I don't know what to do!" and yet, after just a little bit of a scolding, I had the funeral booked, the organ, cornea and skin transplants signed for and going ahead, and the death notice in the paper, all within 24 hours.

What I'm saying is, if I can do it, anyone can - and they don't half make you feel better, all those formalities and tidying-up jobs.

But, according to George Monbiot, I'm not doing myself any favours. In his opinion, it would bode a lot better for my future mental health if I were to "kiss and embrace corpses, wailing and keening, paying tribute to the undeniably dead", as the ever-estimable "other cultures" do.

His argument reminded me of a Victoria Wood joke that was intended to show up the passionlessness of the British: "In India when a man dies," she said, "his widow throws herself on the funeral pyre. Over here, she says, 'Fifty ham baps, Beryl - you slice, I'll butter.'"

But in reality, of course, those widows are thrown on to their dead husbands' funeral pyres - they don't jump. I know which alternative I prefer, and also which shows the most respect for life.

Later in the same article, Mr Monbiot approves warmly of the Dani people of West Papua, for whom the dead, he explains, are everywhere. Apparently, when the living sit around at home of an evening, they leave spaces for all of the dead members of the family, and even give them as much tobacco and as much food as they give to the living.

I'm sorry, but I just do not believe this. For instance, where do they draw the line? Surely, as time goes on, there is simply not enough room for all the dead Dani ancestors to crowd into those modest-sized huts of their living relatives - it's not for nothing that they are called "the majority", after all. Also, I'm sure that food and tobacco aren't so plentiful in West Papua that the Dani can afford to waste it nightly on a bunch of fussy eaters - ie, the Dead. What's more, I really don't see why I should respect this tradition any more than I would a childless western couple who nevertheless leave out a mince pie and a glass of Bailey's Irish Cream for Santa Claus every December 24.

Far from suggesting an ease with death, such gluts of weeping, wailing and generally having the ab-dabs - whether in Mexico, Mombasa or Morecambe - surely signal its exact opposite: a childish refusal to accept death as part of life, but rather to view it as something that is perpetually shocking and upsetting. The British way of death, on the other hand, says simply that life goes on. You slice, I'll butter.

This is not life-denying; instead, it is the most life-affirming notion that the human heart can hold; that we all - living and dead alike - go on together, and that nothing can really divide us. A socialism of souls, if you like.

There may well be some pretty unfortunate consequences of English "repressing" - though judging from the general state of mental health in let-it-all-out America, this seems increasingly debatable - but our hands-on, heads-down, get-on-with-it attitude to death is not, I think, one of them.

fields.headline: Defending their gravy
fields.trailText: Your report on arts spending (Arts Council a bottomless pit, say MPs, January 20) refers to "a £9m overspend on the £57m Royal Albert Hall refurbishment" as one of the worst examples of lack of spending control on our Arts Council lottery project. This is misleading.
fields.body:
Your report on arts spending (Arts Council a bottomless pit, say MPs, January 20) refers to "a £9m overspend on the £57m Royal Albert Hall refurbishment" as one of the worst examples of lack of spending control on our Arts Council lottery project. This is misleading.

In 1998 the budget for the project was increased to £66.3m from the £55.7m estimate made three years earlier at the time of application for lottery grants. This was a conscious decision to ensure the project delivered its objectives in terms of quality and public benefit. It did not reflect loss of control and was not an overspend. The programme is on time and budget. The Royal Albert Hall has never asked for additional lottery grants and is confident it can provide all the partnership funding required to complete its development programme.
David Elliott
Chief executive, Royal Albert Hall

 The Arts Council is certainly not a bottomless pit. Our lottery capital programme is heavily over-subscribed and we have to reject half of all applications. We only award supplementary grants after rigorous scrutiny. We monitor projects closely - and if we have concerns we take immediate action. The Public Accounts Committee looked at a report by the national audit office into 15 of our largest, most complex and earliest lottery awards. They represent less than 1% of the awards we have made. All the recommendations made by the NAO have been implemented. Since the lottery began we have continuously improved our procedures to ensure our limited funds are well spent.
Peter Hewitt
Chief executive, The Arts Council of England

 So London is swallowing nearly all arts sponsorship money from the business world? (Regions lose out in arts dash for cash, January 18) The fat cats are in central, not regional London.The ability of London-based national organisations to raise fortunes, and to spend considerable sums in doing so, will be much enhanced when the treasury brings in its intended tax write-off for arts donations in April.

That would be fine if government funding redressed the balance for the smaller organisations who can't afford fundraisers. However, the signs are not good. In the next financial year the government has increased the grant by £10m to the Arts Council, which has managed to find £7.5m for 10 organisations in metropolitan London. This prompts the usual refrain "It's the rich wot gets the gravy".
Philip Hedley
Artistic director, Theatre Royal Stratford East London

fields.headline: Wakeham's failings
fields.trailText: By proposing the new second chamber be a part-time one where members turn up when they have something worthwhile to say and do not regard their role as a full-time job, the Wakeham commission has flunked one of the big tests (Dismay at Lords plan, January 21).
fields.body:
By proposing the new second chamber be a part-time one where members turn up when they have something worthwhile to say and do not regard their role as a full-time job, the Wakeham commission has flunked one of the big tests (Dismay at Lords plan, January 21).

Too often the Lords was seen as a retirement home for politicians past their prime. The reformed chamber, if this model is ever adopted, will continue that tradition, denying the ability of those without another income and those whose work does not allow them to pop along for votes from their London offices to make a meaningful contribution.

The report is very clear that the movement from second chamber to Commons should be as difficult as possible. Yet no mention is made of movement the other way which, in the interests of political expediency and the cooperation of the politicians on the appointments panel, will probably continue to be all too swift.
Alex Folkes
London

 The Wakeham commission's proposals have all the elan of the proverbial horse designed by a committee. In all but its largest option, the commission has proposed to tals of elected members smaller than any suggested during the reform process. Even the 195 (described as "hardly a runner" by Michael White shared proportionally between the regions, will produce a north-east "delegation" of only nine members. With party divisions and natural attrition it is difficult to see how coherent representation of regional points of view can emerge.

The lowest option, of 65 seats, will return scarcely three members from Tony Blair's home region. With an average population per member of over 900,000 this representation is sparser than for MEPs. It is questionable how such representatives can communicate with their electors, let alone undertake to maintain a regional contribution to the country's governance.
Derek Long
Liverpool John Moores University
urbdlong@livjm.ac.uk

 It is a pity that John Wakeham does not demonstrate the courage of his erstwhile colleague Chris Patten, since it is the significance of the name of the House of Lords that needs to be challenged most of all in this whole process of reform.

It would seem that an op portunity has been lost to distinguish the notion of "honours" among which the granting of a peerage is paramount, from the need to create an effective second chamber. The symbolism of the current designation "Lords" demonstrates the deep and unfortunate deference widely held by English people that power somehow descends from on high, through the sovereign in parliament; hence the term "upper house" which is clearly a nonsense.

Let the peers as such get on with their life, for richer or poorer. But let us have a second chamber which represents the people, whose functions are what determines its composition rather than the other way about.
The Rev Peter Brain
United Reformed Church

 In order to justify the retention of the bishops in the House of Lords, the Wakeham report counts the number of people baptised in the Church of England - 25m according to Wakeham - as a true measure of its support. There could hardly be more economy with the truth. Every survey conducted over the new year (and there were at least six) showed that up to a third of the population now define themselves as unbelievers.

To claim that the Church of England has tens of millions of supporters is an indication that the commission may have had an element of vested interest.
K Porteous Wood
National Secular Society

 If every religion and "faith" has to be represented in a reformed upper house, can we also have a representative from each secular rational philosophy: utilitarianism, structuralism, pragmatism, positivism, phenomenology, humanism, existentialism, behaviourism, etc, etc?
Andrew Belsey
Cardiff
Belsey@Cardiff.ac.uk

fields.headline: Ghost writer
fields.trailText: Mahler's ghost must have interfered with the transcription of my obituary on Hedy Lamarr (Corrections, January 21). Of course it was not Gustav Mahler, but Alma Mahler and her second husband, Franz Werfel, whom Lamarr entertained in the 1930s.
fields.body:
Mahler's ghost must have interfered with the transcription of my obituary on Hedy Lamarr (Corrections, January 21). Of course it was not Gustav Mahler, but Alma Mahler and her second husband, Franz Werfel, whom Lamarr entertained in the 1930s.
Ronald Bergan
London

 Guardian Diary (January 21) suggests that I needed external advice on when to be angry. I can assure you that I was well pissed off by Ken Livingstone's latest antics before talking to colleagues. I topped a one-member, one-vote ballot of over 10,000 Labour party members in my area of south London. It is incredible that a candidate for selection as mayor should attack prospective Labour Assembly candidates in this way.
Cllr Valerie Shawcross
Leader, London Borough of Croydon

 Contrary to the assertion (January 15) that you cannot marry a pair of chimpanzees, I can bear witness to the wedding of a pair of orangutans (Oscar, originally from Chester zoo and Wilhelma from France) at Liberec zoo in the Czech Republic on August 21, 1997. They are now proud parents.
M A Dolan
Welwyn, Herts

 I'm a visitor not a customer (Dust off fusty image, museums told, January 19). Fusty museums provide a refuge from a hyped world of encroaching interactive crap. If you need a fix of non-content content - visit the Dome.
Tim Shore
London

 Simon Hoggart is wrong to suggest that the young Jack Straw did not appreciate the Rolling Stones (Sketch, January 15). I vividly remember him leaping up and bopping enthusiastically at a post-NUS conference party in Bradford to either The Last Time or It's All Over Now.
Nigel Thomas Fishguard, Dyfed

fields.headline: Pipped by a carrot cake
fields.trailText: Ours is the first British company to design and distribute an electric-battery-powered bicycle to the UK market and so we applied to the Design Council to recognise it as an official millennium product.
fields.body:
Ours is the first British company to design and distribute an electric-battery-powered bicycle to the UK market and so we applied to the Design Council to recognise it as an official millennium product.

According to the Design Council, millennium products must be "pioneering in their field, forward-thinking, challenging, creative and innovative". Other criteria of selection include the necessity to open up new opportunities, challenge existing conventions, be environmentally responsible, demonstrate the application of new or existing technology, solve a key problem and show clear user benefit.

Others in the run to millennium products included, to name only a few, millennium stamps (application of new technology?), Viagra (opens up new opportunities?) and a 96% fat-free carrot cake.

How can a 96% fat free piece of carrot cake be in the same race as an electric bicycle and win? According to the millennium product list, approved by our government, the very best of British innovation, creativity and design, lies in a piece of carrot cake

Can someone give us a real explanation of this or shall we revert to a fat-full piece of chocolate cake?
Nick Child
Bath

fields.headline: Equal deals
fields.trailText: Ros Coward depicts specialist schools as selective havens for the middle-class (Creaming them off, January 18). Schools with a specialism are able to select 10% of their pupils by aptitude. This is a deliberately modest percentage and very few have used the provision to vary their admission procedures.
fields.body:
Ros Coward depicts specialist schools as selective havens for the middle-class (Creaming them off, January 18). Schools with a specialism are able to select 10% of their pupils by aptitude. This is a deliberately modest percentage and very few have used the provision to vary their admission procedures.

Specialist schools are about diversity in the comprehensive system and improvements in teaching and learning. One third of the annual funding for the programme is to be spent for the benefit of other schools and the wider community. As to results, many of the schools which have contributed most to the percentage improvements in GCSEs are serving deprived areas such as Birmingham, Brent, Newham, Tameside and Trafford.
Estelle Morris
Minister for School Standards

 Ros Coward sounds a warning about how the specialist schools policy has been applied in inner London, but she fails to reflect the situation on the ground.

Of Gloucestershire's 42 secondary schools, 10 have developed specialisms - seven in technology, two in languages and one in sports. None of them has ceased to operate as a genuine comprehensive. All offer an education to children in their localities, regardless of aptitude or ability. They have developed specialisms that build upon their existing strengths, to counter the effects of social disadvantage, and to pull in much needed resources to a county that is poorly served by government's assessment of our need to spend.
Roger Crouch
Shire Hall, Glos

fields.headline: The lessons of section 28
fields.trailText: Kirsty Scott's otherwise excellent piece (New parliament, same old prejudice, January 21) on the need to repeal section 28 does reveal a worrying fact. Everyone has swallowed the rightwing Tory lie that section 28 is about the promotion of homosexuality in schools.
fields.body:
Kirsty Scott's otherwise excellent piece (New parliament, same old prejudice, January 21) on the need to repeal section 28 does reveal a worrying fact. Everyone has swallowed the rightwing Tory lie that section 28 is about the promotion of homosexuality in schools.

Section 28 forbids the "promotion" of homosexuality (amongst other measures) by a local authority. In effect this could mean that a public library should not contain the works of Shakespeare or Oscar Wilde or that anything connected with gays and lesbians should not attract the support of a local authority.

Section 28 is a wide-reaching and all-embracing piece of legislation designed to discriminate and prevent any understanding of lesbians and gay men. It is worthwhile remembering that both the Thatcher government and the supporters of section 28 refused to offer a definition of the term "promotion of homosexuality".

Without any doubt, lesbian and gay pupils face horrific bullying in schools and the repeal of section 28 would at last give teachers the opportunity, through the promotion of education and understanding, to end such appalling discrimination. It is incumbent upon us to make certain that homophobia is stopped in its tracks because the damage it inflicts casts a shadow across every single one of us.
Michael Cashman MEP
