fields.headline: The magic starts to fade
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair is no longer walking on water now
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Over the past week or two some famous organisations have had to own up to worse than expected trading over the Christmas and new year period. Marks & Spencer was one, Sainsburys another. But an even more eminent name now deserves to appear on that list: that of her majesty's government.
fields.body:
Over the past week or two some famous organisations have had to own up to worse than expected trading over the Christmas and new year period. Marks & Spencer was one, Sainsburys another. But an even more eminent name now deserves to appear on that list: that of her majesty's government.

Tony Blair yesterday was philosophical: these things are sent to try us, he said; what matters is to have a vision, and to pursue it. Almost all the evidence suggests the country is happy with him and his team. The economy has rarely looked bonnier. And yet things are clearly wrong in several departments. It is not the fault of the foreign office that we are selling arms to Zimbabwe at this wholly inappropriate moment, but it has certainly blown a huge hole in Robin Cook's ethical foreign policy. John Prescott, who came to office determined to be tough on traffic and tough on the causes of traffic, has been forced to retreat. The home office looks like a battlefield: here, the dispatch of Pinochet, on medical grounds we are not allowed to see; there, Tyson admitted on unquantified "compassionate" grounds; down the road, a woolly uprising in defence of trial by jury, inflicting a defeat which has wrecked the home secretary's bill. His minimalist approach to Labour's election pledge on freedom of information is part of the same disease. Mr Straw is a decent man, but his use of "liberal" as a term of abuse - even when qualified by "woolly" and "Hampstead" - suggests contempt for a system of values close to the heart of the Labour movement and much of the Labour vote. The rise in crime reported last week is a serious blow for the government's claim to be better at handling crime than the Tories. We have to hope it will not tempt Mr Straw into further reactive illiberalism.

Problems like these undermine a government's reputation for competence. They also set ministers squabbling. It does real harm when some ministers publicly urge us towards the euro while others keep mum and still others are plainly sceptical; when some departments want to sell arms and others are out to stop them; when the prime minister, promising generous help for the the beleaguered NHS, leaves other departments fearful for their allocations and the treasury in a torment over the implications for its spending programme.

When troubles like these become evident in so many parts of a store, shareholders start asking questions about top management. The same applies to a government, especially one as dependent as this one on its leader and those around him. Though some of this government's troubles may be fleeting and easily curable, others seem to reflect a philosophical uncertainty at the heart of the project: nowhere more so than in its handling of constitutional change. New Labour, new Britain, involves a radical assault on the forces of conservatism everywhere, but especially those which shape our government structures. So Labour came in with the promise of perhaps the biggest constitutional shake-up in history. Scotland and Wales were to have a form of home rule. London first, then other cities, would elect their own leaders. That wretched anachronism, the right of hereditary peers to speak and vote in parliament on no other qualification than their privileged birth, would at last be expunged. Even first-past-the-post would no longer be sacrosanct. But New Labour's instincts pull in different directions: one way towards devolution, the other towards control. So self-government for Wales - but don't choose Rhodri Morgan. A mayor for London - but you must not pick Ken Livingstone. A reformed second chamber - but not one which will cause us trouble. Mr Blair's reaction to defeat by the Lords over juries tells us all we need to know about his motivation there. "Profoundly undemocratic," he calls it. What he wants is a second chamber which can always be called "profoundly undemocratic" when it stands in the way of what the government wants. Therefore it can't be elected.

There is, in Mr Blair as well as in Mr Straw, too much impugning of opponents' motives, so that anyone who differs becomes a force of conservatism. There is also duplicity. You could see the best of Tony Blair in his reaction on Sunday when asked about the case of a woman dying because her operation for cancer was four times postponed. He looked genuinely troubled. That, he said, is my responsibility; I have to see it does not occur again. That moment of candour, that total absence of self-exculpation, was worth any amount of highly paid spin-doctoring. Yet gradually, the public discovers it is being lied to; that the extent of the flu epidemic is being played up to make the NHS crisis look exceptional rather than routine; that despite government claims to the contrary, Lord Winston did say what the New Statesman claimed he said about the NHS.

Mr Blair is right: it is the vision that counts. You can find abundant evidence, in the pledges to deal with poverty, in Gordon Brown's commitment to redistribution (even if, to the government's shame, it cannot admit it because of its hang-up on taxes) that the kind of vision the left was looking for all those years is still there amidst all the centrist rhetoric and centrist practice. But when Mr Blair tries to dismiss the government's troubles as if they were local difficulties, we should not be fooled, and neither should he. To return to the high street parallel: there's no Tesco just down the road in this story, no vibrant, coherent opposition. The Tories, and not only on Europe, are a coalition that has collapsed. Faced with an issue causing real public distress, the state of the NHS, their only response is to yak away about giving the private sector its head. That this government seems, even now, to be steaming ahead to further success reflects its real merit. But it also reflects a Tory opposition which is serving Labour's interests as faithfully as Labour, in its turmoils of self-indulgence, served the Tories through much of the 80s.

fields.headline: Schism begets schism
fields.standfirst:
Scotland's famously fissile wee frees
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The free kirk - the wee frees - have been embroiled in a bitter split for over a decade. Yesterday marked another chapter in the unedifying spectacle of a tiny church tearing itself apart. Thirty-one ministers - about a fifth of the church's ministry - have left after they were suspended for breaking ecclesiastical law.
fields.body:
The free kirk - the wee frees - have been embroiled in a bitter split for over a decade. Yesterday marked another chapter in the unedifying spectacle of a tiny church tearing itself apart. Thirty-one ministers - about a fifth of the church's ministry - have left after they were suspended for breaking ecclesiastical law. Plenty more legal wrangles over churches, manses and money lie ahead. The battles through the courts will be accompanied by plenty of theological spin; the departing ministers of the free church defence association (FCDA) claim the split is over an issue of principle derived from the Westminster confessions which were drawn up by Oliver Cromwell in 1648. But the truth of this sorry tale is that these ministers could never reconcile themselves to the decision of the Edinburgh sheriff court in 1996 to throw out the sexual harassment case against one of the free church's most passionate orators and least conventional theologians, Professor Donald Macleod. The court concluded then that the professor had been the victim of a church plot.

The twists of this story fit neatly into Scottish ecclesiastical history which is littered with embittered parties pursuing schisms usually in the name of an elusive concept of purity. Indeed the free church started life in the disruption of 1843 in a battle with the church of Scotland over the power of landlords rather than congregations to appoint ministers and the perceived encroachment of the state on the spiritual independence of the church. The present battle is being conducted in a contemporary idiom - sexual harassment claims in a secular court - but it is a replay of the quest for purity; this time the breakaway faction are rejecting the accommodation with modernity that Professor Macleod had come to represent. To the 12,000 wee frees in their strongholds in the Hebrides and western highlands, the professor's advocacy of hymns in addition to their traditional psalm singing and his attendance at ecumenical meetings with catholics was evidence of how contemporary urban culture could corrupt. The wee frees felt beleaguered by modernity and have a laager mentality akin to close theological relatives - the Dutch reformed church in South Africa and Ian Paisley's free presbyterians.

To anyone outside the narrow reach of the free kirk, the dispute is as bizarre as the church's beliefs and practices - such as the strict sabbatarianism which even forbids hanging out your washing on a Sunday. The irony is that such wrangles will only hasten the very eventuality which causes most concern amongst the elders: the slow but seemingly inexorable decline of their number in line with Scotland's shrinking number of churchgoers.

webTitle: A long hard road for carers

fields.headline: A long hard road for carers
fields.trailText: Looking after someone else's money can be a legal - as well as a relationship - minefield. It is easier to cope with when the person who needs help is in full control of their mental faculties but cannot carry out certain tasks due to a physical disability.
fields.body:
Looking after someone else's money can be a legal - as well as a relationship - minefield. It is easier to cope with when the person who needs help is in full control of their mental faculties but cannot carry out certain tasks due to a physical disability.

According to Penny Letts, who wrote Managing Other People's Money, regarded as the most accessible book on the subject, people who are mentally competent can make "informal arrangements".

These can include:

Setting up joint accounts where either signatory can gain access

Authorising someone else to use a bank or building society account on your behalf. This can be coupled with a limit on withdrawals

Appointing someone as an agent - often to collect pensions and other benefits at the post office.

The beneficiary can cancel these measures at any time.

Granting someone power of attorney to act on your behalf is a step up. It is often used by those with limited mobility, by people who may spend periods in hospital and by those who might be forgetful but otherwise have full possession of their faculties.

The donor - the person giving the powers - completes a form available from legal stationers. This sets out the limits and can be withdrawn at any time. It cannot be signed by anyone with a mental disability and becomes invalid if the donor loses their mental capacity.

The donor could also grant an "enduring power of attorney" while still lucid. This can either allow the attorney to continue when the donor has mental health problems or to act only if they become incapable. Until then, the power can be revoked.

Once the donor reaches a level of mental incapacity, the power has to be registered with the Public Trust Office which is controlled by the Court of Protection. This is done by the attorney whose application does not need to be supported by medical evidence.

The application must be sent to at least three of the donor's closest relatives who can object.

The Court can appoint a receiver of its own choice if there are doubts.

Managing Other People's Money. £9.99 from Age Concern, 1268 London Road, London SW16 4ER

webTitle: Scandal of elderly mugged by post

fields.headline: Scandal of elderly mugged by post
fields.trailText: Stories of elderly folk losing their cash to phoney gas, water and electricity workers who gain access by claiming there is a dangerous leak, are all too frequent.But less well publicised  are the "legalised muggings"  from sources ranging from home improvement salespeople to phoney overseas lotteries as well as commission chasing life insurance agents.
fields.body:
Stories of elderly folk losing their cash to phoney gas, water and electricity workers who gain access by claiming there is a dangerous leak, are all too frequent. Despite warnings from police and neighbourhood watch groups, these incidents still appear almost weekly in local papers.

But less well publicised - although involving far more money - are the "legalised muggings" the elderly can suffer from sources ranging from home improvement salespeople to phoney overseas lotteries as well as commission chasing life insurance agents.

Next week, Help the Aged's Mervyn Kohler will chair a conference on Advising The Elderly Client where lawyers and those involved in care will discuss how best to protect an ageing population that is becoming richer. One in 14 is now aged over 75; the proportion will rise to one in nine by 2025. Better pensions and home ownership have increased the wealth of many older people.

Unlike child protection, where rules on how to deal with anyone aged under 18 have become far more stringent, those governing the elderly - especially those who may be confused or physically disabled - remain sketchy, open to different interpretations, and inadequate, say those who take care of elderly relations.

Equally, those involved with older people say they should have the liberty to make their own mistakes - and there is always a danger that rapacious relatives and friends will exploit weak moments.

Nigel Waskett, a doctor from Newport, south Wales, spends several hours a week trying to save an elderly great-aunt of his first wife from her "foibles". She has a history of mental illness and has shown irrational behaviour from time to time over the past 40 years.

Now, after years of trying to sort out her affairs to her best advantage, he wants a change in the law so that a contract signed with someone over a certain age and over a set value would not be valid unless there was a third party present.

His first difficulty came from a double glazing seller who persuaded her to buy a £12,000 conservatory which did not fit the house. After £700 had been spent on legal fees to recover the £2,000 deposit, the firm had gone bust.

Charity Age Concern, published a consultation paper on "combating cowboy builders" last year. It says: "old people can be daunted by the complicated process of seeking a reliable builder." It is critical of building trade bodies setting up their own accreditation schemes but believes there should be a list of reputable contractors backed by identity cards.

The conservatory was just the tip of the iceberg, Dr Waskett says; it is a major job trying to protect her from herself. "The system is frustrating. You can wave legal papers; some take a lot of notice and are sympathetic while others ignore you."

She suffers from an addiction to illegal lotteries and phoney prize schemes. Last week, she received 46 letters about such schemes at her home. But the way banks reacted to it varied from helpful to offering the old lady more cash to feed her lottery craving. In one week alone, she spent £431.

Although she was going through chequebooks in a week, HSBC let her build up an overdraft of £3,500, gave her a credit card and then suggested she took out a personal loan.

The Standard Life policy was designed for a high immediate payment but was worthless when the holder died - there was no guarantee of a minimum payout.

Ms Parsons says: "She was blind in one eye, and had a cataract on the other. She would not have been capable of reading the small print. She ticked the wrong box. My late father was very ill and died nine months later. The loss on the £40,000 policy was around £36,000."

Last September the north London accountants had to pay fines and costs totalling £16,500 when an Institute of Chartered Accountants tribunal upheld complaints from this case. But the family's attempt to gain compensation has run into a legal dead-end. Ms Parsons says: "I feel guilty that I was not there. I shall never forgive myself. She should have had someone to help her."

But legal protection and restrictions have to be balanced against civil liberties of the elderly, including the freedom to spend their money in ways others might think unwise. "It's a very complicated legal and policy area," says Alexandra Mason, a lawyer specialising in enduring power of attorney and court of protection issues.

"You can start from the proposition that the elderly can be vulnerable but you must still recognise that they may be capable of managing their finances and property as well as someone younger."

Governments of both complexions have been wrestling with the issue of elderly and other people who are not in full possession of their faculties. A Law Commission report in 1995 was followed by a consultation paper Who Decides in 1997. Firmer proposals came late last year in Making Decisions and looked at:

* Defining mental capacity and the person's best interests - around one in five 80 year olds has some degree of mental power loss, according to Help the Aged;

* Replacing enduring powers of attorney with continuous powers of attorney - the old system limits powers to money and property, while the proposed continuous system would extend to medical care and daily life issues;

* Modernising the court of protection so it could resolve disputes about a person's mental condition.

But these will be enacted only "when parliamentary time allows" and offer no help to the vulnerable as opposed to the "mentally incapacitated."

At Help the Aged, Mervyn Kohler says "there will be reforms at some stage, but don't bet on when. The whole area is one that people do not want to talk about and it's never the most urgent issue."

Mr Kohler believes that the law surrounding enduring powers of attorney can present problems, especially when the subject is "devious". There is no central register or clearing house so those with the powers have to show their papers to everyone.

One idea would be to copy the driving licence scheme with its compulsory renewals for the over 70s and insist on regular checks on anyone over 70 to see if they are still capable of signing financial and other contracts. The government could also set up a "public guardian service, though that would be costly.

But the Human Rights Act, which comes into force this October, could throw the whole issue in the air. It will establish that the rights of the individual are paramount, including the right to live an unfettered life and enjoy one's property.

So it could be extremely difficult to persuade someone to give up their financial and other powers. Any system that limits these rights could be challenged in the courts.

webTitle: Disentangle your tax worries on the web

fields.headline: Disentangle your tax worries on the web
fields.standfirst: Patrick Sherwen provides a user's guide to financial help now available on the internet
fields.trailText: Patrick Sherwen provides a user's guide to financial help now available on the internet
fields.body:
Even if you are one of the 3.5m people who has submitted, or will submit in the next 10 days, a tax self-assessment form before the deadline, there is some bad news: it is time to start all over again.

Once the form is in and the tax year 1998-99 just an unpleasant memory, the financially prudent will already be at their desks working out how to save as much money as possible in the next one. There is no better way to take advantage of available tax allowances, and make the most of opportunities to offset one liability against another, than to start tax planning at the beginning of the new financial year. The later it is left, the more inefficient the planning will be, so to help such wise men and women this week Jobs & Money offers a guide to tax planning services on the world wide web.

A quest for such sites reveals that there is still much to be done for the financial planning industry. Typing the words "financial planning UK" into a search engine will unearth a multitude of websites set up by financial advisers of all kinds that are little more than electronic shop windows. Among the names that might appear are Perkins & Co, Money Wise, John Russell, Morganston.com and Wrotham. These are firms that offer tax planning as part of their advisory services and made the first step to joining the internet revolution by touting their wares on the web.

All of the companies mentioned have pasted an online inquiry form on to their sites which allows the user to dispatch an inquiry concerning their personal tax situation to the firm which will supply an answer to their specific questions.

Of those referred to above, Money Wise is the most comprehensive with a dedicated page for investments, pensions, life assurance and mortgages but nothing devoted specifically to tax in its own right.

Each page carries a form on which the user can fill in details to build up a brief profile of their circumstances. The forms ask for a daytime contact number on which one of Money Wise's advisers can call back.

More sophisticated - in interactive terms - is the site at www.moneyweb.co.uk This is a clear and extensive website with explanations of a broad range of tax subjects. It breaks the material down into three basic components: income tax, capital gains tax and inheritance tax. It also has a page entitled "Essays and external tax links", although when the user clicks on this the only link provided is to the inland revenue's own web pages. These are useful for those still dashing to complete self-assessment forms but of little use for advance tax planning.

Each of the subject pages, however, contains links to subtopics and technical terms for users who want fuller explanations.

The income-tax page, for example, leads to a non-taxable income section which has details on annuities, National Savings certificates and tax-exempt special savings accounts, among others. The site offers plenty of plain, sensible advice and takes a light-hearted approach.

The section on the tax status of wedding presents, for example, counsels that marrying the boss's daughter is not a good way to try to get payments passed tax-free.

There are a limited number of sites that offer a truly interactive online service. Firms such as Asset Financial Management and Philip Wallington advertise that their online products are still under construction.

Slightly further down this line is Axatax, which specialises in individuals and family- or owner-managed businesses and charges up to £150 for tax planning queries.

Users must fill in an online form with an outline of their problem, in return for which Axatax will return a quotation for their services. The option to contact an individual at the company is also included, though somewhat undermining the company's apparent confidence in its online services.

A site already reviewed by Jobs & Money is www.virtuallyanywhere.co.uk through which the deTAX service is available.

This is run by a group of former tax inspectors who aim to cut back some of the claimed £6.58bn - enough to buy every adult in Britain a Big Mac meal every week for nearly a year - that was wasted on unnecessary tax in 1997-98. That means a potential saving of £180 a person if the group lives up to its word.

A final alternative is to order specialist tax planning software from manufacturers such as Microsoft or Optio. Details are available on the companies' websites for which addresses are given below:

www.assetfm.co.uk
www.bezeb.co.uk/axatax
www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk
www.optio.co.uk
www.moneyweb.co.uk
www.perkins.co.mcmail.com
www.virtuallyanywhere.co.uk

fields.headline: Game is far from over
fields.trailText: Donald Clark, a genial 42-year-old philosophy graduate from Edinburgh, is passionate about his job as managing director of Epic Group, a multimedia company. He is also worth over £2m more than he was a year ago, at least on paper, because of his enthusiastic steering of the company.
fields.body:
Donald Clark, a genial 42-year-old philosophy graduate from Edinburgh, is passionate about his job as managing director of Epic Group, a multimedia company. He is also worth over £2m more than he was a year ago, at least on paper, because of his enthusiastic steering of the company.

His story is not, however, the increasingly familiar one of a bright young spark thinking up a wonderful internet idea, floating the company on the Stock Exchange and making virtual millions.

Mr Clark has been with Epic since it started 16 years ago in Brighton as a video production company. He first got into computers when, on a summer break from Edinburgh he went on a scholarship to the Ivy League college of Dartmouth, US.

"All students were given free sessions in the computer department at a time when no one had heard of Bill Gates, the internet, or even computers," he says.

This was in 1979. By the time he joined Epic in 1983, the multimedia revolution was about to begin. He says : "We worked on the very first PCs and Apples and used them to teach and train people rather than just number crunching."

Epic moved from videos into CDs for business training. By the mid-90s he and three others had taken over from the founder, Eric Parselow, in a management buy-out. They raised £20,000 each by mortgaging their homes.

The company had grown steadily in its core training software business, but it then moved into computer games. For a while it went well. They gained two contracts for £3m for Endgame and its putative successor, Drowned God, which made them virtually self-financing. Electronic games accounted for half of total turnover. On the strength of this, the company floated on the Alternative Investment Market (Aim) in 1996 at 105p, raising £4.7m.

Then it all went horribly wrong. The US distributor of Endgame decided to get out of games and pulled the rug from under Epic. Time-Warner, which was to distribute Drowned God, also decided it was quitting games. Profits plunged: there was a £2.6m loss in 1997 and the share price sank to 7p at one point. Two of the four directors departed, leaving Mr Clark in charge. It looked like one of the first IT fizzers and failures.

He says that what happened to the share price was quite absurd. "After all, we had half a million in the bank and plenty of other assets. Epic became a bit like a horse and a jockey. The jockey, the games side of the business, fell off. But the horse, the main business, just kept going."

Clark became head of the entire business. He ploughed ahead with the basic business which was training using intranet/internet technology.

There are other strands of the business. One provides online consultancy and an outsourced capability to assist companies in the use of internet technology. Online and e-commerce activities include a large internet site for the Foreign and Commonwealth office. The group is also involved in the development of kiosk applications and in-train entertainment systems and minority investments in online companies with potential for rapid growth.

Profits for the year to May 1999 turned around to £478,000. The share price has risen to 133p. Since Donald Clark owns just over 2m shares (8.7% of the business) he is a millionaire.

Doesn't he feel that he got his big break because his colleagues over-reached themselves and he was left to pick up the pieces? "It was not like that. I was never enamoured with making films and games. I was always more interested in education and training. That's where I got my buzz. But there was no rancour.

"The money is nice but it is all theoretical. We are building a business. Just a few years ago we were all hobbyists. Now we have children it is a bit more serious. But I think the prospects for training and education on the internet are phenomenal.

"No: my real big break was that summer in Dartmouth when I discovered computers and started to realise what a revolution they meant."

webTitle: Has the bubble burst for amateur landlords?

fields.headline: Has the bubble burst for amateur landlords?
fields.standfirst: Although last week's rate rise may dampen the market, buy-to-let can still tempt the shrewd investor. Elizabeth Langton reports
fields.trailText: Although last week's rate rise may dampen the market, buy-to-let can still tempt the shrewd investor. Elizabeth Langton reports
fields.body:
The number of homeowners who have become amateur landlords by taking advantage of the boom in buy-to-let mortgages looks set to fall after last week's interest rate rise.

Lenders predict that the hike will put the brakes on the market as increased mortgage costs eat into rental profits. The past couple of years has seen a steady rise in a new breed of landlord as working people have taken advantage of buy-to-let mortgages. Encouraged by low interest rates, they have bought properties and rented them out hoping to make a long-term investment and a nice little monthly income.

Now there are signs that the buy-to-let bubble has burst. The south-east has seen the largest increase in the number of properties coming on to the rental market. In some areas there is a glut of properties for rent and tenants can be choosy. In a competitive market scruffy one- and two-bedroom flats fall by the wayside as tenants go for smarter homes.

An over-supply of property for rent also leads to more "voids" between tenants for landlords. The mortgage still must be paid but the owners can go for weeks without a tenant. Agents Knight Frank say the supply of rental property, mostly one- and two-bedroom flats in greater London, increased by about 25% in 1999. "In many London locations private investors have been lured by the "promise" of double-digit returns across residential property held as an investment," says the agent. "This is no longer achievable as the supply of rented property has increased but rental levels have not kept pace."

But some areas are faring better. At the heart of the capital Knight Frank branches say tenants are desperate for properties to rent. And in urban areas around Britain there are now two kinds of investors in the market - the sophisticated investor and the unsophisticated landlord. Sophisticated investors have researched the market and are fully aware of all the factors that can make a dent in their profits such as maintenance costs and having to pay the mortgage for an average of eight weeks a year when the flat is empty.

The unsophisticated landlords have been lured by reports of gross yields of more than 10%. They take out the mortgage with a deposit as low as 5%. With an increase in interest rates and a couple of no-rent months they can find themselves having to top up the mortgages out of their own pockets.

John Lee, national sales manager with the Halifax, echoes this: "There is not the same large profit margin on rental income now. As a result, customers taking out a buy-to-let mortgage are changing. People are still coming in but we haven't got as many amateur landlords as we had," he says.

Instead, the bank has been lending to people who own and let up to six properties. "They're going for a standard variable rate rather than a fixed rate because they don't want to have to pay redemption charges if they want to sell," he says.

Graham Wilby, who oversees buy-to-let for the Woolwich, has also seen a change. "More and more people are building up a portfolio of properties and becoming serious landlords. Now 40% of our business in buy-to-let is repeats, arranging mortgages for existing clients."

Figures collected by the Centre for Housing Policy at the University of York show that rents have been increasing in line with inflation. But the rise in house prices means that would-be landlords are having to pay more for properties compared to what they recoup in rent. On a monthly basis, renting looks less attractive than it did, but landlords in for the long haul will reap the benefits of a capital growth in the value of the property.

Mr Wilby says returns aren't too bad. "Someone buying a £70,000 property should get a gross rent of £7,000 on that." Experts agree that the answer to the question: "Will buying-to-let make me rich?" is: "No - not yet," but if you're happy to stick with it for 10 years and ride out the bad times then you'll amass a nice little nest egg. As Mr Lee says: "More and more people are looking to the capital growth of the property and are happy for the rental to cover the mortgage and maintenance costs."

If house prices continue upwards and lenders put interest rates up in a bid to keep the lid on the economy, then buy-to-let will be a less attractive option in six months' time, says Graham Wilby. But Malcolm Harrison, spokesman for the Association of Residential Letting Agents, is optimistic. "There is greater job mobility, a higher divorce rate and many people who can afford to buy who haven't decided where to live," he says. He urges those interested to do their research carefully and take the advice of a letting agent about tenants.

The private rented sector has increased in size since the all-time low of 7% 10 years ago and now accounts for just over 11% of the housing market, he says. Overall, rental demand should continue to go up: "There'll never be a shortage of tenants for the right properties."

webTitle: When the strain turns into pain

fields.headline: When the strain turns into pain
fields.trailText: If asked, most people will probably say they experience some degree of stress at work and a survey published this week says nine out of 10 workers expect it to get worse.
fields.body:
If asked, most people will probably say they experience some degree of stress at work and a survey published this week says nine out of 10 workers expect it to get worse.

Rather than making life easier, developments in communication technology mean demands on workers' time are far more numerous. An indication of rising stress levels is the increase in the number of stress-related workplace injury claims. Figures from the Trades Union Congress (TUC), show a 70% rise in the number of cases handled by their lawyers between 1998 and 1999.

Tom Jones, a partner at Thompsons, the UK's largest personal injury law firm, backs this up. "They have gone through the roof in terms of the number of inquiries over the last couple of years," he says.

But how do you know if you are suffering from stress and what can you do about it? The first question is not easy to answer. Where do you draw the line between pressure, generally considered to be a healthy element of employment, and stress? The Health & Safety Executive (HSE), the body responsible for enforcing the Health and Safety at Work Act of 1974, offers a guide to managers on work-related stress available at www.hse.gov.uk. This says the difference between pressure and stress is that the former improves performance while the latter leads to illness. It describes a set of symptoms a stressed employee might exhibit: irritability, indecisiveness, absenteeism and reduced performance. Stressed staff may also start taking more and more sick days, or frequently turn up late.

Unison, the largest trade union in the UK with 1.3m members mainly in the public sector, won the first case ever in which an employee was awarded damages by his employers on the grounds of stress. Unison defines stress as: "The reaction people have to excessive demands or pressures arising when people cope with tasks, responsibilities or other types of pressure connected with their jobs, but find difficulty, strain or worry in doing so."

But any one of the symptoms described by the HSE could arise for any number of reasons. Equally, Unison's definition describes circumstances that many workers deal with on a regular basis who do not suffer from stress. What is more, as the HSE points out in its guide, "symptoms of stress tend to be seen as a sign of weak ness". Where this is the case, it becomes self-perpetuating, with anxieties about one's performance exacerbating existing problems.

Unison says the best tip it can offer is to act early. If you feel that the tasks allotted to you are too much and you are suffering a significant number of the symptoms mentioned above, inform your line manager. Failing to do so means that the problem will not be officially recorded - a fact which will not help in the instance of any legal action - and help will only be forthcoming if your employers happen to notice.

Sadly, this will not always be the end of the problem. Mr Jones cites the case of a member of staff at a large city council forced to take time off work because of stress-related illness. He had started work as a joiner and was made manager of the works division without the necessary training. On his return after sick leave one of his bosses greeted him by saying: "I hope you've got plenty of Valium because we've got plenty of work for you."

This sort of "crass management", as Mr Jones calls it, is particularly common among public sector organisations. "It has tended to be surprisingly and massively present in local government," says Mr Jones. "I say surprisingly because you might expect that area to be a backwater." It is the imposition of private sector-style management that leads to the problem, says Mr Jones.

Even if someone is convinced they are suffering to the extent that it is damaging their health, fighting for compensation will not be simple, quick or easy. The legal process is expensive. The best source of help is a trade union, which will supply free legal services. If you are not a union member the only other source of financial help is legal aid. In order to qualify you must pass a means test and a merit test, the latter to establish whether there is a chance of the case succeeding. If during the case the Legal Aid Board decides that failure is on the cards, the support will be withdrawn.

This facility will be all but withdrawn in April anyway, when legal aid in personal injury cases will be replaced by conditional fee agreements under the Access to Justice Act. These agreements are effectively an insurance policy against losing a case which the applicant must pay for. If the case is lost the costs will be paid on behalf of the applicant. If the case is won the losing side will pay. Mr Jones says it is not unusual for cases to drag on for three or four years at a cost of tens of thousands of pounds.

Despite the record award of £203,000 made last week, awards are not generous. The principle governing compensation is that the recipient should be put in a financial position as close as possible to that they would have been in if the damage had not occured. In physical injury cases calculations are based on something called the Ogden tables. In stress cases no such model exists, so, Mr Jones says: "Employers offer a sum they think they can get away with but it will be substantially less than you would get in a trial."

Peter Graham, senior claims manager at Norwich Union, which insures companies against compensation cases, says the intention is to minimise additional stress by making a reasonable offer as early as possible. Out of court settlements tend to favour employers. And they avoid setting legal precedents, which makes it harder for future applicants.

But the HSE is discussing the introduction of a code of practice on stress which would put the burden of proof on an offender. Whether anything comes of this will become clear in April.

 Useful sources of information: TUC's Know Your Rights line, 0870-6004882; Citizens' Advice Bureaux, 0171-833 2181. For legal information go to www.emplaw.co.uk which has an "employment law superportal" with hundreds of useful links. The Legal Aid Board is contactable on 0171-813-1000. Thompsons head office number is 0171-637-9761.

webTitle: How to claw back tax concessions

fields.headline: How to claw back tax concessions
fields.trailText: Tax rates have moved in one direction over the past two decades - downwards. Less well trumpeted by politicians has been the way tax reliefs have gradually been eroded.
fields.body:
Tax rates have moved in one direction over the past two decades - downwards. And the budget in March is set to push basic tax levels a further notch downwards from 23% to 22% - despite calls from some politicians for the planned cuts to be frozen, with the extra tax cash raised going straight to the hard-pushed NHS.

But it has not been a one-way journey. Less well trumpeted by politicians has been the way tax reliefs have gradually been eroded.

This special report will show you how to take best advantage of those that will remain after this tax year ends on April 5 and what to do about one that won't.

The married person's allowance has been chipped away over the years and goes completely for those under 65 when the new tax year begins. The same applies to the personal allowance for single parents with dependent children.

Equally, Miras, the tax relief on mortgage interest, has declined in importance and will be given for the last time in March. Irrespective of interest rates, all home loans will cost more in April.

And with stakeholder pensions and their automatic basic-rate tax relief paid to all at source irrespective of tax rate, there is considerable speculation that relief on pension contributions at the top rate might go as well. The relief on pension contributions remains one of the best gifts from the inland revenue to the higher-rate taxpayer.

One little-known way of getting the most out of the tax system is to join the clergy. Special rules applying to all recognised religions and denominations - and increasingly to women as well as men - offer a number of concessions to those called to holy orders. There are tax reliefs on the value of the free accommodation that comes with the job - and if the clergyperson pays his or her partner for cleaning duties, that too can be deductible.

But most of us will regard taking up seven-day-a-week religion as an extreme step in the quest for tax breaks. There are still a number of tax concessions and loopholes that can help ease income tax pain.

Planning starts in just over a week's time. By ensuring your return and the tax due arrive at the inland revenue by January 31, you can avoid fines and interest charges.

If you have a company car, you should consider replacing it with your own vehicle - to save cash for both yourself and your employer.

Tax-efficient investments are the first port for spare cash. They put savers in the same position as those dealing offshore but without the hassle or the risks of dealing with people in an area where investor protection niceties might be overlooked.

Your first savings beyond day-to-day money should be in an individual savings account (Isa - the successor to Peps and Tessas). They are free of income tax and capital gains tax. Beyond Isas lie easy to understand National Savings investments.

The more complicated insurance bonds and zero dividend investment trust bonds have no limit on how much you can put in, although their tax benefits are more specific - so check with an independent adviser. Insurance bonds in particular can demand high commissions so buyers should be careful. Ending up with the wrong product will leave you worse off.

Parking your cash offshore is often seen a tax dodge. Evasion is illegal and your local Hector the tax inspector could demand to know where the nest egg you used to keep onshore went.

But there are legitimate uses of offshore deals. The magic word is "defer", not "dodge". First-E, the internet bank, is based in Dublin and pays interest without deducting tax. That can be useful if you need a cash boost now but can cope with paying up at a later date.

Other offshore products can help investors put off tax even longer. This can be useful if the tax rate you pay is likely to fall in the future, while distributor-status offshore funds can help to use annual capital gains tax allowances that would otherwise be wasted.

The cardinal rule for all complicated tax schemes is to seek professional advice.

Not all tax relief and tax boosts are for the taxpayer's own benefit. Hector can help us to help others. It sounds callous, but the worst way of giving to a charity is to put coins into a collection box. Put a pound in, and the charity gets a pound.

By structuring your payment either through the gift aid scheme or via payroll giving, your generosity is boosted so each £1,000 collected through these plans is worth £1,290 to your favourite good cause - or up to £1,666 if you are a higher-rate taxpayer.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Cold cures
fields.body:
Good Indian sub-continental food, agreeably seasoned, is well suited to wine and, in this month of coughs and colds especially, will only encourage the mucus membranes and enhance the well-being of the virally victimised. A few gallant reds, then, all flowing with soft, rich fruit, to handle this sort of situation with aplomb and purpose.

Asda has Capewater West Ruby Cabernet 1998 (15.5 points, out of 20, £3.79), from South Africa. It's deeply quaffable, yet also perfect for the cuisine in question because it displays its own compressed dry/sweet fruitiness while also bringing out the flavours of the food. Booths, the bijou chain of the north, has Marius Reserva Bodegas Piqueras 1993 (14 points, £4.49), from Spain, which, being mature, offers a middle-aged experience. It is raisin-edged but dry, and also has a sunny richness that defies characterisation beyond the cliché already given. Fullers, the bijou chain of the south, has Hecula Bodegas Castano Yecla 1997 (15 points, £4.99), also from Spain, which is not entirely unlike its compatriot from the north, except that it's younger, feistier, and more complex.

At Majestic, there is the excitingly jammy Sassaiolo Rosso Piceno 1997 (14.5 points, £4.99), from Italy. It carries a layer of spice of its own, and has a decidedly cheeky demeanour as it finishes. At the same retailer is Joao Pires Terras do Sado 1993 (16 points, £3.49), from Portugal, which has a little spice but a lot else besides. I was most taken by its monstrous juiciness and free-flowing fruity ebullience, which makes it one of the nattiest, and best priced, Indian food wines around.

Unwins has Canepa Zinfandel 1998 (14 points, £4.99), from Chile, a decidedly spicy and zingy wine, and a touch exotic, too. It is good for slurping with demanding company, and, such is its sotto voce finish, only suitable for milder Indian dishes.

So much for Indian food. It is, of course, more often a cold in the pocket that many of us suffer from at this time of year - especially after the expenses of the recent double festivity - but there are a number of soothing wines around. What better place to start than at Somerfield, a retailer that may not be the darling of City retail analysts - but then, I doubt that any of those killjoys buy their wine at this retailer anyway, preferring to throw their money away on claret futures.

Somerfield's South African Cabernet Sauvignon 1999 (16 points, down to £3.29 until February 1) is a lovely specimen of Cape warmth and wit: it's a dry, tobacco-edged red of huge charm and commitment, and quite able to sit on a fancy tablecloth and be drunk from a posh glass. Analysts take note.

Pergola Tempranillo Manchuela 1998 (15 points, down to £2.79 until February 1), from Spain, has a very attractive dryness to its layers of savoury, rich fruit and suits, I fancy, pasta dishes.

James Herrick Cuvée Simone 1997 (16.5 points, £3.99 until February 1) is getting delicate as it ages, and the gorgeous opulence of its youth, the tobacco and plum aromas, the invigoratingly rich, dry fruit and the fine fulfilling finish, though still classy and far from witless, are less emphatic. It is a wine, I feel, for the bookworm.

Not so L'Arco Cabernet Franc 1996 (15.5 points, £3.79 until February 1), which, having got somewhat crankier as it has aged, and its cherry fruit more bitter, needs food. And last from Somerfield, there is Marc Xero Chardonnay 1998 (14 points, £3.99 until February 1), from Italy, an iconoclastic, respectably fruity and not ungenerous wine that is ideal to take an elderly relative for sipping during bridge rubbers.

Asda, too, has two splendid bargains. Argentinian Tempranillo 1998 (15.5 points, on offer at a mere £3.49 until January 30) is a quite heavingly juicy and ripely ready wine, but one whose tannins keep it sane and principled. Earthier is Chteau Lahore Bergez 1997 (15.5 points, on offer at £3.99 until January 30), from Fitou, which is not remotely suitable for Indian food, in spite of the name, but is packed with herby fruit that reveals fresh ripe cherries as it softens on the palate.

It is raisin-edged but dry, and also has a sunny richness that defies characterisation beyond the cliché already given. Fullers, the bijou chain of the south, has Hecula Bodegas Castano Yecla 1997 (15 points, £4.99), also from Spain, which is not entirely unlike its compatriot from the north, except that it's younger, feistier, and more complex. At Majestic, there is the excitingly jammy Sassaiolo Rosso Piceno 1997 (14.5 points, £4.99), from Italy. It carries a layer of spice of its own, and has a decidedly cheeky demeanour as it finishes. At the same retailer is Joao Pires Terras do Sado 1993 (16 points, £3.49), from Portugal, which has a little spice but a lot else besides. I was most taken by its monstrous juiciness and free-flowing fruity ebullience, which makes it one of the nattiest, and best priced, Indian food wines around. Unwins has Canepa Zinfandel 1998 (14 points, £4.99), from Chile, a decidedly spicy and zingy wine, and a touch exotic, too. It is good for slurping with demanding company, and, such is its sotto voce finish, only suitable for milder Indian dishes. So much for Indian food. It is, of course, more often a cold in the pocket that many of us suffer from at this time of year - especially after the expenses of the recent double festivity - but there are a number of soothing wines around. What better place to start than at Somerfield, a retailer that may not be the darling of City retail analysts - but then, I doubt that any of those killjoys buy their wine at this retailer anyway, preferring to throw their money away on claret futures. Somerfield's South African Cabernet Sauvignon 1999 (16 points, down to £3.29 until February 1) is a lovely specimen of Cape warmth and wit: it's a dry, tobacco-edged red of huge charm and commitment, and quite able to sit on a fancy tablecloth and be drunk from a posh glass. Analysts take note. Pergola Tempranillo Manchuela 1998 (15 points, down to £2.79 until February 1), from Spain, has a very attractive dryness to its layers of savoury, rich fruit and suits, I fancy, pasta dishes. James Herrick Cuvée Simone 1997 (16.5 points, £3.99 until February 1) is getting delicate as it ages, and the gorgeous opulence of its youth, the tobacco and plum aromas, the invigoratingly rich, dry fruit and the fine fulfilling finish, though still classy and far from witless, are less emphatic. It is a wine, I feel, for the bookworm. Not so L'Arco Cabernet Franc 1996 (15.5 points, £3.79 until February 1), which, having got somewhat crankier as it has aged, and its cherry fruit more bitter, needs food. And last from Somerfield, there is Marc Xero Chardonnay 1998 (14 points, £3.99 until February 1), from Italy, an iconoclastic, respectably fruity and not ungenerous wine that is ideal to take an elderly relative for sipping during bridge rubbers. Asda, too, has two splendid bargains. Argentinian Tempranillo 1998 (15.5 points, on offer at a mere £3.49 until January 30) is a quite heavingly juicy and ripely ready wine, but one whose tannins keep it sane and principled. Earthier is Chteau Lahore Bergez 1997 (15.5 points, on offer at £3.99 until January 30), from Fitou, which is not remotely suitable for Indian food, in spite of the name, but is packed with herby fruit that reveals fresh ripe cherries as it softens on the palate.

webTitle: Why tax credit is a turnoff for self-employed

fields.headline: Why tax credit is a turnoff for self-employed
fields.trailText: Britain's 3m-strong army of self-employed are falling behind in their claiming of the working families' tax credit and the disabled person's tax credit, according to the Low Incomes Tax Reform Group.
fields.body:
Britain's 3m-strong army of self-employed are falling behind in their claiming of the working families' tax credit and the disabled person's tax credit, according to the Low Incomes Tax Reform Group.

It says that after three months of the new schemes, the number of self-employed claimants "is down on the level for former benefits such as family credit".

The LITRG blames "excessive tax office bureaucracy" including over-long forms without step-by-step guidance of the kind provided on income tax self-assessment forms.

To claim the new benefits, the self-employed have to produce different figures for tax and for the new benefits - this can be costly and time consuming. But they cannot claim deductions for spending on business equipment for the new benefits despite these same amounts being allowable against their tax bills.

Other reliefs given for income tax purposes on start-ups or against previous losses are also denied. The result, says LITRG, is a loss of credits which can equate to a tax rate of 100% or even more.

"This unfair treatment needs to be tackled," it says. "But there is little sign the inland revenue is ready to move."

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum
fields.standfirst: 'Harriet assures me that she has often watched 18s - usually in my presence'
fields.trailText: 'Harriet assures me that she has often watched 18s - usually in my presence'
fields.body:
'Mum? Can I get any video I want with my Christmas vouchers?" "Yes... yes." Not really concentrating. Exhausted by effort of moving house just before Christmas and by rigours of settling into life in town. What this means for a Virgo with Prozac transiting Zanussi is a whole new set of dreads. I dread that the kids will buy drugs from the desperadoes who haunt the alleys. I dread that ex-Spouse will visit the brothel next door and plaster over the pale bits of his scalp with shoe polish. I dread that the aged aunt will hear a stream of obscenities - not out in the street, right here in the house.

As for myself, I dread the sudden appearance in my in-tray of the Bank Manager, with his cloven hooves and sulphurous stench. At the moment, I am running three overdrafts. In a thrusting young executive this would be evidence of entrepreneurial genius: in me, it's a sign that I'm a sad old git. Save a corner of the alley for me, chaps.

I economise desperately whilst dreaming of ever more expensive escapes. You'd think the RSPB magazine would be a harmless, wholesome diversion, but it fills me with longing to visit the Danube Delta to see the Red Breasted Geese. Holidays now are becoming even more alluring - packed with activities, whether fair (walk in the oak forests of the Pyrenees) or foul (rotate your naked buttocks in front of TV cameras in Jamaica).

For me, however, the only expedition is to the Oxfam shop in search of a warm winter coat. Watched sceptically by Harriet, I buy a sheepskin jacket for £10. It's not all that smelly, and it'll keep the cold out when I become a vagrant. Minutes later, Harriet steers me into Woolworths, where I am to "help her" spend her Christmas money - ie, stand helplessly by, dreaming of a tour of Lebanon, including Byblos, Baalbeck and Beirut, whilst she loads me up with miscellaneous videos.

As we queue at the till, I begin to experience Global Warming all over my Northern Hemisphere. The sheepskin jacket has turned into a personal microwave, and by the time I am ready to pay, I shall have dropped steaming to the floor, like macro-sausage roll at an ogre's banquet.

Buy videos with difficulty - the sheepskin jacket should be adopted as a garment of restraint by the police force, as raising your hand to anyone, even in affection, becomes impossible. Then discover - too late - that one of Harriet's selections is The Exorcist. Ah! So that's why she wanted me to "help". I look old enough to buy it , though suspect I shall never be old enough to watch it. Remonstrate limply with her all the way home. She assures me she has often watched 18s, usually in the presence of myself, and reels off a list of horror movies I have enjoyed in the past, none of which I recall.

"All right then," I sigh with my usual brisk, no- nonsense capitulation. "You can watch it after Aunt Elspeth's gone to bed." I'm not really so scared of possession, actually - it's repossession I dread.

The aunt stays up late, however, watching Sense And Sensibility for the fifth time since Christmas, and it is 11pm before the rest of us settle down to watch The Exorcist, reassured by ex-Spouse, who is not afraid of anything, except his other ex-wife, Elaine. Some are born to terrify, others to cringe and tremble. I discover I am a lot less disturbed by supernatural green projectile vomiting than I am by the real humdrum puking that takes place every Saturday night in the street outside our house.

However, when we reach the infamous ejaculation "Your mother sucks cocks in Hell!" I am really horrified - not by the film so much as by the arrival of Aunt Elspeth in her nightie, looking pained.

"What was that terrrible scrreaming dearr ?" With one deft flick of the remote, ex-Spouse has terminated The Exorcist and replaced it with something really obscene - the advert for the Fiat Punto.

"Oh, it was just an advert for a holiday, Auntie," I assure her. Hope she did not actually hear the words your mother sucks, etc. Although I suppose, at a pinch, one could pass it off as an adventure escape with Saga Holidays - the Provisional Wing.

fields.headline: How to... Have flu
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Guy Browning
fields.body:
Flu goes through several very clear stages. The first is when you ask someone to feel your forehead. In normal life, we don't go around feeling people's foreheads, so it often comes as a complete surprise to find out just how warm they are. Thankfully, few people will ever ask you to feel their nose and tell them if it's runny.

To have flu, you need symptoms: the standard ones are headache, sore throat, temperature, sickness, achiness, cough, dribbly nose. Once you've got four out of seven, you can skip work. But remember that your cough must sound as though you're starting a chainsaw in cold weather, and that you must cough at least three times during any phone call to the office. Declaring that you've a temperature really isn't good enough; you have to have a raging fever of 120F. Clogged mucal sniffing is also a good idea when you're on the phone, but don't try and communicate general achiness or you may come across as a bit of a ham.

Stage two of flu is bed. Once you're in bed with the flu, you need to accessorise. In this respect, a large box of tissues is vital, as is the hailstorm of used tissues around the bin, a result of your not quite having the energy to throw them in. You will also need a family- pack of paracetamol, to help you cope with the symptoms of flu.

Among the nastiest of these symptoms are the headaches and vomiting shortly after having the 'hot toddy' specially prepared for you by someone who claims to love you. This is a hot mixture of lemon, whisky, honey, paraffin, calvados, Tixylix and castor oil. You lose your appetite when you have flu, so if you find yourself eating a lot of cake and ice cream, you're more likely to be pregnant.

There's a saying, 'Feed a cold, starve a fever' or 'Starve a cold, feed a fever'. This is used by elderly relatives as an excuse to give you the 'country' soup they make by feeding compost to a blender that 'will have you on your feet in no time'. You'll certainly be on your feet, but you'll just be shuttling between your bed and the lavatory.

The final phase of flu is the hacking cough, during which you feel much better but still sound like death. Use this time to get maximum attention and pampering, and to make more death-bed phone calls to work. Finally, you'll be fit again, but when you go back to work, you'll realise that the people you thought were doing your work for you have also been off with flu.

fields.headline: Obsessions
fields.standfirst: It's good to talk - but not when you're having a hair cut, says David Newnham
fields.trailText: It's good to talk - but not when you're having a hair cut, says David Newnham
fields.body:
A friend of mine just had all his teeth pulled out. Why? Because he couldn't face one more session in the dentist's chair. So if I tell you that I'm thinking of having all my hair surgically extracted, you'll know that my nightmares also feature physical contact with armed strangers and a big chair that pumps up and down. "Would you like it just touching the ears, sir?" Arrrghhhhhhh!

I blurted my fears to Christine the very first time she did me. "Not been for a while?" she asked as I stepped nervously forward. Not been recently? It was like being potty trained again. To be honest, I told her, I'd rather go to the dentist than have my hair cut. "You're kidding?" I guess nobody had ever been afraid of her before (Christine wasn't very big). She thought it was so funny that she very nearly forgot to tell me about her holiday in St Lucia.

It's lucky she remembered, because I quickly learned the secret of how to relax as she snipped around me. Just ask her about her holidays. "Been away?" I'd say, as she tightened the nylon sheet around my neck. "Going anywhere nice?" Her grip would loosen, and she'd be off down that runway in a haze of jet exhaust, leaving me to gaze like Dorian Gray at my ageing head and shoulders (it's always frightening what a difference just another six months has made). Occasionally, she'd pause, mid-destination, to ask my opinion about a parting or somesuch - you know that stuff hairdressers seem obsessed with. Her reflection would address my reflection in the mirror, and I'd leave the pair of them to agree on the details. And that was the conversation bit more or less taken care of.

That's almost the worst part, you see. Not that I have a problem with conversation generally. But in front of a mirror, in a raised-up chair, with just my head poking through a sheet like a cherry on a knickerbocker glory, and my hair all dripping and plastered down at the front, Hitler-style . . . "Leave me alone," is all I want to say. "Can't you see I'm having a bad-hair life?" But still they want to talk. "Working hard?" Not until I came in here. "Live locally?" No, I live in New York, but thought I'd fly over to the East Midlands just so I could get my hair done by Joyce in Headz-U-Win.

You don't get any of that with dentists. For a start, they know that you're afraid, so they're not expecting banter. Who goes to the dentist for a natter? It's just not practicable. The first thing a dentist does is ask if you've been having any problems with your teeth. Then, as you attempt to answer ("That's for me to know and you to find out, O Evil One!"), they stuff a wad of rolled-up blotting paper into the groove where your gums meet your mouth, clamp a gurgly suction pipe under your tongue and begin reciting the alphabet loudly to the nurse. My last dentist actually turned the enforced dumbness of his victims into a sort of comedy routine. "So," he would say, having filled your mouth with metal and injected your gums with the sort of stuff hunter-gatherers use to paralyse rhinos and hunter-gatherers from neighbouring villages, "the Conservatives seem to be doing a jolly good job, eh?"

And as you tried to form words using only your diaphragm and neck muscles, his masked, upsidedown little face would crease into delirious giggles.

Christine, of course, knew exactly what she was doing. After seven years, she even had me making minor decisions about sideburn length and conditioner. But she knew I couldn't remain with her forever. Sooner or later, I'd have to return to the wild. The day she broke the news that she was going to become a psychiatrist, she tried her best to help. "The next person who cuts your hair," she said, "just tell them you want a number four on the back and sides, and the top layered in." Could she write it down? Maybe pin it to my jacket? All this talk of dentists has given me another idea, you see - the very next time I go to get my hair cut, I'm going to ask if I can have gas.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.
Email: weekend@guardian.co.uk. Fax: 020-7239 9935. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Yasmin Alibhai-Brown has once again written a sublime piece of west-bashing in her article about contemporary Islamic art in Britain (Sacred Beauty, January 15). If you voice any criticism, you are bad (whatever your motives); approve of it, and you are good. She does not confront the Muslim myth of supreme tolerance of other cultures. No mention of the destruction of pre-Islamic arts and cultures in areas invaded by Muslim armies, or the second-class status afforded to populations that did not submit to the faith. The west is confronting the skeletons in it's cupboard. Muslims have yet to start.
MS Akhtar
London SE17

Sacred Beauty was the first positive thing your paper has published about Muslims in a long time. More often than not, you feature a handful of fanatics and weirdos who purport to represent the Muslim community. This may be partly our own fault, as academics and professionals in our community have stood aside while a minority of extremists have monopolised media attention. I hope that Ms Alibhai-Brown's article marks the start of a more balanced coverage of Muslims and Islam.
MA Syed
Norwich

Jon Ronson writes about the Monster Raving Loony Party (Beyond A Joke, January 15). In the same issue, your fashion pages include a 'Rainbow woolly hat' at £109 from Harrods. Who are the monster raving loonies?
Paulinus Barnes and Maria Pizzoni
Rawtenstall, Lancs

How long before one of your fashion photographers gets away with a picture in which the garment is completely out of shot (January 15)?
Sonya Mills
Oxford

Michael Lewis's claim that Jim Clark's Hyperion is the 'biggest sloop ever built' (Captain Hubris, January 15) cannot go unchallenged. At 200ft overall, Nat Herreshoff's Reliance of 1903 has to be a contender - unless, of course, one were to object that she was a cutter and not a sloop.
Jeremy E Muldowney
Heworth, York

Christopher Eccleston is not just being hypocritical by acting in a West End theatre following his criticism of that medium (Home Truths, January 15). His assumption that 'the kind of people who watch Jimmy McGovern's stuff on telly won't be coming' to watch him at the Theatre Royal borders on middle-class arrogance. Why shouldn't the people who enjoy Strindberg also appreciate the gritty realism of McGovern's drama? And why shouldn't the people who may have appreciated him in those TV roles not seek him out in the theatre?

Who, exactly, is being typecast here?
Toni Silver
London W13

Regarding the compostability of tea bags, Mrs Thorne (Dear Weekend, January 15) is wrong: teabags will rot; the trick is to rip them open before adding to the compost heap.
Dr Jeff Ollerton
School of Environmental Science University College
Northampton

Sarah Gredley's child-centred home has a 'low, super-king-sized bed as family bed and trampoline', but no longer has the children's father in it (Home, January 15). Might the two be connected?
Deirdre Mason
London SW4

I hope that Ms Alibhai-Brown's article marks the start of a more balanced coverage of Muslims and Islam. MA Syed Norwich Jon Ronson writes about the Monster Raving Loony Party (Beyond A Joke, January 15). In the same issue, your fashion pages include a 'Rainbow woolly hat' at £109 from Harrods. Who are the monster raving loonies? Paulinus Barnes and Maria Pizzoni Rawtenstall, Lancs How long before one of your fashion photographers gets away with a picture in which the garment is completely out of shot (January 15)? Sonya Mills Oxford Michael Lewis's claim that Jim Clark's Hyperion is the 'biggest sloop ever built' (Captain Hubris, January 15) cannot go unchallenged. At 200ft overall, Nat Herreshoff's Reliance of 1903 has to be a contender - unless, of course, one were to object that she was a cutter and not a sloop. Jeremy E Muldowney Heworth, York Christopher Eccleston is not just being hypocritical by acting in a West End theatre following his criticism of that medium (Home Truths, January 15). His assumption that 'the kind of people who watch Jimmy McGovern's stuff on telly won't be coming' to watch him at the Theatre Royal borders on middle-class arrogance. Why shouldn't the people who enjoy Strindberg also appreciate the gritty realism of McGovern's drama? And why shouldn't the people who may have appreciated him in those TV roles not seek him out in the theatre? Who, exactly, is being typecast here?
