fields.headline: Fat's life
fields.standfirst:
Long ago, it was all so simple: we ate chips, did our frying in lard, treated ourselves to cream cakes and, sooner or later, we died. Then scientists linked dietary fats to poor health and early mortality, and we began to worry about the sooner. Today, after years of sober research, periodic panics and thousands of diet plans, we seem no nearer to knowing what's good for us. The truth must be out there somewhere...
What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Long ago, it was all so simple: we ate chips, did our frying in lard, treated ourselves to cream cakes and, sooner or later, we died. Then scientists linked dietary fats to poor health and early mortality, and we began to worry about the sooner. Today, after years of sober research, periodic panics and thousands of diet plans, we seem no nearer to knowing what's good for us. The truth must be out there somewhere...
fields.body:
A lesser GP would have bluffed. He'd have mumbled about red meat and long-chain molecules, drawn a whimsical analogy with the internal combustion engine, then referred me to a "jolly good lipids man". A cholesterol test had indicated that my blood contained an alarmingly high level of triglycerides, and a second test had confirmed the finding. Was that death's winged chariot I could hear at my back? Were too many triglycerides bad for the heart? "I don't think anybody really knows," said my candid GP.

"Let's see what the book says." And, with a spin of his chair, he took an overweight volume from the shelf behind him and began turning the pages. "Trichotillomania, tricuspid stenosis, trigeminal neuralgia... Here we are: triglyceride."

This all happened several years ago, and I don't remember what the book said - only that it was vague and non-committal. My GP, it seemed, was not alone in his uncertainty. One thing he did know, of course: I needed to see a specialist. But I wasn't so sure. A specialist, I reasoned, might err too much on the side of caution. "Frankly, old chap," he would say with a smile, "there's a lot of work still to be done on this one. But to be on the safe side, you should draw up a list of everything you enjoy eating, then avoid it like the plague."

A life of rumination would be my fate. A typical day on the safe side would be taken up with the steady munching of vegetables. An evening out would be pizza and side salad, minus the pizza and without any salad dressing. And to wash down this green cud? Mineral water.

I'm not normally one to ignore professional advice, but the doctors weren't sure, for heaven's sake. I was due to move out of the area in a month, anyway. A new address, a change of GP... the Fats Police would never catch up with me. Did I want to spend my life living on the safe side?

But no one can live in hiding forever. You might evade the medical profession, but there's no escaping the voice of reason in your own head. As the years went by, those dreadful test results haunted me. What if there was something seriously wrong? Perhaps they could fix it. Perhaps they could give me tablets. Perhaps they understood these things a little better now. Perhaps I should turn myself in.

The nurse who extracted the blood said, with a little laugh, that she was the daughter of a dairy farmer. And as I studied the sheet of dietary advice she handed me to focus my mind in the week or so before the results came through, I could see why she found the thought amusing. There was my favourite Stilton in the "avoid eating" list. Camembert and brie made it into the "once a week or less" column, along with "grilled back bacon (pre-boiled in water)". Yummy! Even semi-skimmed milk was labelled "Eat in moderation 2-3 times a week only". How I would love to be a fly on the Yorkshire pudding when her family assembled for dinner.

At first glance, her chart told me little that anybody who ever turned on a television or glanced at a magazine doesn't know by heart. Fruit and vegetables were the best source of nourishment, Bailey's cream liqueur the worst (when will they invent Bailey's Lite?). Fish was the food of the gods and taramasalata (fish eggs) the devil's work, while tofu and pork luncheonmeat glared at each other from opposite ends of the page. Occasionally, I would spot something that made my heart sink even deeper - crab meat was in the same category as oven chips, for instance, and both were lumped in with the liver that I had been brought up to consider the healthiest of foods.

But this time I was going to bite the bullet (having first checked its fat content, of course). By giving free rein to my obsessive tendencies, I would show them the true meaning of lean cuisine. I'd be a model pupil - the ultimate convert. If the dieticians and nutritionists advised me to chew through two balls of string a day, then I'd be first in line when the hardware shop opened.

And then I spotted the sunflower oil - "Eat in moderation, once a week or less," it said. That couldn't be right, could it? After all, switching to sunflower oil, "high in polyunsaturates", had been my one major concession to nutritional correctness during the long years in hiding. Yet there it was in pink and blue, on a chart issued "as a service to medicine" by the drug company Pfizer and "produced in association with the British Hypertension Society". Corn oil, soya oil, safflower oil, grapeseed oil, peanut oil, sunflower oil, once a week or less.

The condemnation of something previously recommended unnerved me. Why, even eggs were allowed to appear at table three times a week. What about all those Flora commercials? Had I missed something? It occurred to me that I might not, after all, be committing myself into the hands of sane people. In 1938, the British Medical Association had urged the nation to consume more dairy products, more eggs and more meat, and my own childhood diet, supplemented by lashings of free school milk (full-cream), had clearly been based on precisely that advice. One rule change in a lifetime may be regarded as a misfortune; two looks like carelessness.

Not for the first time, I recalled the film Sleeper, and the scene in which Woody Allen wakes up in the future to be told that bran is now known to be harmful and that biscuits, chocolate and cream cakes are actually the healthiest foods. And never mind the future. Were there not dissenting voices even in the present - people who argued that fatty food no more caused heart attacks than smoking caused lung cancer?

Our fate was predetermined by our genetic make-up, said some. Tense, fidgety types would burn up surplus fat whatever they ate, said others. And how about this? Half of Hollywood and the bulk of the fashion industry (now there's an oxymoron) was apparently living on something called the Zone Diet, a high-protein regime that demanded the consumption of burgers, steaks, butter, bacon, cheese, milk and cream, and actually banned boring bread and prissy pasta - anything, in fact, that was rich in carbohydrate. Carbs, they said, were the new fat. Perhaps these were the people I should be listening to.

As the nurse's syringe sucked at my arm, her little chart of dietary advice worked at my brain and drained from it every drop of my new-found resolve. So nothing had changed since the last time I sat in this chair. They were still running around in the dark. But if they thought they were taking me with them, they were mistaken. They could count triglycerides until they were blue in the face. But when the letter came referring me to the specialist - when the surgery phoned, begging me to come in for an urgent chat - I'd be at lunch. Or breakfast. Or dinner. Waiter! I think I'm ready to order.

Acouple of days later, I was still sounding off noisily to anyone within earshot when a friend, desperate to shut me up, handed me a book called The Aphrodite Diet (Vermilion, £6.99). "The cover's dreadful," she said, "but you might find what's inside useful. It explains lots of stuff about fats." A tanned blonde in a white bikini stared out into the Aegean, wondering, no doubt, where her spare tyre had disappeared to. But beyond the cover were pie charts and bar graphs and any number of words like "arachidonic" and "fibrinogen". So I agreed to give the so-called experts one last chance.

I secretly hoped that this would provide a convincing justification for that succulent meat-and-cream regime I'd been itching to share with Jennifer Aniston and Minnie Driver. But while the authors, Dr Artemis P Simopoulos and Jo Robinson, did have a cunning eating plan to sell - and one which argued that some types of fat, far from being the death of us, were actually an important item on the menu - it had more in common with the nurse's diet sheet than with titles such as A New Diet Revolution or Get Skinny On Fabulous Foods. One thing immediately caught my attention, however. This pair, it seemed, also wanted me to kick the sunflower oil habit.

In fact, failure to cut down my intake of corn, soya, safflower, grapeseed, peanut and sunflower oils, and at the same time to increase my intake of rapeseed, flaxseed, walnut and fish oils might, they said, put me at risk of contracting a whole raft of ailments ranging from sundry inflammations and auto-immune diseases to heart attacks, stroke, depression and cancer.

Cancer? What was going on here? Why was this not headline news? I read the book, then began to dig deeper, dipping into learned and not-so-learned journals, and talking to a variety of researchers. And it wasn't long before I made an important discovery about the subject of dietary fats - namely, that the processes involved are so subtle and complex that anyone can appear to prove anything simply by selecting their evidence with care. And given that, in matters of nutrition, much of the available evidence derives from studies funded by one or another rival branch of the food industry, that makes a quick tour of the subject akin to a drunken stroll through a hall of mirrors.

At the very least, one ought to go armed with the some basic facts. So here are some to be going on with.

The substance we call a fat is actually made up of compounds called fatty acids, attached to a backbone of glycerol (three parts fatty acid to one part glycerol equals my old friend the triglyceride - the chief form of fat obtained from plant and animal foods and stored in the body). For anyone, such as myself, whose knowledge of chemistry extends little further than a grasp of simple molecules with self-explanatory formulae such as H2O (two hydrogen atoms to every oxygen atom), this is tricky territory. The formula for linoleic acid, for example, is CH3 (CH CHCH) 3 (CH2) 7COOH. Most oils and fats contain at least a dozen of these fatty acids, and butter contains more than 100, each with different properties.

But while no layperson should linger long on this level, a brief visit to the world of molecules does clear up one or two nagging questions. Why, for instance, are some fats saturated, and what are they saturated with? Fatty acids are chains of carbon atoms bonded together in different ways, with hydrogen atoms attached, plus some oxygen atoms at one end. In a saturated fatty acid (SFA), the carbon atoms are all joined by single bonds, which means that there is nowhere for extra hydrogen atoms to attach themselves.

The molecule is therefore "satu rated" with hydrogen atoms. Unsaturated fats, on the other hand, have a different structure - one that allows more hydrogen to become attached. In monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFAs), one bond in the carbon chain is a double bond, but in polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) there are two or more such double bonds. Surprisingly, this subtle difference has dietary significance.

Another basic fact, frequently glossed over, is that the oils and fats we eat and cook with are actually cocktails of all three types of fatty acid - saturated, monounsatrated and polyunsaturated - in varying proportions (beef dripping, for instance, contains almost as much monounsaturated fat as saturated, and there's saturated fat in olive oil, but less of it).

With the exception of tropical oils such as palm and coconut, the more saturated fatty acids a fat contains, the more likely it is to solidify when cool (an oil, by the way, is simply a fat in a liquid state). And here's a rather silly fact for your next dinner party. If fish didn't have more unsaturated than saturated fats about their persons, they would seize up in the cold sea, as their saturated fat content congealed. But let's get back to basics.

What is fat for? Animals use it as a source of energy, as do plants (which is why so much oil is found in seeds). A single gram of fat produces nine calories, making it more than twice as valuable an energy source as protein or carbohydrates (starch and sugar). But fat is not just for burning. Every cell in our bodies is surrounded by a membrane that has fat as part of its structure (the human brain is, in fact, more than half "structural" fat), and layers of fat also cushion internal organs and insulate our bodies against cold. Fat carries a number of important substances around our system in solution, including vitamins A, D, E and K, and helps the body absorb them.

One class of polyunsaturated fatty acids is called essential fatty acids (EFAs), because our bodies can't function without them (a lot are used to build neurons in our brains). Nor can we synthesise them internally, so EFAs must be obtained ready-made through our food. Some of the essential fatty acids we eat are converted into chemical messengers, which play a part in a variety of processes involving everything from blood pressure and inflammation to the immune system and the perception of pain. EFAs divide into two groups, called omega-6 and omega-3 (again, the numbering is to do with the precise layout of those carbon atom double bonds), and their different properties are at the heart of much current debate.

Finding out positive things about fat is surprisingly easy these days, since organisations such as the British Heart Foundation and the British Dietetic Association seem anxious that we don't run away with the idea that all fat is bad and not a gram of it should enter our bodies. The Department of Health reckons that women need to consume a minimum of 30g of fat each day and men 40g in order to stay healthy (too little can cause infertility and bone weakness).

But if we get more than 35% of our total calories from fat (around 70g per day for women, 95g for men), things start to go wrong. The most visible problem is obesity, when our bodies lay down any surplus as "depot" fat, straining our systems as well as our wardrobes. In general, western diets - and, if recent reports of obesity among Hong Kong children addicted to fast food are anything to go by, many eastern ones, too - contain more fat than we are likely to burn off by fingering buttons on the TV remote control.

Consequently, while two-thirds of our species is dying from malnutrition, the other third is plagued with obesity and obsessed with reducing its body weight. But obesity is just an outward sign that something else is going on inside us. And we all know what that something is. For when it comes to getting information on the downside of fat, the lines are always open.

Chief villains, all but a handful of lard salesmen and celebrity diet gurus now agree, are the saturated fats, which turn up in meat and dairy products, as well as in those deceptive tropical oils. Men, we are told, should have no more than 30g of saturates a day, and women, including actresses and fashion models, no more than 20g.

Regimes such as the Zone Diet, followed by the likes of Jennifer Aniston, are said to switch off the insulin-driven fat storage mechanism by excluding carbohydrates. This alarms nutritionists, who argue that we are designed to obtain half our energy from carbohydrates. Cutting out an entire category of food has to be misguided, they say - particularly if the aim is to become skinnier than the next person and the next person is themselves so skinny that their next starring role is likely to be at their own funeral.

But most critics of the celebrity diet are concerned because it replaces carbohydrates as a source of energy with food that is rich in saturated fat. For one thing, they say, SFAs cause the blood to become sticky and to form clots; for another, they cause the liver and other organs to make a waxy substance called cholesterol.

Once it becomes oxidised, cholesterol can build up into a layer of plaque on the walls of blood vessels, constricting the flow and causing heart attacks and strokes, as well as scarring the vessels themselves. As a primary component of the membrane that surrounds each cell in the body, and as the starting material from which we make bile acids, steroid hormones and vitamin D, cholesterol, too, is essential to life. But the higher the level of it in our blood, the more readily it builds up on the vessel walls. And not only does saturated fat cause our livers to synthesise more cholesterol, but we also take it on board directly when we eat egg yolks, prawns, brains and other animal organs.

Cholesterol, being fatty in nature, doesn't actually dissolve in the blood (nothing is that simple in this game). Instead, it gets around by attaching itself to clumps of protein called lipoproteins. Low-density lipoproteins (LDLs) carry cholesterol from the liver and drop it off with the cells that need it. High-density lipoproteins (HDLs) are now thought to take excess cholesterol back to the liver to be broken down, which is why cholesterol attached to HDLs is often referred to as "good" cholesterol.

Some researchers believe that monounsaturated fatty acids - olive oil contains 80% and rapeseed oil 70% - reduce levels of LDLs and raise levels of HDLs when eaten in moderation (olive oil also contains a substance called squalene, which is thought to enhance this effect). Others, however, insist that they have no effect one way or the other. When it comes to the effects on cholesterol levels of polyunsaturated fatty acids - corn, cottonseed, fish, flaxseed, peanut, safflower, sunflower, soybean and walnut oils all contain high proportions of these - the picture is similarly confusing, with different claims made for different PUFAs. But on one thing, most authorities seem to agree: any unsaturate - mono or poly - is better than any saturate.

Everybody has said for years that SFAs were trouble. Which is why the late 50s marked the beginning of what must be the biggest shift in general eating habits ever to have taken place outside of wartime - the move from animal to vegetable fats. Such a shift was possible - a conspiracy theorist might say convenient, even - because modern industrial methods such as heat treatment and the use of chemical solvents meant that it was now possible to isolate large quantities of cheap oil from many of the seeds and grains previously discarded by the textile and animal-feed industries.

However, vegetable oil has one serious, practical disadvantage. It is liquid at room temperature. Therefore, in its natural form, it can neither be spread on bread nor used as a shortening in baking. Enter margarine (the word comes from the Greek word for pearl, as does the name Margaret). This stuff was invented by the French chemist Hippolyte Mège-Mouriès, who in 1869 won a prize offered by Napoleon III for a satisfactory butter substitute. It entails a process called hydrogenation, in which unsaturated fats are bombarded with hydrogen to make them more saturated and therefore firmer and longer-lasting. Trouble is, of course, you end up with a whole lot more saturated fatty acids, as well as some new molecules. These are called trans fatty acids (TFAs).

Meat and dairy products contain tiny amounts of naturally-occurring TFAs. But for a really big dose, tuck into fast food, pastries, biscuits, cakes, crisps - anything, in fact, that has "hydrogenated vegetable oil" on the label (anything, you might almost say, that comes out of a packet). The harder the margarine, the more trans fat it contains. And, according to most sources, TFAs work in much the same way as saturated fats. In other words, they also raise cholesterol levels and cause heart disease.

But did the massive shift away from animal fats bring with it deeper problems than those of hydrogenation? Artemis Simopoulos believes that it did. Central to the Aphrodite Diet is one of those arguments that seems so simple you wonder why you never heard it before. In terms of our genetic nuts and bolts, says Simopoulos (the back cover of the Aphrodite Diet points out that she was nutritional adviser to the Office of Consumer Affairs at the White House), humans have changed hardly at all since the Stone Age. For millions of years before that, our bodies developed in such a way as to make best use of the food available, and so slow is the process of evolution that we still need that particular blend of fuel in order to function properly.

Today, we in the west think of dairy and cereal products as age-old cornerstones of a natural, wholesome diet. But humans took up animal husbandry only a few thousand years ago - which may explain why our bodies seem unable to cope with large quantities of dairy products. The same goes for the development of wild grasses into cereal crops worth the bother of harvesting. According to Simopoulos, microscopic analysis of fossilised food and bones from paleolithic times shows that, instead of dairy and cereal foods, those old hunter-gatherers ate fruit and green vegetables - three times as much as we do - as well as considerably more fish. And their meat was from game that had itself fed on wild plants.

We might have grasped the important message about saturated fat, says Simopoulos, but in the rush to convert to vegetable oils we have overlooked the balance of essential fatty acids that our stone-age bodies were conditioned to expect. For while omega-6 fatty acids are abundant in oils such as corn, safflower, cottonseed and sunflower, omega-3 fatty acids are found primarily in seafood, green leafy vegetables, fatty fish, rapeseed oil, walnuts and flax. Recent research, Simopoulos says, suggests that our bodies function best when our diet contains a 4:1 ratio of omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acids. "Yet the typical western diet contains approximately 14 to 20 times more omega-6 fatty acids than omega-3s. This imbalance is now being linked with a long list of serious conditions and diseases."

Her Aphrodite Diet, incidentally - a "comprehensive three-week menu to get you started" with "fifty delicious and easy-to-make recipes" - is based on the local Cretan version of the traditional Mediterranean diet. As luck would have it, the food eaten for 4,000 years by sturdy Cretan shepherds (as opposed to the stuff their grandchildren serve us tourists in the harbourside cafes at Chania) had much in common nutritionally with the diet of prehistoric hunter-gatherers. Rich in the olive oil and fish consumed all over the Mediterranean region, but with additional large helpings of greens and wild plants, the Cretan diet had come out on top in a landmark study of seven world diets conducted back in the 60s.

The fact that Simopoulos is herself of Greek origin is one of those happy coincidences that crop up from time to time in every field of human endeavour.

"The Afro-what diet?"

"Aphrodite."

I was almost embarrassed to mention it. Where was it published? In a book. A book? That's right. A book with a picture of a woman in a white bikini on the cover.

"Pffffa!"

The occasional snort of derision was clearly audible. Did too much omega-6 fat promote tumour growth? If it did, then it was news to any of the researchers I spoke to. Yet other aspects of the Aphrodite argument were clearly present in mainstream thinking on this side of the Atlantic. Of omega-6 and omega-3 fatty acids, Lyndel Costain, of the British Dietetic Association, said, "The balance between these two classes of EFAs is important for their optimal function. As we usually get plenty of omega-6 fatty acids in our diet, we are encouraged to limit these and eat more omega-3s."

And to begin with, Dr Sheila Bingham, of the Dunn Human Nutrition Laboratory at Cambridge, seemed determined to stick to the same line. Clearly anxious that yet another journalist wanted to unpick all the good health education work of the past two decades for the sake of a dubious story, Bingham insisted, "The prime message is to cut down on saturated fats, because that is what brings down cholesterol, which is the risk factor in heart disease." In fact, she would go further than that. "In general, we need to eat less fat overall. And all of this has to be taken in the context of the general message, which is that we should be eating more fruit and vegetables and whole-grain cereals and things like that, because all the epidemiology shows that people who eat more vegetables have less heart disease."

What about omega-3 fatty acids? (I suddenly felt like a sly schoolboy who knew very well what the rules were but was trying to catch the teacher out, anyway). "The current recommendation is to eat two portions of fatty fish per week - mackerel, sardines, salmon, etc." And for omega-6? "The recommendation is that those levels should not increase at the moment. They are quite high."

Aha!

I didn't actually shout "Aha" down the phone, of course. But I was doing it again - turning the whole thing into a silly game - reverting to my former frame of mind in which I supposed that people such as Sheila Bingham take delight in making mealtimes a drab experience, unrelieved even by a dash of rapeseed oil (so conditioned are our palaeolithic bodies to seeking out rich fuel that even now, when fat is all around us and we don't need that much energy anyway, we still find it more appetising than anything else on the menu).

By the time I spoke to Dr Jane Armitage at the Clinical Trial Services Unit in Oxford, I had a firmer grip on my attitude. Which was just as well, since she had clearly had her fill of journalists chasing scare stories and missing the main point.

Armitage's work involves looking at the best research in the field and drawing conclusions from it. "Measuring people's food intake is fraught with difficulty," she told me, "so you need big numbers to make any sense of it. Big numbers mean big studies, and big studies are expensive. So there's no way a lot of it is going to get done."

And the research is difficult in more fundamental ways, too. "You can relate diet to intermediate things like cholesterol, and you can relate the cholesterol to heart disease. But it's extremely difficult to relate the diet to the heart disease. So you have to accept that there will be intermediate markers, but you have also to know that the intermediate markers are not of itself what's interesting. And so you've got to make the second link."

It turns out that my original question about triglyceride levels - still not answered to everybody's satisfaction - is a good example of this sort of conundrum. "It's been difficult to disentangle," said Armitage, "because when triglycerides are raised, the HDL, or good cholesterol, tends to go down. We know low HDL is bad, but because the two things always go together we can't tell whether high triglycerides is bad just because it lowers HDL, or whether it's bad in its own right. And journalists have done a big disservice by highlighting this sort of confusion.

"In the past, people didn't want to believe the cholesterol-lowering story. A lot of journalists highlighted the concerns, which were probably unfounded, about suicide and accidents and depression all being linked to low cholesterol, and that whole thing was blown out of proportion. But over the past five to 10 years, a series of very powerful cholesterol-lowering drugs have become available and a series of very good quality trials using those drugs have actually demon- strated in some groups that cholesterol lowering is both worthwhile and saves lives."

Worthwhile. Saves lives. The words were still ringing in my ears two days later when I dropped by to pick up my dreaded test results. Of course. The daughters of dairy farmers don't spend their lives taking blood samples and giving out dietary advice in crowded doctors' surgeries because they want to become exceedingly wealthy. They do it because it's sort of worthwhile. Because it might save a few lives. Me and the doctors, the dieticians and the nutritionists - we were on the same side, really. And each of us had just one aim in mind - to keep my heart pumping for a few more years. From now on, I would stop looking for excuses not to play my part in this thoroughly worthwhile project. Instead, I would make friends with the greengrocer, become a scourge of fatty fish everywhere and cut out my big breakfasts forthwith.

And nor would I err on the side of obsessiveness, since this was not going to be a competition after all. Her alarming talk about omega-6 fats notwithstanding, Simopoulos seemed a paragon of moderation. It would be a shame to throw the baby out with the sunflower oil, so I resolved to borrow some tips from Aphrodite - among them the almost certainly risk-free advice to switch to rapeseed oil as my "primary fat", and a recipe for a tasty half-saturated butter substitute that spreads straight from the fridge (just blend softened butter 50:50 with rapeseed oil, then refrigerate - it really isn't bad!).

So eager was I to get started on my sensible new regime that I didn't hear the receptionist the first time she said it. Normal, you say? The results are normal? But what about the triglycerides? Are you quite sure they aren't a little on the high side? No?

Oh well. Perhaps I would embark on my new diet, anyway. Perhaps

Even semi-skimmed milk was labelled "Eat in moderation 2-3 times a week only". How I would love to be a fly on the Yorkshire pudding when her family assembled for dinner. At first glance, her chart told me little that anybody who ever turned on a television or glanced at a magazine doesn't know by heart. Fruit and vegetables were the best source of nourishment, Bailey's cream liqueur the worst (when will they invent Bailey's Lite?). Fish was the food of the gods and taramasalata (fish eggs) the devil's work, while tofu and pork luncheonmeat glared at each other from opposite ends of the page. Occasionally, I would spot something that made my heart sink even deeper - crab meat was in the same category as oven chips, for instance, and both were lumped in with the liver that I had been brought up to consider the healthiest of foods. But this time I was going to bite the bullet (having first checked its fat content, of course). By giving free rein to my obsessive tendencies, I would show them the true meaning of lean cuisine. I'd be a model pupil - the ultimate convert. If the dieticians and nutritionists advised me to chew through two balls of string a day, then I'd be first in line when the hardware shop opened. And then I spotted the sunflower oil - "Eat in moderation, once a week or less," it said. That couldn't be right, could it? After all, switching to sunflower oil, "high in polyunsaturates", had been my one major concession to nutritional correctness during the long years in hiding. Yet there it was in pink and blue, on a chart issued "as a service to medicine" by the drug company Pfizer and "produced in association with the British Hypertension Society". Corn oil, soya oil, safflower oil, grapeseed oil, peanut oil, sunflower oil, once a week or less. The condemnation of something previously recommended unnerved me. Why, even eggs were allowed to appear at table three times a week. What about all those Flora commercials? Had I missed something? It occurred to me that I might not, after all, be committing myself into the hands of sane people. In 1938, the British Medical Association had urged the nation to consume more dairy products, more eggs and more meat, and my own childhood diet, supplemented by lashings of free school milk (full-cream), had clearly been based on precisely that advice. One rule change in a lifetime may be regarded as a misfortune; two looks like carelessness. Not for the first time, I recalled the film Sleeper, and the scene in which Woody Allen wakes up in the future to be told that bran is now known to be harmful and that biscuits, chocolate and cream cakes are actually the healthiest foods. And never mind the future. Were there not dissenting voices even in the present - people who argued that fatty food no more caused heart attacks than smoking caused lung cancer? Our fate was predetermined by our genetic make-up, said some. Tense, fidgety types would burn up surplus fat whatever they ate, said others. And how about this? Half of Hollywood and the bulk of the fashion industry (now there's an oxymoron) was apparently living on something called the Zone Diet, a high-protein regime that demanded the consumption of burgers, steaks, butter, bacon, cheese, milk and cream, and actually banned boring bread and prissy pasta - anything, in fact, that was rich in carbohydrate. Carbs, they said, were the new fat. Perhaps these were the people I should be listening to. As the nurse's syringe sucked at my arm, her little chart of dietary advice worked at my brain and drained from it every drop of my new-found resolve. So nothing had changed since the last time I sat in this chair. They were still running around in the dark. But if they thought they were taking me with them, they were mistaken. They could count triglycerides until they were blue in the face. But when the letter came referring me to the specialist - when the surgery phoned, begging me to come in for an urgent chat - I'd be at lunch. Or breakfast. Or dinner. Waiter! I think I'm ready to order. Acouple of days later, I was still sounding off noisily to anyone within earshot when a friend, desperate to shut me up, handed me a book called The Aphrodite Diet (Vermilion, £6.99). "The cover's dreadful," she said, "but you might find what's inside useful. It explains lots of stuff about fats." A tanned blonde in a white bikini stared out into the Aegean, wondering, no doubt, where her spare tyre had disappeared to. But beyond the cover were pie charts and bar graphs and any number of words like "arachidonic" and "fibrinogen". So I agreed to give the so-called experts one last chance. I secretly hoped that this would provide a convincing justification for that succulent meat-and-cream regime I'd been itching to share with Jennifer Aniston and Minnie Driver. But while the authors, Dr Artemis P Simopoulos and Jo Robinson, did have a cunning eating plan to sell - and one which argued that some types of fat, far from being the death of us, were actually an important item on the menu - it had more in common with the nurse's diet sheet than with titles such as A New Diet Revolution or Get Skinny On Fabulous Foods. One thing immediately caught my attention, however. This pair, it seemed, also wanted me to kick the sunflower oil habit. In fact, failure to cut down my intake of corn, soya, safflower, grapeseed, peanut and sunflower oils, and at the same time to increase my intake of rapeseed, flaxseed, walnut and fish oils might, they said, put me at risk of contracting a whole raft of ailments ranging from sundry inflammations and auto-immune diseases to heart attacks, stroke, depression and cancer. Cancer? What was going on here? Why was this not headline news? I read the book, then began to dig deeper, dipping into learned and not-so-learned journals, and talking to a variety of researchers. And it wasn't long before I made an important discovery about the subject of dietary fats - namely, that the processes involved are so subtle and complex that anyone can appear to prove anything simply by selecting their evidence with care. And given that, in matters of nutrition, much of the available evidence derives from studies funded by one or another rival branch of the food industry, that makes a quick tour of the subject akin to a drunken stroll through a hall of mirrors. At the very least, one ought to go armed with the some basic facts. So here are some to be going on with. The substance we call a fat is actually made up of compounds called fatty acids, attached to a backbone of glycerol (three parts fatty acid to one part glycerol equals my old friend the triglyceride - the chief form of fat obtained from plant and animal foods and stored in the body). For anyone, such as myself, whose knowledge of chemistry extends little further than a grasp of simple molecules with self-explanatory formulae such as H2O (two hydrogen atoms to every oxygen atom), this is tricky territory. The formula for linoleic acid, for example, is CH3 (CH CHCH) 3 (CH2) 7COOH. Most oils and fats contain at least a dozen of these fatty acids, and butter contains more than 100, each with different properties. But while no layperson should linger long on this level, a brief visit to the world of molecules does clear up one or two nagging questions. Why, for instance, are some fats saturated, and what are they saturated with? Fatty acids are chains of carbon atoms bonded together in different ways, with hydrogen atoms attached, plus some oxygen atoms at one end. In a saturated fatty acid (SFA), the carbon atoms are all joined by single bonds, which means that there is nowhere for extra hydrogen atoms to attach themselves. The molecule is therefore "satu rated" with hydrogen atoms. Unsaturated fats, on the other hand, have a different structure - one that allows more hydrogen to become attached. In monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFAs), one bond in the carbon chain is a double bond, but in polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) there are two or more such double bonds. Surprisingly, this subtle difference has dietary significance. Another basic fact, frequently glossed over, is that the oils and fats we eat and cook with are actually cocktails of all three types of fatty acid - saturated, monounsatrated and polyunsaturated - in varying proportions (beef dripping, for instance, contains almost as much monounsaturated fat as saturated, and there's saturated fat in olive oil, but less of it). With the exception of tropical oils such as palm and coconut, the more saturated fatty acids a fat contains, the more likely it is to solidify when cool (an oil, by the way, is simply a fat in a liquid state). And here's a rather silly fact for your next dinner party. If fish didn't have more unsaturated than saturated fats about their persons, they would seize up in the cold sea, as their saturated fat content congealed. But let's get back to basics. What is fat for? Animals use it as a source of energy, as do plants (which is why so much oil is found in seeds). A single gram of fat produces nine calories, making it more than twice as valuable an energy source as protein or carbohydrates (starch and sugar). But fat is not just for burning. Every cell in our bodies is surrounded by a membrane that has fat as part of its structure (the human brain is, in fact, more than half "structural" fat), and layers of fat also cushion internal organs and insulate our bodies against cold. Fat carries a number of important substances around our system in solution, including vitamins A, D, E and K, and helps the body absorb them. One class of polyunsaturated fatty acids is called essential fatty acids (EFAs), because our bodies can't function without them (a lot are used to build neurons in our brains). Nor can we synthesise them internally, so EFAs must be obtained ready-made through our food. Some of the essential fatty acids we eat are converted into chemical messengers, which play a part in a variety of processes involving everything from blood pressure and inflammation to the immune system and the perception of pain. EFAs divide into two groups, called omega-6 and omega-3 (again, the numbering is to do with the precise layout of those carbon atom double bonds), and their different properties are at the heart of much current debate. Finding out positive things about fat is surprisingly easy these days, since organisations such as the British Heart Foundation and the British Dietetic Association seem anxious that we don't run away with the idea that all fat is bad and not a gram of it should enter our bodies. The Department of Health reckons that women need to consume a minimum of 30g of fat each day and men 40g in order to stay healthy (too little can cause infertility and bone weakness). But if we get more than 35% of our total calories from fat (around 70g per day for women, 95g for men), things start to go wrong. The most visible problem is obesity, when our bodies lay down any surplus as "depot" fat, straining our systems as well as our wardrobes. In general, western diets - and, if recent reports of obesity among Hong Kong children addicted to fast food are anything to go by, many eastern ones, too - contain more fat than we are likely to burn off by fingering buttons on the TV remote control. Consequently, while two-thirds of our species is dying from malnutrition, the other third is plagued with obesity and obsessed with reducing its body weight. But obesity is just an outward sign that something else is going on inside us. And we all know what that something is. For when it comes to getting information on the downside of fat, the lines are always open. Chief villains, all but a handful of lard salesmen and celebrity diet gurus now agree, are the saturated fats, which turn up in meat and dairy products, as well as in those deceptive tropical oils. Men, we are told, should have no more than 30g of saturates a day, and women, including actresses and fashion models, no more than 20g. Regimes such as the Zone Diet, followed by the likes of Jennifer Aniston, are said to switch off the insulin-driven fat storage mechanism by excluding carbohydrates. This alarms nutritionists, who argue that we are designed to obtain half our energy from carbohydrates. Cutting out an entire category of food has to be misguided, they say - particularly if the aim is to become skinnier than the next person and the next person is themselves so skinny that their next starring role is likely to be at their own funeral. But most critics of the celebrity diet are concerned because it replaces carbohydrates as a source of energy with food that is rich in saturated fat. For one thing, they say, SFAs cause the blood to become sticky and to form clots; for another, they cause the liver and other organs to make a waxy substance called cholesterol. Once it becomes oxidised, cholesterol can build up into a layer of plaque on the walls of blood vessels, constricting the flow and causing heart attacks and strokes, as well as scarring the vessels themselves. As a primary component of the membrane that surrounds each cell in the body, and as the starting material from which we make bile acids, steroid hormones and vitamin D, cholesterol, too, is essential to life. But the higher the level of it in our blood, the more readily it builds up on the vessel walls. And not only does saturated fat cause our livers to synthesise more cholesterol, but we also take it on board directly when we eat egg yolks, prawns, brains and other animal organs. Cholesterol, being fatty in nature, doesn't actually dissolve in the blood (nothing is that simple in this game). Instead, it gets around by attaching itself to clumps of protein called lipoproteins. Low-density lipoproteins (LDLs) carry cholesterol from the liver and drop it off with the cells that need it. High-density lipoproteins (HDLs) are now thought to take excess cholesterol back to the liver to be broken down, which is why cholesterol attached to HDLs is often referred to as "good" cholesterol. Some researchers believe that monounsaturated fatty acids - olive oil contains 80% and rapeseed oil 70% - reduce levels of LDLs and raise levels of HDLs when eaten in moderation (olive oil also contains a substance called squalene, which is thought to enhance this effect). Others, however, insist that they have no effect one way or the other. When it comes to the effects on cholesterol levels of polyunsaturated fatty acids - corn, cottonseed, fish, flaxseed, peanut, safflower, sunflower, soybean and walnut oils all contain high proportions of these - the picture is similarly confusing, with different claims made for different PUFAs. But on one thing, most authorities seem to agree: any unsaturate - mono or poly - is better than any saturate. Everybody has said for years that SFAs were trouble. Which is why the late 50s marked the beginning of what must be the biggest shift in general eating habits ever to have taken place outside of wartime - the move from animal to vegetable fats. Such a shift was possible - a conspiracy theorist might say convenient, even - because modern industrial methods such as heat treatment and the use of chemical solvents meant that it was now possible to isolate large quantities of cheap oil from many of the seeds and grains previously discarded by the textile and animal-feed industries. However, vegetable oil has one serious, practical disadvantage. It is liquid at room temperature. Therefore, in its natural form, it can neither be spread on bread nor used as a shortening in baking. Enter margarine (the word comes from the Greek word for pearl, as does the name Margaret). This stuff was invented by the French chemist Hippolyte Mège-Mouriès, who in 1869 won a prize offered by Napoleon III for a satisfactory butter substitute. It entails a process called hydrogenation, in which unsaturated fats are bombarded with hydrogen to make them more saturated and therefore firmer and longer-lasting. Trouble is, of course, you end up with a whole lot more saturated fatty acids, as well as some new molecules. These are called trans fatty acids (TFAs). Meat and dairy products contain tiny amounts of naturally-occurring TFAs. But for a really big dose, tuck into fast food, pastries, biscuits, cakes, crisps - anything, in fact, that has "hydrogenated vegetable oil" on the label (anything, you might almost say, that comes out of a packet). The harder the margarine, the more trans fat it contains. And, according to most sources, TFAs work in much the same way as saturated fats. In other words, they also raise cholesterol levels and cause heart disease. But did the massive shift away from animal fats bring with it deeper problems than those of hydrogenation? Artemis Simopoulos believes that it did. Central to the Aphrodite Diet is one of those arguments that seems so simple you wonder why you never heard it before. In terms of our genetic nuts and bolts, says Simopoulos (the back cover of the Aphrodite Diet points out that she was nutritional adviser to the Office of Consumer Affairs at the White House), humans have changed hardly at all since the Stone Age. For millions of years before that, our bodies developed in such a way as to make best use of the food available, and so slow is the process of evolution that we still need that particular blend of fuel in order to function properly. Today, we in the west think of dairy and cereal products as age-old cornerstones of a natural, wholesome diet. But humans took up animal husbandry only a few thousand years ago - which may explain why our bodies seem unable to cope with large quantities of dairy products. The same goes for the development of wild grasses into cereal crops worth the bother of harvesting. According to Simopoulos, microscopic analysis of fossilised food and bones from paleolithic times shows that, instead of dairy and cereal foods, those old hunter-gatherers ate fruit and green vegetables - three times as much as we do - as well as considerably more fish. And their meat was from game that had itself fed on wild plants. We might have grasped the important message about saturated fat, says Simopoulos, but in the rush to convert to vegetable oils we have overlooked the balance of essential fatty acids that our stone-age bodies were conditioned to expect. For while omega-6 fatty acids are abundant in oils such as corn, safflower, cottonseed and sunflower, omega-3 fatty acids are found primarily in seafood, green leafy vegetables, fatty fish, rapeseed oil, walnuts and flax. Recent research, Simopoulos says, suggests that our bodies function best when our diet contains a 4:1 ratio of omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acids. "Yet the typical western diet contains approximately 14 to 20 times more omega-6 fatty acids than omega-3s. This imbalance is now being linked with a long list of serious conditions and diseases." Her Aphrodite Diet, incidentally - a "comprehensive three-week menu to get you started" with "fifty delicious and easy-to-make recipes" - is based on the local Cretan version of the traditional Mediterranean diet. As luck would have it, the food eaten for 4,000 years by sturdy Cretan shepherds (as opposed to the stuff their grandchildren serve us tourists in the harbourside cafes at Chania) had much in common nutritionally with the diet of prehistoric hunter-gatherers. Rich in the olive oil and fish consumed all over the Mediterranean region, but with additional large helpings of greens and wild plants, the Cretan diet had come out on top in a landmark study of seven world diets conducted back in the 60s. The fact that Simopoulos is herself of Greek origin is one of those happy coincidences that crop up from time to time in every field of human endeavour. "The Afro-what diet?" "Aphrodite." I was almost embarrassed to mention it. Where was it published? In a book. A book? That's right. A book with a picture of a woman in a white bikini on the cover. "Pffffa!" The occasional snort of derision was clearly audible. Did too much omega-6 fat promote tumour growth? If it did, then it was news to any of the researchers I spoke to. Yet other aspects of the Aphrodite argument were clearly present in mainstream thinking on this side of the Atlantic. Of omega-6 and omega-3 fatty acids, Lyndel Costain, of the British Dietetic Association, said, "The balance between these two classes of EFAs is important for their optimal function. As we usually get plenty of omega-6 fatty acids in our diet, we are encouraged to limit these and eat more omega-3s." And to begin with, Dr Sheila Bingham, of the Dunn Human Nutrition Laboratory at Cambridge, seemed determined to stick to the same line. Clearly anxious that yet another journalist wanted to unpick all the good health education work of the past two decades for the sake of a dubious story, Bingham insisted, "The prime message is to cut down on saturated fats, because that is what brings down cholesterol, which is the risk factor in heart disease." In fact, she would go further than that. "In general, we need to eat less fat overall. And all of this has to be taken in the context of the general message, which is that we should be eating more fruit and vegetables and whole-grain cereals and things like that, because all the epidemiology shows that people who eat more vegetables have less heart disease." What about omega-3 fatty acids? (I suddenly felt like a sly schoolboy who knew very well what the rules were but was trying to catch the teacher out, anyway). "The current recommendation is to eat two portions of fatty fish per week - mackerel, sardines, salmon, etc." And for omega-6? "The recommendation is that those levels should not increase at the moment. They are quite high." Aha! I didn't actually shout "Aha" down the phone, of course. But I was doing it again - turning the whole thing into a silly game - reverting to my former frame of mind in which I supposed that people such as Sheila Bingham take delight in making mealtimes a drab experience, unrelieved even by a dash of rapeseed oil (so conditioned are our palaeolithic bodies to seeking out rich fuel that even now, when fat is all around us and we don't need that much energy anyway, we still find it more appetising than anything else on the menu). By the time I spoke to Dr Jane Armitage at the Clinical Trial Services Unit in Oxford, I had a firmer grip on my attitude. Which was just as well, since she had clearly had her fill of journalists chasing scare stories and missing the main point. Armitage's work involves looking at the best research in the field and drawing conclusions from it. "Measuring people's food intake is fraught with difficulty," she told me, "so you need big numbers to make any sense of it. Big numbers mean big studies, and big studies are expensive. So there's no way a lot of it is going to get done." And the research is difficult in more fundamental ways, too. "You can relate diet to intermediate things like cholesterol, and you can relate the cholesterol to heart disease. But it's extremely difficult to relate the diet to the heart disease. So you have to accept that there will be intermediate markers, but you have also to know that the intermediate markers are not of itself what's interesting. And so you've got to make the second link." It turns out that my original question about triglyceride levels - still not answered to everybody's satisfaction - is a good example of this sort of conundrum. "It's been difficult to disentangle," said Armitage, "because when triglycerides are raised, the HDL, or good cholesterol, tends to go down. We know low HDL is bad, but because the two things always go together we can't tell whether high triglycerides is bad just because it lowers HDL, or whether it's bad in its own right. And journalists have done a big disservice by highlighting this sort of confusion. "In the past, people didn't want to believe the cholesterol-lowering story. A lot of journalists highlighted the concerns, which were probably unfounded, about suicide and accidents and depression all being linked to low cholesterol, and that whole thing was blown out of proportion. But over the past five to 10 years, a series of very powerful cholesterol-lowering drugs have become available and a series of very good quality trials using those drugs have actually demon- strated in some groups that cholesterol lowering is both worthwhile and saves lives." Worthwhile. Saves lives. The words were still ringing in my ears two days later when I dropped by to pick up my dreaded test results. Of course. The daughters of dairy farmers don't spend their lives taking blood samples and giving out dietary advice in crowded doctors' surgeries because they want to become exceedingly wealthy. They do it because it's sort of worthwhile. Because it might save a few lives. Me and the doctors, the dieticians and the nutritionists - we were on the same side, really. And each of us had just one aim in mind - to keep my heart pumping for a few more years. From now on, I would stop looking for excuses not to play my part in this thoroughly worthwhile project. Instead, I would make friends with the greengrocer, become a scourge of fatty fish everywhere and cut out my big breakfasts forthwith. And nor would I err on the side of obsessiveness, since this was not going to be a competition after all. Her alarming talk about omega-6 fats notwithstanding, Simopoulos seemed a paragon of moderation. It would be a shame to throw the baby out with the sunflower oil, so I resolved to borrow some tips from Aphrodite - among them the almost certainly risk-free advice to switch to rapeseed oil as my "primary fat", and a recipe for a tasty half-saturated butter substitute that spreads straight from the fridge (just blend softened butter 50:50 with rapeseed oil, then refrigerate - it really isn't bad!). So eager was I to get started on my sensible new regime that I didn't hear the receptionist the first time she said it. Normal, you say? The results are normal? But what about the triglycerides? Are you quite sure they aren't a little on the high side? No? Oh well. Perhaps I would embark on my new diet, anyway. Perhaps

fields.headline: Candidates braced for domino effect
fields.standfirst:
The US elections: special report

A quiet revolution has taken place in the rhythm of US presidential politics
fields.trailText: Rescheduling of the primary calendar means that Monday's Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary on February 1, which traditionally kick off the political season, are more crucial than ever in the nomination process. Wins will set the successful candidates racing towards more victories in crucial votes on March 7 and 14.
fields.body:
Rescheduling of the primary calendar means that Monday's Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary on February 1, which traditionally kick off the political season, are more crucial than ever in the nomination process. Wins will set the successful candidates racing towards more victories in crucial votes on March 7 and 14.

An early win this time is likely to have a strong domino effect on the later stages of the contest. For the frontrunners in particular, early wins in Iowa and New Hampshire will all but guarantee final victory, while the pressure on the outsiders to win early and often has become even more intense.

In earlier elections, the campaign trail that begins in Iowa and ends at the national party conventions in August used to stretch from midwinter to early summer, but the new timetable means this year's contest is a sprint rather than a long-distance event.

Nearly three quarters of the delegates to the party conventions will be chosen between February 1 and March 7, the primary "Super Tuesday", when the two largest states, California and New York, are among 11 voting that day.

This frontloading of the primary season was designed to help candidates backed by the party establishments - Al Gore for the Democrats and George W Bush for the Republicans - since only they could accumulate the funding to organise so early and on such a wide scale.

The old days when an outsider could win an early primary and then build momentum and funding for a serious challenge have gone. The rescheduling has created a "pre-campaign" in which presidential hopefuls were knocked out not by a lack of votes, but by a lack of cash.

Candidates including Elizabeth Dole and Dan Quayle abandoned the Republican race last autumn, overwhelmed by Mr Bush's financial juggernaut. Among the Democrats, Mr Gore's early lock on the nomination meant that potential challengers like Dick Gephardt and Bob Kerrey decided it was not even worth bothering.

webTitle: Bush stakes all on promise to halve tax bills

fields.headline: Bush stakes all on promise to halve tax bills
fields.standfirst:
On Monday the battle for the White House begins in Iowa. The next 10 days could decide who becomes the world's most powerful political leader
The US elections: special report
George W Bush official site
fields.trailText: If the opinion polls are correct, then in just twelve months' time, George W Bush will stand in front of the United States Capitol in Washington, place his hand on the Bible and be sworn in as Bill Clinton's presidential successor.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Pittsfield, New Hampshire
fields.body:
If the opinion polls are correct, then in just twelve months' time, George W Bush will stand in front of the United States Capitol in Washington, place his hand on the Bible and be sworn in as Bill Clinton's presidential successor.

Cheryl Kendall voted for Mr Clinton, twice, though she would not do so again "after Monica". This week, along with other workers at Globe Manufacturing in Pittsfield, Ms Kendall took a break from her sewing machine to listen as Mr Bush toured their factory, campaigning for next month's New Hampshire Republican party primary.

As at every stop on the campaign trail, Mr Bush focuses on his proposed tax-cutting plan. His message is "a tax cut for every American", and he promises to halve taxes for what he calls "the typical New Hampshire family". It adds up to a $483bn cut over five years.

But if Ms Kendall is any guide, he is pushing the wrong buttons. "Honestly, taxes aren't that important to me," she said after he had finished speaking. "I do OK. Health reform - that's a big thing."

Around her, other workers seemed to agree. "Tax cuts really aren't a big deal," said Dave Hauver, a cuff cutter at the factory which makes protective clothing for firefighters. "I'd rather see him put the money into social security. I have other issues that are important to me."

For a man who is riding high in the polls, and who sits on top of a campaign war chest that has daunted almost all of his rivals out of the Republican nomination contest, Mr Bush is taking a momentous gamble. The opinion polls consistently say that American voters are less concerned with tax cuts than they are with "saving" the social security pension system and bolstering the limited health care systems for the elderly and the poor. Voters like Ms Kendall and Mr Hauver reflect those priorities.

The Bush bandwagon believes that voters like these clothing workers are either untypical, or else that in the privacy of the polling booth they will take a more self-interested view, as voters often have in traditionally anti-tax New Hampshire.

Mr Bush's gamble is that the politics of the 1980s still work in the 21st century. Tax cutting was the issue that defined US politics in the 1980s, when inflation reigned. It took Ronald Reagan and Mr Bush's father to the White House and fuelled the Republican revolution led by Newt Gingrich in 1994.

Tax is again the battleground in the Republican race between Mr Bush and John McCain in New Hampshire, where the 2000 election year's first primary contest occurs in 10 days time, and is set to be at the centre of the clash with the Democrats before the November 7 presidential election.

This week, with Mr McCain attacking his rival's tax-cutting plan as irresponsible, Mr Bush hit back, campaigning in a more aggressive manner as he shuttled between the icy cold of the New Hampshire winter and the snow covered plains of Iowa, where voters go to the polls in caucuses on Monday.

"There's a fundamental debate going on in this contest," Mr Bush, his breath steaming in the sub-zero temperatures, told truck drivers assembled in a Concord warehouse for an early morning breakfast stop.

"My tax plan is not a political document. It is a policy document. I believe that someone running for president must lay out a plan that he is willing to defend all the way, through not only the primaries but the general election."

His campaign has begun airing two new television adverts. "Washington politicians want to keep your money in Washington. Not me," he says in the first ad. "You settle the debate: tax cuts or bigger government."

The Bush camp has been in vigorated by what it believes is both a tactical and a strategic error on taxes by Mr McCain. Mr Bush thinks his rival's more modest tax plans, which are focused on lower paid and middle-class voters rather than on the rich, do not add up, and that they underestimate the public's appetite for bigger cuts.

"There are fundamental flaws in the costing of his tax proposals that undermine its credibility," said Karen Hughes, Mr Bush's chief spokeswoman, yesterday. webTitle: Bradley puts brave face on health setback

fields.headline: Bradley puts brave face on health setback
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Bill Bradley's attempt to win the Democratic nomination for the presidency with a campaign based on a new politics of decency and honesty was knocked further off course yesterday by the old doctrine of human frailty.
fields.body:
Bill Bradley's attempt to win the Democratic nomination for the presidency with a campaign based on a new politics of decency and honesty was knocked further off course yesterday by the old doctrine of human frailty.

Only three days before the most important test of support for the former New Jersey senator, he admitted that he had suffered four more "episodes" of the heart condition first revealed last month.

Mr Bradley, who has atrial fibrillation - a normally benign heart rhythm disturbance in which two chambers flutter instead of pumping properly - said that the stress of campaigning had not affected his health.

But the 56-year-old former New York Knicks basketball star, who is running something of a one-man campaign, has had four bouts in the past five weeks, compared with seven in the previous four years. And Dr Barry Mangel, a cardiologist, said: "Stress can play a role in how frequent the reoccurrences are."

Mr Bradley, who went ahead with a campaign breakfast as planned yesterday, said: "It has no impact on the race or my campaign, or my intensity of campaigning. It's just the nature of the particular situation that from time to time it spins out. You don't feel weak, it's just this odd sensation." He was taking medication and had consulted his doctor on the telephone.

The challenger to vice-president Al Gore for the Democratic nomination, whose devotion to privacy has been represented by his opponents as aloofness, spoke about his condition after it was reported on the internet.

His advertising for Monday's Iowa caucus, in which he trails Mr Gore by up to 23 points, has tried to have it both ways: reminding voters of his celebrity and record as a scholar while trading on the self effacing line: "Basically the guy you hated in high school".

Other presidential hopefuls are happy to wear their faith on their sleeves: the Republican frontrunner George W Bush is a soldier for Christ; Mr Gore is born again. Mr Bradley doesn't want to talk about it.

What he does want to talk about are the central issues of his campaign: child poverty, health care, race relations and gun control - issues chosen with little help from his advisers.

The extent to which the burden of Mr Bradley's campaign falls on the candidate is indicated by Dan Okimoto, an old college friend. "His mastery obviates the need for close policy advisers" said Prof Okimoto of Stanford university.

"There is no such structure in place on foreign policy or any other issue. The candidate is in charge of tone, direction, vision, and those around him provide support. Both in a political sense and on policy, Bill Bradley is his campaign."

He has tried to play on his outsider status by claiming that the Iowa caucus rewards entrenched power, a charge the Gore camp dismisses as an acknowledgement that Mr Bradley's failure on Monday is inevitable. And Mr Bradley's decision to invest so much time and money in Iowa - the maximum $2.2m - has been questioned when he has a much better chance of victory a week later in the New Hampshire primary.

The apparent contradiction of sometimes appearing remote and arrogant while aspiring to restore trust and civility to politics was demonstrated when Mr Bradley was told of a mother without health insurance for her four sons, one of whom apologised for being ill.

Mr Bradley was moved and said no child should have to do so. "I feel that it was clearly a moment where my personal feelings yielded and in a way it reminded me at a very deep level why I'm doing what I'm doing."

But when he was asked if he could speak about the co-chairman of his Iowa campaign, who had just died, Mr Bradley said "No, I can't," then later delivered a eulogy.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Remand for boy in murder case
A 12 year old boy appeared before magistrates yesterday charged with murdering his six-month-old baby brother. The boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was remanded to local authority secure accommodation for a week at a 20-minute hearing in Bristol.

Designer jailed for arson scam
The daughter of an Egyptian high court judge has been jailed for setting fire to her belongings in a £165,000 insurance scam. Interior designer Suzanne Halim, 46, torched a garage piled high with designer clothes, paintings and jewellery at her home in Gerrards Cross, Buckinghamshire, days after taking out a £214,000 policy. She was jailed for three months at Reading crown court.

She was jailed for three months at Reading crown court.

Dyke shares saga goes on
The saga of Greg Dyke's shares continued yesterday when the new director-general of the BBC was reminded he owns £175,000 of shares in Pearson Television - a day after disposing of his shares in Granada. Mr Dyke said he had forgotten the shares but had now asked Pearson to hold them in trust to be sold for charity. Teenager drove over mother
A teenage boy who had never driven before accidentally reversed over his mother and killed her, an inquest heard yesterday. Shan Stalker, 41, had been cleaning the car at her home in Broughton, north Wales. Her son Bryn, 17, was in the driving seat when she stood at the open door and started to tell him how to drive. The vehicle shot back over his mother.

North-east Wales coroner John Hughes, recording an accidental death verdict, said: "I can only imagine the horror that young boy felt."

webTitle: Cities to vote on elected mayors

fields.headline: Cities to vote on elected mayors
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Big cities in England will be ordered by the government to hold referendums to test whether electors want a London-style mayor.
fields.body:
Big cities in England will be ordered by the government to hold referendums to test whether electors want a London-style mayor.

Angered by strong resistance to council reforms in a string of town halls, ministers have decided to get tough with Labour councils by forcing through changes.

They want to hold a "democracy day", possibly in November, when all large cities - principally Manchester, Liverpool, Leeds, Newcastle, Bristol, Sheffield, and Birmingham - will be told to hold referendums, similar to an exercise in London after the last election.

But to avoid a repetition of the London selection fiasco, they are already sounding out potential mayoral candidates, such as Jeff Rooker, the social security minister and MP for Birmingham Perry Barr. He is to leave parliament at the next election, but plans to stay in public life.

In a series of surprise amendments to the local government bill, now before parliament, ministers have also decided to make it much easier for electors to force change on smaller councils.

They had stipulated that a petition from a minimum of 5% of the electorate would be necessary to force a reluctant council to hold a mayoral referendum.

That limit is to be scrapped. This leaves the way open for the environment secretary, John Prescott, to decide on a much lower threshold.

webTitle: Isle of Man to raise fishing boat to recover bodies

fields.headline: Isle of Man to raise fishing boat to recover bodies
fields.trailText: The fishing boat Solway Harvester, which sank with the loss of all seven crew, is to be raised to recover their bodies, the Isle of Man government said yesterday.
fields.body:
The fishing boat Solway Harvester, which sank with the loss of all seven crew, is to be raised to recover their bodies, the Isle of Man government said yesterday.

Authorities are seeking a contractor to bring up the scallop dredger, which has been lying about 11 miles east of the island since January 12.

The chief minister, Donald Gelling, said: "We can understand the feelings of the families and their desire to have their menfolk back. If we can give the families the comfort of returning the crew members for burial, then we will do so."

The move to raise the boat was agreed by the island's council of ministers and is subject to approval by Tynwald, its parliament, which will sit on Tuesday. Approval for funding is unlikely to be withheld.

Mr Gelling said: "This stance was adopted on humanitarian grounds and because the Isle of Man has a maritime and fishing tradition which it shares with the people of Whithorn."

The seven men who died all came from the Machars area of Galloway in Scotland, which includes the villages of the Isle of Whithorn - Whithorn and Garlieston.

The operation will start next Friday at the earliest, subject to weather conditions.

Whithorn councillor Alistair Geddes said the community was grateful for the Manx government's pledge to raise the wreck. "The community is totally behind the families in their endeavours to bring the boys home," he said. "The quicker the boat is raised and the quicker the crew is recovered the better for the families and the community."

Among the contractors bid ding to raise the wreck is Smit, Dutch owner of the Tak Lift 7, the recovery vessel that raised the wreck of the Sapphire, which sank off Peterhead, Aberdeenshire, in 1997 with the loss of four men's lives. It was retrieved only after hundreds of thousands of pounds was raised through an appeal by the widows after the government refused to help.

One body among the Solway Harvester crew was located this week by video cameras surveying the wreck, but has not yet been identified.

Any bodies recovered will be returned to the families after an inquest has been opened on the Isle of Man.

The seven were the skipper, Andrew Craig Mills, 29, his brother Robin Mills, 33, their cousin David Mills, 17, Martin Milligan, 26, John Murphy, 22, David Lyons, 18, and Wesley Jolly, 17.

fields.headline: Charity defends heroin advert
fields.trailText: Barnardo's, the children's charity, yesterday defended the use of an advertisement which shows a baby boy apparently preparing to inject heroin.
fields.body:
Barnardo's, the children's charity, yesterday defended the use of an advertisement which shows a baby boy apparently preparing to inject heroin.

It said the image was designed to be challenging, and attacked the advertising industry watchdog, the Committee of Advertising Practice, for attempting to "censor" the campaign. The committee has written to newspapers, asking them not to accept the advertisement.

Andrew Newbel, the charity's director of marketing and communications, said it had carefully considered the use of the graphic image, which is part of a series of adverts. "The basic premise of the entire campaign is centred on Barnardo's work with children and young people to prevent them experiencing the negative situations shown in the advertising.

"The campaign is designed to make sure people stop and reconsider their views, not only about Barnardo's work, but also about the range of issues highlighted in the campaign."

Other adverts in the series have attracted complaints, but all have been rejected by the Advertising Standards Authority. The latest image portrays a heroin addict as a young child. The picture has been digitally altered to show the baby grasping a tourniquet in his teeth and holding a syringe.

The advert appears in the Weekend section of today's Guardian. Alan Rusbridger, the editor of the Guardian, said: "It is shocking, but it is the sort of image that Guardian readers are sophisticated enough to deal with, and understand its message."

webTitle: Rural patients to benefit from mobile GP surgeries

fields.headline: Rural patients to benefit from mobile GP surgeries
fields.trailText: People living in rural areas may soon be able to step outside their front door into a fully functioning doctor's surgery, under government proposals announced yesterday.
fields.body:
People living in rural areas may soon be able to step outside their front door into a fully functioning doctor's surgery, under government proposals announced yesterday.

The hi-tech mobile treatment units would offer services ranging from check-ups to minor surgery, removing the need for people to travel miles to see their GP simply for a routine procedure.

Building on the principle behind mobile breast screening and blood donation vans, other services such as chiropody, physiotherapy, and ear, nose and throat examinations could also be provided.

As well as improving access to care, the move would save money on renting buildings for the same services, which are often only used on a part-time basis.

The proposals are part of a package of measures unveiled yesterday by the health minister John Denham to improve access to GP surgeries in some of the most deprived areas of England. "Patients expect modern and accessible local service and GPs want to provide them," he said. "What we are doing is making it more practical and financially feasible for this to happen."

A few areas have already begun to develop the idea of taking some specialist services out of hospitals, putting them on wheels and carrying them to where they are most easily accessible. "If you look at an area like the Welsh valleys, it has be come difficult to justify massive investment in health care because the communities are breaking down," said Simon Fradd, a Nottingham GP and chairman of the BMA's GP committee. "But why should these people have a second-rate health service? With mobile units, they can have specialist services right in the middle of their village."

Lorna Sambrook, policy officer for Action with Communities in Rural England, said: "Mobile health centres would be an important step towards taking some of the difficulty out of the lives of people living in rural areas. Just getting access to a GP can be very difficult, especially for the elderly or for people living in poverty who cannot afford to get transport."

fields.headline: Robber gets 22 life sentences
fields.standfirst: 'Two strikes and you're out' law applied to gunman
fields.trailText: A Glaswegian was yesterday given 22 life sentences after travelling to London to raise cash through armed robbery but netting only £1,500.
fields.body:
A Glaswegian was yesterday given 22 life sentences after travelling to London to raise cash through armed robbery but netting only £1,500.

Dereck Brockwell, 38, had admitted carrying out nine armed robberies and two attempted armed robberies, and had pleaded guilty to 11 charges of possessing a firearm while raiding bookmakers, off-licences and a building society over three weeks last year.

At the Old Bailey, Judge Giles Forrester jailed Brockwell for life on each charge under the "two strikes and you're out" rule.

Brockwell, who had previous convictions, was told the sentence was equivalent to 13 years in jail. He could seek parole after six years.

The judge said: "You well deserve the life sentences. You had a genuine firearm, and there is no doubt the employees, who were mainly women, were terrified. Crimes like this are all too prevalent. This type of sentence may halt the ever increasing violence in London."

The court was told that Brockwell had been living in various hostels and hotels with his wife and daughter in Glasgow. He told police he had owed £4,500 because of a drugs deal, and decided to go to London to raise some money with the aim of returning to Scotland to make a new start.
