fields.headline: Scuba diving death toll soars
fields.trailText: The number of people killed in scuba diving accidents in UK waters has more than doubled in three years, according to official figures released yesterday which raise fresh fears that the soaring popularity of adventure sports is endangering lives.
fields.body:
The number of people killed in scuba diving accidents in UK waters has more than doubled in three years, according to official figures released yesterday which raise fresh fears that the soaring popularity of adventure sports is endangering lives.

The maritime and coastguard agency revealed there were 18 fatalities last year - compared with 15 in 1998 and seven in 1997 - the overwhelming majority of which were blamed on a lack of training.

In one incident, said the agency's report, a diver suffered a burst lung when he surfaced too quickly, while another lost buoyancy and sank to her death in 55 metres of water.

Six people died after suffering suspected heart attacks while diving, another diver became separated from her support boat and drowned on the surface in rough seas, and a novice was hit on the head by a boat's propeller and died instantly.

Reg Hill, the agency's diving officer, blamed most incidents on "rapid ascents and missed decompression stops".

"It is clear that divers are failing to maintain correct buoyancy control, and have failed to keep their weightbelts attached at crucial moments," he said. "It is also evident that some of the incidents are caused by divers panicking, especially novices.

"The primary reason for lack of buoyancy control appears to be training, or the lack of it."

In common with other pursuits once regarded as extreme, such as white water rafting, skydiving, snowboarding and canyoning, scuba diving has enjoyed a huge burst in popularity in the past 10 years, driven to a large extent by the wide availability of cheap diving excursions on package holidays overseas.

The agency estimates that up to 1.5m dives take place in UK waters annually. While most of these are in coastal waters, one diver died at Coniston Water in the Lake District.

The figures are likely to in crease calls for the statutory enforcement of minimum training standards.

In the UK, the three main training organisations are British Sub Aqua Clubs, the Sub Aqua Association and the Professional Association of Diving Instructors (PADI), each of which designs its own instruction programmes.

Eric Albinsson, quality assurance manager at the UK branch of PADI, the world's largest dive training organisation, said the sport had grown so much because, as well as becoming more accessible, the equipment was better and the training, "which used to be very militaristic", was now geared towards the recreational diver.

"Of course we strive to reduce incidents to a minimum, ideally zero, but as with any activity, the more people you have the more difficult that becomes."

There was some positive news for the sport in the agency's report.

The number of non-fatal incidents last year was down on the previous two years, with 105 people requiring medical assistance after dives. This was mainly for decompression sickness.

webTitle: Tension high for return of 'Mi General'

fields.headline: Tension high for return of 'Mi General'
fields.standfirst:
Pinochet on trial: special report

Supporters pray for Pinochet but families of the disappeared still hope to pursue him through the courts
fields.trailText: The military church is packed with worshippers on this balmy Santiago night. They kneel beneath the crossed-rifles banner of the police, they sit quietly as the army chaplain addresses them on the love of God and they rise to the strains of Ave Maria. But the beneficiary of their adoring prayers remains thousands of miles away in Virginia Water.
fields.body:
The military church is packed with worshippers on this balmy Santiago night. They kneel beneath the crossed-rifles banner of the police, they sit quietly as the army chaplain addresses them on the love of God and they rise to the strains of Ave Maria. But the beneficiary of their adoring prayers remains thousands of miles away in Virginia Water.

The Pinochetistas have gathered for what they hope will be the last such mass before the return of Mi General which is daily anticipated as imminente in the Chilean press. The congregation of some 400 who have gathered in the Providencia district opposite the military hospital to hear the chaplain, Enrique Lehuele, praise Gen Pinochet and mock Jack Straw, are almost all women over the age of 50, a sub-tropical Conservative party conference with the general substituted for his biggest supporter, La Thatcher.

There are a few younger supporters gathered outside. Pancho Malo, as he introduces himself, is wearing a Glasgow Rangers shirt. "I like Paul Gascoigne," [who has, of course, long since departed Glasgow]. He backs the general: "If it had not been for him this country would have been taken over by communists."

A woman passenger in one of the capital's bright yellow buses makes a "you-are-loonies" sign at the crowd by twirling a finger beside her head. Two Pinochetistas immediately board the bus and furiously upbraid and threaten her.

Tensions are high and any Britons or Spaniards in the vicinity are given a swift angry lesson on communism, socialism and the necessity for "strong action".

A few miles up towards the Andes, in the wealthy suburb of Las Condes, a portrait of Gen Pinochet, casually dressed in beret and combat fatigues, smiles across the table.

This is the headquarters of the Pinochet Foundation, the body set up to promote his beliefs and provide scholarships for young Chileans. And it is here that his supporters are waiting for news of the general's liberacion from the United Kingdom.

Monica Wehrann of the foundation says: "We find it hard to understand why there is so much hatred for him."

Focus on fundraising

The foundation's chief work over the past year has been raising funds for Gen Pinochet's considerable legal costs in London. Their current bulletin prints a picture of a member of his defence team, Clare Montgomery QC, and gives details of the latest legal news and demonstra tions in favour of the general in Chile and London.

"No, we are not angry with the British because so many of the British are supporting us - Lord Lamont, Lady Thatcher, many people," says Ms Wehrann, siting beneath the portrait and beside a bust of Gen Pinochet in his more familiar military cap.

"When he comes back, everything will be as before with Britain and Spain." She does not believe that Gen Pinochet will make political capital of his return: "He is an old man, I don't believe he will be active. He wants to see his family."

Leonora Gajardo, of the Comando Soberania Nacional, has been helping to organise the regular street demonstrations in favour of the general. She is adamant that the general is genuinely unwell and is not faking senility to avoid trial.

"I know he is ill, he will have to spend at least two months in hospital. He is suffering. He has been called a fanatic but he is just patriotic, he loves his people, he loves his country. He is a symbol of Chile."

Ms Gajardo, an animated young woman from Santiago who has been involved in the campaign to have Gen Pinochet returned for more than a year, said that the international protesters against him did not understand what was happening in Chile in 1973.

"There were 1,000 Cubans here preparing for a civil war. The people asked them [the military] to intervene so that they could have something to eat." She does not think the return will provoke a violent reaction - "only the socialists would provoke violence". But equally she does not think that there will be a grand fiesta. "It will be a moment for reflection."

Whether Gen Pinochet carries out his reflections in the military hospital in the Providencia district or elsewhere when - or if - he returns is still a subject of discussion. The foundation believes he will go to the hospital, but it is located at a busy intersection and near tall buildings where human rights demonstrators could make their feelings heard.

Another possibility is that he would avoid Santiago and go to the Chilean air force base in Iquique in northern Chile where he could be treated in the airborne medical facility that is due to take him out of Brize Norton.

One woman who has had more time than many to reflect is Viviana Diaz, whose father, a leading communist and union organiser, "disappeared" in 1976, three years after the coup that brought Gen Pinochet to power.

The poster that greets the visitor to the Families of the Disappeared off Avenida O'Higgins is of a group of those who are still missing with the slogan Donde estan? (where are they?): smiling young men with 70s' haircuts, smiling young women dressed as for a graduation photo, a small percentage of the 3,000 now officially believed to have been murdered during the Pinochet dictatorship.

Morale boost

"We are still hoping that he will not be coming back," says Ms Diaz. Above her is a notice, changed daily, noting that it is now 461 days since Gen Pinochet was detained in London. She says that his arrest and the time that he has now spent out of the country had been a great morale-booster for all those who had lost family members.

There are still 300 active members of the group but it is dwindling. "All your life you continue looking but now there are mothers dying who never knew what happened to their children."

But she is concerned that if Gen Pinochet returns he may never stand trial. "His illness is just the illness of age. Here people who rob in order to eat go to prison while someone who has killed and tortured goes free. And the torture of not knowing what has happened [to a relative] is an ongoing torture. This is still an open wound for us."

She is hopeful, however, that he will be prosecuted because the amnesty dealt only with crimes that had been commit ted in the past while a kidnap or disappearance, she said, was a continuing crime and thus could be pursued. This is a view shared by the crusading judge Juan Guzman, who is still anxious to pursue criminal charges in connection with more than 50 cases against Gen Pinochet and believes he is fit enough to stand trial.

Ms Diaz, who has dedicated her life to the cause of the disappeared, takes her telephone off the hook at night because of the anonymous threats still made. Such threats were a feature of the Pinochet years, the main difference being that then they were often carried out. "Happily, there has not been violence towards us recently."

Protests against Gen Pinochet and a decision to release him are planned by the Assembly for Human Rights today in the Plaza Italia in Santiago. "In Pinochet's case there is no room for clemency on humanitarian grounds," said Julia Urquieta of the assembly, "because no clemency was given to the thousands of victims of the dictatorship on humanitarian grounds."

Back in Providencia, the congregation departs waving Chilean flags and blowing whistles, ignoring the gestures of derision from people driving past. The church, with its tall mural of Christ tending the dying and the dead, is empty once more.

webTitle: The wise avoid Morecambe, says travel guide

fields.headline: The wise avoid Morecambe, says travel guide
fields.trailText: Morecambe's most famous son, Eric Morecambe, must be turning in his grave. A new travel guide to his beloved home town, where the seafront boasts a 6ft 7in bronze image of the comedian, has advised would-be tourists in no uncertain terms that it is a place to avoid.
fields.body:
Morecambe's most famous son, Eric Morecambe, must be turning in his grave.

A new travel guide to his beloved home town, where the seafront boasts a 6ft 7in bronze image of the comedian, has advised would-be tourists in no uncertain terms that it is a place to avoid. Far from enhancing the resort's image as a summer haven where families amble along the seafront nibbling on fish and chips, the guide paints a bleak - if not third world - picture.

Not surprisingly, residents of the Lancashire town are incensed.

The article in Escape Routes magazine describes Morecambe - from which the comedian took his stage name - as "cheap" and "sad" with only one beautiful building. "If this resort had been a horse," the magazine adds, "someone would have put it out of its misery a long time ago."

Paul Morris, chairman of the town's economic development and tourism committee, responded by branding the magazine's comments as uninformed, out of date and verging on libellous.

The bi-monthly travel and leisure magazine, launched last September, advised its readers: "Finally, a less than gentle word about Morecambe in Lancashire. Its single beautiful building, a white modernist 30s hotel, no longer attracts glamorous tourists.

"Too many of the guest houses have been turned over to otherwise homeless B&B clients and the wild west theme park is just sad. The prom's filled with cheap shops, and looking out over the muck at low tide is pure melancholy."

Mr Morris claimed that picking out Morecambe was a cheap publicity stunt written by somebody who had probably not been in the town for more than 10 years. "The article is an insult to all the people who have worked very hard over the past 10 years to put Morecambe back on the map. It is getting to the point of being libellous," he said.

"The town has spent £50m over the last 10 years. The Queen came to the town to open the Eric Morecambe statue last year, and that has brought so many people into the area it is unbelievable."

But the magazine's editor, Sharon Ring, was standing firmly by the comments made in the article, which she said was researched by a "well-respected" travel journalist and gave an accurate picture of the town.

"We are not being nasty or poisonous," she said. "We are just doing what we believe is our job - to tell the truth. We do not feel it is somewhere we could recommend. Money is being spent on the town now, but you do not turn a town around by spending money on it in the short term.

"The problem is that the town went untouched for 30 years. After all, a view of the sea and a statue of Eric Morecambe does not make a good resort."

fields.headline: Surrogate child claim is refused
fields.standfirst: Woman left infertile by negligence loses bid to try for motherhood
fields.trailText: A woman left infertile by negligent medical care 26 years ago yesterday lost an unprecedented high court action to make her local health authority pay for a surrogate child.
fields.body:
A woman left infertile by negligent medical care 26 years ago yesterday lost an unprecedented high court action to make her local health authority pay for a surrogate child.

Margaret Patricia Briody, 46 and a teacher, was awarded £80,508 damages but, under the rules of the court, her award is likely to be consumed by legal costs, leaving her in debt.

Leaving the court in tears, she said she was "devastated" by the ruling, which came after an eight-year legal battle for damages following two stillbirths and an emergency hysterectomy in 1973.

Ms Briody, of Billinge in Lancashire, had claimed £400,000 damages from St Helens and Knowsley health authority, which in 1998 had been found guilty of negligence in treating her. It was the first time a woman had sued to pay for a surrogate pregnancy.

However, Ms Briody who had intended to use a commercial service in California, is likely to have to pay both sides' costs, an estimated £100,000, because the damages awarded were less than the £110,000 pretrial offer made by the authority.

Mrs Justice Ebsworth had been asked at a high court hearing last month to decide whether damages should be awarded, in part, towards trying to restore Ms Briody's chance of becoming a mother.

The judge ruled that Ms Briody had suffered pain and suffering as a result of the negligence, but dismissed a claim for post-traumatic stress disorder. She concluded it would not be reasonable to "provide a legal remedy doomed to almost inevitable failure" due to Ms Briody's age.

The judge also noted that commercial surrogacy was unlawful in Britain, adding: "On any view of our law the claimant seeks an award of damages to acquire a child by methods which do not comply with that law; that seems to me to be wrong." Ms Briody's medical witness, Professor Ian Craft, said that her chances of success using her fertilised eggs implanted in a surrogate mother were about 1%. And Lord Winston, professor of fertility studies at Imperial college, London, told the court her chances were "negligible".

Ms Briody said: "I am absolutely devastated. It's a total injustice. I will appeal, and if I can find the money I will still try to have a child by a surrogate mother."

In her ruling, the judge did not exclude any other woman claiming to fund a surrogate pregnancy, saying: "I do not on the basis of the quite exceptional facts of this case find it necessary or desirable to exclude a claim for the costs of surrogacy from the ambit of recoverable heads of damage in an appropriate case...

"It is possible to foresee a case in which a young married woman rendered incapable of bearing a child brings a case whilst still young and within the ambit of our law."

Margaret Patricia Briody, 46 and a teacher, was awarded £80,508 damages but, under the rules of the court, her award is likely to be consumed by legal costs, leaving her in debt. Leaving the court in tears, she said she was "devastated" by the ruling, which came after an eight-year legal battle for damages following two stillbirths and an emergency hysterectomy in 1973. Ms Briody, of Billinge in Lancashire, had claimed £400,000 damages from St Helens and Knowsley health authority, which in 1998 had been found guilty of negligence in treating her. It was the first time a woman had sued to pay for a surrogate pregnancy. However, Ms Briody who had intended to use a commercial service in California, is likely to have to pay both sides' costs, an estimated £100,000, because the damages awarded were less than the £110,000 pretrial offer made by the authority. Mrs Justice Ebsworth had been asked at a high court hearing last month to decide whether damages should be awarded, in part, towards trying to restore Ms Briody's chance of becoming a mother. The judge ruled that Ms Briody had suffered pain and suffering as a result of the negligence, but dismissed a claim for post-traumatic stress disorder. She concluded it would not be reasonable to "provide a legal remedy doomed to almost inevitable failure" due to Ms Briody's age. The judge also noted that commercial surrogacy was unlawful in Britain, adding: "On any view of our law the claimant seeks an award of damages to acquire a child by methods which do not comply with that law; that seems to me to be wrong." Ms Briody's medical witness, Professor Ian Craft, said that her chances of success using her fertilised eggs implanted in a surrogate mother were about 1%. And Lord Winston, professor of fertility studies at Imperial college, London, told the court her chances were "negligible". Ms Briody said: "I am absolutely devastated. It's a total injustice. I will appeal, and if I can find the money I will still try to have a child by a surrogate mother." In her ruling, the judge did not exclude any other woman claiming to fund a surrogate pregnancy, saying: "I do not on the basis of the quite exceptional facts of this case find it necessary or desirable to exclude a claim for the costs of surrogacy from the ambit of recoverable heads of damage in an appropriate case... "It is possible to foresee a case in which a young married woman rendered incapable of bearing a child brings a case whilst still young and within the ambit of our law."

webTitle: Wee Frees fall victim to big split

fields.headline: Wee Frees fall victim to big split
fields.standfirst:
Religion in the UK: special report

Calvinist church prepares for legal battle as rebels go it alone
fields.trailText: For nearly 200 years it has held fast against the ravages of contemporary life - spurning luxuries and holding thousands of worshippers in its grip.
fields.body:
For nearly 200 years it has held fast against the ravages of contemporary life - spurning luxuries and holding thousands of worshippers in its grip.

But yesterday the Free Church of Scotland, the Wee Frees, became a victim of a very modern malaise - a messy divorce.

Britain's most austere Christian denomination has split. Strangely for a devoutly serious organisation, when the 22 breakaway ministers walked away from the Kirk, the schism that rent it apart was not one born of theological differences. The dispute was instead over a mixture of allegations of sexual misdemeanour and worries that the church was sliding away from fundamentalist orthodoxy.

After a campaign spanning several years, the rebel ministers quit the church before a meeting of the general assembly could sack them. Both sides are now preparing for a protracted and bitter legal battle over church property.

Sixteen of the ministers who left are still in control of churches and live in manses, or rectories, owned by the Wee Frees. The church wants them out and is considering eviction proceedings. Meanwhile, their stipends have been stopped.

Since the 19th century the free church has held the west Highlands and Islands in its Calvinist grip. Under its strict doctrine, the whole area, until very recently, effectively shut its doors on Sunday.

In its dour unadorned churches, adherents believe only the elect are destined for heaven, and everyone else is damned. They are hugely intolerant of mainstream morality and, even today, many members eschew the most basic forms of modern life - the cinema, music, and theatre - in favour of religious piety.

As the breakaway group met in Magdalen chapel in Edinburgh yesterday, neither side would compromise. A church spokesman said: "As far as we are concerned they have left the church and they have no right to remain in the manses."

The rebel group, who are calling themselves the Free Church Continuing, were similarly unbending. "Those who are staying will resist attempts to evict them," said David Murray, minister at Lochcarron. "The most important issue is truth and trying to establish the truth."

The civil war revolves around one man: Donald Macleod, principal of the Free Church College in Edinburgh. In 1996, the comparatively liberal Professor Macleod was cleared by Edinburgh sheriff court of five charges of indecent assault on four women.

John Horsburgh, who heard the case, said Prof Macleod had been the victim of a conspiracy. He ruled that all the women involved had lied in the witness box to abet Prof Macleod's critics.

Earlier, a church committee had concluded there was insufficient evidence against him. But that finding and the secular court's ruling were dismissed by his enemies: they wanted a full trial before the general assembly.

When their requests were turned down, the critics set up the Free Church Defence Association and waged a campaign against him. The church ordered that the association be disbanded, but its leader re fused and was suspended sine die, an effective sacking.

But yesterday it was apparent the rebels intended to add to the breakaway church set up in Stornoway, Lewis.

"Where we consider we have a legitimate claim on property we will be considering our position and it is likely we will be attempting to maintain what property we are advised is ours," said John Macleod, a rebel minister from Skye.

The breakaway group represents around a fifth of the Free Church's serving ministers, but it is not clear exactly what proportion of the congregation of 6,000 members and 10,000 adherents they will take with them.

Although the group claims the schism has been brought about not just by opposition to Prof Macleod but by a dispute over church constitution, others say the rebels could not tolerate Prof Macleod's move away from the church's repressive conservatism.

"This is about the sober-suited dog collar brigade and pious old women being unable to accept change. The church has led total repression on the Western Isles for as long as anyone can remember and these ministers don't like that their grip is being loosened," said one observer.

In recent years, the Free Church's influence has waned slightly, but it remains a potent force.

The hardline attitudes are not to the taste of Prof Macleod. And they are not, Prof Macleod claims, to the taste of the modern Calvinist: in the modern Free churches he says attendance and donations are up.

But on some islands, particularly Skye, congregations and families will be split by the schism. As both sides prepare to do battle, some communities, like the church, are going to be ripped apart.

"There is no doubt this is going to cause terrible problems for many worshippers," said the church spokesman. "On Sunday, I think many people will have to make big decisions."

When God's word is law

The hardline Free Church of Scotland was formed in 1843 in protest at the Moderates who controlled the Church of Scotland. It has around 16,000 worshippers, but has a disproportionate influence on life in the West Highlands.

It maintains a commitment to the literal word of the Bible and the Westminster Confession, a Calvinist creed of 1643. Adherents believe that only by seeking God's salvation will you be saved; good deeds alone will not get you into heaven.

Congregation worship by singing psalms unaccompanied by music. No music or hymns are allowed in the evangelical Free Church.

Sundays must be devoutly observed. When ferries first served Skye the local minister lay in front of the cars as they disembarked.

When a worshipper becomes a member and takes communion, he or she gives up regular social life in favour of religious piety.

webTitle: Oasis unlikely to stop Brit rock and pop flop

fields.headline: Oasis unlikely to stop Brit rock and pop flop
fields.trailText: When rock stars such as Noel Gallagher start quoting - or misquoting - Isaac Newton you know you are in serious trouble. Newton's guiding principle was what goes up must come down - and that is exactly what has been happening to the once booming British music industry.
fields.body:
Go let it out,

Go let it in,

I'm the keeper of the gasoline

- from the forthcoming Oasis album, Standing on the Shoulder of Giants

When rock stars such as Noel Gallagher start quoting - or misquoting - Isaac Newton you know you are in serious trouble. Newton's guiding principle was what goes up must come down - and that is exactly what has been happening to the once booming British music industry. Even Oasis, Britpop's most stellar and boorish offsprings, are beginning to feel the effects of gravity.

If reaction to their new single, Go Let It Out, is anything to go by the omens are not good for their first album in two years. The record chains HMV and Our Price have ordered far fewer copies of the single than their last underwhelming effort, All Around the World.

Not even the Gallaghers' own label, Big Brother Records, seems all that hopeful. It has only made 250,000 copies of the new album - half the number the teen idol Britney Spears' last single, Crazy, sold.

Go Let It Out may be getting blanket radio airplay, and Oasis can still sell out Wembley in two hours, but industry insiders detect a desperation behind the hype - even if no one takes too seriously Noel Gallagher's boast that Britain's biggest band only made Standing on the Shoulder of Giants "cos we're skint".

With the band so often written off as retread Beatles, there may be more than mere self-parody behind Gallagher's decision to go on Radio One next week and cover the Who's My Generation rather than play one of his own new songs.

But the problems are not confined to Oasis, whom the veteran pop pundit Jonathan King dismissed as going the way of all "old, fat, lazy bands trying to be hungry, poor and enthusiastic". As if to prove the point, Gallagher popped up yesterday to say that "when you've four houses or nine cars" it no longer really matters how well your group does.

Europop

The snap and crackle has gone out of pop too, with sales slipping and international revenues deep in doldrums. Even the Spice Girls have lost their ginger.

Only two British artists have made any impact in America this year, the fortysomething DJ Fatboy Slim and the 13-year-old Welsh soprano Charlotte Church. It's a long way from the heady days of the mid-90s when Oasis, Blur, the Verve and Radiohead were taking on the world.

British rock and pop has not done much better at home where Europop, so long the butt of our jokes, dominated last year. Only two acts made the domestic top 10 singles of 1999 - the worst performance in years - and one of those was Cliff Richard's Millennium Prayer, a song so risible that Mel C of the Spice Girls felt moved to publicly condemn it as a "steaming pile of shit".

Market share for both albums and singles is down 10% on last year, after similarly disappointing showings in 1998 - a not inconsiderable blow to the whole economy given that the music business long ago surpassed the steel industry with export earnings in excess of £1.2bn a year. UK sales account for a further £1.9m.

To make matters worse, Creation, the record label that was once the epitome of Britpop cool, appears to be in freefall after its founder and svengali Alan McGee departed for cyberspace.

If it were not for the relative success of such unadulteratedly commercial teeny poppers such as Steps, S Club 7 and Lolly, and the rash of Irish boy bands, things would be very grim indeed.

Even the British Phonographic Industry, which lobbies for the sector, admits: "No one can claim that we are doing as well as we were." Certainly as executives pack their bags this weekend for the annual industry jolly, Midem, in Cannes, they have a lot to ponder.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, will tell them on Monday that they are still the pick of the government's cherished "creative industries", but the chances of Downing Street throwing open its doors again as it did to Oasis in 1997 look pretty slim.

Chris Green, of the BPI, is adamant that there is no crisis and maintained that the poor figures were a blip.

He said: "These things tend to be cyclical. I don't think there are any signs of anything fundamentally wrong in the industry. Britpop was a phenomenon. We had bands who were right up there internationally and that obviously had a tremendous effect. No doubt others will come along and we will be right up there again."

He argued that British acts were doing better in some genres and claimed that big worldwide hits by Irish bands such as the Corrs were distorting the figures. "Many of these bands are actually signed to UK labels." Although we were "not doing great" in the US, Mr Green added, British bands still accounted for one-third of all platinum discs last year in Europe. "There a lot of albums from big British bands due this week, so there is a lot to look forward to."

Steve Jones, of Music Week magazine, the industry bible, said the relative success of the teen bands and pop acts such as Robbie Williams had masked the decline, but that trend was beginning to wane. "Still, there's a lot of new exciting bands around right now, and even more established bands like All Saints are winning back fans with their song from the new film The Beach."

He said new albums due this year from A-list bands that include the Prodigy, Radiohead, the Spice Girls and the former Verve frontman Richard Ashcroft would probably reverse the losses. "There is a lot of energy out there. I think we are going to see more girl pop acts coming through. We shouldn't write ourselves off just yet."

Johnny Hopkins, the former Oasis publicist once known as "the fifth member of the band", who parted company with the Gallaghers earlier this week, said it was true that British rock had "got a bit staid and grey and going nowhere.

But he said: "You have to remember that before 1994, people would not touch British bands," he said. "It was all Nirvana and that sort of stuff. Then Oasis and Blur and Pulp came along. It all goes in cycles. There is a lot of good pop around here at the moment but the more interesting creative bands like Primal Scream and Death In Vegas are now making the dents."

webTitle: Royal Opera told to cut prices

fields.headline: Royal Opera told to cut prices
fields.trailText: The crisis-racked Royal Opera House came under government pressure last night to sacrifice a holy of holies and sell cheap tickets for its best seats to the general public.
fields.body:
The crisis-racked Royal Opera House came under government pressure last night to sacrifice a holy of holies and sell cheap tickets for its best seats to the general public.

Senior management at the opera house, in Covent Garden, central London, have been told to "get a better social mix, particularly in the stalls, so it doesn't feel so snooty".

Some stalls seats, which sell for up £150 - mostly to corporate clients - should be offered to opera lovers for the price of a ticket to a West End musical, managers were told.

The shot across the bows comes after another technical disaster at the house. Ashley Page's ballet Hidden Variables was abandoned on Thursday night after computers that shift sets broke down again.

For the first time since the £218m house reopened in December, the patience of the audience snapped. The cancellation was greeted with boos.

Earlier in the week, a schools matinee of Harrison Birtwistle's opera Gawain was also scrapped. A source close to the culture secretary Chris Smith described this as "very disturbing indeed".

"What is depressing is what this says about their priorities. They must do something to demonstrate they are committed to access," the source said.

The credentials of the house chief executive, Michael Kaiser as a reformer keen to open the house up were not in doubt, the source said, but "there seemed to be a mindset" in the organisation that is unchanged since its bad old days.

Last night the house confirmed that it was reinstating day tickets, after the MP Ben Bradshaw raised the issue in the Commons. Sixty-seven single seats will be kept back to be sold on the day from April.

The u-turn comes as the house conducts a "wide-ranging" ticketing review after criticism from many opera goers.

webTitle: A thorn in side of church establishment

fields.headline: A thorn in side of church establishment
fields.standfirst: Deacon, gay activist and enemy of the Christian rightReligion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Richard Kirker embodies all the nightmares of Cardinal Thomas Winning in his battles to keep Section 28 on the statute book in Scotland.
fields.body:
Richard Kirker embodies all the nightmares of Cardinal Thomas Winning in his battles to keep Section 28 on the statute book in Scotland.

He is a proselytising Anglican homosexual clergyman; he has been the victim, on television, of an impromptu exorcism by an African bishop; he has sold copies of The Joy of Gay Sex from the bell-tower of St Botolph's Aldgate; he has queued for an audience with the Archbishop of Canterbury. In a week when the Christian right has been determined to keep Section 28 in Scotland, he has, as usual, been working for the gays who want to be Christian and the Christians who find themselves gay.

A deacon who is entitled to call himself the Rev Richard Kirker, he has run the Lesbian and Gay Christian Movement almost since its inception in 1975, just after he had been told that he would never progress from being a deacon to a priest because of his open and unrepentant gayness. He is not very flamboyant, though some of his cardigans might be so described. Neat, rather bird-like, with an educated precision of speech; if anything less camp than the vicar he almost became.

It is openness and a kind of patient courage that have distinguished him throughout his curious career. The Church of England is full of gay clergy but they exist in a state of submerged quasi-honesty. Kirker has made it his business to be the tip of this iceberg and it is a rather disappointing job. "We do act as a mouthpiece to people who feel unable to put their names to the views they hold. I have become more convinced that the gay clergy collectively simply don't have the will to transform their lives and use the power which they have or could have. They have with two honourable exceptions refused to stand up to the hierarchy."

So why does he bother? Why be a Christian at all?

He was the child of a colonial civil servant (he shut up the Nigerian bishop who was trying to exorcise him by saying he'd had his first sexual experience with a Nigerian boy), and went to a minor public school whose headmaster worried lest visitors form Chichester theological college pollute his boys with high church theology.

"I was a Christian only in the most nominal sense. But I had a curious fascination with the things of God. This gave rise to a keenness to put myself at the disposal of the institution which I most closely associated with God." So he went to Salisbury theological college.

He spent a year as a deacon in a parish in Southampton. "A very ordinary working-class parish, and some of the people I got closest to there were extraordinarily positive to my being gay. This was a revelation because I had been told time and time again in my training process that I would have to be more discreet when I came into the outside world."

Then his partner died in a motorcycle crash. Kirker's grief was so extravagant and his demand to be recognised as the partner so loud that his bishop, Robert Runcie, decided not to let him go forward to complete his ordination as a priest. "So the Church of England has both offered me the happiest and unhappiest experiences in my life."

Yet he stays there. He says of gay Christians: "Perhaps we're driven to reflect on why we are who we are. You might think think God has done a wonderful thing in creating you."

The end of the century was a bad time for his movement. "Theological colleges are still not gay-free zones but I don't think Tony Blair could teach George Carey [Archbishop of Canterbury] anything abut control freakery. He has been an an astute controller of the church. He has put very clear limits on dissent."

Indeed, no bishop would talk formally to Kirker for the first few years of the 90s, until Outrage named 10 of them at a synod meeting. "I remain confident that all the principles we stand for will become commonplace in the church, but certainly not while the present archbishop is in place."

webTitle: Paedophile jailed for abuse of girls at French campsite

fields.headline: Paedophile jailed for abuse of girls at French campsite
fields.trailText: A Briton who abused children at a holiday campsite he owned in France was jailed for three years yesterday.
fields.body:
A Briton who abused children at a holiday campsite he owned in France was jailed for three years yesterday.

Kenneth Biden, 64, became the first person to be convicted under the 1997 sex offenders act for offences committed in another country.

Biden assaulted young girls at his Le Grand Motives campsite in Brittany during babysitting and entertainment sessions, telling his victims to keep quiet about "their little secret", Middlesex Guildhall crown court had heard.

When police arrested him at his home in Exeter, after complaints from parents, he told the officers he had a psychic rapport with children. "They are good enough for Jesus, they are good enough for me," he said.

Biden pleaded guilty last month to six charges of indecent assault on five girls aged between five and 12. A retired engineer, he bought the converted farm with his wife in 1993 and hoped to turn it into a nudist colony, the court heard. When that venture failed, he built a campsite and promoted it in brochures as a family resort.

Biden vetted his customers, choosing families with young girls and rejecting bookings from social workers, teachers and police officers. He used a marker pen to highlight the ages of potential victims in a ledger, and encouraged guests to walk around naked, the court heard.

Thomas Wilkins, prosecuting, said that, after winning parents' trust, Biden would spend hours playing with their children in the swimming pool, a hedged enclosure, on swings, and in surrounding woodland.

He "groomed" victims by secretly showing them films featuring nudity, said Mr Wilkins.

The abuse was first uncov ered in 1997 when a five-year-old girl told her parents that Biden had indecently assaulted her. No action was taken because of her age, but Scotland Yard's paedophile unit investigated when a second girl came forward to reveal she had been assaulted by Biden when she was nine.

Mr Wilkins said the case was the first of its kind involving crimes committed abroad.

Sentencing Biden yesterday, Judge Henry Blacksell said: "You had a duty as a responsible adult to look after young children.You seem to have little idea what harm, actual or potential, you may have caused these girls, and none of us know what that might be."

Det Insp David Marshall, of the paedophile unit, said Biden may have targeted other children between 1997 and his arrest in September 1999. "The act has enabled us to convict a very calculating, manipulative and dangerous paedophile," he said.

fields.headline: Let's get bolshie
fields.standfirst: Labour's attempts to quash dissent appear to be having entirely the opposite effectNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: It seemed to die in Thatcher's time; revived like Lazarus to bring New Labour into power almost a thousand days ago; then, redefined as an act of treachery, went back on hold for many. But could it be, miracle of miracles, that dissent is back?
fields.body:
It seemed to die in Thatcher's time; revived like Lazarus to bring New Labour into power almost a thousand days ago; then, redefined as an act of treachery, went back on hold for many. A small price to pay, or so some thought, to give the fresh boys on the block the opportunity to dismantle the Old Establishment, and create a new and better Britain. But could it be, miracle of miracles, that dissent is back?

Is resistance beginning to rule, if not OK, then a lot more strongly? Are more and more - especially those courted by the patronage of Blair - waking up to the realisation that no matter what the gains in some areas, if politics is to be redefined as a management exercise conducted by a charismatic leader who believes he knows what's best, then the power of the corporate kings waxes as the health of democracy wanes?

So who has recently opted to go - horror of horrors? - "off message"? Members of the House of Lords in throwing out the proposal to abolish the right to elect for a jury; Glenys Kinnock, MEP, writing a forceful letter to this newspaper yesterday opposing New Labour's sales of arms' spare parts; some of Blair's Babes in making a tentative alliance with women trade union officials to constructively challenge government actions (or lack of them) when necessary; the TUC this week (having had Cherie Booth's expert opinion since December) in applying for a judicial review of the government's decision to limit parental leave and supporters of Ken Livingstone's campaign which grows apace not least because he's regarded by many as beyond the Blair pale, and therefore, almost no matter what he does, a bloody good thing.

At the same time, outside the world of Westminster, the muscle of resistance is also being flexed more vigorously, assisted by the internet (and, international connections). Last year's City of London and Seattle riots; the opposition to Tyson's entry; the campaign against the fudged Freedom of Information legislation; concerns raised by issues such as GM crops; globalisation; third world debt; discrimination and the environment, are drawing on a surprisingly eclectic group of protesters. Pick 'n mix mainstream politics (vote for the issue not the party) is being matched by pick 'n mix dissenters.

But why is the political ground beginning to shake and move (if only a little) in Britain particularly now? Partly, it's because, of course, the debacle in the NHS has made Blair appear vulnerable, our leader no longer walks on water. And also because, for many, even those unconcerned by issues, the growing long-term unease over New Labour's attitude to propaganda and principles, the apparent supremacy of the former over the latter, when so much that was different was promised, is beginning to come to a head .

In the 1960s, Jacques Ellul, published Propaganda, The Formation of Men's Attitudes, a stunning critique of the inherent dangers to democracy of the use of propaganda. Written 40 years ago, he predicted precisely the spin doctors' techniques today. He pointed out that propaganda was not only the manipulation of lies, the telling of tall stories, it is also supplying selected fragments of accurate information, "to persuade the public of one point of view and to close off other options".

"All democracy that is maintained or propagated by propaganda eventually scores this success," he pointed out, "...Its own negation with regards to the individual and the truth..."

"On message" worked initially because the enemy was out there. If differences were revealed to rightwing media moguls and to the corporate world, the Establishment would sink the fragile fleet of New Labour's ideas, by taking pot shots at dissenters on its bows. So, trade unions, campaign groups, MPs, kept mum.

Three years on, of course, New Labour is the Establishment. Cronyism appears a 21st-century version of the masons. Presentation still matters more than evolving policies through genuine debate and discussion. And where in all this is the transparent, modern society that was promised? Witness Lord Robert Winston's naive belief that you could accept a peerage and still tell the whole truth and nothing but the truth.

In the New Statesman last week, Anthony Bevins, political editor of the Daily Express, wrote admiringly about the prime minister not so much as a statesman but as the country's chief executive officer who views the untidiness of a functioning democracy like an irritatingly unreliable work force. Bevins wrote, "If politics gets in his way, [he] has no qualms about neutering the nuisance". "The nuisance?" Bevins went on to quote Blair from the Labour manifesto, "We will be a radical government... but the definition of radicalism will not be that of doctrine... but of achievement... What counts is what works...".

What has worked so far is to be applauded - the New Deal, help with childcare, devolution, debt relief, a pledge to end child poverty; but what also has to count as much is the democratic process of government, the means by which the ends are achieved. How else are the brightest and best ideas to emerge for Labour's second term? Instead, stripped of the right to question, unable to rely on instinct (since that way dangerous "Old Labour" ideology may lie), those within Westminster appear moribund; junior clerks instead of representatives of the people.

New Labour knows it has a fatal flaw in its make-up: Mr Blair's affair with big business. One day, if he is serious, for instance, about ensuring a better work-life balance and a decent minimum income for all, he may have to upset his new found friends. How much easier that would be for him, although no less painful, if he could say that such demands must be met, because the level of demand inside the House, as well as outside, has become too clamorous too ignore?

Ironically, in attempting to silence all opposition and diminish constructive criticism, by associating it in derogatory terms with "the dark forces of conservatism", New Labour is now fuelling the very dissent it has tried so hard to dampen. It's time we all got bolshy.

webTitle: Council faces claim over school bullying

fields.headline: Council faces claim over school bullying
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The parents of a 15-year-old girl who was the victim of a two-year campaign of racist bullying at her school are considering legal action against their local education authority to recover the cost of moving her to a private school.
fields.body:
The parents of a 15-year-old girl who was the victim of a two-year campaign of racist bullying at her school are considering legal action against their local education authority to recover the cost of moving her to a private school.

Debbie Bell was removed from St Michael's Roman Catholic high school in Barnsley, South Yorkshire, after being targeted by a gang of six girls who racially abused and intimidated her.

Her parents, John and Mary Bell, placed her in a fee-paying school and are now being backed by the Commission for Racial Equality in their attempt to force the local council to meet the costs.

The gang of girls allegedly scrawled obscene remarks on her school work, threw things at her, pushed and shoved her and damaged her school equipment.

St Michael's has recently joined in a new anti-racist campaign, but Debbie, who is of mixed race, described the school's move as "too little, too late".

Although she now attends the Barnsley Christian school, she said the harassment by the gang had continued.

A spokesman for Barnsley council said: "The LEA is satisfied that its anti-bullying procedures are sound and the appropriate procedures were followed in the case of Debbie Bell. St Michael's made every effort to investigate and follow up allegations that were made of racial harassment."

A spokesman for the CRE said: "We are hoping to reach an amicable settlement with the council over this tragic case."

Mobile phones have created a new form of hi-tech bullying using text messages, it was claimed yesterday. Offenders key in intimidating messages to send to their victim by withholding their own number.

Martin Watson, head teacher at Lavington school near Devizes, in Wiltshire, ordered all 616 pupils to leave their mobiles at home after a series of threats.

webTitle: Plunge into red is blow to leader's health pledge

fields.headline: Plunge into red is blow to leader's health pledge
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's public finances sank deeply into the red last month, causing City analysts yesterday to scale back estimates of the size of Gordon Brown's war chest going into the next election.
fields.body:
Britain's public finances sank deeply into the red last month, causing City analysts yesterday to scale back estimates of the size of Gordon Brown's war chest going into the next election.

Official figures released yesterday showed an unexpectedly large budget deficit of £9.2bn in December. Although the public finances are still expected to be in the black for the financial year as a whole, last month's setback means that predictions of a £10bn surplus look unlikely.

Treasury figures suggest Mr Brown is already facing an uphill struggle finding the cash to meet Tony Blair's pledge, on last Sunday's Frost programme, to raise NHS funding by 5% so as to bring Britain's spending on health into line with the rest of the European Union.

Although the treasury may be able to afford to increase spending by 5% a year in the new three-year spending plans due to be unveiled in the summer, it will not be enough to increase the proportion of GDP devoted to health from the current level of 6.8% to the EU average of 8%. A 5% a year increase will still leave a gap of 0.8% of GDP, equivalent to more than £5bn, according to treasury figures.

To fulfil Mr Blair's pledge, public spending would need to rise by around an unprecedented 6% a year. Even that would be insufficient to match the resources devoted to health by the big European economies. To catch up with Germany and France, Britain would need to spend more than 8% more a year over the next three years.

Sources close to the treasury suggest that it was fully prepared for Mr Blair's promise to increase health spending in real terms by 5% a year.

But officials are thought to have been surprised by his assertion that this would be enough to raise spending as a proportion of GDP to the European average. This may explain why the treasury, and subsequently Downing Street, were keen to water down the prime minister's pledge to an aspiration in subsequent briefings.

Last month's shortfall between government spending and income was double the figure in City forecasts. Analysts said it reflected weaker revenue growth from taxes and a pick-up in departmental spending. Cumulatively, the budget deficit for the financial year 1999-2000, which ends in April, stands at £4.3bn, a £5.4bn deterioration from the same point last year.

David Walton, of the US investment bank Goldman Sachs, said December's figures were distorted by one-off factors: a lack of proceeds from the windfall tax this year compared with last year, and a temporary lift last year due to early payment of tobacco duties to beat a pre-announced increase at the turn of the year.

Philip Shaw of Investec bank said Mr Brown might regard the data as a blessing in disguise: "The absence of a large war chest will reduce pressure for a pre-election tax cutting spree."

fields.headline: Student dies after 'allergic reaction'
fields.trailText: A teenager died after suffering an apparent allergic reaction following a meal at an Indian restaurant, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
A teenager died after suffering an apparent allergic reaction following a meal at an Indian restaurant, it emerged last night.

Durham university student Nicola Ratcliffe, 18, of Guildford, Surrey, was dining with friends when she became ill.

She left the restaurant to return to her accommodation for medication but collapsed in the street in Durham city centre on Thursday night.

She was taken to Dryburn hospital in Durham but died later.

Her mother and brother travelled to Durham yesterday and were being comforted by university staff.

A Durham university spokesman, Keith Seacroft, said: "It is understood that she was feeling unwell after a visit to a restaurant."

A postmortem examination carried out yesterday proved inconclusive. Police said last night they were awaiting the results of further laboratory tests.

Detective Chief Inspector Kim Hunter, of Durham constabulary, said the student was known to be allergic to nuts and her symptoms suggested she had suffered a severe allergic reaction.

Ms Ratcliffe joined Durham university last October to read for a combined arts degree and was studying politics, English literature and music at St Mary's College.

The college principal, Jenny Hobbs, said: "Nicola loved Durham and had made many friends here.

"We are all absolutely devastated and we offer our deepest sympathy to her family."

fields.headline: Blair turns on his critics
fields.standfirst: Prime minister rounds on his criticsNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: A defiant Tony Blair yesterday rounded on his critics and declared that his government would press ahead with its reformist agenda despite the past week's setbacks and attacks from "forces of conservatism and reaction, left or right".
fields.body:
A defiant Tony Blair yesterday rounded on his critics and declared that his government would press ahead with its reformist agenda despite the past week's setbacks and attacks from "forces of conservatism and reaction, left or right".

Mr Blair used a speech in east London to brush aside the mounting difficulties of what some were calling his worst week for more than a year by insisting that the government would not be deflected from its programme of modernisation by day-to-day crises.

"Struggle is part of politics. And here is the rub. Reform is hard, it causes dissent, it upsets vested interests, some very well-meaning. It can seem unfair, even when its very purpose is greater fairness in the long-term," said Mr Blair.

He seemed rattled and defensive as he took a sideswipe at the media. "In the end what is essential is to have a vision and stick to it. The daily head lines, the passing frenzies - and I have lost count of the number of times this or that week was supposed to be our toughest since taking over - all that comes and goes. But the vision of the big picture must remain."

Amid talk of "total determination, absolute focus on the long term", Mr Blair grimly conceded that the forces of conservatism "can have superficial popular appeal". It seemed to goad him into slapping down the all-party coalition that wrecked Jack Straw's £100m plan to curb the right to jury trial on Thursday night as an offence to liberty.

The run-up to Labour's 1,000th day in office this Wednesday has been rough. Mr Blair's aggressive speech came after a week in which he has faced anger over NHS spending, rising crime, heckling for his criticism of Ken Livingstone, divisions over the government's ethical foreign policy and rows about General Pinochet's departure and Mike Tyson's arrival.

Last night William Hague, the Tory leader, taunted Mr Blair with being a "cheque is in the post" prime minister. "Once again he is all talk but no delivery. He is always making promises, but he hasn't actually delivered on the promises he made in the first place," he said.

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, said the shine was finally coming off the government, with "more normal politics" being restored.

In yesterday's speech, Mr Blair again set out his third way: a knowledge-driven economy based on full employment, mutual respect and an end to poverty.

"Economic competence and social justice, fairness and enterprise" went hand in hand, in contrast to the old Labour indifference to wealth creation and the Thatcherite disdain for compassion, he suggested once again.

With Mr Hague trailing 47%-30% in this week's Guardian/ICM poll, Blairites deny that their hero is bitter. But his anger was evident when he complained: "The more radical our reforms, the more they are resisted, but in the long run the better [are] the rewards."

From devolution to the welfare-to-work programme, which had helped cut unemployment by 700,000 since 1997, Mr Blair was adamant that his critics were being proved wrong.

Some schools, hospitals and police forces performed much better than others - proof that more needs to be done, he said.

"I believe we have a way of reforming public services that again breaks with the past.

"It rejects the old left view that money was the basic answer to all problems, that few difficult decisions about structure or methods or new practices need to be taken if only the money is available," he said.

fields.headline: Troubles as the 1,000th day nears
fields.standfirst: As Blair dismisses 'passing frenzies', Labour MPs might fear he has lost his touchNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair arrives at an important landmark for politicians on Wednesday, his 1,000th day in office. He can only hope that next week will be better than this one, one of his worst since coming into office, with one bad news day after another.
fields.body:
Tony Blair arrives at an important landmark for politicians on Wednesday, his 1,000th day in office. He can only hope that next week will be better than this one, one of his worst since coming into office, with one bad news day after another.

Mr Blair tacitly admitted as much yesterday in a speech at a London school. He dismissed the "daily headlines, the passing frenzies" and said he had "lost count of the number of times this or that week was supposed to be our toughest since taking over".

The prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, keeps in his drawer at Downing Street cuttings by journalists saying that the "honeymoon is finally over". That had been written, he claimed, on at least 200 days out of the 1,000 in office.

Looking back, Mr Blair and his aides can finder tougher weeks, such as the one in which the then trade and industry secretary, Peter Mandelson, was forced to resign. For them the two toughest weeks of the premiership came last year: the opening week of the Kosovo conflict, when each night they fell into bed "totally knackered" (as one of them put it), and the week in the spring in Belfast when Mr Blair failed to broker a peace deal.

But even retaining a sense of perspective it has been a horrendous week. With the general election possibly less than 18 months away, Labour MPs in marginal seats must be beginning to wonder if Mr Blair and his team are losing their touch.

Awkward

The most awkward issue has been the National Health Service, reflected in Mr Blair's decision to devote most of yesterday's speech to it. Desperate to end the sense of crisis engulfing the NHS, he made the astounding promise during the Frost programme last Sunday to provide £12bn extra funding. The government followed that up on Monday by confirming above-inflation rises for nurses. It was all looking good.

At the Downing Street briefing on Monday afternoon, some journalists thought they spotted backtracking by Mr Campbell on the health pledge. This had suddenly become "an aspiration".

Mr Campbell remains adamant he had never used the word aspiration and that his line has been consistent with Mr Blair's. The prime minister, in the interview, had built lots of caveats round the pledge, saying much depended on the state of the economy, and that had been ignored by newspaper journalists.

Health was not the only issue to dominate the first part of the week. On Tuesday the published crime figures showed the first rise in six years. If it was a tough week for Mr Blair, the home secretary, Jack Straw, has had an almost unrelenting fortnight of bad news stories.

He joked at a party that evening that he had thought the job was about providing a just, safe and tolerant society but discovered his role in life was to provide the media with stories. Unlike Mr Blair yesterday, he acknowledged it had been a tough passage: he compared the past fortnight with the legendary nightmare week of the Tory home secretary, Lord Whitelaw, when Michael Fagan managed to break into Buckingham Palace. There was more trouble later in the week when the new-look Lords defeated his proposal to end the automatic right to jury trial.

The problems kept heaping up. The Guardian published a poll on Wednesday showing opposition to the European single currency at a record high, 63%. It was a reminder of the biggest dilemma Mr Blair faces: he needs to launch a positive campaign to turn round public opinion, but to do so risks alienating the public and the rightwing press.

Then came the Guardian's exposé on Thursday that Mr Blair had personally intervened to allow the sale of spare parts needed by Zimbabwe for British-made Hawks used in the gruesome civil war in Congo. This time round it was not the ministry of defence or the department of trade and industry that was to blame, but the prime minister himself. In spite of the repugnance at the decision, and condemnation from groups such as Oxfam and respected figures in the Labour party, Downing Street was adamant yesterday it would not back down.

It is usual for governments in trouble to dismiss such weeks as "mid-term blues" or "events". But there are fundamental problems. The Congo row is one of them, with Labour divided in the cabinet and the country over its ethical foreign policy.

Tension

Another is devolution, the continuing tension in Downing Street between giving power away and wanting to retain control. In Scotland there is stomach-churning debate over the repeal of the homophobic section 28 clause, making a mockery of Labour's "New Scotland" label. Even pro-devolutionists are now beginning to wonder whether proportional representation was such a good idea. Wales, too, is facing instability. But Mr Blair, in yesterday's speech, claimed that devolution had worked and "we now see the nations of the UK more confident within the UK".

The row over Ken Livingstone for mayor of London is part of that contradiction between devolving power and trying to retain it. Mr Blair has alienated many within his own party, as was demonstrated when he and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, spoke at a mass meeting on Wednesday night.

They turned up 15 minutes late and were slow-handclapped as they arrived, setting the tone for the rest of the meeting. Planted questions were greeted with groans. Mr Blair rallied them in the end, but it was a fraught night, one in which a Labour prime minister had to face the indignity of being heckled by his own party.

Downing Street insisted yesterday he was sanguine about it all and was working through his red boxes in the afternoon so he could "chill out" with Cherie and the children in the evening, and that he had been joking with a European leader about the problems that having a baby while in office would bring.

The Downing Street official spokesman said it was all short-term. "Who remembers Dolly Draper now?" he said, referring to the Lobbygate scandal. The latest poll shows the party further ahead than at the general election.

When Labour is in trouble, it usually finds a string of news announcements. So expect these next week. They may not be enough to overshadow other events, such as General Pinochet flying home, or the foreign office trying to explain its ethical approach towards central Africa.

One senior Labour figure, less sanguine than Downing Street, said: "It has not been our most glorious week."

Six days of woe

Sunday

Tony Blair, trying to get a grip on the NHS crisis, promises £12bn extra funding

Monday

Looks like another good day for Blair as government announces above-inflation rises for nurses. But at Downing Street briefing in the afternoon, Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, seems ambiguous about health pledge

Tuesday

Some papers claim u-turn on health spending, saying it was an aspiration, not a pledge.

Day gets worse when home office publishes statistics showing crime rates up 2.2% - the first rise for six years

Wednesday

Guardian poll shows 63% of voters are sceptical about the European single currency, a huge headache for Blair.

After prime minister's question time, journalists prepare more stories about u-turn on health.

That night Blair and Gordon Brown are heckled at a Labour party meeting in London, at which the prime minister attacks Ken Livingstone.

Thursday

Guardian exposes Blair's support for resuming the supply of spares parts for use by Zimbabwe's Hawk jets in the Congo war, a breach of Robin Cook's ethical foreign policy.

Plans to restrict right to jury trial defeated by new-look House of Lords

Friday

Blair dismisses "the daily headlines, the passing frenzies" and denies it has been his toughest week in government

fields.headline: The new believers
fields.standfirst: Russia's war on God is over. But an alliance between the orthodox church and the state has led to a disturbing campaign of religious intolerance.  John O'Mahony reports
fields.trailText: Russia's war on God is over. But an alliance between the orthodox church and the state has led to a disturbing campaign of religious intolerance. John O'Mahony reports
fields.body:
As we pull away from the coastline, the island monastery of Valaam rises from the steely waters of Lake Lagoda like an apparition. Only a single, gleaming dome is visible at first through the haze, a gilded beacon guiding the ferry towards its destination. Soon, it is possible to make out the pillbox-like chapel beneath, perched on the crest of an outlying island and moored to the archipelago by a wooden walkway. The stocky ramparts of the monastery building rear up behind. Finally, as we turn into the ice-logged main waterway, we are confronted by the soaring, cobalt spire and cupolas of the Cathedral of the Transfiguration, the focal point of this fortress of orthodoxy.

The effect of this vision on the handful of monks returning to spend winter in the monastery, might seem, to the unaccustomed observer, a little startling. Throughout most of our journey, they have seemed sullen, quietly praying or staring impassively into the distance. Suddenly, the cabin is flapping with black habits and flowing beards. Some are setting their watches to "monastery time", Valaam's own private time zone, in synch, not with Russia, but with Jerusalem and the Holy Land. Others form a line along one frozen, wind-swept deck, their heads nodding, their cupped fingers frantically working through the co-ordinates of the sign of the cross. After we had disembarked, one young novice explained the need for such observance: "The beauty of this place, it moves you to prayer." It is now 10 years since the monks began returning to this outpost on the Karelian peninsula, a 10-hour train and ferry ride north of St Petersburg.

It's been a decade of extraordinary transformation and renewal for the orthodox church in Russia, one that has seen it cast off the shackles of soviet suppression to achieve a degree of independence unknown throughout its 1,000 year history. Since 1990, 13,000 parishes have been re-established and 460 monasteries reopened, about 20,000 clergy given official posts and 22 new seminaries established; 50% of Russia's population now declares itself to be orthodox, the largest congregation of any eastern Christian church.

This burgeoning sense of self-confidence has coincided with the rise, within church ranks, of a growing tendency towards anti-liberalism and an alarming level of aggressive chauvinism towards other religions. The last 10 years have also seen the church form an uncomfortably close relationship with the largely unreformed state that once suppressed it, regularly supporting the Russian government (the Patriarch's endorsement of the war in Chechnya) and wielding in return considerable political influence. The most sinister consequence has been a controversial new law, pushed through the Russian parliament in 1997, mostly as a result of orthodox support, which human rights groups claim has triggered a "secret offensive" by the state services against "non-traditional" religions in Russia, with tactics from bureaucratic obstruction to alleged beatings.

Euphemistically titled "On freedom of conscience and religious associations", the law recognises the "special role of orthodoxy in the history of Russia". It also gives elevated status to the Russian federation's estimated 10m Muslims, Jews and mainstream Buddhists, despite uneasy attitudes to these faiths, illustrated by the current onslaught in Chechnya and by endemic anti-Semitism. The legis lation required religious organisations to meet stringent conditions, many designed to exclude minority faiths, in order to re-register with the state before December 31 1999. The passing of that millennial deadline has deprived about half of Russia's religious bodies of legal status, theoretically casting them back into the unofficial "underground" of the soviet era. They have lost the right to worship in public, own property, have bank accounts and engage in missionary or charitable work. The "war on God" may have ended, but just a decade after the humiliating defeat of the world's first avowedly atheist state, a new religious cold war in Russia may only be beginning.

Nowhere could seem further from these inter-church battlefields than Valaam, accessible when temperatures plunge only by helicopter or a treacherous jeep-ride across the ice. For the 100 or so monks living here, this is the most extreme form of retreat from the grimy contradictions and the disappointments of "worldly" Russian life, a place to surrender themselves to prayer, chastity, poverty and to the ascetic ideal of obriad , ritualised living.

Rising at 5.30am, they spend as much as 10 hours a day in the incense-laden darkness of the cathedral, sparkling in their gold-embroidered robes and filling the air with plainchant or the cadences of church Slavonic. The contrast between the stringency of the ritual and the splendour of the sacred vessels suggests a contradictory God of sumptuousness and austerity. Often the monks don't emerge from the cathedral until after midnight, to be greeted by the northern lights flickering in the sky.

The monks of Valaam could be regarded as the future of the orthodox church. A large proportion seem young, in their twenties or early thirties, and their drooping beards and pitchy robes are ill-fitting. Many have come to Valaam via extraordinary paths. Brother Daniil was a DJ, well known on the Moscow club scene. Brother Icidor was an actor who found God through a stage adaptation of Dostoyevsky's novel, The Possessed. The Valaam iconographer, who now presides over a cupboard full of verdigris, ochre and cobalt, and books of delicate gold leaf, was once a socialist realist painter whose commissions included Lenin and Brezhnev; an unbeliever who discovered religion through a paperback bought in the Moscow metro.

All the monks smoulder with a conviction of spiritual superiority, what they refer to as the truth of orthodoxy: "If Russia does not become an orthodox nation, then there is no hope for its survival," says Brother Alexander, 23. "At a time when there are so many unChristian ideals, this is the only thing that can bring us together." On the historical persecution of orthodox believers by other faiths, Brother Kukshe, 27, a monk with burning eyes and an almost messianic intensity, is even more forthright: "Throughout the whole history of Russia, we have seen from the Catholics only blood," he exclaims. "We can't count the amount of orthodox they have killed, particularly in Serbia."

While Archimandrite Pankraty, the affable Abbot of Valaam, is eager to temper the more outspoken assertions of his monks, he tends to agree with them in principle and is in tune with the sentiment behind the new law on religion: "Just take a country like Greece, a member of the European Union and ostensibly a civilised country. The orthodox religion is its state religion and the state helps it because it understands that the stronger the church, the stronger the society. The same is true of Israel, where Judaism is state-sponsored, despite lots of Christians and Muslims. Nobody finds that strange. Russia, too, has its own particular history and religious tradition and needs to preserve it."

In principle, the monks' position is irrefutable. Since the conversion of the Slavs in the 10th century, shortly before the great schism when eastern and western branches of the Christian church split , the orthodox faith has had a definitive role in the life of the Russian nation.After the fall of Constantinople in 1453, the idea that Moscow would take its place and become the "third Rome" gave the nation its sense of purpose.

About the same time, missionary monks, including crusaders from Valaam who penetrated as far as Alaska, helped conquer Siberia. Beliefs were so entrenched that when Peter the Great, in a secularisation drive, ordered the nobles to cut off their beards [a symbol of orthodox belief] they hid the cut-off hair in their pockets, for fear they might not be admitted clean-shaven to heaven. Right up to the 1917 revolution, the sense of statehood was so indistinct that, if asked about nationality, a Russian peasant was likely to answer: "I am orthodox and from here."

While the communist era anti-religious onslaught is estimated to have produced 170,000 Christian martyrs and led to widespread desecration of church property (Valaam was first a sanatorium for disabled soldiers and later a repository for exiled dissidents), it is estimated that 50m Russians still clung to their religion. Ironically, what the quasi-religious conception of Russian identity, and the orthodox faith, have proved least well-equipped to survive is the pluralism of modern liberalisation. The church was most alarmed by the groups flooding into the country after the collapse of the Soviet Union, many (including Mormons, Jehovah's Witnesses, Seventh Day Adventists and Scientology) with assertive missionary policies.

Even today, a trip to the red-brick Hubbard Humanitarian Centre in north Moscow, with its psychic personality tests, or a visit to the Pentecostal temple in the southern suburb of Tsaritsyno, give an indication of how exotic these religions must have seemed 10 years ago. In starkest contrast to the solemn majesty of Valaam, the Pentecostals worship in a sweaty, low-ceilinged cubicle, most of which is taken up by the band in front and a giant mixing desk at the back.
