fields.headline: Vocal heroes
fields.standfirst: Joyce is available. Orwell isn't. Lloyd George is, but not Keir Hardie.  Robert Perks  on a new CD which re-creates a century in sound
fields.trailText: Joyce is available. Orwell isn't. Lloyd George is, but not Keir Hardie. Robert Perks on a new CD which re-creates a century in sound
fields.body:
There's something thrilling and unexpected about listening to Christabel Pankhurst, after her release from Holloway prison in 1908, passionately demanding the vote for women. Or hearing Charles Lightoller, second officer on the Titanic, remember watching the ship go down. Or hearing the excitement in the voice of Howard Carter from 1936 describing his discovery of the tomb of Tutankhamun.

Some of the key historical moments and figures of the 20th century were never captured by photographers, still less by moving images. But they survive in sound. The last century was the first to give us a complete soundtrack of its path and for historians of the future it will be the first moment amid centuries of documents when they can actually hear the raw emotion, the intonation, accent and stress of the authentic voice of history.

What would they give for a recording of Henry VIII or an interview with a soldier at the Battle of Waterloo? If Thomas Edison hadn't invented recorded sound in 1877 - and by the way, almost anyone could have done, as it used no new scientific knowledge, technology, or materials - we would lack the ability we now have to eavesdrop on history.

Yet when the British Library National Sound Archive came to compiling its own soundtrack of the 20th century for a new CD, A Century in Sound, we were amazed by what had never been recorded.

Although gramophones were popular in Britain by the 1930s, the arbitrariness of what was recorded at the time and what has survived is astonishing. Some key figures and events are nowhere to be found amongst the archive's 1.1m discs and 185,000 tapes, one of the largest in the world. Where is the voice of Oscar Wilde or Thomas Hardy? Why has not one second survived of George Orwell when he broadcast so extensively? Why do we have recordings of James Joyce and even Queen Victoria, William Gladstone and Florence Nightingale, but not of King Edward VII? Why Lloyd George but not the founder of the Labour party, Keir Hardie; Antarctic explorer Shackleton, but not Captain Scott?

In some cases we had recordings but they were disappointing. Virginia Woolf gives few clues as to her brilliance as an author, and no single recording of Bertrand Russell seems to do justice to his standing as one of the key thinkers and peace campaigners of the century. The same can be said of the recordings of trade union leader Ben Tillett, and Labour's first prime minister, Ramsay MacDonald, both of whose oratory was marvelled at by contemporaries but who utterly fail to impress now.

No doubt some of these absences and disappointments are due to the recording technology of the day. Until the end of the first world war, live "actuality" recording (which we can now carry in our back pockets) was virtually impossible. Sound quality was appalling and recordings lasted only a few minutes. The BBC invariably stage-managed and scripted everything, and until the 1960s, a very large and intimidating amount of heavy equipment was required for even the simplest recording, which was rarely conducive to spontaneous self-expression. It was also an expensive and time-consuming process, favouring people of fame, influence and money, such as Churchill, Amy Johnson, Gandhi and King George V (who all appear on the CD), rather than ordinary people, whose voices are largely missing from the archive. Hardly any contemporary recorded accounts survive of ordinary life for millions of Britons before the second world war.

Fortunately for posterity, from the late 1950s oral historians such as George Ewart Evans, and an increasing number of broadcasters (led by Charles Parker's Radio Ballads and Stephen Peet's Yesterday's Witness on television) pioneered a movement to democratise not only the collection of the voices of ordinary people but also their preservation in archives. Compact tape recorders made it easy to gather interviews with people who had witnessed some of the remarkable events of the century, talking at length.

T his helped us to plug gaps in our soundtrack of the 20th century. We were able, for example, to include a vivid account from a heckler who was ejected from Oswald Mosley's infamous fascist rally at Olympia in 1934 alongside a rare recording of the meeting itself. The architect of the Festival of Britain, Hugh Casson, touchingly remembers sheltering under a piano during German bombing raids in Kent during the first world war, and seeing the bloodstain left by the death of the local rector. And in 1959 (luckily for us) an amateur tape recordist decided to drag his tape-recorder along to a memorably witty speech by Nye Bevan about the National Health Service, one of the last that survives.

Selecting Britain's soundtrack since the 1960s has been in many ways even more difficult, with a host of events for which both sound and moving images exist. Some recordings were so iconographic they chose themselves, such as the Apollo 11 moon landing, President Kennedy's assassination and the funeral of the Princess of Wales.

Others we included might nonetheless surprise those of us whose collective consciousness dictates a televisual version of events. How many of us recall the crucial Saturday morning debate in the House of Commons that led to the Falklands conflict as opposed to the televised press briefings? The Commons proceedings were broadcast in sound only. Or the fact that there are two versions of the commentary for the 1966 World Cup final in which Brian Moore's radio version is more sceptical of Geoff's Hurst's winning goal than his television colleague.

In the end we had to pick only 47 CD tracks to represent the century, which meant we didn't have space to include Dr Van Zwanenberg talking about the last outbreak of the bubonic plague in Ipswich before the first world war; or John Henry Hay, a market gardener from Worcestershire, who volunteered for the Boer war; or Harry Jones, a fisherman born in 1887, encountering a "sea monster" at Hoylake later identified as a porpoise; or Barbara Stimler movingly recalling arriving at Auschwitz in 1943; or Diana Rigg defending single motherhood in church in 1976.

All these are in the National Sound Archive for posterity, and of course for anyone who wants to produce a CD at the end of the next millennium.

 Dr Robert Perks is curator of oral history at the British Library National Sound Archive. The Century in Sound CD, out this week, is produced by the British Library, 96 Euston Road, London NW1 2DB, priced £8.99 (cheques to the British Library Bookshop).

The BBC invariably stage-managed and scripted everything, and until the 1960s, a very large and intimidating amount of heavy equipment was required for even the simplest recording, which was rarely conducive to spontaneous self-expression. It was also an expensive and time-consuming process, favouring people of fame, influence and money, such as Churchill, Amy Johnson, Gandhi and King George V (who all appear on the CD), rather than ordinary people, whose voices are largely missing from the archive. Hardly any contemporary recorded accounts survive of ordinary life for millions of Britons before the second world war. Fortunately for posterity, from the late 1950s oral historians such as George Ewart Evans, and an increasing number of broadcasters (led by Charles Parker's Radio Ballads and Stephen Peet's Yesterday's Witness on television) pioneered a movement to democratise not only the collection of the voices of ordinary people but also their preservation in archives. Compact tape recorders made it easy to gather interviews with people who had witnessed some of the remarkable events of the century, talking at length. T his helped us to plug gaps in our soundtrack of the 20th century. We were able, for example, to include a vivid account from a heckler who was ejected from Oswald Mosley's infamous fascist rally at Olympia in 1934 alongside a rare recording of the meeting itself. The architect of the Festival of Britain, Hugh Casson, touchingly remembers sheltering under a piano during German bombing raids in Kent during the first world war, and seeing the bloodstain left by the death of the local rector. And in 1959 (luckily for us) an amateur tape recordist decided to drag his tape-recorder along to a memorably witty speech by Nye Bevan about the National Health Service, one of the last that survives. Selecting Britain's soundtrack since the 1960s has been in many ways even more difficult, with a host of events for which both sound and moving images exist. Some recordings were so iconographic they chose themselves, such as the Apollo 11 moon landing, President Kennedy's assassination and the funeral of the Princess of Wales. Others we included might nonetheless surprise those of us whose collective consciousness dictates a televisual version of events. How many of us recall the crucial Saturday morning debate in the House of Commons that led to the Falklands conflict as opposed to the televised press briefings? The Commons proceedings were broadcast in sound only. Or the fact that there are two versions of the commentary for the 1966 World Cup final in which Brian Moore's radio version is more sceptical of Geoff's Hurst's winning goal than his television colleague. In the end we had to pick only 47 CD tracks to represent the century, which meant we didn't have space to include Dr Van Zwanenberg talking about the last outbreak of the bubonic plague in Ipswich before the first world war; or John Henry Hay, a market gardener from Worcestershire, who volunteered for the Boer war; or Harry Jones, a fisherman born in 1887, encountering a "sea monster" at Hoylake later identified as a porpoise; or Barbara Stimler movingly recalling arriving at Auschwitz in 1943; or Diana Rigg defending single motherhood in church in 1976. All these are in the National Sound Archive for posterity, and of course for anyone who wants to produce a CD at the end of the next millennium.  Dr Robert Perks is curator of oral history at the British Library National Sound Archive. The Century in Sound CD, out this week, is produced by the British Library, 96 Euston Road, London NW1 2DB, priced £8.99 (cheques to the British Library Bookshop). Tel: 020 7412 7735, email: bookshop@bl.uk

fields.headline: Return of the cowpat
fields.standfirst: Tom Service on a very unlikely classical revival
fields.trailText: Tom Service on a very unlikely classical revival
fields.body:
In programming works by Joseph Holbrooke, Ernest Bristow Farrar and York Bowen, Ronald Corp and the New London Orchestra at St John's Smith Square sought to atone for decades of neglect to that murkiest of musical periods, the so-called "cowpat school" of early 20th- century English music.

Oscar Bettison - the composer of the world premiere given by Corp and the NLO and winner of the BBC's first young composer award - is almost better known than any of them. At the heart of Bettison's Hour Tree is a simple clarinet melody, repeated a total of 150 times during the piece.

Stravinsky and Andriessen came to mind in Bettison's orchestration, with strident soprano saxophone and Rite of Spring-inspired woodwind arabesques. But there was little of the hard-edged coolness or clarity of either composer. Instead, Bettison created lush, luxurious textures from the large ensemble.

Whatever the surface beauty of the sounds in Hour Tree, its technical ideas were trapped by a lack of orchestral finesse. In the central part of the work, the music could not escape the centrifugal orbit of that incessant clarinet theme.

Holbrooke's tone-poem, The Birds of Rhiannon, is a pastoral parallel to Wagner's Siegfried Idyll and a distillation of Holbrooke's gargantuan opera trilogy based on Welsh mythology. But "the cockney Wagner", as he was known, smothers the simplicity of his pseudo-leitmotifs in gloopy chromaticism.

York Bowen's Viola Concerto, skilfully handled by Martin Outram, also seems in the throes of wannabe Teutonism. But a real discovery was Farrar's English Pastoral Impressions. In place of continental pretension, Farrar uses the simplicity and stasis of folk-tunes to create a distinctive English music. On the strength of this work, with its breathtaking imagery of melodies suspended by tubular bells over an oasis of string sound, Britain was robbed of another great talent in the trenches of the first world war.

fields.headline: Slow train to fame
fields.standfirst: If there's any justice, the singer Raissa is about to get her big break. By  Caroline Sullivan
fields.trailText: If there's any justice, the singer Raissa is about to get her big break. By Caroline Sullivan
fields.body:
Raissa Khan-Panni must be used to seeing her name on lists of major new Brit contenders because it has appeared there every year since 1997. But while other hopefuls from the class of '97 - such as Stereophonics - are on mutual adoration terms with Zoë Ball, Raissa's star has failed to rise at the rate predicted.

This fact wasn't lost on a tactless interviewer from local radio, who cornered her before Wednesday's show at WKD - a cupboard of a Camden club - and commiserated: "Your career's been a bit of a slow-burner, hasn't it? But you could always go back to busking." All by way of saying that 2000 is make or break - by the end of the year, she'll either be living large with Zoë or playing guitar in Camden Town tube.

But if the size and avidity of the crowd at WKD was any indication, Raissa is finally on her way. Now all she's got to do is take the mini-horde of boho-chic girls and their dainty boys and multiply them by 10,000.

As she wafted through a short set she plainly touched a nerve - the same one touched in susceptible people by Bjork. Though Raissa is less wacky than her Icelandic counterpart, you could jus tifiably dub her Bjork Again, because - let's not be coy - she looks the part (feathers around her neck, head bristling with short plaits) and sounds it.

She's blessed with one of those force-of-nature voices that run the gamut from Baby Spice mewing to something that more properly belongs to a bronchial centenarian. And, like Bjork, she pitches the voice against trip-hoppy beats and whirling layers of Middle Eastern exotica.

Yet the music is more immediately accessible and Raissa more charming - a gamine with a fairy wand who steps into the audience to sing the swaying title track of her Believer album right into her public's dazzled faces. The song is as close to an anthem as she gets, and the crowd goes appropriately jiggy. The rest of the songs are in the mode of the single How Long Do I Get? and the trumpet-blatting Walk Right Through, wistful confections that she sings dreamily into the middle distance.

It's so fully realised that the indie-kid programmer and guitarist who back her had better have steel egos to cope with the certainty that no one will ever notice them. The British music biz is bereft of strong female talent, and it would be foolish indeed if Raissa has to wait much longer.

webTitle: Is it Jagger or Reggie Perrin? Why has Bryan Ferry got a hose in his ear?

fields.headline: Is it Jagger or Reggie Perrin? Why has Bryan Ferry got a hose in his ear?
fields.trailText: Lost in music
fields.body:
In the past couple of years there's been much talk about the widening gap between the consumer and the icon. All the signs point to the pop industry going the same way as the movies, with ever-decreasing access to celebrities, and an impenetrable PR shrink-wrap being vacuum-sealed around the Real Star. In a sense, this is dangerous: pop-star-meets-psycho news stories suggest that a more enigmatic icon makes for a more tenacious stalker. But, as far as the well-balanced fan is concerned, it's possible that this situation is for the best: after all, nine out of 10 flesh-real musical heroes let you down. Contemplate them from a distance, however, without seeing the full (singular) dimensions of their personality or having to witness them reluctantly acknowledge you as a fellow human, and your dreams are safe.

Where does the buzz emanate from when we see a pop star in the flesh? Do we need them to shake their hips and say "Hello Huddersfield, are you ready to rock?" before the buzz starts, or is their silent, motionless presence enough on its own? I've been wondering, so I thought I'd go to Rock Circus, the Madame Tussaud's of pop in London's Piccadilly Circus, to find out.

I make the visit with a friend, Pete, since Rock Circus, like a shopping complex at midnight, isn't the sort of place you want to be in alone. As we arrive, the ticket collector hands us a huge trophy and congratulates us on being the first British residents to visit Rock Circus. He doesn't really, but he might as well have done: after all, how many non-tourists do you know who spend their afternoons looking at waxworks? Most music biz people I spoke to about the place asked me if it was a new gig venue.

First we meet Thriller-era Michael Jackson (grade: B-). I compliment him on his bum-fluff, but he stares right through me. Pete assures me that it's nothing personal: Michael's just shy. Upstairs, next to the model of Bryan Ferry (C+), there's a picture of the Roxy Music singer with what appears to be a hose in his ear and a skewer in his nostril, looking like he's about to twat the person on the other end of said implements. The unconvincing caption informs us that "Bryan remained typically suave for his sitting".

Across the room, we find Cliff Richard (F-) in the little-known Miami Vice phase of his career, and an authentically out-of-it Brian Wilson (A-), staring vacantly up at the ceiling, obviously considering what sort of skirting board topping to spread over his beetroot soufflé. Further on, second-rate celebrities make do with getting model hands. Pete and I are delighted to discover that we have bigger hands than Meatloaf, taking this as confirmation that we could "have" him. Kiss's hands all have the distinguishing feature of being bigger than my feet.

There's a gaping lack of emphasis placed on natural environment: most of the waxworks are impeccably attired but stand next to a stark wall. Would it have stretched the budget to put Brian Wilson in a sandpit, Bob Dylan on a motorbike, Jimi Hendrix in a dressing room entangled with six or seven groupie succubi, or Keith Richards serving on the pharmaceutical counter at Boots? Crude? Maybe. But Rock Circus's most vulgar section - the graveyard of the stars - is the place's most successful feature_ and the one that feels least funereal.

I'm still trying to figure out why that buzz isn't coming through. Is it because, having met a few famous people, I'm inured to their presence? Or is it because the Mick Jagger model (F-) would make a more convincing Reginald Perrin? One slip - a wonky nose, a wandering chin - and the illusion is over. Pete Townshend (ungraded) looks more like former Blue Peter presenter Peter Duncan. And, no matter how much you use your imagination, Duncan leaping into the air, poised to make his Fender into matchwood, isn't the same as Townshend doing the same thing, is it?

webTitle: Snowy synonyms and other famous fictional 'facts'

fields.headline: Snowy synonyms and other famous fictional 'facts'
fields.trailText: Down at the house | Politicos on pot
fields.body:
I read a fascinating piece of research from the University of Minnesota this week. Apparently the Eskimos do not have 36 (or whatever) different words for snow, as is almost universally believed and frequently quoted. In fact the Inuit have two. We have far more terms for "rain" (shower, drizzle, Scotch mist, sleet, hail, storm, cloudburst, downpour, plus dialect words such as scud and mizzle). But of course the old Eskimo story will still get trotted out. It's too useful.

Likewise the myth that 90% of the human brain is unused by the average person. Simply not true. If it were we could play Pokmon and translate the works of Corneille while asleep. Many Americans firmly believe that half of all electric power is wasted by computers being left on overnight (think about that for a minute). Children have innumerable such beliefs. I was certain that if you left a tooth overnight in a bottle of Coca-Cola it would have dissolved by morning. I never tried it, but if that were true, half the children in the world would have nothing but black stumps in their mouths. People cling desperately to their favourite myths.

For years exasperated people asked me why I didn't write about the affair between Michael Portillo and Peter Lilley. I used to answer the same way as Ian Hislop: there wasn't a shred of evidence because it isn't true. One friend solemnly assured me it was true. "I know, because my aunt works in the House of Commons." "So do I!" I almost screamed. Peter Lilley must have been greatly relieved, when Portillo came out, to deny it formally. Do readers know any other such myths - at least any I can print?

 Down at the House we're delighted that Michael Brunson's job as ITN political editor has gone to John Sergeant of the BBC, who really should not have been held back for so long. Not many people realise that John used to be a successful comic actor, and appeared in Alan Bennett's sketch series on BBC2 umpteen years ago. Now he is brilliantly witty on shows such as The News Quiz, Room 101 and Masterchef. He and I spent a very happy couple of months covering Ted Heath in the two 1974 general elections. We decided it would be a good idea to have meaningful slogans, instead of the usual nonsense, such as "Good on yer, Ted", and "Vote Tory!"

So we would hide behind cars and hoardings, bellowing: "Resist import surcharges on the Italian model, Mr Heath!" and "Say no to a re-definition of the M3 money supply statistics!" He looked very surprised. We flew around on Dan Air, a not greatly lamented independent line, and one of our stewardesses had clearly been trained at Treblinka. Once we were taxiing on to the runway at, I think, Glasgow, when John's finger went up to the orange button. She stormed down the aisle. "While we are taxiing, that lights the emergency signal in the cockpit! What, might I ask, is the emergency?"

"My friend needs a drink," said John. Wisps of steam began to come from her ears. "That is not an emergency!" she yelled. John stayed calm. "I don't think you understand. My friend" - he waved vaguely at me - "is an alcoholic. He requires a drink. Please bring him a gin and tonic, and I'll have a Carlsberg." Amazingly, we got served soon after take-off. No doubt she believed him.

 I think that there ought to be a firm rule. Any politician who was at university at any time from the mid-1960s and who did not try pot, should be barred from office for life. There must be something dreadfully wrong with them if they didn't even try, or "experiment" as we're supposed to call it.

 Thanks for your very welcome suggestions, letters and tapes of dreadful songs, and I shall return to the topic soon. In the meantime, I've been touched by how many of you have a really soft spot for some terrible tear-jerkers. Many otherwise sane people admit to having to wipe a moist eye when they hear Rolf Harris's Two Little Boys, or No Charge by both Melba Montgomery and JJ Barrie - the one about the little boy who wants to be paid for doing the chores, and is reminded by his mum of all she does for nothing. Some readers even confess to liking Tell Laura I Love Her by Ricky Valance or Ray Peterson and Terry, by Twinkle, though not very many. My shameful secret is that I have to conceal a manly tear when I listen to Old Rivers by Walter Brennan, about an ancient farmer who dreams of heaven "where there ain't no fields to plough." It's absolutely appalling. I love it.

 Latest from the world's greatest ad industry: the clever clogs in red braces are raving about the lager ad which shows an Andy McNab paperback with bumpy cover entitled: I Wet My Pants And Ran Away. "How refreshing. How Heineken." Yes, it's quite funny. But didn't it dawn on them that almost all canned lager looks and tastes like urine with the flavour removed? And that all this ad does is subconsciously remind us of that fact? And the poster for Sleepy Hollow advertises the "novelisation" by someone or other - not Washington Irving, who wrote a perfectly good novel in the first place.

fields.headline: The last word on drugs
fields.standfirst: The spirit of the world comes not forth to the sorceries of opium or of wine - Emerson
fields.trailText: The spirit of the world comes not forth to the sorceries of opium or of wine - Emerson
fields.body:
This week, Mo Mowlam has admitted to smoking cannabis as a student, the footballer Maradona has gone into a Cuban clinic for his cocaine habit, and in a gross misapplication of justice, two charity workers at a Cambridge drop-in centre for the homeless have been sentenced to a total of nine years imprisonment for failing to take "reasonable steps" to prevent drug-dealing on the premises.

A drug is a substance which alters mood or mental states. Caffeine, alcohol, heroin, nicotine, cocaine, Prozac, cannabis are all drugs. It might seem puzzling why some are legal and some not - and even more puzzling that some of the most dangerous ones, such as alcohol and nicotine, are legal whereas relatively innocuous (even medically helpful) ones such as cannabis are illegal. But the reasons, which have nothing to do with logic or science, are not hard to fathom. Drugs were first legally controlled in Britain in 1868, not to regulate their use but to protect the business of pharmacists. Opium was widely used in laudanum, and heroin was developed from opium towards the end of the century.

During the first world war soldiers tempered the horrors they faced by using opiates and - as did Freud in fact and Sherlock Holmes in fiction - cocaine. This prompted a law banning the public sale of these drugs for the first time. Anti-drug legislation thus began as a way of ensuring that young men would be fit to kill one another. For several decades prior to 1914 moral conservatives had been campaigning for prohibition of alcohol. The war gave them their chance; in the United States the great folly of Prohibition was enacted, and in analogous mood most western countries passed laws against opiates, cocaine and marijuana too. At that time the incidence of drug use was relatively small, and in the case of addiction was regarded as a medical rather than a legal problem.

The main result of criminalisation was rapid growth in drug consumption, by the familiar mechanisms of marketing by criminal organisations, and the attractions of the forbidden. The disaster of Prohibition in America should have taught the world lessons enough: criminalisation creates enormous problems, by providing opportunities for organised crime, and turning many users into criminals - principally those who become addicted and who therefore have to steal to pay for their habit. And it entangles the police, courts and customs authorities in mighty, expensive, and generally futile labours.

All these problems would be abolished at a stroke by decriminalisation. Would the entire populace suddenly become drug addicts? Of course not. Most people who wish to take drugs already do so; most people who regularly consume currently legal drugs - alcohol, nicotine, caffeine - do it sensibly, and lead normal lives despite their addictions and consequent health problems. Just as people are encouraged not to smoke or drink excessively, so they would be encouraged not to take heroin or cocaine; and just as one prosecutes people for driving a motor-car or causing a public nuisance under the influence of alcohol, so one would prosecute those who misbehaved under the influence of cocaine or LSD.

Drug use is not a moral problem; but drug abuse can be. In Ambrose Bierce's definition a drug is "an unlocked door in the prison of identity - which leads into the jail-yard"; which illustrates the point that people who depend upon drugs (rather than occasionally employing them for recreational purposes) to attain fulfilment or to escape from difficulties, are sad cases, either because they genuinely need help, or because they lack the intelligence or courage to achieve fulfilment through their own resources. Dependence on drugs is thus either pitiable or contemptible; but neither is a reason for making them illegal. Those who believe otherwise need an injection of something - preferably sanity.

fields.headline: Gré Brouwenstijn
fields.standfirst: Soprano with a faultless sense of style
fields.trailText: Gré Brouwenstijn, the eminent Dutch singer who has died at the age of 84, was one of the most admired sopranos in the lyric-dramatic repertory of the early postwar era, not least in Britain, where she appeared regularly at Covent Garden and Glyndebourne.
fields.body:
Gré Brouwenstijn, the eminent Dutch singer who has died at the age of 84, was one of the most admired sopranos in the lyric-dramatic repertory of the early postwar era, not least in Britain, where she appeared regularly at Covent Garden and Glyndebourne.

Her Elisabetta was one of the main adornments of the legendary Visconti staging of Verdi's Don Carlos at the Royal Opera House in 1958, and she had preceded that with an equally admired Desdemona in Otello in 1955. Her Leonore, in Fidelio at Glyndebourne in 1959, was another triumph. As in all her roles, she was noted for her eloquent acting, which supported firm and true singing, and both were consonant with the character in hand.

Brouwenstijn was born in Den Helder, in the northern Netherlands, and at 16 began attending singing classes at the Amsterdam Musik Lyceum. After the war, she joined the Hilversum radio choir, and was soon invited to take solo parts in broadcasts of operatic excerpts. She joined the Netherlands Opera, the country's first national company, shortly after it was formed in 1946, debuting in no less a role than Tosca the following year. That was soon followed by Elisabetta, then Leonore in Trovatore, Rezia in Oberon, the title role in Janacek's Jenufa, Amelia (Un ballo in maschera), and Tatyana in Yevgeny Onegin.

Her first appearances abroad were in Dublin in 1950 and, thereafter, she sang regularly for the BBC Third Programme in London, for which she performed Jenufa, Yaroslavna (Prince Igor), and the title role of Dvorak's Rusalka. In October 1951, she first appeared at Covent Garden, as Aida, under Sir John Barbirolli, and, the following year, as Amelia, one of her most sympathetic creations, but neither performance was that well received.

It was when Rafael Kubelik, who had conducted Brouwenstijn in Rusalka and Jenufa for the BBC, took over as music director at the Royal Opera House in 1955 that she received the support she needed to give her full confidence, and her Desdemona was considered on all sides a most moving interpretation. One critic wrote that "she was a tall, dignified, sweetly gentle and infinitely touching Desdemona".

Giulini, who was to conduct the 1958 Don Carlos, chose Brouwenstijn for Elisabetta after being impressed by her performance in the Verdi Requiem he conducted at the 1957 Holland Festival. His confidence was amply justified, as she sang the taxing role with beauty of tone and depth of feeling.

Bayreuth was also attracted by her talents. She appeared as a radiant Elisabeth in Tannhauser in 1954, and reappeared as Sieglinde, Gutrune and Eva in 1955-56. That, in turn, persuaded Wieland Wagner to cast her as Leonore in his then- controversial staging of Fidelio in Stuttgart, in which she scored a further triumph. She again had a personal success in the role, this time with Sir Thomas Beecham conducting (one of his last appearances), in Buenos Aires in 1958. She was also acclaimed at the Chicago and Vienna state operas, and at La Scala. She continued her career until the mid-1970s.

Brouwenstijn's art is preserved on a few discs, notably her interpretations of Elisabeth, Eva, Sieglinde at Bayreuth - all live recordings - and Tosca, Elisabetta and Leonore. They confirm the conviction and sincerity of her singing, and her faultless sense of style.

Alan Blyth

fields.headline: Ion Ratiu
fields.standfirst: Romanian emigré leader unable to adjust to the politics of post-communist society
fields.trailText: Ion Ratiu, the Romanian emigré leader, politician and businessman, spent 50 years in self-imposed exile in Britain. When he did return to his homeland, after the overthrow of the Ceausescu dictatorship in 1989, he found the experience of post-communist politics something of a disappointment.
fields.body:
Ion Ratiu, the Romanian emigré leader, politician and businessman, spent 50 years in self-imposed exile in Britain. When he did return to his homeland, after the overthrow of the Ceausescu dictatorship in 1989, he found the experience of post-communist politics something of a disappointment.

Ratiu, who has died aged 82 in London, earned considerable recognition as president of the World Union of Free Romanians (WUFR). But back in Romania he never received the acknowledgement he expected, and his presidential ambitions were dashed when he came a poor third in the first post-communist elections in 1990.

Born in the small town of Turda, near the Transylvanian regional capital, Cluj, Ratiu came from a family with a long tradition of advocating the cause of a united Romania. That dream came true in 1918 when, with the dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian empire, Hungary lost control of Transylvania and the region became part of Romania.

After studying law at Cluj university, Ratiu moved to London in 1940 as a diplomat at the Romanian legation. When his country joined the Axis powers, he resigned and applied for political asylum. He then read economics at Cambridge, where he met Elisabeth Pilkington, of the glass manufacturing family, whom he married in 1945.

After his studies, Ratiu became a journalist, specialising in western policy towards the communist world. His work included regular contributions to the Romanian service of the BBC. He also ran Regent Line, a shipping company, and acquired extensive property interests.

As the WUFR's indefatigable - and millionaire - president, he organised demonstrations and meetings, published a regular newsletter in English and Romanian, and did his best to make the organisation an effective lobbying group. His most spectacular move came during Ceausescu's state visit to Britain in 1977, when Ratiu chained himself to the railings outside the Ritz Hotel in London in protest at the royal hospitality extended to Ceausescu.

After the dictator's summary execution, Ratiu returned home and became active in the newly-revived Christian Democratic-National Peasant Party (CD-NPP). During the May 1990 presidential race, he was one of two challengers to Ion Iliescu, the communist-era apparatchik, who had taken over as head of state after Ceausescu was ousted. Although Iliescu was the hot favourite, Ratiu's showing of only 4.3 per cent of the vote still came as a surprise. It had much to do with his nascent party's weakness, but he was also seen as being out of touch with Romanian realities after an absence of 50 years.

Unlike the vast majority of his countryman, Ratiu had not suffered the hardships associated with communist rule; his opponents accused him of eating caviare in the west instead of salami and soya at home. With his English manners and somewhat antiquated language, "Mr Bow Tie", as he became known, also resembled an old-fashioned industrialist, an image exploited by his adversaries, who played on fears that a vote for Ratiu would bring back the harsh conditions of pre-war Romania. His advocacy of privatisation reinforced such populist sentiments.

Although he was elected to parliament, and later became vice-president of the CD-NPP, his heavy defeat spelt the end of any realistic chances for a high office of state. It was the irony of the times that many of his policy proposals were eventually adopted by political friend and foe alike.

But his ambition remained. Prior to the 1996 elections, Ratiu, by then close to 80, strongly argued that he would do better in the ballot than Emil Constantinescu, the agreed candidate of the united opposition. In the event, Constantinescu's victory did nothing to reconcile Ratiu to the new president - or to the coalition government, by now led by his own CD-NPP.

Ratiu's daily, Cotidianul, remained highly critical of both, although Ratiu claimed that, as the paper's owner, he had no influence over its editorial line. He also adopted a firmly nationalist line, which only highlighted his differences with senior party colleagues, who relied on the representatives of ethnic Hungarians in the coalition government.

Ratiu is survived by his wife and two sons, Nicolae and Indrei. In accordance with his wishes, he is to be buried in his home town.

Gabriel Partos

webTitle: Japan fears sect violence as guru's son is snatched

fields.headline: Japan fears sect violence as guru's son is snatched
fields.trailText: A son of the guru of the doomsday Aum Shinrikyo sect was abducted by fellow-members of the cult yesterday, prompting fears of a violent battle for control of the sect, some of whose members were responsible for a deadly gas attack on the Tokyo underground in 1995.
fields.body:
A son of the guru of the doomsday Aum Shinrikyo sect was abducted by fellow-members of the cult yesterday, prompting fears of a violent battle for control of the sect, some of whose members were responsible for a deadly gas attack on the Tokyo underground in 1995.

The abduction, which occurred under the noses of police and anti-sect protesters, came just days after Aum's leaders denounced their guru, Shoko Asahara, changed the cult's name and pledged to compensate its victims in a bid to avert a crackdown by the authorities.

Police said that one of Mr Asahara's daughters was among six cult members who burst into an Aum compound in Asahimura, scuffled with residents and seized the guru's seven-year-old son, Akiteru. One of the intruders, Satoshi Nagayama, a former cult member, was arrested, but the others escaped by car.

The motive for the abduction remain unclear, but speculation has centred on the possibility of a power struggle within the sect, whose willingness to resort to violence was shown by the 1995 sarin gas attack, which killed 12 people and injured thousands.

Faced with an imminent crackdown by security authorities, senior cultists announced on Tuesday that they were no longer led by Mr Asahara, who is on trial for the gas attack and 16 other crimes.

Fumihiro Joyu, the guru's former right hand man, criticised Mr Asahara for wrongly predicting Armageddon last year and acknowledged for the first time that the man who claims to be a reincarnation of Shiva, the god of destruction, was involved in the gas attack.

Aum also announced that it would change its name to Aleph, the first letter of the Hebrew alphabet, recant its doomsday doctrines and sell its properties to compensate the victims of its crimes.

This is likely to have enraged hardliners in the cult, which has always been divided between a violent political wing and disciples seeking only enlightenment. The hawks are likely to have been strengthened in recent years by the release of several cultists who were convicted of crimes in the 1995 crackdown.

It has not been revealed which of Mr Asahara's three daughters was involved in the abduction, but the most likely candidate is 14-year-old Rika Matsumoto. As the first child to be born after Mr Asahara claimed to have attained enlightenment in 1982, she was once considered the guru's successor. However, she was removed after throwing violent tantrums in public.

"If you are singled out for special treatment from birth and do not have to go to school, it is inevitable that you believe you are number one," said a member of the public security investigation agency, which has 1,700 detectives monitoring the cult.

In the past two years, cultists have increasingly focused on Akiteru for spiritual leadership. They claim that even a video tape of the small boy emits a special light and creates powerful vibrations.

His whereabouts are now unknown. Cultists have proved skilled at evading the police. Three of those involved in the sarin attack have been on the run for more than four years, despite posters of them being displayed at stations throughout the country.

The abduction is certain to strengthen the hand of the public security investigation agency, which has applied for new powers to monitor the cult. A decision on whether to grant those powers will be made early next month.

It will also raise anxieties among a nervous public. Aum is believed to have rebuilt much of its organisation to the level where it now has about 2,000 members and an income of more than £40m a year from its computer businesses.

Most worrying, however, is that cultists have testified that they would have been willing to carry out the gas attack on the orders not just of Mr Asahara, but of his children.

Despite its claimed change of doctrine, the cult's website still declares that Mr Asahara is the messiah and that the end of the world is nigh.

webTitle: Burma bans politics on the net

fields.headline: Burma bans politics on the net
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Burma's military regime has forbidden the posting of political writings on the internet, even though it has yet to allow public access to cyberspace.
fields.body:
Burma's military regime has forbidden the posting of political writings on the internet, even though it has yet to allow public access to cyberspace.

The Myanmar Post and Telecommunications (MPT), a government agency, broadcast on state-run television this week tough new regulations for internet users. Prohibitions include publishing anything on the net that is "detrimental" to Burma or "directly or indirectly detrimental to the current policies and secret security affairs of the government".

"Writings related to politics are not to be posted," the broadcast said.

All media are tightly controlled by the state in Burma, which has been ruled by the military since 1962. Under existing law, possession of a computer or fax, or setting up an unauthorised computer network, is punishable with jail terms of up to 15 years.

Last month, the two local private email providers using overseas servers were suspended by the government, which announced that the MPT was to be the sole agency authorised to provide email. There is now no internet provider in the country.

The regime is sensitive to the large volume of websites and newsgroups set up overseas by exiled dissidents and foreign supporters of the opposition leader and 1991 Nobel prize laureate, Aung San Suu Kyi. Her party won the country's last elections in May 1990 but she remains under house arrest in the capital Rangoon.

The rules specify that users of the MPT's internet service must obtain "prior permission from the organisation designated by the state to create web pages". Any violators of the regulations will face "legal action" and have their accounts suspended.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Last farewell to corrupt PM
fields.body:
Last farewell to corrupt PM

Friends gathered in Tunisia yesterday to pay their last respects to Bettino Craxi, the former Italian Socialist prime minister convicted of corruption who died of heart failure in self-imposed exile.

Italy's foreign minister, Lamberto Dini, and the opposition leader, Silvio Berlusconi, a friend of Craxi's, were among the mourners. Reuters, Tunis

Huge dinosaur's remains found

Scientists working in the remote Patagonia region of Argentina say they have discovered partial remains of what may be the largest dinosaur species on record.

A team of palaeontologists have unearthed what they believe are the bones of a plant-eating dinosaur thought to have roamed earth 105m years ago.

The creature, not yet named, is believed to have been up to 50m (164ft) long and weighed more than 10 tons - or the equivalent of two large elephants. AP, Buenos Aires

Swiss banks have frozen £390m in accounts belonging to the late Nigerian dictator, General Sani Abacha, and his associates, and more money may be found, the federal office of police affairs said yesterday.

That is more money than in any previous case where Switzerland has frozen funds of former dictators.

The government is also believed to be taking steps to recover money from Britain, France, Germany, Belgium, Luxembourg and Liechtenstein. AP, Bern

Switzerland's highest court yesterday threw out a complaint by a Holocaust survivor who claimed that the Swiss government was responsible for handing him over to the Nazis - but then awarded him the money he had demanded anyway.

But it agreed that Mr Spring, 73, should be given £38,000 to cover his costs and on ethical grounds. AP, Lausanne, Switzerland

webTitle: Take a break but don't bend the eternal city's rules

fields.headline: Take a break but don't bend the eternal city's rules
fields.standfirst: Capital letters
fields.trailText: It's relentless. Every afternoon I take a break in the nearest cafe and give my order. Every afternoon the waiter looks at his watch, does his surprised look and repeats what I've just said. "Cappuccino?"
fields.body:
It's relentless. Every afternoon I take a break in the nearest cafe and give my order. Every afternoon the waiter looks at his watch, does his surprised look and repeats what I've just said. "Cappuccino?"

At first I thought it was my pronunciation. I practised so the word rolls out like a Roman, to no avail. The head tilts, the eyebrows arch and the tone rises. "Cappuccino?"

His mouth creases as if he's about to say something else but he doesn't. He makes the drink and places it on the counter with exaggerated care. This, it is being made clear, is an unusual event.

And it is. Not just in this cafe but all over the city. Romans drink cappuccino only in the morning. All that milk and sugar is the last thing they want swilling in the digestive system after a hearty lunch.

Ordering anything other than an espresso is seen as eccentric.

Sometimes it is so subtle to be almost invisible, but it gradually emerges that almost every act, big and small, is entwined by a rule. Break it and there will be some response, albeit no more than an arched eyebrow or patronising glance.

There are rules for fruit juice (OK with a pastry, never with a meal), fish (on Tuesdays and Friday only, the market days), gnocchi (Thursdays only, no one knows why), and salad (only after the main course).

There are rules for banning petrol stations from selling food, rules for deciding when department stores can hold sales, rules for limiting which prices can be given out over the phone, rules for restricting how far in advance a taxi can be ordered, rules for how many locks a front door must have and rules for when exceptions are allowed.

The image of Romans as freewheeling, extravagant, anything-goes anarchists is a fraud. A spectacular, unexpected, wildly successful con.

To step outdoors is to enter a regimented matrix because, contrary to every cliche, Romans follow the rules.

That they are feted around the world for doing the opposite shows just how long it is possible to string out a joke. Forty years, more or less. That was when a melange of inspired, glamorous, decadent originals made carnival in the Via Veneto and declared Rome to be the numero uno of trendy capitals.

Federico Fellini immortalised Marcello Mastroianni and Anita Ekberg frolicking in the Trevi fountain, and other directors, artists, writers, actors arrived to suckle la dolce vita, the sweet life, for themselves. Cult films such as Three Coins in a Fountain, La Strada and Roman Holiday were pumping out of the Cinecitta studio. Dylan Thomas's widow Caitlin arrived and took a lover 11 years her junior.

The rest of the world marvelled at the style and daring. But the carnival started to move on. When Fellini made Roma in 1971 it was gone.

The joke is that this louche, style-setting exuberance took place in a conservative town verging on the provincial. It went back to sleep but had the sense to cling to the image of la dolce vita.

As I try and fail to cross the street, it occurs to me that even the chaos is ruled by convention. Jumping red lights, ignoring lanes and driving by instinct seems neither daring nor individualistic when everybody is at it.

The need to be the same spreads into the most surprising places. Romans still puzzle over why corruption was able to sweep through an entire generation of politicians. They seek explanation in the evolution of the mafia, the structure of party funding, the greed of individuals.

And yet perhaps the explanation is simple. As Bettino Craxi, the former prime minister who died this week, said in self-defence after he was convicted: "They all took part; they all kept quiet."

Capital Letters is a regular Saturday column rotating between Guardian writers in three of Europe's most lively cities - Rome, Berlin and Moscow.

webTitle: Greeks fight for right to rest in peace

fields.headline: Greeks fight for right to rest in peace
fields.standfirst: Campaigners and clerics clash over ending a ban on cremation, as the cost of a cemetery plot spirals
fields.trailText: Campaigners and clerics clash over ending a ban on cremation, as the cost of a cemetery plot spirals
fields.body:
If there is one thing that many Greeks hope the new millennium will bring them, it is a peaceful afterlife.

But resting in peace is not always easy. Cemetery space is at a premium, yet Greece is the only European Union country where cremations are banned. Campaigners claim the problem is so serious that they plan to go to the European Court of Human Rights if the government does not implement plans to legalise the practice before the end of the month.

"Freedom of religion, as a fundamental human right, extends to funeral rituals whatever they may be," said Alekos Alavanos, an MEP who is planning to raise the subject at the European parliament. "Outlawing cremation is not only antiquated but very costly for both tourists and Greeks."

With nearly half of Greece's population resident in the greater Athens area, land is expensive. A plot for permanent burial is a luxury few Greeks can afford. Owners pay from £11,000 to nearly £73,000 for a family vault in Athens' First Cemetery - the capital's most prestigious burial ground - and almost as much in overcrowded cemeteries elsewhere.

"We've got to the point that there are turf wars between local municipalities over cemeteries," Mr Alavanos said. "Last month there was a televised fight outside the Piraeus graveyard between people wanting to bury their dead and the local government officials who said there were no free plots."

The shortage of space has meant that most Greeks rent burial sites for their loved ones and wait for an exhumation notice after three years. The graves are then recycled, with marble masonry sometimes re-used in pavements (on one occasion the inscription was still visible). The bones of the dead are removed to an ossuary, an unceremonious vault provided by cemeteries for about £35 a year. But many families are unwilling to fund this service and simply stop paying rent, forcing local authorities to transfer abandoned remains to pits.

"I'll never forget how I had to carry my mother's bones by plane for reburial on Chios, the family island," recalls a retired Greek academic now living in the United States.

"Passing the remains through the x-ray machines caused quite a stir. I had to tell them it was my mother."

The undignified process of disinterment - sometimes long before bodies have totally decomposed - often sees Greeks become "migrants in death" with relatives preferring to transport the deceased to other, more cremation-friendly Orthodox countries.

Since the collapse of com munism, Bulgaria and Romania, where cremation was legalised under the old regimes, have become particular favourites. Although the practice is officially outlawed by all the Eastern churches, clerics often disregard the ban to conduct funeral rites over ashes for a fee.

"It's an unbelievable situation, bodies leaving this country and coming back as ashes," said Christel Schneider, a German who has lived in Greece for 30 years. "As for non-Orthodox foreigners, there are so many of us who live here, work here, are taxed here and will probably die here. We should have the right to choose what happens to us when we die."

It is claimed that the Athenians were the first people to cremate their dead - long before the birth of Christ.

But the Greek Orthodox church - already annoyed by the state's blessing of civil marriage and abortion - argues that there are religious reasons for maintaining the ban.

Cremation, it argues, contradicts the idea of resurrection as laid out in ancient Judaic tradition. "The body is the dwelling place of the Holy spirit, a temple for the divine," says Yiannis Hadjifotis, editor of the ecclesiastical Orthodox News. "By burning the body we could inadvertently destroy the bones of a saint which we always venerate in Greece. The Bible stated it very clearly: 'From dust thou art, and unto dust thou shalt return'."

The church, Greece's biggest landowner, has already used its considerable influence to stop the government moving ahead with plans to legalise cremation. Faced with an ageing population and an influx of more than 800,000 non-Orthodox residents, the ruling Socialists announced last March that they would soon be legalising the burning of the dead for foreigners. Some local councils have even set aside space for crematoria.

But pro-cremation campaigners say the battle is far from over.

"The church fears that cremating foreigners will be a first step towards cremating the Orthodox," said Alekos Alavanos.

"A lot of Greeks might not choose cremation but the church is clearly going to fight this. We're hoping that the European Union can somehow pressure the government to change its stance."

webTitle: Banks fail to give credit to fake smart card 'genius'

fields.headline: Banks fail to give credit to fake smart card 'genius'
fields.trailText: Serge Humpich believed he held a secret that could do more damage to the banking system than a dozen Nick Leesons. A self-styled electronic genius, Mr Humpich claimed to have perfected a false credit card that could talk any cash terminal into handing him an unlimited supply of money.
fields.body:
Serge Humpich believed he held a secret that could do more damage to the banking system than a dozen Nick Leesons. A self-styled electronic genius, Mr Humpich claimed to have perfected a false credit card that could talk any cash terminal into handing him an unlimited supply of money.

His mistake was to offer his invention to France's top banks for £20m. Instead of making a fortune he found himself in court yesterday faced with a possible seven years in prison and a fine of £500,000.

Mr Humpich, 36, claimed that the coded numerical system that can pick out all 35m French PINs on Visa and other plastic cards could be cracked by using a home-made smart card that could lie its way through the most complicated numerical traps.

"I didn't discover a crack in the system," he said before appearing in a Paris court. "I showed the card company managers that the entire system from A to Z was unsafe. The group which controls the use of credit cards did not believe me so I showed them how I could fool any terminal by cracking the basic mathematical formula based on 96 numbers."

Mr Humpich, who has been sacked as a computer expert since his arrest, said he had no intention of stealing. He told banks that if he could crack the system anyone else could do the same and he was ready to help them close the security gap.

"I could have put a page on the internet which would have enabled other computer programmers to make their own cards from blanks fitted with a microchip," he said. "They could have made purchases in any store and emptied cash dispensers. They would not even have needed to know PINs."

All French credit cards are equipped with microchips so that payments can be made through a special terminal, resembling a mobile telephone, found in most shops and restaurants. Users tap in their own code and the amounts are immediately deducted without the need to sign an authorisation form. This has made it easy to use stolen credit cards, as long as the PIN is known, without producing identification.

Mr Humpich decided that the quickest way to cash in on his discovery was to send a lawyer to the bank card control group to negotiate a cash payment. To prove that his system worked he bought 10 Metro tickets from an automatic dispenser with a false card without being detected and sent the receipt to the credit card company.

At first the banks played ball and asked him to make copies so that they could test them, but in September, three months after making contact, he was arrested by 10 policemen and held in custody. The charge against him, based on the Metro ticket purchase, accused him of using forged credit cards.

"We consider the whole affair a form of blackmail," a banking spokesman said. "We don't believe he fabricated anything that endangered the security of our microchip cards. For two years he threatened a catastrophe that never came."

But his lawyer, Francois de Saint-Cyr, said Mr Humpich had no case to answer.

"He really could fool the whole system and did the honorable thing by offering to provide a defence to the banks," he said.

"The banks took the message and have just overhauled the entire network without his help and introduced new cards which they say are foolproof."

fields.headline: 14 jailed for Vietnam baby trade
fields.trailText: A court in southern Vietnam has sentenced 14 people to prison terms ranging from 13 months to 20 years for involvement in the country's biggest illegal adoption ring
fields.body:
A court in southern Vietnam has sentenced 14 people to prison terms ranging from 13 months to 20 years for involvement in the country's biggest illegal adoption ring, the state-owned news agency reported yesterday.

Bui Van Khanh, a former official in the justice department in An Giang province, and Nguyen Kim Thanh, a local obstetrician, received the longest sentences of 20 years, the official agency said.

They and the other defendants had been charged with assisting the illegal adoption of nearly 200 children to foreigners via an orphanage run by the An Giang Red Cross branch from 1995-97.

Khanh had accepted a total of £8,500 in bribes to legalise adoptions, while nurses received up to £9 for every child they "successfully collected", the news agency said.

In some cases, nurses would persuade pregnant women who were either unmarried, ill or getting divorced to give up their babies by saying the children would be brought up by relatives of medical workers.

The case was postponed in May last year because of a lack of evidence.

Adoptions of Vietnamese babies by foreigners have soared in recent years, with some couples trying to avoid red tape by using unauthorised agents, according to diplomats.

Since the An Giang case was exposed, other adoption rings selling babies to foreigners have also been smashed.

Western couples and their newly adopted babies are a common sight in Vietnam's foreign medical clinics, where doctors examine the health of the infants before the adoption process is complete.

It is unclear how much couples are expected to pay to adopt a Vietnamese baby.

webTitle: Indians storm Ecuador's congress building in Ecuador's capital

fields.headline: Indians storm Ecuador's congress building in Ecuador's capital
fields.standfirst: President accuses army of coup and dismisses calls to step down
fields.trailText: President Jamil Mahuad of Ecuador accused the country's military of trying to stage a coup when the armed forces chief asked him to resign yesterday after thousands of Indian protesters backed by an army unit stormed congress.
fields.body:
President Jamil Mahuad of Ecuador accused the country's military of trying to stage a coup when the armed forces chief asked him to resign yesterday after thousands of Indian protesters backed by an army unit stormed congress.

"If this is a military coup which wants to take power by force, gentlemen, take power by force," Mr Mahuad said during a nationally televised speech in which he refused to step down. "I will fulfil my duties until the last moment."

"In their ambition and lack of respect for democracy in Ecuador, the armed forces are trying to mount a coup d'état ," Mahuad said. "I call on the people to oppose this coup."

Moments earlier, the country's armed forces chief, General Carlos Mendoza, said he had asked Mr Mahuad to resign in order to avoid a "social uprising" after an army unit of about 50 men helped thousands of highland Indians protesting against Mr Mahuad's economic policies to take control of congress. The rebel army unit then said it had the support of some 500 Ecuadorean military officers.

A harried Mr Mahuad left the government palace in an ambulance guarded by four security vehicles, according to the building's chief of security.

The US strongly condemned what one official called a "proto-coup" and warned of "disastrous consequences" for Ecuador.

"Any regime that emerges from such an unconstitutional process will face political and economic isolation, bringing even greater misery upon the Ecuadorean people," said the White House national security council spokesman, Mike Hammer.

Brazil's foreign ministry also issued a statement condemning efforts to "subvert the rule of law".

In Quito, the Indians and their army allies told cheering crowds in congress that they had declared a "government of national salvation". They threatened to replace Mr Mahuad, congress and the supreme court, alleging that the bodies were corrupt and unable to solve Ecuador's worst economic crisis in decades.

The Indian leader Antonio Vargas and Colonel Lucio Gutierrez led the occupation of the parliament building and then got the support of the head of the army's war school, Fausto Cobo. "We're here to end the looting [by the government] and to support a just cause by our indigenous comrades," said Mr Cobo.

However, Mr Mahuad's government did later try to reassert its authority. The interior minister, Vladimiro Alvarez, said Mr Mahuad believed his resignation was "not the solution our country is waiting for".

"It would be worse to abandon our functions during a crisis like the one our country is living through," he said.

Thousands of highland Indians claiming to represent almost half of the country's 12.4m people have marched into Quito in recent days, after staging roadblocks since Saturday. The government estimates that 5,000 to 6,000 Indians have arrived in Quito, while Indian leaders say they have up to 30,000 supporters in the capital.

Gen Mendoza demanded earlier yesterday that Mr Mahuad take "constitutional" measures to restore order. But he did not specify what those measures should be and he fell short of clearly stating that the military supported the president. "The armed forces fully support the constitutional order," Mr Mendoza said in a vaguely worded statement.

A presidential spokesman, Carlos Larreategui, called the recalcitrant military unit "marginal" and "subversive" and said the government would take severe actions against the rebellious unit.
fields.bodyText: President Jamil Mahuad of Ecuador accused the country's military of trying to stage a coup when the armed forces chief asked him to resign yesterday after thousands of Indian protesters backed by an army unit stormed congress. "If this is a military coup which wants to take power by force, gentlemen, take power by force," Mr Mahuad said during a nationally televised speech in which he refused to step down. "I will fulfil my duties until the last moment." "In their ambition and lack of respect for democracy in Ecuador, the armed forces are trying to mount a coup d'état ," Mahuad said. "I call on the people to oppose this coup." Moments earlier, the country's armed forces chief, General Carlos Mendoza, said he had asked Mr Mahuad to resign in order to avoid a "social uprising" after an army unit of about 50 men helped thousands of highland Indians protesting against Mr Mahuad's economic policies to take control of congress. The rebel army unit then said it had the support of some 500 Ecuadorean military officers. A harried Mr Mahuad left the government palace in an ambulance guarded by four security vehicles, according to the building's chief of security. The US strongly condemned what one official called a "proto-coup" and warned of "disastrous consequences" for Ecuador. "Any regime that emerges from such an unconstitutional process will face political and economic isolation, bringing even greater misery upon the Ecuadorean people," said the White House national security council spokesman, Mike Hammer. Brazil's foreign ministry also issued a statement condemning efforts to "subvert the rule of law". In Quito, the Indians and their army allies told cheering crowds in congress that they had declared a "government of national salvation". They threatened to replace Mr Mahuad, congress and the supreme court, alleging that the bodies were corrupt and unable to solve Ecuador's worst economic crisis in decades. The Indian leader Antonio Vargas and Colonel Lucio Gutierrez led the occupation of the parliament building and then got the support of the head of the army's war school, Fausto Cobo. "We're here to end the looting [by the government] and to support a just cause by our indigenous comrades," said Mr Cobo. However, Mr Mahuad's government did later try to reassert its authority. The interior minister, Vladimiro Alvarez, said Mr Mahuad believed his resignation was "not the solution our country is waiting for". "It would be worse to abandon our functions during a crisis like the one our country is living through," he said. Thousands of highland Indians claiming to represent almost half of the country's 12.4m people have marched into Quito in recent days, after staging roadblocks since Saturday. The government estimates that 5,000 to 6,000 Indians have arrived in Quito, while Indian leaders say they have up to 30,000 supporters in the capital. Gen Mendoza demanded earlier yesterday that Mr Mahuad take "constitutional" measures to restore order. But he did not specify what those measures should be and he fell short of clearly stating that the military supported the president. "The armed forces fully support the constitutional order," Mr Mendoza said in a vaguely worded statement. A presidential spokesman, Carlos Larreategui, called the recalcitrant military unit "marginal" and "subversive" and said the government would take severe actions against the rebellious unit.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Yorkshire
fields.trailText: It is good to see that they are chopping down trees on the Yorkshire Wildlife Trust's Askham Bog nature reserve. The normal conservationist reaction to tree felling is one of horror, but there is now a greater understanding that felling can be good, and that planting may be bad.
fields.body:
It is good to see that they are chopping down trees on the Yorkshire Wildlife Trust's Askham Bog nature reserve. The normal conservationist reaction to tree felling is one of horror, but there is now a greater understanding that felling can be good, and that planting may be bad.

At Askham there is one of the finest wetlands in the country, a mixture of woodland carr and open fen. Water violet, marsh orchids and bog myrtle grow there. In the ditches and dykes, dragonflies and water beetles abound.

However, over the years willow and alder have spread across the open areas, shading out sedges and flowering plants, smothering water courses with their fallen leaves, even drying up some of the boggy bits with their thirst for moisture. So, the trust is chopping down trees and, at the moment, it looks more like a battlefield in places than a nature reserve.

Cloying mud hangs onto your feet, the bright orange wounds of sawn alder stumps stand stark against the black ground. Everyone is looking forward to spring, when a carpet of wild flowers will cover the scars, the streams will glitter brightly in the sunlight and the whole purpose of the work will be evident. Only a few small areas of trees are being felled. The ancient woodland carr alongside the bog remains intact.

Being a bog, real horsepower has been used to remove the felled timber. It has been fashionable in recent years to do this, more often for aesthetic than practical reasons, but at Askham it is purely practical. The ground is so wet that a machine large enough to cope would damage the habitat. That is assuming such a machine exists. The horse picked its way over the drier ground, threaded through the woodland carr, delivering the logs to a point on the perimeter from where they could be carted by road.

The impact on the haul route has been minimal. In fact, you would only know that timber had been dragged out that way if you had actually seen it happening.

fields.headline: Dilemma for Microsoft's chief architect
fields.standfirst:
Gates fights it out with Torvalds
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Why did Bill Gates move job? The answer may have appeared this week in the guise of Transmeta's Crusoe chip. Billed as Silicon Valley's new, new thing, it hit Wall Street this week in a big big way. Cheaper, faster, more powerful than anything residing on your desk, Transmeta's offering knocked the stuffing out of microprocessor-makers Intel and ARM.
fields.body:
Why did Bill Gates move job? The answer may have appeared this week in the guise of Transmeta's Crusoe chip. Billed as Silicon Valley's new, new thing, it hit Wall Street this week in a big big way. Cheaper, faster, more powerful than anything residing on your desk, Transmeta's offering knocked the stuffing out of microprocessor-makers Intel and ARM.

But it may be the sucker punch to the plans of Microsoft's newly installed chief software architect to dominate the globe. For behind the new chip is the 29-year-old Finnish programmer Linus Torvalds, who, along with hundreds of other rocket scientists, cobbled together Linux, the world's fastest-growing operating system.

Operating systems - such as Windows, the MacOS on Apple computers and Linux - provide the set of instructions that allow computers to process information. And at the moment, it is Linux that is the code of choice. Nasa swears by it. Hollywood's Titanic would not have been made without it.

The word is that Linux is more reliable than Microsoft's Windows NT and cheaper than another rival, Unix.

But most important, Microsoft's dominance - its Windows software is used on 85% of the world's computers - is predicated on the people using Intel-style chips. Under the current rules of the game, software designed for one processor will not run on another. For example, a word processor designed for a Macintosh computer will not run on an Intel-based PC. That may be history. Thanks to Torvalds' wizardry, Crusoe will transmute the instructions of other processors into a set the Transmeta chips can understand.

The new alchemy is called "code morphing" and it threatens Microsoft's doctrine - and, like the US administration's anti-monopolies case, the Seattle company's cash flow.

Torvalds, although he denies it, is making a habit of challenging Gates. Whereas Bill Gates has become the richest man in history by controlling the operating system in the home of nearly every computer user on the planet, Torvalds gave his out - over the net - for free.

But what is surprising is not what divides them but how much unites them. Both were brattishly clever. Both have come to dominate computer systems around the world. Both have brown hair and wear glasses.

The real question is who will get Gates first: the government or the geek.

Penny wise...

Forget Mike Tyson against Julius Francis. The real bruisers are to be found elsewhere, slugging it out over British membership of the single currency. The latest round will get under way on Monday when global management consultancy AT Kearney unveils its latest foreign direct investment confidence index.

The UK had a high ranking in the last of the six-monthly surveys of 155 of the world's biggest firms - it came fourth - and is tipped to have done better this time.

This will be seized on immediately by euro-sceptics as evidence that Britain is not being damaged by being out of the single currency zone. Certainly the survey looks likely to present a sharply contrasting view from that expressed somewhat tentatively recently by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, and more directly by Toyota's honorary chairman, Shoichiro Toyoda.

There is no doubt which corner the crowd is cheering for - euroscepticism is on the rise according to the latest opinion polls. There is, however, a danger that the arguments in favour of signing up to the single currency are being subsumed into a related but different argument over the level of the exchange rate.

The pound is now at a 14-year high on a trade weighted basis and at a staggering DM3.20. Even Switzerland is starting to look cheap - OK, cheaper.

True enough, manufacturing exporters are showing signs of being able to cope - though they can hardly welcome the prospect of further sterling appreciation now being touted in some City circles.

Britain's farmers, who have had the double whammy of a rising pound and a fall in agricultural prices, face a further extension of the sector's five-year long recession.

But though there will be many in the pro-euro camp who see membership as a solution to the squeeze exerted by the pound's current exchange rate, that is scarcely a sufficient reason in itself for British membership, nor a guaranteed solution for the immediate problem.

Some investors may be deterred from investing in Britain because of a perky pound but if the euro's supporters are to mount an effective case they need to broaden the argument.

fields.headline: Durlacher leads Zetters bid
fields.standfirst: Bookmaker destined for net in £3.6m sale
fields.trailText: The Zetters pools business is to be reinvented as an internet betting and gambling business after the founding family yesterday accepted £3.6m to cut its ties with the firm.
fields.body:
The Zetters pools business is to be reinvented as an internet betting and gambling business after the founding family yesterday accepted £3.6m to cut its ties with the firm.

A consortium of investors including three businessmen with spread betting and conventional gambling backgrounds yesterday agreed a 135p a share deal to buy the 38% of the company still owned by the Zetters, valuing the business at £9.6m.

But as details of the deal emerged, investors keen to back internet firms piled in and the shares shot up to 320p, valuing it at £22.8m.

Last summer Zetters sold its bingo hall interests to rival Riva, and shrank back to a pure pools business.

At the time Paul Zetter, the 74-year-old chairman who inherited the business from his father and has been on the board for more than 40 years, conceded that the company was fighting a losing battle against larger competitiors and the National Lottery, and announced that it was open to takeover bids.

Yesterday's successful bid was led by investment bank Durlacher, which specialises in advising internet businesses and took 21% of the 2.7m Zetter family shares for £775,440. By the time the stock market closed last night its stake was worth £1.84m.

Anthony Wollenberg, a senior partner at City solictor Rakisons and a former chairman of spread betting group City Index, has bought 14% of the family shares, along with Jonathan Sparke, founding managing director of City Index.

Mr Sparke later joined independent bookie Victor Chandler, where he worked alongside Ben Shaw, a third member of the consortium. Mr Shaw also founded and is a director of NetComs, a specialist e-commerce consultancy.

The consortium also includes UAT Dealing, an offshoot of Undervalued Assets Trust - a listed investment trust - and investment funds advised by venture capital group Apax.

The traditional Zetters pools business will continue to operate, and Paul Zetter has been installed as life president of the business.

The pools business made a profit of £1.54m last year on a turnover of £15.5m. Zetters' net assets are some £6.2m.

Under the rules of the takeover code the consortium's offer must be extended to all shareholders, but with the share price so far in excess of the price at which the deal was done, there are unlikely to be any takers.

The betting executives moving into the business aim to build the Zetters name into a leading internet betting brand.

In a statement, it said: "The consortium proposes to build upon the brand name of Zetters and, through acquisition, organic growth and the establishment of strategic alliances, to develop an interna tional online betting and gaming business."

Web betting is regarded as potentially one of the most lucrative e-commerce businesses - and spread betting as a particularly profitable segment of the market.

Sports Internet, run by entrepreneurs Chris Akers and Peter Wilkinson, recently bought a bookmaking group with the aim of attracting online punters, and even Ladbrokes has set up an online operation in Gibraltar.
