fields.headline: BP deadline forces Arco talks
fields.trailText: BP Amoco's decision to set a final deadline on its $26.8bn (£16bn) takeover of Atlantic Richfield, the US oil company, has prompted further discussions with regulators after talks between the two sides appeared to have reached a stalemate.
fields.body:
BP Amoco's decision to set a final deadline on its $26.8bn (£16bn) takeover of Atlantic Richfield, the US oil company, has prompted further discussions with regulators after talks between the two sides appeared to have reached a stalemate.

Shares in BP rose in London yesterday as investors welcomed signs that an anti-trust lawsuit could be avoided.

Some analysts voiced concerns at the lack of common ground between BP and the federal trade commission on what concessions the oil company should offer to win approval for the takeover. Some suggested that the latest discussions could be a ploy by FTC chairman, Robert Pitofsky, to win support for an injunction against BP from other members of the commission.

A spokesman for BP Amoco confirmed yesterday that the FTC had "made an approach and indicated some areas that they want to examine in more detail". The discussions are to include whether litigation can be avoided by February 3, the deadline imposed by BP under a 20-day takeover timetable.

The FTC, which refused to comment on the discussions yesterday, is concerned that the merger would reduce competition in the politically sensitive west coast oil market. The deal would give BP Amoco control of more than 70% of Alaskan oil production, which supplies most of the oil for refineries on the west coast.

The FTC has already rejected BP's offer to contract out or divest a total of 385,000 barrels of oil a day from these oil fields. But BP is understood to be committed to keeping the remaining production to supply Arco's two west coast refineries. Its Alaskan operations were set to provide $200m of the $1bn cost savings expected from the deal.

If no agreement is reached, the FTC is expected to seek an injunction to delay the takeover. The resulting court battle will be the biggest US anti-trust case involving the oil industry since the early 1980s.

webTitle: Delays may drive post off the rails

fields.headline: Delays may drive post off the rails
fields.trailText: The Post Office yesterday threatened to shift some of its mail back to road transport because of persistent failure by rail freight company, English, Welsh and Scottish Railway to meet performance targets.
fields.body:
The Post Office yesterday threatened to shift some of its mail back to road transport because of persistent failure by rail freight company, English, Welsh and Scottish Railway to meet performance targets.

The PO said that Royal Mail customers needed the same level of service every week, not three weeks in four.

The PO's £50m contract with EWS runs until 2006, but Neil Brewer, the Royal Mail's head of network design, said that it could not wait that long. He said that the next month could be crucial because EWS is beginning to take delivery of new rolling stock capable of achieving speeds of up to 125mph.

Mr Brewer said: "If trains cannot run at speed, there is little point in investing in faster services."

The loss of the PO's business would be a considerable setback for EWS. It is one of the company's biggest customers. The PO has a long history of involvement with the railways. It runs 55 trains a day as well as 37 aircraft and 7,500 long-distance lorries to move 76m letters from 210,000 collection points.

Mr Brewer said that it would be reluctant to move mail on to the roads, but it had to be realistic. There was no doubt that rail was the best way to transport first class mail between 100 and 300 miles, or second class for all distances over 150 miles.

He added that customers expected more and more from the Royal Mail, including later collections and earlier deliveries. "If we don't meet their expectations, they will go elsewhere."

Mr Brewer said that rail could have a bigger slice of the cake in future, winning business from air because of restrictions on night flying.

He did not believe that the present shape of the road haulage industry was sustainable. Road pricing was inevitable and the motorway system was building "towards even more serious congestion".

The PO has already abandoned using rail at weekends, because the service provided by Railtrack was so poor, and has fallen back on a road and air network. This means that the PO's £200m train fleet is standing idle.

Mr Brewer said: "It's up to the rail industry to organise itself. Sadly our perception is that the rail industry is still inward looking rather than driven by the customer."

EWS last night said it was trying to improve performance targets for mail deliveries and that the arrival of new speedier engines would help. But it disagreed with the PO's assessment of its record: "We are not offering excuses, but most of the trains we run for the PO arrive on time."

This means that the PO's £200m train fleet is standing idle. Mr Brewer said: "It's up to the rail industry to organise itself. Sadly our perception is that the rail industry is still inward looking rather than driven by the customer." EWS last night said it was trying to improve performance targets for mail deliveries and that the arrival of new speedier engines would help. But it disagreed with the PO's assessment of its record: "We are not offering excuses, but most of the trains we run for the PO arrive on time."

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: • What a week it has been for Britain's fraudbusters. Round at Port-au-Prince (alias Elm Street), Mama Doc unleashed the serious fraud office on ailing trade finance group Versailles, while it was quite like old times at the DTI, with a QC and an FCA (the DTI's idea of a couple of ordinary chaps) parachuting into the wreckage of TransTec, the Geoffrey Robinson-founded engineering group. Down at Canary Wharf, one might have thought that Howard Davies and his crack sleuths at the financial services authority (FSA) would be browned off by their non-invitation to the party. Not at all. Discussing yesterday regulatory approaches for the new century (or something like that), Mr Davies disclosed that the FSA is busy recruiting. Competition specialists are being hired, it seems, along with experts in consumer affairs. Then there's a corps of league-table compilers to be assembled.  What a week it has been for Britain's fraudbusters. Round at Port-au-Prince (alias Elm Street), Mama Doc unleashed the serious fraud office on ailing trade finance group Versailles, while it was quite like old times at the DTI, with a QC and an FCA (the DTI's idea of a couple of ordinary chaps) parachuting into the wreckage of TransTec, the Geoffrey Robinson-founded engineering group. Down at Canary Wharf, one might have thought that Howard Davies and his crack sleuths at the financial services authority (FSA) would be browned off by their non-invitation to the party. Not at all. Discussing yesterday regulatory approaches for the new century (or something like that), Mr Davies disclosed that the FSA is busy recruiting. Competition specialists are being hired, it seems, along with experts in consumer affairs. Then there's a corps of league-table compilers to be assembled. And, finally, a group of boffins skilled in cost-benefit analysis, doubtless to discover whether or not the new staff (including themselves) are worth employing.

 Back at Versailles, and founder Carl Cushnie was very cross on December 20 with "wholly inaccurate" press coverage of his company's woes. Doubtless all the negative publicity was very distressing in the comparison to the sort of treatment he is used to from the media. In June 1999 (as Versailles' problems were starting to mount) Mr Cushnie - billed as Europe's wealthiest black man - spoke to Pride, a magazine aimed at high-flying black Britons, in an exclusive interview. Despite running to three pages, no hint emerged of the DTI's interest in the group, but then Mr Cushnie had taken one elementary precaution - through his family interests, he is the publisher of Pride. After a series of hard-hitting questions - "What kinds of music do you like listening to?", "Are you an over-indulgent father?" (respectively Beethoven's 7th and "No") - Pride did elicit one interesting answer, when Mr Cushnie commented thus on his thrusting young staff: "I understand when they succeed how they feel about it. It's not about money for them, it's a game. And I don't mean game in the trivial sense, there are rules of engagement." Yes, quite.

 His bankers, meanwhile, are totting up the damage from their backing of Mr Cushnie's gamesmanship. Simpletons might wonder why Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclays and NatWest did not make loans direct to the struggling businesses concerned rather than use Versailles as middleman (Royal Bank actually referred clients to the company). Ah-ha, well prudential practice, you see, means that banks lend only to firms with strong balance sheets, ruling out the strugglers and ruling in, er, Versailles. As a result of all this prudence, the banks could be down more than £50m.

 NatWest, famously, has other things on its mind, not least the assault from fellow Versailles bankroller Royal Bank. On another flank, NatWest is under attack from Bank of Scotland which has, we learn, sent a 100-strong undercover squad into NatWest branches to open accounts. Rule one for all staff engaged in these gumshoe activities is first to remove the BoS corporate tie, which is regulation issue. Alert NatWest clerks ought presumably to refer new customers with Scottish accents and open-necked shirts to the nearest security guard.

 Pricewaterhouse Coopers, the accountancy giant, ended the week level after a couple of nailbiting spins of the wheel. Monday they were the dunces who, as auditors of TransTec, had failed to spot that £12m claim from car group Ford. By Friday, they were the Holmesian geniuses who, acting on behalf of the abovementioned banks, had swiftly located multi-million pound gaps in the books of Versailles, thus bringing in both the tontons macoutes and the receivers. Others were less lucky. Buchanan, the City PR firm that defended Versailles so valiantly, is likely to stand at the end of a long queue of creditors. We cannot help but think that top solicitors Ashurst Morris Crisp - hastily engaged as the sewage hit the ventilation equipment - have been less trusting in securing their remuneration. Final wooden spoon in terms of timing goes to the Runnymede Trust, the race relations think tank. Hitting the streets on Thursday, just as Versailles hit the buffers, was a communique announcing that "ethnic minorities are still seriously under-represented at senior management level". Indeed so.

fields.headline: Dispensed and dispatched
fields.standfirst: Brand values Beecham's
fields.trailText: Thomas Beecham, if he were alive today, would be bemused by the planned £107bn merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham announced on Monday.
fields.body:
Thomas Beecham, if he were alive today, would be bemused by the planned £107bn merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham announced on Monday.

It is unlikely he would be disappointed that the name of his firm will not feature in the name of the new holding company; perhaps he would be surprised it had survived so long.

He started business in 1842, setting up a chemist's shop in Wigan. A few years later he began selling Beecham's Pills, a laxative he had invented. The pills proved wildly successful, probably a reflection of contemporary diet. A comment by a lady customer gave the business its first advertising slogan: "worth a guinea a box".

In 1859 he opened a factory in St Helens. Just 28 years later the factory was replaced by another on the same site - the first in the area to be electrically powered.

By the first world war more than a million pills were being produced a day, and they were only withdrawn from the product line three years ago.

Thomas Beecham died in 1907, and the business was taken over by his son, Joseph. But Joseph and his son were more interested in music than medicine, and bought the freehold of the Royal Opera House as part of the family's efforts to revive British opera.

After Joseph's death in 1916, the business was run by his executors until it was bought in the late 1920s by Philip Hill, a banker, for £1.7m. Mr Hill realised the business could do more than make laxatives, no matter how popular.

In 1932 Mr Hill, as chairman of Covent Garden Properties, threatened to demolish the Royal Opera House as part of a commercial redevelopmentbut was persuaded against it.

Two years after he took control Mr Hill launched Beecham's Powders, a cure-all analgesic which is still being produced today.

The 1930s saw a huge increase in product range, mainly through acquisition. In 1938 Beecham's bought Macleans, the toothpaste and Lucozade business, and Eno Proprietaries, makers of the fruit salts. Within 15 years Lu cozade was accounting for almost half of group profits.

Over the next 20 years Beecham's was to add some of its subsequently best known products to its range. These included Ribena, Brylcreem, Silvikrin shampoo and Horlicks. Brylcreem and Silvikrin were sold in 1993.

An early sign of the group's future direction came in the second world war, with the establishment of Beecham Research Laboratories.

One of the Beecham scien tists' great discoveries was the penicillin nucleus 6APA, in 1959. This opened the way to making semi-synthetic penicillins that could deal with bacteria which had become resistant to organic penicillin.

But development costs were soaring. Beecham, by now a global research-led business, merged with American group SmithKline Beckman to form SmithKline Beecham in 1989, creating a £6.7bn global health care group capable of great economies of scale.

The new group was the largest over-the-counter medicines maker in Europe. Consolidation continued when Wellcome Foundation merged with Glaxo and Zeneca merged with Sweden's Astra.

Glaxo Wellcome's merger with SmithKline Beecham is to be named Glaxo SmithKline. But the name lives on - Thomas Beecham's grandson, Sir Thomas, set up an orchestra in St Helens and went on to become one of Britain's best known conductors.

fields.headline: 14,000 jobs in store for Manchester
fields.trailText: Plans for a new £250m rail distribution park at Carrington, near Manchester, which could create up to 14,000 jobs in the north west, were announced yesterday. Shell, the oil group that owns the site, and property group Burford Holdings said they were planning a development of the 375 acre site, known as the Trafford interchange.
fields.body:
Plans for a new £250m rail distribution park at Carrington, near Manchester, which could create up to 14,000 jobs in the north west, were announced yesterday. Shell, the oil group that owns the site, and property group Burford Holdings said they were planning a development of the 375 acre site, known as the Trafford interchange.

The property is bounded by a Shell chemicals plant on the north and a disused railway line to the south. Burford said that it planned to reinstate the railway line to provide a link with the national rail network.

It said the scheme would help the government with its policy of shifting freight traffic off the roads and on to rail.

The distribution and manufacturing jobs created could have a big impact on reducing Manchester's jobless total, which numbers about 50,000.

Burford says that the site could be developed over several years.

Trafford council leader, David Acton, said: "This means a boom in Trafford and the region."

About 31% of the area's population are long term unemployed and 40% have no access to a car. The plan also ties in with the government's plans to raise the profile of rail and rail freight.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Aga Khan air stake for sale
fields.body:
Aga Khan air stake for sale

The Aga Khan will sell his 79% holding in Meridiana, Italy's leading private airline, to strengthen its competitive position, the group said yesterday.

The airline is second in Italy to Alitalia, with 21 jets serving all main Italian and European airports and 1999 turnover of 630bn lire (£200m).

The company said the Aga Khan had decided to sell as it "has reached such a size as to require a strong strategic alliance to pursue its growth objectives". It said his aim was to "encourage the widest possible interest especially from European airlines".

The remaining 21% of Meridiana is in the hands of staff and the Cariplo Bank foundation.

Go moves with the seasons

British Airways' low-cost airline, Go, yesterday confirmed that it will be increasing flights to Palma, Alicante and Ibiza next summer while cancelling those to ski-ing destinations such as Zurich and Lyon.

The changeover will take place from March 26, although the airline said that ski flights would resume next winter.

Go said the launch of new destinations over the past year meant that it would not be able to operate the same level of summer services on holiday routes without cutting back elsewhere.

Post Office marries funds

The Post Office is to marry two pension funds in the biggest ever occupational plan merger.

The new scheme will embrace 420,000 members and have assets in excess of £16bn.

The 122,391 employees in the now replaced Post Office pension scheme - set up in April 1987 - will now have fixed contributions instead of monthly deductions rising and falling with investment values.

But they will not receive the full inflation linking given to the 263,450 - now mainly retired - members who joined up before 1987.

The new plan has been approved both by unions and trustees.

Monorail for Portsmouth

Britain's first inner city monorail system could be built at Portsmouth. The city council has approved an 11km project to link the city centre with the docks.

It will carry up to 3,500 passengers an hour in each direction at peak times. The system will cost £2.5m per km, funded by private investment, with no cost to local residents.

Blacks Leisure sales up 18%

Blacks Leisure Group said total retail sales for the 19 weeks of the second half to January 8 were 18% ahead of last year, while like-for-like sales increased 3%.

For the key Christmas trading period covering the six weeks to January 8, the sportswear and outdoor clothing retailer reported total retail sales were 22% ahead and like-for-like sales improved 8%.

Artprice wins over the French

The initial public offering of French online auction information company Artprice.com was heavily oversubscribed, co-lead manager KBC Securities said yesterday.

Demand was so strong that only 5% of A orders (covering 100 shares maximum) could be met, while B orders (over 100 shares) could not be met, it said. A orders totalled 9.429m shares and B orders 23.149m shares.

Artprice.com was floated on the Nouveau Marché yesterday and will start trading on Monday.

Its stock was placed at €19.06 (£11.70) per share and the 1.15m shares on offer represent 18.4% of the company capital.

webTitle: A sorry state of terminal decline

fields.headline: A sorry state of terminal decline
fields.trailText: Tumbling with-profits bonus rates spell more problems for endowment mortgage homebuyers. And with the near certainty of further falls in future years, each cut heightens the chance of premium increases if policies are to repay loans.
fields.body:
Tumbling with-profits bonus rates spell more problems for endowment mortgage homebuyers. And with the near certainty of further falls in future years, each cut heightens the chance of premium increases if policies are to repay loans.

And that also means one of the most powerful endowment sales pledges - the promise that with-profits backed homebuyers would get a tax-free lump sum on top of the loan repayment when the policy matured - has receded further into the mists of oblivion.

Most of the with-profits companies that have so far declared 1999 results, have slashed annual, or "reversionary", bonus rates. There are usually two bonus figures, one based on the sum assured and the second a bonus on previous gains. Scottish Provident has cut its figure from 3% to 2.5% on the sum assured and from 4.5% to 3.75% on previously declared bonuses. And Royal London, rated one of the top with-profits firms, has slashed its total annual bonus package by a fifth.

Friends Provident, which backs many Abbey National home loans, and Norwich Union have both declared annual bonus rates at lower levels than previous years.The exception is Guardian, sold by Nationwide, which stabilised its bonus after years of poor performance.

Annual bonuses are vital because they set the base for future years, and once granted cannot be taken away. But they are only half the total payout story. Terminal bonuses, which reflect gains over the policy's life, are also down despite a strong stock market end of year, leaving total maturity cheques up to 10% lower.

Norwich Union's total for a £50 a month 25-year policy - the most common endowment backing a home loan - is £89,518 this year compared with £98,037 in 1999. And a similar plan with Friends Provident offers £102,341 - a year ago it would have netted £106,434. Norwich Union's lower rates reflect an investment policy based on a greater percentage of bonds - which have performed poorly - compared with offices with higher equity exposure.

Despite the falls, maturing policies have still performed well thanks to tax relief on premiums, which still applies to policies taken out before 1984, big inflation and major equity gains. Some policies maturing this year will pay off loans and leave sums of twice that amount over for policyholders to spend as they wish.

The "tax-free lump sum" promise was used to persuade millions throughout the 70s to the early 90s to go for an endowment mortgage even though premiums were often more expensive than conventional repayment loans. It helped to overcome consumer resistance to the endowment's inflexibility and low surrender values.

David Carrington, of traded endowment dealer PolicyPlus, believes the tax free bonus has fallen off the agenda. He says: "They made a lot of the lump sum in the sales patter. And 25-year policies paid out this year in respect of mortgages taken out in 1975 will generally produce a substantial extra sum. But that will become more difficult in future as the good years in the late 70s and early 80s disappear from the calculation. The concept has been conveniently ditched - perhaps the life companies hope that policy purchasers will forget all about it."

Even the life companies accept that bonus rates will continue to slip, although you may have to penetrate actuarial doublespeak. Richard Harvey, chief executive at Norwich Union, talks of "managing annual bonuses at a realistic level" while David Woods, Scottish Provident's managing director, says there will be "lower future absolute returns for equity investments"

At Scottish Life, where the bonus on the basic policy has stayed unchanged but where the bonus on declared bonuses has slumped from 4% to 3%, chief executive Brian Duffin predicts "interest rates and stock market returns lower than in the past".

Future figures may still look good compared with inflation, although that will not comfort mortgage endowment customers who need a set sum rather than the inflation plus a percentage that the insurers boast about. But endowment policyholders are unlikely to see any clue in annual policy statements as to whether they are on track to pay off their home loan.

Brian Foster, of Shrewsbury based IFA Kingswood, an expert in with-profits policies, says: "The simple fact that most life office annual bonus notices do not even mention the word mortgage, let alone relate the performance of the policy to the home loan should cause each and every policyholder great concern, especially as there is very little sign of a reverse in the trend of falling returns."

Kingswood is offering a "PolicyMinder Analysis" which analyses where the policy is at the moment and what the options are. It costs £26.95: details on www.policyminder.co.uk or phone 08707-89-89-89.

But that will become more difficult in future as the good years in the late 70s and early 80s disappear from the calculation. The concept has been conveniently ditched - perhaps the life companies hope that policy purchasers will forget all about it." Brian Foster, of Shrewsbury based IFA Kingswood, an expert in with-profits policies, says: "The simple fact that most life office annual bonus notices do not even mention the word mortgage, let alone relate the performance of the policy to the home loan should cause each and every policyholder great concern, especially as there is very little sign of a reverse in the trend of falling returns." webTitle: Emotional Reeve has his 'ultimate goal' in sight

fields.headline: Emotional Reeve has his 'ultimate goal' in sight
fields.standfirst: Paralysed actor tours Body Zone and talks of regaining use of legs
fields.trailText: Christopher Reeve, the Superman actor who was paralysed in a riding accident five years ago, made an emotional visit to the Body Zone of the Millennium Dome in Greenwich yesterday and declared he would walk again in five years.
fields.body:
Christopher Reeve, the Superman actor who was paralysed in a riding accident five years ago, made an emotional visit to the Body Zone of the Millennium Dome in Greenwich yesterday and declared he would walk again in five years.

In a dramatic display of determination and optimism on his first trip abroad since he was confined to a wheelchair, Reeve, 47, said he was 'strong and healthy'.

He could breath for the first time without a tube attached to his throat and was 'building up strength very quickly'.

He predicted he would stand again on his ­fiftieth birthday. 'I hope that on my birthday in 2002 I will be able to stand up and publicly thank everybody who has helped my recovery.'

Reeve chose Britain to make his dramatic declaration because, he said, British people had been so supportive and sympathetic. He 'fell in love with London' when he was making the first Superman film in the city in 1977 and spent the next 10 years in the capital.

His eldest children, Alexandra, 17, and Matthew, 20, live in London with their English mother. 'I am very grateful for the support and interest that people have taken in my situation. When the chips were down British people were really there for me. Britain now really feels like my second home,' Reeve said.

The latest medical breakthroughs in treating paralysis were 'very encouraging', but it would be at least five years before he could walk again, he said. 'In five years I will be well on the road to recovery. There will be a long period of rehabilitation to learn co-ordination - simple body movements.

'It won't be like lighting up a Christmas tree. It will be incremental - arms first, then legs. All along the way each improvement will be like a wonderful present. The ultimate goal of walking is not only possible, it's probable. It will happen.'

Touring the Dome with his American wife, Dana, 39, their son, William, seven, and Alexandra, he asked to see the Body Zone. Wearing a black suit and sitting in a motorised wheelchair, he looked remarkably animated as he nodded, grinned and chatted to the stars of the Millennium show.

Asked about his condition he said he was thrilled that human trials in spinal chord repair could begin as early as 18 months' time. 'Five years ago that would have been unthinkable. People ask me when I would get a trial - it will be other people first. I have a very high-level injury. If anything were to go wrong, it would set back progress 10 years.

'They will start trials with people with lower level injuries. Then over the next five years scientists will move on to tackle paralysis. I will come in the third phase.'

Reeve revealed that two doctors in Florida had taught him to breathe without a ventilator. 'Losing the hose for good,' he joked, was his first goal. 'You know, the doctors said to me I would never breathe again. I love it when doctors say that. My competitive spirit kicks in. I don't take no for an answer.'

In an emotional appeal, he urged everyone struggling to overcome any physical disability never to give up hope. He said he was glad to be a role model. 'I have willpower - the discipline to stay in shape. I am in a position to help others.

'I am the figurehead of a club I would not have wanted to join, but if I serve as a role model that's a very worthwhile thing to do.

'I feel I have got to do something to make it easier for people to get up in the morning. I say to people be the best you can be.'

After starring in a remake of Alfred Hitchcock's 1954 classic, Rear Window, Reeve said he would now devote his time to directing. Shooting on his second film in the director's chair, Heartbreaker, a romantic comedy set in New York, begins this spring. He is planning a third film which will go into production this autumn.

Asked what he thought of the beleaguered Millennium Dome, he said it was 'very, very uplifting - fantastic, overwhelming. I was blown away. It's definitely the right way to make an entrance.' His son, William, was 'over the moon about the whole thing. I love to see the joy on children's faces when they see something that is a mixture of fantasy, magic and circus, all under one roof. The scale is bigger than anything I had imagined.'

Organisers of the Greenwich attraction hope Reeve's visit will boost visitor numbers which have been as low as 5,000 a day - only one quarter of the break-even figure.

But as sleet covered the Dome's roof yesterday, obscuring the hoardings promising 'one amazing day', there was no sign of the promised upturn in weekend day trippers.

Managers refused to reveal the number of visitors. 'It is more than 5,000 but less than 50,000,' one said. The true picture will emerge later this month when the full month's attendance figures are published.

Reeve said last night that he was planning to meet 'around 40 of my oldest London friends' today before returning home to America tomorrow.

webTitle: Blair rules out using the law

fields.headline: Blair rules out using the law
fields.trailText: The pressure on Chelsea, Portman and Skipton building societies, which have attempted to block conversion resolutions, grew this week when the prime minister became involved for the first time.
fields.body:
The pressure on Chelsea, Portman and Skipton building societies, which have attempted to block conversion resolutions, grew this week when the prime minister became involved for the first time.

In the Commons on Wednesday, Tony McWalter, Labour MP for Hemel Hempstead, asked Tony Blair whether he shared the backbencher's "distress at the activities of carpetbaggers who deprive building societies of funds they might otherwise have used to provide resources for affordable housing?" A follow up question asked: "Does he agree with the select committee that urged swift legislation on the matter?"

Mr Blair's answer acknowledged the value of maintaining some "variety and choice" in the savings and loan market provided by mutual societies but suggested no further legislation would be required. "Only a society's board can propose conversion, which requires the support of 75% of saving members on a 50% turnout and 50% of borrowers who vote. Those are high thresholds, which have been reinforced by our action, but it is right that they are high. The current balance is correct," he said.

The prime minister's comments were quickly picked up by members of the Carpetbagger.com website, which is behind resolutions to secure conversion votes at the three societies, and interpreted as a vindication of their position.

The carpetbaggers also seem to have gained some sympathy from Dr Vincent Cable, Liberal Democrat MP for Twickenham and Sir Teddy Taylor, Conservative MP for Rochford and Southend East. Both were members of the Treasury select committee on mutuality which recommended increasing the voting thresholds for conversion votes. They have also publicly stated support for mutuality on the grounds of its democratic benefits.

But the action taken by the three societies under scrutiny has made them distinctly uncomfortable. Portman has expelled 500 members who supported the resolutions, while Chelsea and Skipton claim the resolutions do not aim at conversion - so rendering the vote meaningless.

Dr Cable says he has been "bombarded" with e-mails from people he suspects are members of the Carpetbagger.com organisation. While he does not appreciate their aggressive approach he says: "To a degree they've got a point. These are supposed to be democratic institutions and they are finding a way to avoid answering their members' questions."

Sir Teddy Taylor has a mortgage with Skipton and was visited by society representatives after he expressed doubts about their tactics. "It seems directors regard themselves as monopoly managers who are not answerable to anyone," he says.

webTitle: Policies that are failing to protect the planet

fields.headline: Policies that are failing to protect the planet
fields.standfirst: Friends of the Earth have rapped UK insurers' reluctance to take an ethical stance, say Tony Levene and Jill Papworth
fields.trailText: Friends of the Earth have rapped UK insurers' reluctance to take an ethical stance.
fields.body:
UK insurance companies have come under pressure to sharpen up ethical investment policies following a report from green campaign group Friends of the Earth (FoE) this week.

Capital Punishment: The Insurance Industry and the Global Environment, names and shames top life companies which invest in businesses which FoE says harm the environment.

FoE also claim that short-term investment policies could be storing up long-term problems, with insurance companies in the front line of the predicted storm with climate change and resulting claims for damage and death set to batter their reserves.

FoE policy director Tony Juniper says: "We found that most major insurers are investing in the very firms that we and others have been campaigning against because of their particularly bad environmental performance."

Many of the 14 life firms listed as holders of shares in companies harming the planet also offer ethical funds to private investors. But none has a record that satisfies FoE. And three - Equitable Life, Clerical Medical and Scottish Widows - refused to answer any questions on sustainable development or on whether the insurer carries out screening of companies in mainstream funds.

They were even silent on whether they had an ethical fund available to the public. Scottish Widows says it could find no record of any questionnaire, but FoE says all the no-shows were reminded.

But leaving aside the no-shows, there was a wide spread of answers from the life insurers. FoE has ranked Scottish Equitable and Allied Dunbar as having the most environment-friendly policies while Axa Sun Life and Norwich Union - both have ethical funds - are at the bottom of the table.

The lobbying group also checked recent unit trust statements to see if they invested in 14 multinational companies including ICI, Monsanto, Exxon, Rio Tinto and Zeneca. Collectively it accuses these firms of harming the environment, abusing human rights, or reducing bio-diversity.

Legal & General is good on most counts although it is an investor in 11 out of the 14 "no-no" stocks. It says many of these shares are held in passive index tracking funds so it cannot avoid them.

The report concludes that most major UK insurers operate,"very poor and inadequate environmental investment policies". The good news for ethical investors is that this report adds to the increasing pressure on fund managers and pension trustees to clean up their acts and adopt ethical investment strategies.

But the biggest boost to the SRI (socially responsible investment) movement over the next few years will be the introduction of the government's new pension legislation in July when pension fund trustees will have to state whether they have any ethical investment policy and, if so, what it is.

Company pension scheme members will be told for the first time what ethical and environmental principles are taken into account when money is invested on their behalf in their pension.

And they'll be able to ask questions of pension trustees about ethical issues which could have a financial impact on their pension fund's future performance.

Many pension funds are expected to adopt an ethical investment strategy as a result of the new regulations. The giant institutional investment managers are already gearing up to satisfy the anticipated demand for investment policies with an ethical slant. Prudential Portfolio Managers, one of the biggest, says it will soon be introducing screening on a range of environmental and social issues across its entire UK investment portfolio.

A growing realisation that environmental factors can have a direct impact on the financial performance of companies means fund managers are moving away from the negative screening and sector avoidance approach traditionally associated with ethical funds.

 Copies of FoE's report Capital Punishment: The Insurance Industry and the Global Environment , price £10, are available on 0171 490 1555 . Readers can call the same number for a free briefing on personal finance and the environment.

fields.headline: Millions miss retirement saving targets
fields.standfirst: Beef up your pension fund now or you may end up with less than you hoped, warns David Hunt
fields.trailText: Beefing up your pension fund makes sense, and there are a number of tax-saving ways of doing it.
fields.body:
Few of us have much of a clue as to what sort of income we will actually have to live on in retirement. It seems that despite all the scare stories about pensions in recent years, survey after survey shows we don't tend to worry about retirement until it is around the corner.

Asked to guess what our pension income will be in terms of current salary, we are usually overly optimistic. In general, the 10m or so members of company pension schemes are likely to be better off than most, but their final retirement income could still be disappointing.

Increased job mobility and a move by employers away from final salary schemes mean that hardly any of us will retire on what is often quoted as the optimum pension level - around two-thirds of current salary.

Beefing up your pension fund makes sense, and there are a number of tax-saving ways of doing it. The first step is to find out how far short of the target you actually are. Your firm's personnel or pensions department will tell you how you are doing and what you are likely to get from their scheme. You can find out what the state will give you by filling out form BR19, available from local benefits offices. Then ask previous employers for an up-to-date pensions statement.

Other investments which may have been earmarked for pension purposes - personal pensions or savings schemes - should also be added into the mix.

Having established the scale of the shortfall, what do you do? Jon Briggs, pensions expert at independent financial adviser Chartwells, says that those in a company scheme cannot take out a personal pension (and may be barred from the new stakeholder pension as well) but there are three types of additional voluntary contributions (AVCs) that might be available to top up the total:

Some final salary schemes, mainly in the public sector, allow the purchase of added years. These are particularly good for anyone expecting a dramatic increase in salary before retirement and offer cast-iron guarantees.

All firms must offer an in-house group AVC scheme

You can go outside the company scheme into a free standing AVC alternative. These come from insurance companies, carry charges which are usually higher than in-house schemes and have not proved very popular.

Mr Briggs suggests that the in-house AVC is usually the better bet. "They are subsidised by the company and premiums will be deducted from salary. This is particularly useful for the higher rate taxpayer who gets immediate higher rate tax relief."

Freestanding AVCs offer only basic-rate tax relief initially and the rest must be reclaimed, but if you are young, you expect to move around and the in-house scheme offers only a cash fund, they may be useful.

But Mr Briggs sees a strong case for boosting retirement funding by going outside of the pensions arena and investing in an Isa. "Isas are probably more tax efficient at the moment," he says. "Both pensions and Isas get capital gains tax exemption but the Isa can reclaim tax on any dividends until 2004, whereas the pension fund can't."

Stuart Bayliss, a director of IFA Annuity Direct, is another fan of Isas for topping up a pension because of their flexibility. "Around half of your target income should come from pension products but the rest could well come from other sources," he says.

The Isa route allows up to £7,000 to be put aside this tax year (£5,000 in subsequent years). The level of risk taken can be varied by choosing to invest in equities, insurance or cash deposits.

Up to 15% of net relevant earnings - minus the percentage employees contribute to their main company scheme - can be invested via the AVC route in any tax year, and most providers offer funds with varying degrees of risk.

webTitle: FSA toughens up on net crime

fields.headline: FSA toughens up on net crime
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Major inquiries have been launched into e-commerce and money laundering as part of a shift to "proactive regulation" by the financial services authority. Chairman Howard Davies said yesterday the inquiry's reports would be used as the basis for day-to-day supervision of the City.
fields.body:
Major inquiries have been launched into e-commerce and money laundering as part of a shift to "proactive regulation" by the financial services authority. Chairman Howard Davies said yesterday the inquiry's reports would be used as the basis for day-to-day supervision of the City.

Three other inquiries have also begun - into the implications for investors of a low-inflation environment, into after-care for savers and investors and into ways the FSA can provide market incentives for firms to conform with rules and regulations.

The agency is setting up what is in effect an internal ad hoc think tank to guide its enforcement policy. Mr Davies said the pension mis-selling affair was a set-piece example of something that could have been prevented by one of the FSA's new "theme projects".

Denying it would be "an academic body", Mr Davies said the think tank represented "a shift to more front-end activity". He was presenting the FSA's conclusions to a review of the old regulatory system, one crucial finding of which is that there has been too much emphasis on routine surveillance and on reacting to scandals when they occur.

Regarding the inquiry into e-commerce, Mr Davies said the development of investment over the net presented risks, especially in terms of "potential criminal activity".

fields.headline: Equitable loses £1.5bn fight
fields.trailText: Thousands of pensioners yesterday won a major court battle which could see Equitable Life, the world's oldest mutual insurer, forced to pay out up to £1.5bn to policyholders and leaving it vulnerable to a takeover bid.
fields.body:
Thousands of pensioners yesterday won a major court battle which could see Equitable Life, the world's oldest mutual insurer, forced to pay out up to £1.5bn to policyholders and leaving it vulnerable to a takeover bid.

The court of appeal ruled that the company's decision to cut valuable final bonuses payable to 90,000 pension policyholders was unlawful. It said the company should pay the money to holders of "guaranteed annuity rate" policies.

However, the 238-year-old company immediately said it would be appealing against the ruling to the House of Lords, leaving the policyholders, many of them elderly, in limbo once again.

The judgment will send shockwaves through the insurance industry, with Scottish Widows and MGM Assurance among the firms which have issued similar policies.

The guaranteed annuities were sold as part of pension plans between 1957 and 1988. Those who bought policies with this option believed it would assure them of a guaranteed minimum income at retirement.

But annuity rates have plummeted in the past few years, which means that the guarantees, which promised rates of 11% and above, have become very costly. Market annuity rates are now about 8% or 9%.

While many other life companies decided to absorb the costs, Equitable Life infuriated many of its customers by announcing it would pay lower final bonuses to policyholders who opted to exercise the guarantee.

The company said it had the right to vary final bonus payments, but customers who bought these plans claimed it was reneging on promises, which in some cases add hundreds of thousands of pounds to people's pensions. They claim they were promised a minimum annuity rate and full final bonuses.

Equitable Life won the first round of the legal battle in the High Court last September when vice-chancellor Sir Richard Scott ruled the society was acting lawfully in cutting final bonuses to guaranteed annuity policyholders.

But the Court of Appeal overturned the judgment by a majority of two to one, with Lord Woolf, master of the rolls, stating it was "not a permissible exercise of discretion" for the insurer to apply different rates for final bonuses depending on how a policyholder chose to take their benefits.

Equitable Life said it was "disappointed" at the decision but was pleased that its current approach to the issue "can be maintained pending the result in the House of Lords".

The judgment delighted David Hyman, 69, a retired stockbroker chosen as the representative defendant for the policyholders. He has held policies with the company since 1970. "The policyholders have been very badly treated. They are predominantly elderly people and, since the society changed its rules, many of them have died," he said.

Some analysts claimed the company could be left vulnerable to a takeover approach if the Court of Appeal ruling is upheld, or could be forced to seek a buyer. It would have to pay out £1bn-£1.5bn.

Jeremy Batstone, at Natwest Stockbrokers, said: "If the company is going to be in a parlous financial state it could well attract a predator, possibly a European insurance firm or a major UK financial group."

Barclays, Aegon - the Netherlands-based pensions group - Prudential and AXA Sun Life have all been named as possible buyers.

fields.headline: Utilities bill promises big changes
fields.trailText: The government sought yesterday to place consumer interests at the heart of utility regulation when it tabled a new bill designed to impose sweeping changes on the privatised electricity, water and gas industries.
fields.body:
The government sought yesterday to place consumer interests at the heart of utility regulation when it tabled a new bill designed to impose sweeping changes on the privatised electricity, water and gas industries.

Publishing his long-awaited utilities bill, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers promised the measures would ensure "first class utilities for all consumers at lower prices".

Among the pledges are a promise to cut electricity bills by 10%, and a commitment to bring new powers to bear on the industries so that fuel poverty and poor performance can be tackled more effectively.

The bill also promises tough fines for companies guilty of bad practice such as mis-selling, interruption to supply and tardy reconnection. The fines will have no upper limit.

The measures follow long-standing criticism of the privatised utilities by Labour when it was in opposition. The party pledged at the time to revamp regulation so that consumer interests would be better protected. Yesterday's bill follows publication earlier of official proposals, and consultation.

The market reacted calmly to the news, which had been anticipated.

Shares in National Power closed 3p higher at 378p, while PowerGen shares closed 26p higher at 489p. Shares in United Utilities ended the session at 622p, down 1p, while Centrica shares closed 1p higher at 180p.

The electricity industry welcomed the measures in the bill aimed at ensuring greater regulatory stability.

Philip Daubeney, chief executive of the Electricity Association, said the industry had been working closely with the government on the measures and that the industry was pleased with the "broad thrust".

But he warned: "The government is giving itself considerable new powers to direct regulation. We want to see these used judiciously and transparently, with proper consultation, avoiding regulatory shocks which have the effect of increasing uncertainty, which in turn leads to increased costs."

Environmentalists criticised the bill for encouraging higher energy consumption by cutting prices. Friends of the Earth said that the new law ought to be accompanied by measures to increase renewable energy generation and more use of combined heat and power systems.

The Worldwide Fund for Nature said the bill abolished a regime that supported the development of emerging technologies used in renewable energy, without putting an alternative system of support in its place. Solar and biomass power systems could suffer as a result.

The trade and industry department is understood to be planning to publish more detailed proposals on renewable energy in two weeks.

webTitle: Cellnet makes internet by phone a reality

fields.headline: Cellnet makes internet by phone a reality
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The hype surrounding internet access via mobile phones should at last become a reality on Monday when BT Cellnet begins selling its first handsets able to surf the net.
fields.body:
The hype surrounding internet access via mobile phones should at last become a reality on Monday when BT Cellnet begins selling its first handsets able to surf the net.

The company announced a series of partners for its start up service including BBC News, the Guardian, Lastminute.com, European Investor.com and Exicte which will reconfigure their online content for the smaller screens of a mobile phone.

Among the services, users will be able to retrieve news, sports results, personal share portfolios, television and cinema listings, guides to the nearest cash machine and turn-by-turn driving instructions around the country.

"2000 is the year this goes from a vision to reality," said BT Cellnet managing director Peter Erskine.

The wireless application protocol (WAP) handsets will retail for £129.99 and users will be charged 5p a minute for accessing the web.

BT Cellnet is launching with the Nokia 7110 handset but will have a Motorola version available shortly. The first Ericcsson models will not be available for some months.

Vodafone, the UK's largest network, said it had taken delivery of its first batch of WAP handsets and would be launching its internet service next week.

Orange which attempted to steal a march by introducing its internet access in November was stalled by problems in the handsets. A spokeswoman said they would be on shelves by Monday.

Mr Erskine cited forecasts of 1bn mobile phones in use by 2003 worldwide compared to 550m personal computers as evidence that internet access would migrate to mobiles.

fields.headline: Grace under pressure
fields.standfirst:
A Celebration of International Choreography
Royal Opera House, London
***
fields.trailText: On Thursday night, when the Royal Ballet started their performance half an hour late and, after a second interval of nearly an hour, had to cancel the concluding ballet, Ashley Page's Hidden Variables, the normally sedate audience booed and yelled.
fields.body:
Ballet audiences have so far been tolerant of the glitches affecting the reopened Opera House. OK, the Christmas tree didn't always grow for the Royal Ballet's opening performances of The Nutcracker, and the trap doors didn't always work, but most of the public was in a holiday mood, and there was a kind of British doggedness about struggling on which struck a chord.

But on Thursday night, when the Royal Ballet started their performance half an hour late and, after a second interval of nearly an hour, had to cancel the concluding ballet, Ashley Page's Hidden Variables, the normally sedate audience booed and yelled.

The problem was the late dismantling of an opera set, which had been used in rehearsals during Thursday afternoon. It wasn't a simple case of incompetence, more a reflection of a scheduling policy that alternates ballet and opera performances back to back instead of giving productions separate runs. But it overshadowed much of what did appear on stage.

The performance was a remix of the programme of international ballet with which the company began its season in December, and outstanding among the new dancers and choreographers was American Ballet Theatre's Ethan Steifel, partnering Susan Jaffe in a pas de deux from Twyla Tharp's Known by Heart. The work is set to a percussion score with the strident beat of a street carnival, and the dancers surf upon characteristically Tharpian extremes of vernacular and virtuoso dance.

Jaffe started out looking jittery but by the end of the duet had loosened into a stylish mix of acerbic wit and ballerina delicacy. Steifel, however, was a star from the moment he stepped onstage. Veering from louche mobster to ballet prince, he flipped between outrageously sly insinuations of his hips to elegantly cocky strings of pirouettes. His timing was faultless and his demeanour entrancing.

The other new choreography was William Forsythe's The Vertiginous Thrill of Exactitude, which could be subtitled Bill's Mischief. Confounding his own antichrist image as arch desecrator of classical principles, Forsythe's surprising little show-stopper proves he can do ballet like the best of them. Not only is the work set to the impeccably classical music of Schubert (rather than Forsythe's preferred electronic scores) but its five dancers are spun through almost every classroom step in the book.

As the title suggests, this is an outright celebration of the precision and speed unique to ballet, but it's also a wicked exaggeration. Familiar steps become barely visible as they race on each others heels, change direction and then link in perilous combinations. Forsythe contains the whole breathtaking flurry within a very untypical classical decorum, and the audience loved it.

They also loved Darcey Bussell, despite the fact that she was performing Peter Martin's silly duet from his Barber Violin Concerto. This is a piece blighted by a vaguely fraught feeling and by hangdog male posturing, but Bussell used all her technical subtlety and power to give texture to the choreography, and all but convinced us she was making emotional sense of it.

fields.headline: Chamber of intimate pleasures
fields.standfirst:
Brahms and Mendelssohn Festival
Wigmore Hall, London
****
fields.trailText: Chamber music is perhaps the only genre in which the paying punters regularly feel that the performers are having more fun than they are. Even those who have made it to the top as soloists want to perform in this way - like violinist Joshua Bell, who organises an annual chamber music series at the Wigmore Hall.
fields.body:
Chamber music is perhaps the only genre in which the paying punters regularly feel that the performers are having more fun than they are. Even those who have made it to the top as soloists want to perform in this way - like violinist Joshua Bell, who organises an annual chamber music series at the Wigmore Hall.

Brahms and Mendelssohn are this year's chosen composers; this concert, the second of three, featured not one Mendelssohn but two. Fanny Mendelssohn was encouraged by many, including her brother Felix, to write music. Though she wrote several hundred pieces, only a few were published in her lifetime. The Fantasia in G minor and Capriccio in A flat major were written for her other brother, Paul, an amateur cellist; here they were performed by cellist Steven Isserlis and pianist Alexander Lonquich.

These are intimate pieces, truly chamber music in that both instruments are treated as equals. However, they proved difficult to project to the audience. Despite Isserlis's best efforts, the cello melodies placed in the middle of the instrument's range still blended in with the piano writing rather than having a life of their own.

His sister's pieces were written for performance in the family drawing room, but Felix Mendelssohn's Piano Trio No 1 was much more at home in this sold-out concert hall. The cello launches straight into the opening melody without any fuss and when the violin (played by Bell) joins in, the individual lines are written so that they are clearer, more distinct from each other and considerably more powerful for it.

There was plenty of drama in this performance. Isserlis and Bell threw motifs back and forward wittily during the Scherzo, and Lonquich certainly looked like he was enjoying rattling lightly through his semiquavers.

A more intense atmosphere of communication came when the Vellinger Quartet joined Bell and Isserlis for Brahms's Sextet No 2. A quartet like the Vellingers, who perform together all the time, can play as one instrument or as four. Bell and Isserlis were assimilated easily into their finely woven texture, at times emerging, like them, as soloists, at times falling back into the ensemble. Tim Boulton's smile at a particularly glorious viola moment underlined the impression that the players were enjoying themselves; this time the audience could feel equally indulged.

fields.headline: BoS in pledge to Pru
fields.trailText: Prudential will sell its insurance products in NatWest branches should a Bank of Scotland bid for the clearing bank succeed, BoS said yesterday.
fields.body:
Prudential will sell its insurance products in NatWest branches should a Bank of Scotland bid for the clearing bank succeed, BoS said yesterday.

The announcement fuelled speculation that the Pru would back the Scottish bank's £22bn hostile bid, although the insurance group, which is NatWest's biggest shareholder with a 5% stake, stressed the link with BoS was "completely separate" to any decision made by its fund managers about how to use its shares.

Shareholders are not expected to decide whether to back either of the rival bids by BoS and Royal Bank of Scotland or support NatWest's new management until the final hours before the Valentine's Day deadline.

They face a last-ditch lobbying offensive from all three banks in the coming days, starting on Monday when NatWest must file its final defence document. It is expected to report last year's profits and suggest fresh ways to return cash to shareholders.

NatWest's next largest shareholder is Mercury Asset Management, which also has a large stake in Royal Bank, prompting speculation that it might come out in favour of the Royal Bank's offer.

Royal Bank's advisers, Credit Suisse First Boston, yesterday received a public reprimand from the takeover panel, which polices bid battles, over information it released about the intentions of NatWest's shareholders.

The BoS deal announced yesterday would allow Pru to buy NatWest Life, at an estimated £800m, and sell Pru-branded products through the branches.

webTitle: Buy is brave but not barking

fields.headline: Buy is brave but not barking
fields.trailText: When the definitive history of this great bull market is written, Citigroup's purchase of the Schroders investment bank may well be highlighted as one of its defining folies de grandeur . It is a breath-taking gamble on continuing European merger activity and - in all likelihood - a cultural cataclysm.
fields.body:
When the definitive history of this great bull market is written, Citigroup's purchase of the Schroders investment bank may well be highlighted as one of its defining folies de grandeur . It is a breath-taking gamble on continuing European merger activity and - in all likelihood - a cultural cataclysm.

For Schroders, Citigroup is laying out a cool £1.35bn on some of the City's bluest-blooded corporate financiers, analysts and brokers. Its objective is, through a merger of their skills and address books with those of Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney, to secure a position at the top of the banking league tables.

This is one hell of a price for assets that walk out through the front door every evening - and may not relish that front door being in Docklands when Salomon relocates.

Citigroup is reputedly setting aside £250m in sweeteners for 200 "key" Schroders staff. Quite a relocation allowance.

As Salomon is likely to transplant Schroders people into its own operational platform, £1.6bn in purchase price and sweeteners works out at £8m per "key" employee. Oh, and of course the name Schroders will be tacked on to the front of Salomon Smith Barney, which must have some brand value.

It is conceivable that the new SSSB name will merely serve as a constant reminder to the investment bank's customers of the cultural contradictions within the consolidated business. Many - perhaps most - of the Schroders staff have made positive career choices not to serve a global behemoth and no amount of inducements will make them happy to do so.

One Schroders equity salesman, with commendably stiff upper lip, conceded to me this week: "I guess we'll just have to be happy trying to knock Merrill Lynch off their perch". It may not be what he was put on this earth to do, but it's certainly what his new masters perceive as their destiny.

Forget Tyson v Francis, we've all got free tickets to watch the contest between the Thundering Herd and the Masters of the Universe. My money's on Merrill, but the odds are not as short as those on Tyson for next Saturday. On a one-week view, Citigroup's gamble is brave but not completely barking.

Merger and acquisition activity continues to dominate the financial news. The week began with confirmation of the (once postponed) marriage between Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham. It ended with speculation of a knot-tying by retailer Kingfisher and German counterpart Metro.

The pharmaceutical merger is Europe's largest, though one by-product is that the new entity is likely to be run out of the United States. A case, perhaps, of a company from over here doing rather too well over there.

Although the medical foibles of the world's peoples vary greatly, according to custom, inclination and opportunity, it is plausible to talk of one global market for drugs. The mooted economies of scale from the Glaxo-SKB deal are, as a consequence, believable.

But cross-border transactions in industries that are, by their nature, domestic deserve far greater scrutiny. Rarely have acquisitions by retailers in other countries proved successful. No doubt once M & S is finally put out of its corporate misery, its new owners will dispose of the retailer's ill-starred American operations before concentrating on resuscitating the patient at home.

The hope of the global investment banks is that the world continues to become a smaller place, and that the expensive transnational mistakes of the past serve only as a challenge to the machismo of industrialists to do better next time.

A precipitate drop in the general level of share prices could draw all involved in the M&A boom up short.

After the upward move in stockmarkets in the final months of 1999, only a fool would dismiss the possibility of a major correction out of hand. You can be sure that the advice being given to would-be predators is to move early.

The current spate of takeovers is certainly failing to drive markets higher. Indeed the prevailing trend is gently downwards, a nagging headache persisting after the severe hangover that afflicted share prices in the early days of the new year.

The Dow Jones industrial average is now 3.8% below its record high, the FTSE 100 Index 8.6% off its own peak.

Beneath all the M&A hype cloaking the markets, investment fundamentals remain sound. Economies are growing and monetary authorities are applying suitable restraint.

But while this may justify prevailing stockmarket levels, it does not excuse the prices paid by many corporate acquisitors - including those whose stock in trade is providing acquisition advice to others.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Albert E Sharp Securities.

As Salomon is likely to transplant Schroders people into its own operational platform, £1.6bn in purchase price and sweeteners works out at £8m per "key" employee. Oh, and of course the name Schroders will be tacked on to the front of Salomon Smith Barney, which must have some brand value. It is conceivable that the new SSSB name will merely serve as a constant reminder to the investment bank's customers of the cultural contradictions within the consolidated business. Many - perhaps most - of the Schroders staff have made positive career choices not to serve a global behemoth and no amount of inducements will make them happy to do so. One Schroders equity salesman, with commendably stiff upper lip, conceded to me this week: "I guess we'll just have to be happy trying to knock Merrill Lynch off their perch". It may not be what he was put on this earth to do, but it's certainly what his new masters perceive as their destiny. Forget Tyson v Francis, we've all got free tickets to watch the contest between the Thundering Herd and the Masters of the Universe. My money's on Merrill, but the odds are not as short as those on Tyson for next Saturday. On a one-week view, Citigroup's gamble is brave but not completely barking. Merger and acquisition activity continues to dominate the financial news. The week began with confirmation of the (once postponed) marriage between Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham. It ended with speculation of a knot-tying by retailer Kingfisher and German counterpart Metro. The pharmaceutical merger is Europe's largest, though one by-product is that the new entity is likely to be run out of the United States. A case, perhaps, of a company from over here doing rather too well over there. Although the medical foibles of the world's peoples vary greatly, according to custom, inclination and opportunity, it is plausible to talk of one global market for drugs. The mooted economies of scale from the Glaxo-SKB deal are, as a consequence, believable. But cross-border transactions in industries that are, by their nature, domestic deserve far greater scrutiny. Rarely have acquisitions by retailers in other countries proved successful. No doubt once M & S is finally put out of its corporate misery, its new owners will dispose of the retailer's ill-starred American operations before concentrating on resuscitating the patient at home. The hope of the global investment banks is that the world continues to become a smaller place, and that the expensive transnational mistakes of the past serve only as a challenge to the machismo of industrialists to do better next time. A precipitate drop in the general level of share prices could draw all involved in the M&A boom up short. After the upward move in stockmarkets in the final months of 1999, only a fool would dismiss the possibility of a major correction out of hand. You can be sure that the advice being given to would-be predators is to move early. The current spate of takeovers is certainly failing to drive markets higher. Indeed the prevailing trend is gently downwards, a nagging headache persisting after the severe hangover that afflicted share prices in the early days of the new year. The Dow Jones industrial average is now 3.8% below its record high, the FTSE 100 Index 8.6% off its own peak. Beneath all the M&A hype cloaking the markets, investment fundamentals remain sound. Economies are growing and monetary authorities are applying suitable restraint. But while this may justify prevailing stockmarket levels, it does not excuse the prices paid by many corporate acquisitors - including those whose stock in trade is providing acquisition advice to others. Edmond Warner is chief executive of Albert E Sharp Securities.

webTitle: How to get the pension you deserve

fields.headline: How to get the pension you deserve
fields.trailText: Employed and in a company pensions scheme? Think yourself lucky - you would be insane to leave it. But if you're employed and there is no company pension scheme - the general rule in most small firms - what do you do?
fields.body:
Employed and in a company pensions scheme? Think yourself lucky - you would be insane to leave it. But if you're employed and there is no company pension scheme - the general rule in most small firms - what do you do?

One idea is to find out if there is an optional group personal pension scheme. With this, your contributions are invested in an insurance company fund, growing into a nest egg which will buy your pension when you retire.

These schemes are sometimes funded entirely by the employer, but it is more usual for both the employer and employee to chip in - and sometimes the employee takes up most of the burden.

As with other pension schemes, you get tax relief at your highest marginal rate, but, because of this, the percentage of your earnings you can put in is limited. The lim its start at 17.5% and go up to 40% depending on your age.

Your employer decides which insurance company runs the scheme, although you can choose what type of investments you want, and what you come away with will depend on investment performance.

But costs are likely to be lower than taking out your own personal plan because of the number of members in the scheme.

Life cover can be included for an additional charge, as can waiver of premium (if you're unable to work, the insurance company pays in on your behalf after the first six months).

The personal pension plan is the same as a group plan, except that you take it out as an individual. This means it will generally be more expensive, though you can choose your provider. Of course, if you're self-employed, an individual plan is the only option.

webTitle: Good times push the all-powerful pound to 14-year high

fields.headline: Good times push the all-powerful pound to 14-year high
fields.trailText: Sterling hit its highest level for 14 years yesterday, with City analysts predicting that it could rise further still.
fields.body:
Sterling hit its highest level for 14 years yesterday, with City analysts predicting that it could rise further still.

A recent run of buoyant economic data, expectations of higher interest rates and a growing perception that manufacturing exporters are learning to live with the all-powerful pound have all contributed to the currency's strength.

Sentiment was reinforced by the publication yesterday of the M4 money supply data, and mortgage lending figures betrayed no signs of any reduction in the strength of consumer activity.

The pound's trade-weighted index, which measures sterling's value against the currencies of Britain's most important trading partners, hit 109.5 yesterday - its highest since January 1986.

The euro is now worth less than 61p - equivalent to a sterling-mark rate of DM3.20.

"There are good British reasons for why sterling has con tinued to strengthen. With few exceptions, all British economic releases have been stronger than expected," said Michael Metcalfe, a currency strategist at NatWest Global Markets in London.

"We had the recovering manufacturing figures early in the week and a forthcoming CBI survey is expected to show a solid recovery in the industrial sector," said Stuart Weatherby, senior economist at Panmure Gordon in London.

"Exports have suffered a bit, but overall they seem to be coping okay with the strength of the pound. I don't see why sterling can't strengthen further from here."

The pound is being seen by some traders as a safe haven in a nervous foreign exchange market. The euro remains firmly out of favour - hovering just above parity against the dollar while the markets' attention is focusing on the strength of the yen ahead of this weekend's meeting of the leading industrial economies in Tokyo.

The Japanese are increasingly uncomfortable with the high level of the yen which has appreciated by 40% over the last 18 months.

Tokyo is worried that the strength of the currency could choke off the economy's feeble attempt at recovery.

The Japanese are thought likely to ask the United States privately for help in capping the yen's appreciation, with Washington likely to use the opportunity to demand further moves to liberalise the Japanese economy.

"Japan wants a weaker yen and a home victory. They don't want to lose this because it is a home fixture for them," said Commerzbank economist Nick Parsons.

A weaker yen would take some of the pressure off the euro, currently the weakest of the world's big currencies.

While Europe's leading economies are benefiting from single currency's 14% slide since its launch at the beginning of last year, policymakers would be happy to see a comfort zone between its levels against the dollar and parity.

The G7 will need to do more than reiterate familiar concerns about the strength of the yen in its final communiqué, if it is to have an effect on the foreign exchanges.

But some analysts believe that they may be prepared to issue a strongly worded statement talking down the yen.

"I think there is a real chance of a surprise this weekend," said Mr Parsons.

fields.headline: A study in despair
fields.standfirst:
Dublin Carol
The Old Vic, London
***
fields.trailText: First impressions are crucial. With Conor McPherson’s The Weir it was love at first sight - I even bought tickets for friends. In the case of McPherson’s new play, occupying a temporary space at the Old Vic before moving to the Royal Court next month, I feel affection rather than the quiver of excited passion.
fields.body:
First impressions are crucial. With Conor McPherson's The Weir it was love at first sight - I even bought tickets for friends. In the case of McPherson's new play, occupying a temporary space at the Old Vic before moving to the Royal Court next month, I feel affection rather than the quiver of excited passion.

As so often, McPherson deals with a middle-aged Irishman in a state of desperation. Here he is a lonely Dublin undertaker, John Plunkett, confronted on Christmas Eve by the ghosts of his past. As the title implies, there are strong Dickensian echoes, but Plunkett is less a Dublin Scrooge than a reformed alcoholic. In the first and third scenes he recalls, for the benefit of his young assistant, the terrors of cyclical drinking and the seeming impossibility of escape. And in the emotion-charged central scene of this 90-minute play he confronts his estranged daughter who wants him to come to the bedside of his dying wife.

Like Dickens, McPherson is unafraid to suggest that redemption is possible, even for the loneliest soul. In the past Plunkett was rescued from total degradation by the owner of the funeral parlour, symbolically named Noel. And even now, when his daughter's presence brings back shaming memories of his epic binges and familial desertion, you feel he is not without hope.

The play makes a visceral impact. If I love it less than The Weir, the reasons are partly structural. Each of the three scenes is a two-hander in which Plunkett does most of the talking. I like McPherson more when he offers interplay of character. And where The Weir offers an extraordinary metaphor for Ireland, this play strikes me more as a study in individual despair.

But I've no wish to cavil at a play packed with good writing. And Ian Rickson's production, ingeniously mounted in the Old Vic scene dock with the audience on stage, boasts a magnificent performance by Brian Cox as Plunkett. Bronagh Gallagher as his daughter and Andrew Scott as his helpmate listen attentively to this self-confessed show-off. One looks forward to encountering the play again at the Royal Court. Maybe by then admiration will have turned to love.

•At the Old Vic (0171-369 1722), until February 12, then transferring to the Royal Court
